column2: A look at what's happening around the site of the Formula One race in Austria, near Graz, this weekend.
Mayor Bill de Blasio said the budget signaled a more compassionate era for New York, with investments in public housing and expanded prekindergarten programs.
After a decade away, Formula One is returning to Austria this weekend, where the dominant energy-drink company’s team is the local hero.
Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg, rivals from contrasting backgrounds at Formula One's dominant team, are playing out a drama on track and off.
A State Department report released Friday ranks the two Southeast Asian countries with North Korea, Iran and Zimbabwe.
“Sitting here listening to this testimony, I don’t believe it,” Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, told the agency’s commissioner, John Koskinen.
The Mauritshuis reopens next week in The Hague, its treasures re-ensconced after a subtle renovation and expansion.
The “beautiful game,” like a work of art, contains an ineffable aesthetic quality.
It doesn’t matter where you stand on the political spectrum — if you are a woman, your body is not safe.
President Obama said that up to 300 military advisers would go to Iraq, which is facing an uprising of Sunni militants.
A 2013 federal report showed that one-third of beginning farmers are over 55, and seem to take up the task after leaving a different career.
The government forces were carrying out searches and arrests in a campaign to find three Israeli youths abducted a week ago.
Art, itself a form of worship, can spread truths where religions divide.
Those who major in subjects like engineering and finance increase their pay advantage over those in other fields.
The reasons for a pause in advancing tax plans are partly practical, but philosophical shifts have also played a role.
More than 350,000 Hong Kong residents voted Friday in a nonbinding referendum on how their next leader should be chosen. The Chinese government called it “illegal and invalid.”
The Obama administration said Moscow was continuing to covertly arm rebels in the eastern part of Ukraine, despite its denials.
Their presence in the heart of the capital raised new concerns among Lebanese who had cautiously been enjoying a renewed sense of security.
What to watch for in Friday’s Group D and E matches of Italy vs. Costa Rica, Switzerland vs. France and Ecuador vs. Honduras.
Martin Luther King Addo, a former Mr. Ghana bodybuilding champion, helps frail seniors restore their balance, mobility and strength at a storefront gym in Lower Manhattan.
After being narrowly edged out by a Tea Party-backed challenger, Senator Thad Cochran needs to expand the number of voters who will show up for the Republican runoff election.
More than 51 million people have been displaced by violence around the world, according to the head of the United Nations refugee agency.
After decades of blocking gay married couples from receiving the same benefits as their heterosexual counterparts, most federal agencies will now treat married couples alike, regardless of gender.
Mr. Wooster’s capsule collection, to debut at the Pitti men’s fair in Italy, is just one of the products of his web fame.
By canceling the simulcast of “The Death of Klinghoffer,” Peter Gelb and the Metropolitan Opera are losing a chance to open a dialogue about anti-Semitism.
Critics said that Mr. Hylas’s works captivated audiences with its eclectic originality, propulsive rhythmic force, companionable combination of dissonance and consonance.

ROBINSON--Donald J.,of Weston, Vermont died on June 11, 2014 at the age of 79. He was born in Chicago, Illinois on August 24, 1934 to Stafford and Anne (Hinrichs) Robinson. He graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1955 and Columbia Law School in 1958. He was a public finance attorney whose distinguished career in the municipal securities industry spanned more than 45 years. He has served as Bond Counsel to many of the most prominent issuers in the nation and the New York metropolitan region and was an early advocate of improved municipal disclosure. He served as bond counsel to the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York, the financing vehicle created to deal with New York City's fiscal crisis, the Power Authority of the State of New York, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He also served as special counsel to the Bonneville Power Administration to refinance certain debt of the Washington Public Power Supply System (now known as Energy Northwest). He served as bond counsel to the State of Louisiana on an issue of revenue anticipation notes in connection with that state's financial crisis. He served as one of the counsel for the Sawhill Commission, which conducted preliminary studies to determine the control of the Long Island Lighting Company's Shoreham nuclear facility. He joined Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe in 1987 and helped to build the New York public finance practice to national prominence. He was a member of the firm's Executive Committee. Prior to joining Orrick he was a partner at Hawkins, Delafield & Wood from 1969 to 1987. Before that he was associated with Caldwell, Trimble & Mitchell and with Nixon Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Mitchell from 1965 to 1969. He was also a staff member of the Securities and Exchange Commission from 1961 to 1965. In 1981 he was a member and then in 1984 Chairman of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board. In 1985 he was a member of Governor Cuomo's Committee to Reform Local Borrowing. He was a member of the National Association of Bond Lawyers and Chairman of the Committee on Judicial Policy in 1986. He was Chairman of the Municipal Finance Officers' Association Revisions Committee for Disclosure Guidelines for Offerings of Securities by State and Local Governments in 1975 and a member of the Public Securities Association Treasury Regulations Committee. As Chairman and Lecturer of the Practicing Law Institute's Municipal Bond Workshops since 1969, he authored and contributed to numerous professional publications. In 1996 he was honored by The Municipal Forum of New York for his service in the Municipal Securities Industry. An avid golfer, he was a member of Piping Rock Club, Ekwanok Country Club, and the U.S. Seniors Golf Association. He also served as a Trustee of the Museum of the City of New York. He was a member of the River Club and The Pilgrims of the United States. Don is survived by his wife of 40 years, Rebecca, three sons, Donald, Christopher, and Nicholas, and two daughters Ann and Susan, many grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

TAYLOR--William Robert, (1922-2014), professor and founder in the field of American Cultural History, fellow at the New York Institute for the Humanities at NYU, author of Cavalier and Yankee (1962), In Pursuit of Gotham (1991), Inventing Times Square (1992), loving husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle, cousin, mentor friend, WWII veteran (Navigator D-Day), story-teller, novelist, poet, fly fisherman, equestrian, bicyclist, sailor, joker, martini drinker. A long life fully engaged. Memorial to be announced.

ROBINSON--Charles, 82, artist and illustrator of Mendham, NJ, died June 15 in Morristown after a long illness. A native of Morristown and a graduate of Milton Academy, Harvard University (1953), UVA Law school, (1958) he was a member of the New Jersey Bar and practiced law for 10 years before changing careers. He illustrated more than 150 children's books and in 1971 received the Society of Illustrators Gold Medal. He served in the US Army during the Korean War. Survivors include his wife of 57 years, Cynthia McClean Margetts; his brother, Powell Robinson; three children, Meredith, Charles and Edward and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

SIMON--Kathy Gale (Shapiro), born March 5, 1957 in Manhattan, died June 19, 2014 at her home in Cold Spring Harbor, NY. She is the daughter of the late Theodore Shapiro and she is survived by her beloved mother, Judith Shapiro, her beloved husband Scott and daughters, Matti and Alix, sister Hilary, brother John and his wife Geri, sister-in-law Randi, brother-in-law Ricky and mother-in-law Nancy in addition to several nieces, nephews and cousins. Kathy graduated from Boston University with a degree in Art and was a senior executive at Ciao Ltd in addition to being a wonderful mother and devoted wife. She traveled the world extensively, had a passion for life and truly loved her family and dear friends, for which she had many. She will be eternally missed by everyone who had the great fortune to know her. In lieu of flowers, please make all donations to the Elizabeth R. Woods Foundation. Service Sunday at 2pm at Star of David Memorial Chapels in West Babylon. For info go to www.jewish-funeral-home.com

TRIPP--Madelyn "Maggie" (nee Beresin) (June 18, 2014) of Bryn Mawr, PA. Beloved wife of Alan R. Tripp. Mother of the late Barbara Tripp Berman and Jeffrey Tripp and Grandmother of Dr. Abigail Tripp Berman, Noel (Liza) Tripp, and Lyle (Hazel) Tripp. Great-grandmother of Sienna, Walter Alan, Lorelei and Ariel. Private graveside services will be held Sunday June 22 at the Mt. Sinai Cemetery, Bridge and Walker Streets, Philadelphia, PA. Friends will be invited to a memorial service at Beaumont at a date to-be-determined. Family respectfully requests that contributions in Maggie's memory be made to The Maggie Tripp Library at the Wellesley Centers for Women, 106 Central Street, Wellesley MA 02481. www.levinefuneral.com
GLADSTEIN--Dr. Arthur. 3/3/22-6/20/94. Miss you today and always. Love, Roz & Family

WEISSENSTEIN--Charlotte (Zentawer), formerly of Manhattan, died in Stockbridge, MA, June 18. Services to be held 11am, June 23, Temple Anshe Amunim in Pittsfield, MA. Predeceased by husband Heinz and stepson Herbert; survived by sons Peter, Robert and David and seven grandchildren. Info: www.legacy.com/obituaries/ berkshire/

ROWAN--Barbara J. The Western Wall Heritage Foundation extends its deepest sympathies to our dear friend Marc and the entire Rowan family on the loss of his dear mother. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yogi Loshinsky Suli Aliav

VINER--Arthur W. Of Vero Beach, Florida died at home on June 19. Art was born in Chicago on April 22, 1922, to Dr. Jacob Viner and Frances Klein Viner. While growing up he attended the University of Chicago Lab School from pre-kindergarten through High School with the exception of the 3rd and 5th grades when he attended the International School in Geneva while his father was a visiting professor at The Graduate Institute Of International and Development Studies. At age 16 he arrived at Harvard for freshman orientation in the midst of the famous 1938 hurricane. As a sophomore he was invited to participate in the Grant Study, now known as the Study of Adult Development, and was a member until his death more than 75 years later. In 2007 he was asked if he would donate his brain to the Study for further research, which he readily agreed to do. While at Harvard he enjoyed being a member of the Lampoon and the Hasty Pudding and as such co-authored their senior play with Robert Benchley and Coles Phinizy. It was never performed as suddenly our country was at war. Immediately upon graduating Art enrolled in the Coast Guard Officers Training School. After graduation he served as a "Coastie" for the duration, participating in one of the fiercest battles fought in World War II - The Anzio Landing. Upon returning home, Art became President and COO of the Voluntary Home Mortgage Credit Program and was awarded their Distinguished Service Award. While living in the D.C. area he worked as a volunteer for the Republican Party. He also discovered in the woods of Virginia what would become a life-long passion birding. Sea and shore birds, songbirds and raptors all became a source of great joy. He loved taking friends and grandchildren on bird walks at Orchid Island Golf and Beach Club where he helped design an Orchid Island life-list and brochure for club members. Art served on the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts for many years as a member of its Board of Governors, as President in 1975-76 and was the 1993 recipient of its Industry Leadership Award. In 1983-84 Art served as President of the Pension Real Estate Association and in 1984-85 served as Chairman of the Board. From 1958 until 1991, Art founded and was President and CEO of Investors Central Management Corporation, which sponsored three Real Estate Investment Trusts that were listed on the New York Stock Exchange. After retiring from corporate New York, Art soon became the U.S. representative of the Dutch real estate investment company, IBUS, arranging their U.S. acquisitions and serving as their consultant for many years. Art was predeceased by his first wife, Ann Welch Viner and is survived by his wife, Teryl Townsend Viner, his son William Viner, his sister Ellen Seiler, his stepchildren Don and Shawn Speers and his three grandchildren Katherine, Robert and Dorothy Speers. Services will be held Friday, June 27 at 2:00pm in the Chapel of the Community Church of Vero Beach., 1901 23rd Street. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Community Church of Vero Beach or the Vero Beach Museum of Art Endowment Fund. Services are by Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. A guest book is available at www.strunkfuneralhome.com.

ROWAN--Barbara. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Barbara Rowan, beloved mother of Marc and Andrea Rowan. Barbara leaves behind a legacy of exceptional philanthropy and love of Jewish heritage and culture that will be carried on by her beloved family. We extend our deepest condolences to Barbara's children, Andrea and Marc (Carolyn); her grandchildren; and her entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

WIENER--Geoffrey Richard, of Larchmont, NY, died Friday, June 6, 2014, surrounded by his children at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, NY from complications of pneumonia. He was 95. Geoffrey is survived by his four children: Margaret (Steven Goldstein), Geoffrey Jr. (Wendy Banner), Robert (Katherine Clark) and Alison (George Bryant); 10 grandchildren: Katherine, Elizabeth, Alexander, and Maura Goldstein, Arrol and Corinn Bryant, and Daniel Wiener, Stephen Gordon, Ellie Wiener, and Olivia Wiener. His wife of more than 58 years, Margaret, died in 2008. Geoffrey was born October 26, 1918 in New York City, the son of Ernest Wiener and Claire S. Wiener. From a young age and throughout his life, he loved sailing. Geoff was a World War II veteran, serving as an Army officer in the South Pacific. His desire to help those less fortunate led to a career as a social worker, with Masters and Doctoral degrees from Columbia University School of Social Work, and made him a fierce civil rights and anti-poverty crusader. He served as executive director of Hamilton Madison House in lower Manhattan where he spent 16 years leading the settlement house and contributed more than 50 years of service, including as a Board member. He also taught at Hunter College School of Social Work and at the State University of New York, Downstate Medical Center, and served for 10 years as executive director of Abbott House, a child welfare, foster care and adoption organization. In retirement he volunteered with the International Executive Service Corps, with the Larchmont/Mamaroneck Local Summit, and strongly supported the Mamaroneck Hispanic Resource Center. He loved learning, traveling and his family, including the family dogs. Geoffrey was fond of the "Winnie the Pooh" books and had a well-known sweet tooth (especially for ice cream). His bear hugs, even at age 95, were strong - he put all his love into every embrace. In recent years, he loved to walk in Manor Park and weekly visited the Larchmont Senior Center, where he became a prolific painter. His Coolidge Street home has become a veritable art gallery. His family would like to thank his live-in aides Cutie Fraser and Auda Moncion, Karen Schwartz and her staff, and Dr. Steven Meixler and the nurses and staff at White Plains Hospital. He was well-loved and will be missed by all who knew him. Donations in his memory should be made to Hamilton Madison House, 253 South St., New York, NY 10002.

SIEGEL--Louis, of Fort Lee, NJ, previously of Englewood Cliffs, NJ, died on June 16, 2014, at age 94. Mr. Siegel was born in New Bedford, MA in 1920 and moved to New York City in 1923. He was educated at Stuyvesant High School and New York University. He retired from the United States Air Force as Lieutenant Colonel after 39 years of service. After his military service he worked for ITT, from which he retired in 1988. As a member of the 15th Air Force based in Italy, he completed 51 combat missions flying B-24H Liberators Patricia Ann and Boobie Trap, his final mission being pilot of a bombing run on the Romanian oil fields at Ploiesti, on May 31, 1944. He was recalled for extended duty in 1951 during the Korean Conflict. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, 10 Air Medals, a Purple Heart, and numerous other medals and citations. Mr. Siegel was a member of several military support organizations including the Air Force Reserve Officers Association and the Military Officers Association of America. He is survived by many cousins with whom he was quite close.

SOWDERS--Travis Lee, (March 12, 1975 June 11, 2014). Travis Lee Sowders, age 39, of West Hollywood, CA died Wednesday, June 11, 2014 due to injuries sustained in an automobile accident in Los Angeles, CA. He was an extraordinary partner, son, brother, uncle, cousin, friend, and all around bon vivant. Travis is survived by his partner Rob Six of West Hollywood, CA; parents, Ancil and Lynn Sowders of Barbourville, KY; his sister, Synthia Sowders of Barbourville, KY; his nieces, Lillian and Audra Partin; many dear and beloved aunts and uncles; friends from around the world; and his beloved dog, Sofie. He was preceded in death by his maternal grandparents, William and Cordia Graham and his paternal grandparents, Bev and Betty Sowders. Contributions can be made to the Liberty Hill Foundation/ Travis Sowders Future Fund, which will be invested in causes such as K-12 education and equality and advancement of at-risk youth. Tax-deductible contributions can be mailed to 6420 Wilshire Blvd., Ste 700, Los Angeles, CA 90048. Funeral services for Travis will be conducted at the East Barbourville Baptist Church, Monday, June 23, 2014 at 1:00pm. Burial will follow in the Barbourville Cemetery. Friends will be received at the East Barbourville Baptist Church, Monday, June 23, 2014 after 11:00am until the funeral hour at 1:00pm. A second celebration of life for Travis will be held in Washington, DC on Saturday, June 28th at Evermay Mansion in Georgetown from 6pm to 8pm. All are welcome.

LITZ--Arthur Walton, the Holmes Professor of Belles Lettres, Emeritus, and professor of English, Emeritus, at Princeton University, died of respiratory failure at the University Medical Center of Princeton at Plainsboro, New Jersey, on June 4. He was 84. Born in Nashville, Tennessee in 1929, Litz earned his bachelor's degree from Princeton in 1951 and his D.Phil. from the University of Oxford, where he studied as a Rhodes Scholar. He was an expert on modern American and English literature with a focus on T.S. Eliot, James Joyce, Ezra Pound and Wallace Stevens. Litz was also a longtime instructor at the Bread Loaf School of English, the graduate school of English at Middlebury College. In 1989, he was named to the Eastman Visiting Professorship at Balliol College, Oxford. He was a member of the American Philosophical Society and served on the executive council of the Modern Language Association and as a trustee of Oxford University Press and the Ezra Pound Literary Trust. Litz was awarded fellowships by the American Council of Learned Societies, the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Guggenheim Foundation. He is survived by four children, Katharine, Andrew, Victoria and Emily; and six grandchildren.
OXMAN--Leon, We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Elaine and friends. Leon was a good friend and client. He will be greatly missed. Michael L. Landsman, Partner, Holm & O'Hara LLP

PERMUT--Michael, 84, longtime resident of Kings Point, New York died at home on June 19th, 2014 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. His family was by his side. Son of the late Miriam and Morris Permut, Michael was born on August 22, 1929, and was pre-deceased by his sister, Minette Kushner. Michael was a proud graduate of Brooklyn Technical High School, The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and The New York University School of Law. He and his devoted wife, Connie, celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary this past April. A member of the New York Bar Association for almost 60 years, Michael was a well respected New York attorney who specialized in Real Estate Law and was considered to be a foremost expert in the area of Title Insurance. Best known for his warmth and gregarious personality, "Mike" loved all people, had a smile for everybody, and was the consummate gentleman. He was a die hard sports fan who loved his hometown Rangers and Giants, and could give you the complete history of all of the New York team's origins. Mike and Connie shared a love of bridge where they were both "Life Masters," collected antiques, and devoted much of their time together to raising and showing their champion bred Boxers. Michael is survived by his wife, Connie, daughter Kerry (Ronny) Baron, son Dr. Todd Permut, and son Kyle (Barbra) Permut and loving grandchildren Chelsey, Jory, Jacy and Jamy (Baron) and Oliver and Hayley (Permut). He was most proud of and involved with all of them. He attended countless sporting events and graduations for all of his children and grandchildren. Funeral services will be private and any donations in Michael's memory should be directed to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation: www.pdf.org
RADOMSKY--Gloria, 87. On June 15th, 2014. Holocaust survivor. Loving, devoted wife, mother and grandmother.

REGAN--Thomas Patrick, 74, of Gulfport, FL; formerly of Sea Cliff, LI, died Thursday, June 19, 2014 peacefully at home. He worked for IBM for 35 years in New York City. He is survived by his wife Peachy; daughters Siobhan and Stephanie and his extended family. For complete obituary visit: www.alifetribute.com
MORGAN--Tom. "The Wednesday Ten" mourns the loss of our esteemed friend and member, who graced 50+ years of dinners combining camaraderie, fun, and important issues.

RAQUET--Andrew Walter. A world renowned Interior Designer and creative inventor, passed away at the age of 45 on June 14th, 2014. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends, colleagues and clients. Andrew Raquet enjoyed a life that incorporated his formidable talent as an interior designer. His commitment to reviving high end luxury design in an unpretentious, refreshing way earned him a stellar reputation amongst clients. His originality and fearless approach to transforming spaces earned him the respect of his peers. He was a favorite on the show house circuit, designing spaces from Paris to Manhattan to the Bahamas. He served on the Kips Bay Designer's Committee. His work was heralded by major publications including: Architectural Digest, House Beautiful, The New York Times, Quest, and Veranda. In addition Raquet founded BAMBOO BAMBOO, the most well-regarded luxury home furnishings and gift shop in the Bahamas, with outposts in Nassau and Harbor Island. He was a member of the Lyford Cay Club. Raquet grew up in Garden City, Long Island, NY. He graduated from Deerfield Academy and Columbia University. He also studied at Parsons School of Design and the Sotheby's School in London. Most recently, he was working with his sister, Merridith, on a showroom in Manhattan to display his extraordinary designs and visionary ideas. He is survived by his father Walter Raquet, mother Kristine Scerbo and his two sisters, Kim Ponce and Merridith Raquet. A memorial service will be held at First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, CT on Thursday, June 26, at 5pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Bruce Museum, 1 Museum Drive, Greenwich, CT, 06830.

McCARTY--Marianne Chi, 48, passed May 28, 2014, at Cooley Dickinson Hospital, Massachusetts, daughter of the late Gale Brooks, surrounded by her beloved family, her mother, Lynn Tran (McCarty, Dryden) Dupont, classmates and friends. Marianne attended St Hilda's & St Hugh's and Loyola schools, both in New York City, and Hampshire College in Massachusetts. Caring and creative. Memorial: French Church du St. Esprit, 109 East 60th St between Park and Lexington Avenues, NYC, Saturday, June 28 at 3:30pm. Donation in her memory to: Intrepid Fallen Heroes Fund, One Intrepid Square, West 46th St., and 12th Avenue, New York, NY 10036. www.fallenheroesfund.org

ROBINSON--Carmen Maria Warren. On Wednesday, June 11, Carmen Maria Warren Robinson lost her courageous battle with cancer at age 63. Carmen was an accomplished equestrian, a talented painter, potter and floral artist; but it was her courage that truly inspired. Her family is grateful to Dr. Anna Gattani for helping her beat the odds as her cancer metastasized and to Dr. Sandra Park for keeping her grounded. Carmen's faith enabled her to live each day at its fullest with no worry about the next. The bible tells us of Enoch who walked with the Lord each day until one day they went much further than usual. The Lord said, "Enoch you have come so far with me, come just a little further and we will go home together." Carmen did just that; she walked a little further on the road all of us must travel. Carmen's dream was to train guide dogs for the blind. Donations may be sent in her memory to: guidedogs.com. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held on Saturday, August 16, at 2:00pm at the Trinity Methodist Church, City Island, NY. Carmen is survived by her husband, Ritch Robinson; her father, Peter Warren and stepmother Hollis; her sister AJ; her brother Peter, former wife Peggy and nephews, Josh, Peter and Aiden Warren; her Aunt Christina Bracho and cousins, Pablo, Juan and Diana and Giles and Hugh Parker. This obituary was submitted by the Warren and Robinson families. You may contact the family at: mariawarren2@yahoo.com.

MASLIN--Herb, passed away peacefully, at 91 on June 18, 2014. He is survived by his loving partner and best friend of 30 years, Arlene Lichterman. Devoted father of Joan and Mitchell (Joy) and grandfather of Jessica and Derek. He had two separate careers: Chairman/CEO of a publicly traded aeronautical firm and in 1978 he opened the Cajun Restaurant in New York City, where he introduced Dixieland Jazz. Affectionately known as the "Cajun Maven," Herb was always ahead of his time - a self made, creative entrepreneur - a unique man. "Young at heart," with a zest for life, he and his sense of humor/jokes will be missed.

RAPOPORT--Gladys Bernstein, 96, June 13, 2014. Witty, forthright, well-read, enthusiastic tennis competitor, kind and caring Oakland University administrator, cherished wife of Bernard for 67 years, loving mother of John, Carol Monteleoni and Sarah Kaufman, grandmother of six and great-grandmother of three. Her legacy of intelligence, compassion, humor and idealism survives in those who love her.

MARCUS--Junis Roberts. Peacefully on June 18, 2014. Teacher, art collector and jazz club owner. Survived by husband Burt, son Michael (Diane), daughter, Stacy (Aaron), her "fabulous" grandchildren Hannah, Philip, Jonathan and Avery and sister Samoan. Pug lover and passionate friend to many.

MACREERY--Ruth K.,94, of Granite Springs, NY, at her home following a brief illness and surrounded by loving family. She was born in Washington, DC on August 5, 1919, the daughter of Otto E. Koegel and Rae Fisher Koegel. She graduated from Bronxville High School and then Smith College where she received her Bachelor of Arts degree in music. During World War II, she was a volunteer with the American Red Cross. When the War ended she married John B Macreery of Watkins Glen, NY where they lived for a short time before moving to Westchester County, NY. She was active in community and charitable service throughout her life. She is survived by her four children and their spouses, Katherine M. and Ronald L. Weyhrauch, William Frank and Abbey Kelley Macreery, John Brian and Linda Calabrese Macreery and Kevin Owens and Kiersten Roberts Macreery, seven grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband of 64 years, and by her two brothers, James E. Koegel and William F. Koegel. She was devoted to her family and her friends, and will be sorely missed by all. A memorial service will be held in her honor at the Church of the Good Shepherd in Granite Springs, NY on July 12, 2014 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to the American Lung Association.

MacPHERSON--Ian Keith, died peacefully on June 19, 2014 at the age of 91. He was born in London and served in the British Merchant Navy during WWII for which he received the Arctic Star. A 40 year career in telecommunications brought him to the US where he settled in 1960. He became an American citizen in 2012. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis and two daughters, Cayre and Michele, and three grandchildren, Jason, Zoe and Gordon. Funeral service is at St. Ann's, Bridgehampton, NY on June 23 at 10am and he will be laid to rest at Kensico, Valhalla, NY.

MONT--Dorothy. The Eakins Press Foundation mourns the passing of our beloved Dorothy Mont. Such a loss is only tempered by the fond memories of nearly three decades of dedication to the programs of the Press, which Dottie always ministered with good humor and grace. We offer our condolences to her children and grandchildren and to all the friends whose lives she touched.
MORTENSON--Scott Andrew. Makeup artist, 50, passed away on June 9 in New York City. His work was included in several magazines. He is survived by his sister Kim, father Bob and mother Pat Horner.

MOSIER--Frank Moffett, May 15, 1929 - June 13, 2014. Actors' Studio Playwrights' group; New Dramatists; The Actor's Place at St. Luke's; Off-Off-Broadway Alliance; Quintano's School for Young Professionals. Obituary at frankmoffettmosier.com.

LEVINE--Joan (Slocum). Joan lived and worked in NYC for most of her life, a city she loved. She also raised roses in Spain for her nursery business. She later retired on Cape Cod. Joan is survived by her sister, Sue Buschner and numerous nieces and nephews. She will be greatly missed. Interment private.
OKEEFE--John. We mourn the death on June 7 of our beloved friend and treasure the memory of his kindness to us and others, and to his loyalty, talent and Irish charm. Kay and Elliot Cattarulla
LEWIN--Margie. To our dear, loving friend, our lives together were beautiful and now end sadly. We will miss you. Stanley, Marcia, Amy, Eli, Ken, Sami, and Linda.

MYERS--Charles Twiggs, legendary history teacher and coach at Berkshire School in Sheffield, Mass., died June 14 at the age of 83. Insatiably curious, Twiggs had interests ranging from clocks to railroad trains, from trees and flowers to anything written by May Sarton and Walter Pritchard Eaton, from the Philadelphia Phillies to the back roads of the Adirondacks, where he spent his summers at the Crater Club in Essex, N.Y. Twiggs Myers was born on August 2, 1930, in Bryn Mawr, PA, the youngest of three children of Charles Myers, a Philadelphia attorney, and the former Gertrude James Hearne. He was the namesake of his great-great grandfather, David Emmanuel Twiggs, a hero of the Mexican War who later became the oldest Confederate general in the Civil War. As a child, Twiggs raised homing pigeons kept in a loft attached to the family garage and was a member of the International Federation of American Homing Pigeon Fanciers. (Years later, Twiggs would raise chickens at his home in Sheffield, which he called Laywell Farm.) Twiggs attended the private Haverford School. In 1952, he graduated from Princeton University with a degree in history. Among his classmates were tailback Dick Kazmaier, the last Ivy Leaguer to win the Heisman Trophy, and former Treasury Secretary and Secretary of State James A. Baker. After a year at Harvard Law School, Twiggs was hired by Berkshire School, then an all-boys school with 150 students. Twiggs Myers was among the last of a breed: the bachelor schoolmaster whose institution is his love and whose students are his children. With a passion for the Civil War and a reverence for Lee and Lincoln, he taught history from 1953 to 1995, when he was named the school's Senior Master Emeritus. He coached track and field his entire career and, in 1966, founded the school's cross country running program, whose teams racked up 200 victories while he was coach. Twiggs was an inveterate storyteller with a quick, often irreverent, wit. Among the staples in his repertoire was Adlai Stevenson's quip, "I find Norman Vincent Peale appalling and St. Paul appealing." Every August, as he reluctantly left his camp on Lake Champlain for the classroom, Twiggs would pronounce, "The curtain of seriousness is descending." In addition to countless former students, survivors include sister Eliza Miller; nieces Diane Hulburt, Katje McIntyre, Wendy Miller, and Susan Curtin; nephews Hunter Ten Broeck and Mark Miller; 12 grand-nephews and nieces; and five great-grandnephews and nieces. A memorial service for Twiggs Myers will be held on July 12 at 11 am at Christ Church in Sheffield. Gifts in his memory may be made to Berkshire School or to the Sheffield Land Trust in care of Birches Roy Funeral Home, 33 South Street, Great Barrington, MA 01230.

LISANSKY--Dr. Milton, DDS, NYU '43, MPH, Yale '52 born April 7, 1918 and died quietly at home with his family on June 13, 2014. He touched many lives; nurturing everything from dreams to plants to dental interns. His legacy includes creating the first sliding scale dental clinic in the country, treating POWs in his MASH unit on Okinawa with respect and dignity, serving as Chief of Dentistry and Oral Surgery at Yale-New Haven Hospital and raising four accomplished children. He is survived by his wife, Sybil, his sister, Pearl, his sons, Stephen (Sophie) and Eugene (Daisy) and his daughters, Judith (Larry) and Susan Pinco. He was well-loved and will be sorely missed.

OWEN--Jane Dale. Jane Dale Owen was born September 30, 1942 and passed away on June 11, 2014 at her home in Dallas, surrounded by her beloved caregivers and her son, Erik. She was the first child born to Jane Blaffer Owen and Kenneth Dale Owen of Houston, Texas and New Harmony, Indiana. She attended the Kinkaid School until she contracted polio in 1951. She subsequently moved to New York to be near the New York Hospital for special surgery to mitigate the ravages of the disease. She attended the Nightingale-Bamford School and Bennington College. Jane courageously faced her challenges with beauty, a sense of humor, a gentle spirit and grace. In 1963, she was married to the Norwegian ship broker, Per Arneberg, and was blessed with two children, Erik and Ingrid. They lived in New York City. Jane loved caring for her family and pets. They enjoyed weekends and summers in Oyster Bay Long Island, sailing and taking long swims. Jane was an accomplished chef. In New York, she was involved in fund-raising for the Public Broadcasting System (PBS). Jane taught remedial reading to school children. She loved her dogs and shared this love with others in need. Through the Pet Partners, she took her dogs to hospitals and nursing homes where they brought joy to patients and the elderly. Jane and Per were amicably divorced in 1976. In 1980, she married Peter Leslie Jarvis. They divorced in 1987. She had a love of adventure, spoke three languages and traveled extensively to Great Britain, France, Italy Spain, Greece, Japan, Holland and Norway. No trek or terrain was impossible for Jane. Her strength and will enabled her to traverse shores, mountains and cobble-stone streets. There was never a time when she gave up or out - she willed herself to do what everyone else could do with ease. Jane moved back to Houston in 1993 to be closer to her parents. She soon became involved in alerting the public to the hazards of air pollution and other environmental issues. In 2000, she founded Citizens League for Environmental Action Now (CLEAN). For more than a decade, she boldly spoke out about the responsibility of energy companies, government leaders, state agencies and citizens to reduce pollution and work toward clean energy solutions in opinions published in the Houston Chronicle and Climate Progress. She also provided funding to local projects including a citizen air sampling project known as the "Bucket Brigade" and Texas Environmental Advocacy Services, TEJAS. She was the only non-scientist member of the Federation of American Scientist. Jane endowed The University of Texas School of Public Health, with a professorship of Environmental Health Protection, established in 2008. Her philanthropy extended to the protection of prairies and other natural areas. In addition to Jane's environmental work, she has made a significant contribution to the quality of life in Houston as a patron of the arts and historic preservation. She has served on the advisory board and executive committee of the Blaffer Gallery at the University of Houston. She has been honored by the gallery for her dedicated support, leadership, and for continuing her mother and grandmother's legacy and vision for the museum and arts in Texas. She also served on the executive committee of the Moores School of Music. She funded the popular Children's Film program and served on the film committee at Museum of Fine Arts. Jane had a home in Rhode Island where she spent summers with children, her mother and many friends. She loved going out on the boat with Captain Dave and swimming almost every day. She was deeply committed to preservation of historic homes in Middletown, Rhode Island. In 2008, after one hurricane too many, she moved from Houston to Dallas. She also has a home in Palm Beach, Florida. In New Harmony, Indiana, she made significant donations to preserve the family legacy through the preservation of historic homes. She also contributed to the New Harmony Artist Guild which sponsors the New Harmony Music Festival and School. Jane's homes were a safe haven for her friends, sisters, children and many loving cousins. She was always there to provide encouragement, wisdom and compassion. Her boundless generosity enhanced the lives of her family, friends, and bolstered charitable causes. Jane will be greatly missed by her son, Erik, his wife, Lora, their children Per Erik and Ellis Jane; her daughter, Ingrid and grandaughter Sarah; her sister, Anne Owen Pontez, and her husband Harold J. Pontez; her niece and godchild, Abigail Owen-Pontez; nephew, James Owen Coleman; and her brother-in-law, James J. Coleman, Jr. She was predeceased by her parents, Jane Blaffer Owen and Kenneth Dale Owen, and sister, Carol Owen Coleman. The family would like to say a special thank you to those who loved and cared for her during good times and bad: Brad, Comfort, Maria, Claudia, Angela, Zandra, Adriana, the nurses at Baylor University Medical Center and Aspen hospice care. A memorial service will follow in New Harmony, Indiana. Announcements will be sent out when the date is confirmed. In addition, there will be a memorial service in Houston on September 30th (Janie's birthday) at 5:00 pm at her family's home in Houston. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Gulf Coast Restoration, American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and/or the American Cancer Society.

OXMAN--Leon, died on June 13, 2014. His primary passions were music, art and investing. He was a percussionist and traveled the world as a member of the 7th Army Symphony. He also performed on Broadway, including in productions of Indians, Celebration and Oliver! He was an avid investor in real estate and owned and managed several commercial properties. A man of tremendous intellect, strong opinions and wide-ranging interests, he will be sorely missed by his beloved wife Elaine Cameron-Oxman, and many friends. A memorial gathering will be held on June 27, 2014 in Manhattan. Contact m.voelz@hohlaw.com

FISCHER--Nancy Sarah Kaplan, (1928 2014) passed away peacefully at her home in New York City on June 16, 2014, after a brief illness. She earned her degrees in art and education from the University of Chicago and Columbia. Mrs. Fischer served as an educational advisor to the Department of Education at City College and was the Director of the Long Ridge School in Stamford, Connecticut. Nancy was predeceased by her beloved husband, Roy; and her brother, Stephen Kaplan. She is survived by her three children, David Schaffer and his wife, Amy, Peter Schaffer and his wife, Wendy Lecker, and Joanna Schaffer and her husband, Joseph Pastore; also, her stepson, Richard Fischer and his wife, Donna DeLaurentis; and her stepdaughter, Patrice Fischer; also by nine grandchildren, Philip, Caleb, Nicole, Megan, Laura, Julia, Hannah, Heather and Noah; and four great-grandchildren. She is also survived by a sister-in-law, Caryl Kaplan; her niece, Judy Kaplan Walker, her husband, Robert Walker and their sons, Aaron and Isaac Walker; and by her nephew, Allan Kaplan. She is fondly remembered by her loving cousins and her truly dear friends whose devotion she cherished and returned. A memorial service will be held in August. In lieu of flowers, we welcome you to make a donation to a charity of your choice in her memory.

FREEDMAN--Jeffrey Steven, born December 17, 1946, Brooklyn, NY, died June 13, 2014, Jacksonville, FL. We honor the memory of Jeffrey, son of the late Gertrude and David Freedman. Survived and mourned by brother Alan David Freedman, and sister Karen Frank, Jacksonville. Jeffrey earned a BA in Philosophy from Temple University, graduate of New England School of Acupuncture; compassionate, licensed Acupuncturist, and practitioner of Oriental Medicine. Attended Peters Valley School of Craft, and Philadelphia College of Art. Accomplished and talented painter, potter and photographer, had deep appreciation of the arts through his mother; a multi talented artist. World traveler, made the overland trip from Europe to the India he came to love, and revisit. As a young man, an avid school yard basketball player, he could drive left and right and fought hard under the boards. He will be deeply missed, he would have us reflect on precious memories of the good times we shared.

EVERETT--William H. M.D.,died on June 14, 2014. Born in New York and raised in Larchmont, he attended Williams College and Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. Devoted to his family, his medical practice in Williamstown, MA, and the Williamstown Theater Festival in his role as President from 1976 to 1994, he will be deeply missed. Survived by his wife, Gintare Sileika Everett, his children, Patricia Everett of Amherst, MA and James Everett and his wife Helene of Chapin, SC, along with three grandchildren, Zael and Django Ellenhorn and Kevin Everett. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown on July 6, 3pm.

FISHER--Charles Thomas III. Grosse Pointe Farms resident Charles Thomas "Chick" Fisher III, former chairman, president and CEO of NBD Bancorp Inc., died Sunday, June 15, 2014. He was 84. Mr. Fisher was born November 22, 1929, in Detroit to Charles Thomas Fisher Jr. and Elizabeth Briggs Fisher and was a grandson of Charles T. Fisher Sr. co-founder of Fisher Body, which later became part of General Motors Corp., and Walter O. Briggs, who founded the Briggs Manufacturing Company, a maker of automobile bodies, and who owned the Detroit Tigers baseball team. Mr. Fisher graduated in 1947 from Portsmouth Priory School in Rhode Island; Georgetown University in 1951 and earned an MBA from Harvard University in 1953 and an honorary Doctorate from Georgetown University in 1990. He began work as an accountant with Touche, Ross, Bailey & Smart, and became a certified public accountant in Michigan in 1957. He joined NBD as an assistant vice president in 1958, became president in 1972 and chairman in 1982. He retired in 1993. Mr. Fisher was active in professional and community organizations including serving as a director of American Airlines, DTE (Detroit Edison), General Motors, Hiram Walker, American Broadcasting Company, National Intergroup, Jannock Ltd, Mackinac Bridge Authority, and the Georgetown University Board of Regents (Founding Member) and Board of Visitors (Chairman). He also was a member of the Country Club of Detroit, Detroit Athletic Club, Grosse Pointe Club, Bloomfield Hills Country Club, Little Traverse Yacht Club, St. Andrews Club, Question Club, Alfalfa Club, New York Yacht Club,The Key Largo Anglers Club, Delray Beach Yacht Club, the Links Club, Old Club, Wequetonsing Club, Little Harbor Club, Golf Stream Golf Club, Golf Stream Bath and Tennis Club, and the Yondetega Club. Mr. Fisher is survived by his wife, Margaret Elizabeth "Beth" Keegin Fisher, whom he married June 18, 1952; children, Margaret Elizabeth "Lisa" Fisher Jones (Macy); Curtis William Fisher, Lawrence P. "Larry" Fisher II (Maria Elena) and Mary Florence "Mimi" Fisher Hickey (John). He was predeceased by his son, Charles T. Fisher IV. Mr. Fisher also is survived by his grandchildren, Kristin Fisher Allen, Elizabeth Briggs Jones Coleman, Charles T. Fisher V, Curtis William Fisher Jr., Marta Cristina Fisher, John Keegin Fisher, Keegin Marie Fisher, Emily Ryan Hickey, Kathryn Keegin Hickey and Alison Briggs Hickey; four great-grandchildren; siblings, Mary Elizabeth Fisher, R.S.C.J., Fred J. Fisher II (Juelle), Jane F. McDonnell (Richard C. Tucker), Walter B. Fisher (Sandy), Sarah F. Champion (Robert) and John A. Fisher (Didi). A funeral Mass was celebrated on Thursday, June 19, at St. Paul on the Lake Catholic Church, 157 Lakeshore, Grosse Pointe Farms, MI. Share a memory at http://verheyden.org

duPONT--Helen Quinn "Pennie", of Greenwich Village, New York, passed away peacefully in Wilmington, Delaware on June 13, 2014. She is survived by her sister Deborah duP. Riegel of Wilmington, and by two brothers, P. Coleman duPont of Wilmington and Jamie MacKenzie of Taconic, Connecticut. After graduating from Miss Porter's School, Bradford Junior College and Yale Drama School, Pennie studied with Uta Hagen in New York. She then worked in theater both on and off Broadway. Pennie also taught acting and directing at the NYU Tisch School of the Arts, in New York and Singapore, and at the Lee Strasberg Theater and Film Institute. Services are private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: HB Studio, 120 Bank Street, New York, NY 10014.

FRANKL--Kenneth R.,died June 16, 2014. Jeanne, Keith and Kathryn will receive guests at home, 67 Old Montauk Highway, Amagansett, Sunday, June 29, 2014 after a 3pm memorial at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons, 44 Woods Lane, East Hampton 11937, and Monday, June 30th 4-7pm. Contributions in Ken's memory may be made to the Jewish Center or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach 11978-7048.

GRAHAM--Wallace E.,79 years old passed away June 8th 2014, in Boynton Beach, Florida. Formerly of Boston, MA. He attended Boston Latin School and Lawrence Academy. He served in the Armed Svcs in Germany. Returned to Boston to graduate from Tufts University. Moved to New York to work for CBS and ABC Networks. In the mid 70s he moved to Palm Beach and was a columnist for Palm Beach Daily News (The Shiny Sheet), with a column called "Skylarking". Then moved to Nashville to work for the Tennessean and taught journalism and marketing at Western Kentucky University in Bowling Green, KY. In 1980 relocated to Los Angles to work on the 1984 Olympics Marketing Committee. After the Olympics he moved back to Boston to work in the Division of Employment Security for the Governors Office. He retired from the State of Massachusetts and moved to Boynton Beach, FL, where he was very active in the local Democratic Party as a precinct captain. He and his surviving partner Jimmy Carden were active in volunteering in the Highpoint West II Condo Association. Predeceased by brother Terrance Graham. He will be missed by family, sister-in-law Peggy Graham and nephews Terrance and Paul Graham of South Boston and his many friends.

ESSESDeanne. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Deanne Esses. Her exceptional philanthropic traditions live on through the generosity of her cherished family. We extend our condolences to Deanne's children, Arlene Esses Maidman, Gail Esses Weiner, and son-in-law, Mitchel Maidman; to her grandchildren; and to the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

GERSH--Edward. Our beloved husband/father died peacefully on Father's Day, Sunday June 15, 2014. He is survived by his wife Holli Gersh, his children: Esther Greenhaus, Laurie Gersh Roxanne Gersh, Kevin Gersh, Heather Greenberg; his brother Gabriel Gersh; his eight grandchildren, and 17 great- grandchildren. His career as an educator spanned over 70 years. He was a teacher, dean of students, college professor, and a founding member of Wilmington University. He was the founder and owner of West Hills Day Camp in Huntington, NY. His athletic career included all scholastic varsity football player as well as the 1943 Golden Gloves heavyweight open boxing champion. He both managed and promoted professional boxing. He sat on many educational boards. His dedication to the welfare of children as well as his abiding friendship to all he knew made him beloved by everyone. He will be deeply missed. Donations can be made to the "Edward I. Gersh Scholarship" at New York University and the "Edward I. Gersh Scholarship" at Wilmington University. For information call 631-427-3500.

HOLLANDER--Seena. The entire Hebrew Home family mourns the loss of Seena Hollander. Seena was an integral part of the fabric of the Hebrew Home, who radiated warmth and kindness. Devoted to her children and grandchildren, Seena treasured family time and was proud of each of their accomplishments. As someone who appreciated the arts, a good book and a robust conversation about politics and history, Seena was truly one of a kind. Her three sons, Alan, Joel and Les, her grandchildren and all who had the good fortune to know her, will miss the sparkle in her eye, the smile on her face and her positive outlook. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey Maurer, Chairman, Board of Directors Daniel Reingold, President & CEO David V. Pomeranz, COO

DAVIS--Anna, "Asia," 96, died peacefully with family around her on June 15. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Sydney. She maintained the values they both held dear throughout her life. She reveled in the accomplishments and happiness of every one of her family and was not above telling anyone who would listen that they were special. Beloved sister of Mica Deouell of Israel. Devoted mother of Elana Zucker (Brian), Varda Solomon (Alan) and Leo Davis (Orietta). Doting grandmother and great-grandmother to Keren Beckerman (Igor) parents of Joshua; David Zucker (Dana) parents of Sydney and Samuel; Daniel Solomon (Rachel) parents of Lila and Sabrina; Jonathan Zucker (Randi) parents of Michael and Rachel; and Seth Zucker (Sheryl) parents of Alexandra and Joshua. Decades ahead of her time, she insisted that each of her children, male or female, have a career, be independent and she supported their education throughout their lives. She valued the family above all and worked tirelessly to instill this in those she loved. She also had a deep commitment to the Jewish community here and in Israel and was a founding member of the Little Neck Jewish Center and the local Hadassah chapter. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hadassah, Little Neck Jewish Center; LI Alzheimer's Foundation, or Temple Israel of Great Neck.

GERARD--Frank, of Westbury, NY, formerly of Manhasset, NY passed away peacefully on June 20th, 2014 at the age of 91. Devoted husband of Eva. Loving dad of Patricia Marson (Peter), and William (Colleen). Cherished grandpa of Patricia, Mark, Peter, Christine and Bryan. Loving great-grandpa of Chayton and Declyn. Frank and his late brother Jimmy were the proud owners of Gerardi's Restaurant in the Financial District in New York City for over 50 Years. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10am at St. Mary's R.C. Church, 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. Entombment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Services entrusted to: Donohue-Cecere Funeral Home (516) 333-0615. www.donohue-cecere.com

KING--John Gordon, of Cambridge, MA, Francis L. Friedman Professor of Physics Emeritus at MIT, died on June 15 in Wellfleet, MA, aged 88, surrounded by family. "Goodnight sweet prince, and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest." http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ John--G.--King

BELSHAW--Elizabeth "Betsy" (Wheeler), of Princeton, New Jersey and Prout's Neck, Maine died on Tuesday, June 17, 2014 at home. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 24 at 11 a.m. at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton. Betsy was born to the late Richard E. and Wilhelmina West Wheeler in 1931 in Providence, Rhode Island. She graduated from Miss Porter's School in 1948 and from Smith College in 1952. An accomplished pianist and avid bridge player, Betsy devoted much of her life to the Episcopal Church, supporting parish activities in Honolulu, Hawaii, Dover, Delaware, Rumson, New Jersey and Princeton. Betsy is survived by her husband of 60 years, G.P. Mellick Belshaw, the 9th Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, her son Richard and his wife Julia, her daughter Elizabeth (Lisa) Ham and her husband Peter, her son George and his wife Dorothy, and by seven grandchildren: Emily, Elizabeth, Daniel, Martha, Alexandra, Alice and George. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, NJ 08540. www.trinityprinceton.com

CUTRONA--Marianne J. (nee DiCostanzo), on June 18th, 2014, wife of the late New York State Supreme Court Justice Anthony J. Cutrona. Born August 18th, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY, daughter of the late Philip F. and Aurelia (Mirabito) DiCostanzo. Marianne is survived by her daughter, Marianne Cutrona Ritz, son-in-law, Charles Ritz, daughter, Carol Anne Cutrona, son, Michael Cutrona, and daughter-in-law, Antonietta Chieco Cutrona. She will be dearly missed by her five grandsons, Charles Ritz, Anthony Cutrona, Nicholas Ritz, Anthony Ritz, Tommaso Cutrona, by her sister Jacqueline LaBella, brother Vincent DiCostanzo, sister-in-law, Kathleen DiCostanzo and all whose lives she touched. Family and friends may call at John J. McManus & Sons Funeral Home, 4601 Avenue N, Brooklyn, NY on Saturday, June 21 and Sunday, June 22 from 2-4:30pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday June 23, 9:30am at Our Lady Help of Christians RC Church, 1315 E 28th Street, Brooklyn, NY. Entombment will follow at Greenwood Cemetery. In honor of Marianne, donations may be sent to her favorite charity, Salesian Missions, 2 Lefevre Lane, New Rochelle, NY 10801.

HONOROFF--Richard A.,on June 13, 2014 after a long illness. Born in Chicago, May 24, 1951. A composer, arranger, musician and musical director, he worked in television, musical theater, jazz and classical venues. He wrote music for television sports including theme music for the National Football League, Atlanta Hawks basketball and for the 1988 and 1992 Olympic Games coverage. He performed as pianist on Broadway for the show, Eubie, and performed with many jazz greats. Off-Broadway he was musical director for five shows, including The Cotton Club Revisited. He wrote three orchestral works. Symphony No. 1 "Shoah" and a companion piece "Testament" were composed for and performed at The Shoah Concert in Berlin on February 4, 1994. Symphony No. 2, "From Ashes Reborn" was in part inspired by the protest of a Viet Nam War veteran. All three works were recorded in 1994 and 1995 by the Moscow Radio and Television Orchestra, led by Alexander Mikhailov. He is survived by his son, Zachary, and daughter, Julia, as well as his brother and sister-in-law, Brad and Jane Honoroff. A private memorial service will be held in July.

COHEN--Frances, Ph.D. Professor Emeritus in Psychology, University of California School of Medicine in San Francisco, died on May 28, 2014 after battling pancreatic cancer. Dr. Cohen was raised in Boonton, NJ. A member of the Medical Psychology faculty at UCSF, she co-authored with George C. Stone and Nancy E. Adler the foundational text "Health Psychology" (1979). Dr. Cohen was predeceased by her parents, Oscar H. Cohen, M.D., and Elsie F. Cohen. She is survived by her beloved son, Brett Cohen; sister Anne C. Richards (Fred Richards): brother Alan L. Cohen (Eva Marie Carney); niece Elise Cohen and nephew Marshall Cohen. A woman of great energy, drive, and optimism, her active involvement in Berkeley, CA community organizations continued up to the time of her death. A memorial service will be held at The Faculty Club, UC Berkeley, from 1-4pm on Saturday, July 12, 2014. In lieu of flowers, please donate to curePC.org or a charity of your choice.

KOENIG--Julian. April 22, 1921 - June 12, 2014. The One Club mourns the loss of Julian Koenig, esteemed member of the Creative Hall of Fame. Julian was inducted in 1966 to the Copywriters Hall of Fame, as it was known then. Born in New York, April 22, 1921, he graduated from Dartmouth and then studied at Columbia Law School. Julian was an eccentric intellectual who created a new style of copywriting that went on to define advertising's creative revolution. It was smart, simple and accessible to the public--writing that neither exaggerated nor overpromised. Contemporary writers compared him to Holden Caulfield, for being aloof and reserved in a business that favored popular culture. Julian is best known for his iconic work for Volkswagen while at Doyle Dane Bernbach. Working with art director Helmut Krone, he created the groundbreaking ads "Think Small" and "Lemon," which came to define the new style of advertising. Julian and Fred Papert launched a new agency with George Lois called Papert Koenig Lois where they created award-winning work for Wolfschmidt Vodka, Xerox, Peugeot and Allarest, proving as he once said that good taste is good for business. Many well-known advertising talents started their careers at PKL, including Carl Ally and Sam Scali, who went on to start their own agencies. Fred Papert and Julian remained good friends throughout their lives and made annual trips to Saratoga for the races. During his lifetime, Julian amassed a large coterie of colorful characters, including sportswriter Jimmy Breslin, Senator Jacob Javits, and his own alter ego, Groucho Marx. Among his many contributions was the naming of "Earth Day" in 1969, for a committee organized to bring environmental awareness to the public. The One Club offers heartfelt sympathy to Julian's children and grandchildren. (Photo credit, Carl Fischer)

COHN--Richard M.,94, died on June 17. Son of the late Hugo and Elsie Rothschild Cohn and brother of the late Walter Cohn, he is survived by dear friend Lia Fraenkel and many devoted cousins. Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at Rutgers, he received his Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1947. He was an expert in the field of Difference Algebra Theory. Memorial Service at 11am, July 24, 2014 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, NYC.

FINKELSTEIN--Paul, M.D.,passed away on June 20th, 2014. Born in 1920, he received undergraduate and medical degrees from Louisiana State University. An accomplished surgeon, he began his career as a Captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps stationed in Japan. Paul was devoted to and loved by both his family and patients. He was the Chief of Urology at The Brooklyn Hospital Center from 1971-1989 and served as Chairman of the New York State Board of Medicine, President of the Kings County Medical Society, Vice President of IPRO and Congregation Beth Elohim in Brooklyn, and was a board member of The Brooklyn Hospital and Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Home. Paul is survived by Doris, his loving wife of sixty years, and was the proud father of Henry, Susan (Michael), Dru and Lewis, and grandfather of Lindsey, Emma, David, Charlie, Natalie, Matthew and Sam. The funeral service will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, June 22nd at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at East 81st Street. Shiva will be held from 5:00-8:00pm on Sunday, June 22nd and from 2:00-8:00pm on Monday and Tuesday, June 23rd and 24th at 500 East 77th Street, New York City.

BERELSON--Dorothy G. The niece of famed cartoonist Rube Goldberg passed away June 12th in San Francisco at the age of 102. Dorothy Golden Berelson, lived in Tiburon, California since 1978. She was the widow of the late Edwin T. Golden and William Berelson. Mrs. Berelson leaves two daughters, Ann Mizel of Mill Valley, CA, Bobbi Lambert of Novato, CA and son Garrett Golden of Sacramento, CA. In addition, she is survived by three grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, and her sister, Hannah G. Samuels of San Francisco. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El in San Francisco on June 23. Donations to the Jean Mizel Scholarship Fund for Art History at Dominican University, San Rafael, California, in honor of Mrs. Berelson's beloved late granddaughter or favorite charity.

GRODNER--Arthur "Artie", passed away on June 19th, 2014, age 78. Born and raised in Brooklyn, he served in the Army and attended City College. As well as being a top Nationwide Insurance Agent for 40 years, he was a Little League coach, racehorse owner, pilot, blackjack player, avid reader and he loved golf. He was a man who made an impression on everyone he met; infused laughter wherever he went. He will be missed and loved always by his wife Harriet of 49 years, sons Michael and David, grandsons Jake, Dylan and Lucas, daughters-in-law Barbra and Cari, and a multitude of friends.

COHEN--Barry S.,of Keene, NH, formerly of New York City, passed away peacefully in Sarasota, FL on June 9, 2014 surrounded by his family. He was 87 years old. Barry grew up in Brooklyn, NY. He served in the US Navy in WWII, then earned his BA from Cornell University ('47) and his JD from Yale Law School ('50). Barry is survived by his sister, Phyllis Cohen, his daughters Vivian Farmery and Debe Holland, and his grandchildren who were his heart's delight: Kyle and Hannah Farmery, and Lily, Sam, and Wes Holland. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Lynda Fox, his mother, Mathilda Sheer, and his father, Harry Cohen. A man of great intellectual curiosity and wit, Barry was adored by all who knew him. He will be deeply missed. Burial was in Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ.

AHERN--John "Jack", 60, died in Old Westbury on June 17, 2014. Jack is survived by his wife, Susan, sons, Corey (Jennifer) and Michael, daughter, Taryn, mother, Margaret, brother, Liam (Nuala), sisters, Christine (Frank) and Karen (Darren). In lieu of flowers, donations requested to the Emerald Isle Immigration Center, 59-26 Woodside Ave., Woodside, NY, 11377, (718) 478-5502.

BATES--Chandler, Jr.,a resident of Greenwich, CT, died June 18, at 94 years of age. He was born in New York City, the son of Chandler and Amy Reick Bates, of New York City and Gloucester, VA. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Patricia Dickinson Bates. He leaves behind four children: Candice Gammill (Ken) of Woodstock, VT; Chandler Bates III (Jeanne) of Orem, UT; Christopher Bates (Marie) of Palm City, FL; and Cheryl Pace (John) of Barrington, RI; 11 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. Chan served with the OSS in World War II. After a career in advertising in New York City, he retired in 1973 to travel. He served with many Greenwich civic and community organizations. Chan was the first Director of the Cemetery at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich in the 1970's. His funeral service will be at St. Barnabas at 2:30pm, Monday, June 23, 2014.

ALPERT--Robert. Robert "Bob" Alpert, 96, passed away on June 13th in Dallas, TX. He was a resident of Highland Park, IL for 50 years, before moving to Delray Beach, Fl. and Dallas, Tx. Bob graduated Dartmouth College, Class of 1939. He was a decorated Captain in the U.S. Army Air Corps in World War II. His business career spanned creating innovative products to sales, management and producing industrial films. Bob was happily married to Corinne ("Corie") Stroock Galinger. He is survived by his son, Steven G., Dallas, TX; and granddaughters Sarah Elizabeth (Max Olesen) of Victoria, B.C., and Hannah Allene of New York, NY. Prior to entering the hospital on June 9th, Bob celebrated his birthday week with parties, a Texas Rangers baseball game, wine-making, and feasting surrounded by his entire family and those he loved. His was an old-time passing, just as one might imagine a biblical patriarch or a Bronze Age hero, Bob was conscious, smiling, and wise to the end. He died in stunningly perfect peace within himself and with the universe. Just before he passed away his youngest granddaughter, Hannah called him. To allay her fears, Bob sang in that smooth Tony Bennett voice of his an old standard made famous by Billie Holiday, "I Can't Give You Anything But Love, Baby." That was Bob -- He was all about timing, memory, love and spreading joy. Burial private in Gloversville, NY. BEDFORD--Ruth Thomas, daughter of Frederick T. and Lucie Thomas Bedford, died peacefully in her sleep on June 15, 2014, in her home in Greens Farms, Connecticut. Miss Bedford would have celebrated her 100th birthday on August 8, 2014. Miss Bedford led a very active and interesting life. She was a woman ahead of her time. Miss Bedford attended Foxcroft School in Virginia and upon graduation worked in social services. She served with the American Red Cross in the European theater during World War II. She had a great interest in the New York theater and worked for Rodgers and Hammerstein as a stage manager on several Broadway shows. Miss Bedford was a licensed sea plane pilot, an accomplished sailor, golfer, tennis player and horse woman. Upon returning to Connecticut Miss Bedford volunteered at the Norwalk Hospital for over fifty years. She made a difference in many people's lives by following her father's and grandfather's example in continuing to support many organizations and charities. The Town of Westport and the Norwalk Hospital as well as many other charities and individuals have been the beneficiary of her generosity. Her great love of animals is well known, particularly dogs and horses. Her race horses, ridden under the Nyala Farm name, won races at Belmont and Saratoga and other eastern tracks. Ruth Bedford will be gratefully remembered for loyalty to her family and friends. She made a difference in many people's lives. She was loved by all who knew her and will be greatly missed. Miss Bedford is survived by her niece, Cythlen Maddox, and nephews, James McCashin, Fred McCashin, Bruce McCashin, Briggs Cunningham, III, her cousin, Helen Watkins and several great nieces and nephews. She is predeceased by her sisters, Lucie Bedford Cunningham Warren, Helen Bedford McCashin, Mary Bedford, her niece, Lucie Cunningham McKinney, and her nephew, John McCashin. At the request of Miss Bedford services will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Aspetuck Land Trust, P.O. Box 444, Westport, CT 06881, Norwalk Hospital Foundation, 34 Maple Street, Norwalk, CT 06856, or the Westport Weston Family Y, 59 Post Road East, Westport, CT 06880. To sign an online guest book, please visit spearmillerfuneralhome.com.

BERNSTEIN--Ernestine, 95, of Manhattan, peacefully passed away on Sunday, June 22 in East Quogue, NY, three days before her ninety-sixth birthday. Ernestine was born in Brooklyn, NY, on June 25, 1918 to Alexander and Bertha Wolf. She was a caring and loving wife and mother. Ernestine spent many years as an active volunteer with the Park Avenue Synagogue, the Whitney Museum, the New York Philharmonic, and the New York City Ballet. She was an avid fisherwoman, world traveler and a patron of all art forms. Ernestine is preceded in death by her husband, Dr. Arthur Harold Bernstein and brother, Charles I. Wolf. Ernestine is survived by her children, Terry Kimmel (Dr. Martin Kimmel) and Daniel Bernstein (Vivian), grandchildren, Andrew Kimmel (Ioana) and Dr. Bonnie Kimmel (Shari Krell), Peter Bernstein (Jennifer) and Michelle Bernstein, and great-grandchildren, Sophia Kimmel, Sydney and Benjamin Kimmel-Krell and Benjamin Bernstein. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the charity of your choice. Funeral service will be held. on Monday, June 23 at 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

BEDFORD--Ruth Thomas, daughter of Frederick T. and Lucie Thomas Bedford, died peacefully in her sleep on June 15, 2014, in her home in Greens Farms, Connecticut. Miss Bedford would have celebrated her 100th birthday on August 8, 2014. Miss Bedford led a very active and interesting life. She was a woman ahead of her time. Miss Bedford attended Foxcroft School in Virginia and upon graduation worked in social services. She served with the American Red Cross in the European theater during World War II. She had a great interest in the New York theater and worked for Rodgers and Hammerstein as a stage manager on several Broadway shows. Miss Bedford was a licensed sea plane pilot, an accomplished sailor, golfer, tennis player and horse woman. Upon returning to Connecticut Miss Bedford volunteered at the Norwalk Hospital for over fifty years. She made a difference in many people's lives by following her father's and grandfather's example in continuing to support many organizations and charities. The Town of Westport and the Norwalk Hospital as well as many other charities and individuals have been the beneficiary of her generosity. Her great love of animals is well known, particularly dogs and horses. Her race horses, ridden under the Nyala Farm name, won races at Belmont and Saratoga and other eastern tracks. Ruth Bedford will be gratefully remembered for loyalty to her family and friends. She made a difference in many people's lives. She was loved by all who knew her and will be greatly missed. Miss Bedford is survived by her niece, Cythlen Maddox, and nephews, James McCashin, Fred McCashin, Bruce McCashin, Briggs Cunningham, III, her cousin, Helen Watkins and several great nieces and nephews. She is predeceased by her sisters, Lucie Bedford Cunningham Warren, Helen Bedford McCashin, Mary Bedford, her niece, Lucie Cunningham McKinney, and her nephew, John McCashin. At the request of Miss Bedford services will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Aspetuck Land Trust, P.O. Box 444, Westport, CT 06881, Norwalk Hospital Foundation, 34 Maple Street, Norwalk, CT 06856, or the Westport Weston Family Y, 59 Post Road East, Westport, CT 06880. To sign an online guest book, please visit spearmillerfuneralhome.com.

RILEY--Daphne Nowell, born September 29, 1926, died on June 19, 2014, in Santa Fe, NM. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Edgar Alsop Riley, and children, Diana Miriam Johnson and Ian Geoffrey Robin MacLaury. Daphne is survived by two loving daughters, Timothea Sampson and Celia Strebendt, and four grandchildren. Services will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY, on June 25, 2014, at 11:00am.

WINTRINGHAM--Nina, 64, passed away surrounded by loving friends and family on Saturday, June 21st after a year-long battle with breast cancer. She was born in Somerville, New Jersey and made her home on Roosevelt Island in New York City, where she was very active in the community and served as President of the Board of the Main Street Theatre & Dance Alliance. She was an executive in the graphic arts and printing industry, and recently retired from RR Donnelley. She is survived by her husband, John Dougherty, her daughter Rebecca, and a large and loving family including many brothers and sisters. Friends may call on Tuesday, June 24th from 2-5pm or 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to her beloved Main Street Theatre & Dance Alliance, 548 Main Street, NY, NY 10044.
DEMESHULAM--Lorie Fein. 9/27/57-6/21/09. Darling wife, mother and daughter who made so many people's lives so much happier. Your loving family

RAQUET--Andrew Walter. A world renowned Interior Designer and creative inventor, passed away at the age of 45 on June 14th, 2014. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends, colleagues and clients. Andrew Raquet enjoyed a life that incorporated his formidable talent as an interior designer. His commitment to reviving high end luxury design in an unpretentious, refreshing way earned him a stellar reputation amongst clients. His originality and fearless approach to transforming spaces earned him the respect of his peers. He was a favorite on the show house circuit, designing spaces from Paris to Manhattan to the Bahamas. He served on the Kips Bay Designer's Committee. His work was heralded by major publications including: Architectural Digest, House Beautiful, The New York Times, Quest, and Veranda. In addition Raquet founded BAMBOO BAMBOO, the most well-regarded luxury home furnishings and gift shop in the Bahamas, with outposts in Nassau and Harbor Island. He was a member of the Lyford Cay Club. Raquet grew up in Garden City, Long Island, NY. He graduated from Deerfield Academy and Columbia University. He also studied at Parsons School of Design and the Sotheby's School in London. Most recently, he was working with his sister, Merridith, on a showroom in Manhattan to display his extraordinary designs and visionary ideas. He is survived by his father Walter Raquet, mother Kristine Scerbo and his two sisters, Kim Ponce and Merridith Raquet. A memorial service will be held at First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, CT on Thursday, June 26, at 5pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Bruce Museum, 1 Museum Drive, Greenwich, CT, 06830.

MARCUS--Junis Roberts. Peacefully on June 18, 2014. Teacher, art collector and jazz club owner. Survived by husband Burt, son Michael (Diane), daughter, Stacy (Aaron), her "fabulous" grandchildren Hannah, Philip, Jonathan and Avery and sister Samoan. Pug lover and passionate friend to many.

HANSEN--Cornelia Catsouphes, passed on June 8, 2014. In her work life "Cornee" was a teacher, decorator and businesswoman. She loved being a New Yorker and was always a curious learner. In later years, she relished in art classes and joined a summer art community in Barcelona, Spain. She was married to the late George Hansen and worked with him in the lamp business. She is survived by her stepson, Peter Hansen and nephew, Corvis Catsouphes.

LEWIN--Marjorie "Marge", passed away on Saturday, June 21st. She lived more than 89 years. She was an adored and adoring Wife married to Stanley for 66 years and Mother to Bruce Lewin and Jamie Meadow (Mark), a loved and loving Grandmother to Tey, Matt, Sienna and David and Great-Grandmother to Noa and Grant. Graveside services will be held on Monday, June 23rd at Mt. Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY at 1pm.
