WALSH--Kevin J.,64, a Iongtime resident of the Upper West Side, died on June 22. Beloved husband of Molly A. McEneny, devoted father of Catherine Maeve and Brenddan Denis, dearest brother to Patricia and master of Seamus, a loyal dog. Born to Beatrice (County Clare) and Denis (County Limerick) Walsh in New York City on August 6, 1949. Kevin graduated from Fordham University in 1971 and the University of Virginia School of Law in 1974. He began his legal career at Donovan Leisure Newton and Irvine and was later a partner at Kelley Drye & Warren LLP. From 2003 until his death he was a partner at Locke Lord. Kevin loved his family, friends, books and the law. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell on Tuesday from 7-9pm and Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church, 213 West 82nd Street on Thursday at 11am. Contributions in his memory to Inner-City Scholarship Fund or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center would be appreciated.

SAN FILIPPO--Augustus. Gus passed away June 23, 2014. Beloved husband of Trudy Wallace. Devoted father of Kim and John, Allyson and Dino, adored grandpa of Gabrielle and Austin, brother of Richard (Pam) and Mark (Janet). Services Wednesday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

SITOMER--Annette. 84, of Tarrytown, NY, passed away surrounded by her family on June 22, 2014. She is preceded in death by her loving husband of 61 years, Alan Sitomer, who passed away in 2011. She is survived by her children, Todd Sitomer, of Springfield, NJ; Joan Sitomer and Frank DeSanto, of Ypsilanti, MI; and Barbara Sitomer and Kathie Fox of Tarrytown, NY. She also leaves behind seven grandchildren - Matt and Wendy Sitomer, Dan and Rachel Sitomer, Tim and Rachel Sitomer, Pete Sitomer, Aaron DeSanto, Jacob DeSanto, and Kelly and Dan Kasper, as well as one great-grandchild, Benjamin Sitomer. Irrepressible, passionate, and intensely loving, with a memorable sense of humor, Annette was fiercely devoted to her family. After raising three children she built a successful career, eventually retiring as Assistant Vice-President with Scudders, Stevens, and Clark in Manhattan. She will be laid to rest at the non-denominational Trinity Church Cemetery and Mausoleum in Manhattan in a private ceremony for the immediate family. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Jewish War Veterans of the U.S.A., the United Jewish Appeal, or the American Civil Liberties Union. Grandma: Your raucous laughter may be gone from our ears but it will ring forever in our hearts.

BRYANT--Gretchen Johnsen. A beloved member of the community and strong advocate for youth literacy, passed away Sunday at her home in Denver. She was 60. She was the daughter of Niels W. Johnsen and the late Millicent M. Johnsen. She shared her humor, love, compassion, and brilliance with all as a mother, daughter, sister, aunt, grandmother, and friend. A talented writer, editor, and avid reader, her love of books was contagious. She traveled the world from Oslo to Rome. A model to all who knew her of how to walk through life with grace, dignity, and tireless service. She is survived by her daughters: Heather C. Bryant; Stephanie A. and husband Ken Moyers; three grandsons, Harrison, Hayden, and Hewitt Moyers. Also survived by brother, Niels M. and wife Marlene M. Johnsen, and sister Ingrid J. and husband William Barrett, along with numerous other cousins, friends, and loved ones. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, June 24, at 11am at South Broadway Christian Church, 23 Lincoln Street, Denver CO, 80203. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Society of Children's Book Writers and Illustrators Tribute Fund or the charity of your choice.

WINTRINGHAM--Nina, 64, passed away surrounded by loving friends and family on Saturday, June 21st after a year-long battle with breast cancer. She was born in Somerville, New Jersey and made her home on Roosevelt Island in New York City, where she was very active in the community and served as President of the Board of the Main Street Theatre & Dance Alliance. She was an executive in the graphic arts and printing industry, and recently retired from RR Donnelley. She is survived by her husband, John Dougherty, her daughter Rebecca, and a large and loving family including many brothers and sisters. Friends may call on Tuesday, June 24th from 2-5pm or 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to her beloved Main Street Theatre & Dance Alliance, 548 Main Street, NY, NY 10044.
DUCHAN--Irving. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Irving Duchan. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

STEIN--Dr. Abby, With immense sorrow, the Sexual Abuse Service of the William Alanson White Institute notes the untimely death of our colleague, Dr. Abby Stein. Never has a more humane person and a more dazzling intellect been amongst us. Condolences to her family. Julie Marcuse, SAS Director

FELDSHUH--Lillian K. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff of the Cardiovascular Research Foundation mourn the passing of Lillian K. Feldshuh, a courageous pioneer whose persistence and humor will be deeply missed. We send our sincere condolences to her children, Tovah and David, and to the entire Feldshuh family. Martin B. Leon, MD Founder Jack C. Lewin, MD President Eric B. Woldenberg, Esq. Chairman
CADE--Elisabeth, "Lisl," age 88, died on June 21, 2014. Notable book publicist, be- loved mother of Joan and generous friend to many. Private arrangements.
SAN FILIPPO--Augustus. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

LOW--Josiah O. III, 75, died peacefully on June 20, 2014, surrounded by his family and with his German shepherd by his side. Joe was born to Katherine and Josiah O. Low Jr. on June 5, 1939 in Detroit, Michigan. He worked his way through Williams College graduating in 1961. Joe built a career as an investment banker, first at Merrill Lynch and then at Donaldson, Lufkin, & Jenrette where he led the corporate finance group for 15 years. On Wall Street he was known for his unbending integrity and unending interest in others. Colleagues he worked with 40 years ago cite his mentorship as critical to their own success. Many also recall that he kept a saddle in the trunk of his car. After leaving DLJ, he continued to serve on the board of a number of companies, including Centex Development, CoStar Group, and Rosetta Resources. In 2002, he joined Catterton Partners as a Senior Advisor. He advised CEO's of Fortune 500 Companies and later helped friends and local business people expand their businesses or find a path out of trouble. If you came in contact with Joe, you remembered him with a smile. He blew his nose with a trumpet that turned heads, and he sang along to opera and Willie Nelson, whether or not he knew the words. He entertained children with his cowboy yip and songs about cowpies. He disliked mini-golf, "a bastardization of the game", cilantro and the snapping of gum. Joe grew up working as a ranch hand at French Creek, his family's guest ranch in Wyoming's Platte River Valley. His love for the West was infectious. He introduced hundreds of friends and colleagues to Wyoming with visits to the A Bar A, a ranch down the valley from French Creek. Joe was unexpectedly friendly and sincerely interested in everyone he met. Ordering at a restaurant was always time consuming because Joe needed to learn the name and background of the waiter -- some connection could always be found. By the time dessert came, he was often sitting at another table with people he had just met. To his five grandchildren, he was Poppa Joe. The grandfather who hid a radio under your pillow so you could listen to the Giants game at night. The patient teacher who poured a little extra root beer float in your glass to demonstrate the concept of principal and interest. He did not allow whining or weak handshakes. He was irreverent, generous, joyful and loving. He let you ride the ATV despite what your parents said. He paid his six year-old granddaughter to paint his toenails. To his three sons, he was a father who arose every morning at 5:30 to provide his children with opportunities and experiences that he never had. He encouraged his sons to pursue their passions, put together a plan, and then to "get it done." He was an investor in their dreams, their advisor, and friend. Joe loved the outdoors and gave generously to the Williamstown Rural Lands Foundation. He planted hundreds of trees and was often seen mowing the meadows surrounding his home in Williamstown. He had an extensive collection of John Deere tractors. When he ran out of space for more tractors, he gave them away to friends, because "everyone needs a tractor." He shared his passion for western music by setting up concerts in Williamstown. At these events, he would often join his hero Don Edwards on stage for a duet, despite the cringes of his wife and children. He served as a Williams class agent for many years and was selected to lead his class's procession at their 50th reunion. Joe was the lead donor in the purchase and renovation of the Sand Springs Recreation Center, a historic aquatic center that now serves as community gathering place and swim academy in Williamstown. He set up a foundation to fund free swim lessons so that no child would ever be afraid of the water. He loved opera, American antiques, and Western art. His favorite fashion statement was a young woman with a ponytail poking out of the back of a baseball cap. Joe was unbeatable in horseshoes, a devious opponent in gin rummy, and he could still out drive his sons well into his 70's. He gave his wife old pick-up trucks for her birthday. Children he barely knew named stuffed animals after him. He was loved by so many. There is now a giant hole in our hearts that we will all try to fill with the openness and generosity that was Joe Low. Joe is survived by Penny (Ireland) his loving wife of 50 years, three sons Tad (Alisa), Timothy (Loriann), and Jeffrey (Stacey), five grandchildren: Ryan, Julia, Aidan, Nicholas, and Eliza, his sister Katherine, and two brothers David and Charles, and numerous nieces and nephews. There will be a private family memorial service. Gifts in Joe's honor may be made to the Williamstown Rural Lands Foundation Williamstown, MA 01267 or simply through unexpected kindness or interest in another person's life.

KLATZKIN--Estelle, on June 22, 2014. Longtime psychotherapist with ties to VNS, VNAB and the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association. Beloved mother of Karen. She will also be dearly missed by her son-in-law Greg, cousins, nieces, nephews and friends. Service Wednesday, June 25, 2014, 11:15am, at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LEWIN--Marjorie "Marge", passed away on Saturday, June 21st. She lived more than 89 years. She was an adored and adoring Wife married to Stanley for 66 years and Mother to Bruce Lewin and Jamie Meadow (Mark), a loved and loving Grandmother to Tey, Matt, Sienna and David and Great-Grandmother to Noa and Grant.

GOLDEN--Rhoda, 82, died on June 18, 2014. Survived by husband Julius Golden and two sons, Todd and Spencer. Rhoda was Executive Assistant to Congressman Lester Wolff, NYS Attorney General Robert Abrams, and Craig Robins of Dacra. Rhoda is remembered for her energy, compassion, and fun.

FEY--Albert E.,of Briarcliff Manor, NY died on June 13, 2014 after a brief pulmonary illness. He was born in Dearborn, MI on June 6, 1933. Al is survived by his wife, Marguerite Fey; daughter, Nancy Fey Walker (Evan); son, Daniel; stepdaughters Holly Boes (Larry) and Aimee McGuire (John); 2 grandsons and 5 step-grandchildren. Al was predeceased by his first wife, Norma Fey and second wife, Judith Fey. Al graduated from the University of Michigan Engineering School 55. He was a devoted fan of the Wolverines, and a member of Sigma Phi Epsilon fraternity. He graduated from George Washington Law School 58. A senior partner at Fish & Neave LLP (now Ropes & Gray), he was a renowned patent litigator and member of the American College of Trial Lawyers. Al was generous of spirit, a universally loved man. Extremely active throughout his life, he spent countless hours on the golf course and ski slopes surrounded by family and friends. Al will be greatly missed as a patriarch, force of nature and friend to all. In lieu of flowers, please give to the University of Michigan. A memorial service will be held at 3:00 on June 27th at Scarborough Presbyterian Church, 655 Scarborough Rd., Briarcliff Manor, NY.

MILSTEIN--Sylvia, Died peacefully in her sleep on June 23, 2014 in her home in Sunrise, FL. Sylvia would have celebrated her 94th birthday on August 16, 2014. Sylvia devoted her entire professional career to teaching elementary education in Manhattan, having received a masters from Barnard College. She was loved by all who knew her and will be greatly missed. She was married to the late Paul Milstein and is survived by her son Edward and his wife Andrea, her daughter Judith Katz and her sister Thelma. Sylvia is also survived by her grandchildren Jesse and Jen Katz, Scott and Rakhel Milsten and Erika and Jared Shulman. Sylvia also leaves seven great-grandchildren. Graveside services will be private.

SCOBLIC--Joseph M.,passed away at the age of 74 on June 16. Born on March 19, 1940, in Mitchell, South Dakota, to Joseph Peter and Mary Scoblic, Mr. Scoblic was the valedictorian of his high school class in Big Stone City, South Dakota, and graduated cum laude from St. John's University in Collegeville, Minnesota. He then served as a lieutenant in the US Army, stationed in Stuttgart, Germany. After receiving his MBA from the University of Chicago, he joined First National City Bank, which later became Citibank and then Citigroup. After 40 years with the bank, he retired as a managing director in 2004. A longtime resident of New York City, he traveled the world extensively and loved fine art, architecture, and classical music. He was also an expert carpenter and took great pleasure in the outdoors, sharing his appreciation of America's national parks with his children. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Barbara; his sons, Peter and Stephen; and his grandson, Theodore. Services will be held on Friday, June 27, from 2:00-4:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. A second service will be held in Minnesota at St. John's, where Mr. Scoblic will be laid to rest. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in his name to St. John's University in Collegeville or to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

SIBERT--Robert Pearson, 82, of Cold Spring Harbor, died on June 18, 2014. Born in Chicago on November 21, 1931. Mr. Sibert was raised in Los Angeles, CA. He attended Stanford University where he was Captain of the tennis team. He contributed his skills, including a blistering forehand, and love of the game, to many tournaments, teams, and Wimbledon. He married Mary Beryl White, of Midland, Texas, and they lived in Cold Spring Harbor, NY for the past 46 years. Mr. Sibert was beloved for his sense of humor, sharp wit and unending kindness and generosity. After graduating from Stanford, he entered the United States Air Force and was stationed in Spain for two years. First Lieutenant Sibert distinguished himself by meritorious service while serving in the military receiving an Award of Commendation Ribbon in 1957. He then had a long and distinguished career in finance including his years as a Vice-President at Irving Trust Company and The Bank of New York from which he retired in 1989. After retiring from The Bank of New York, he completed an MBA Degree at the University of Essex in England and continued to be active in venture capital projects. He is survived by his wife, Mary, his four children and their families: Michael and his wife, Patricia; Barb Vonnegut and her husband, Mark; Wendy Secor and her husband, David; and Robert. Six beloved grandchildren, one great-grandson, and his sister, Margaret Ann Miller of Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Cold Spring Harbor Library, 95 Harbor Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724 or Stanford Tennis, 641 E. Campus Dr., Stanford, CA 94305-6150. A private gathering of family and friends will be held at a later date. Services entrusted to M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station, NY. maconnellfuneralhome.com

ROWAN--Barbara. We extend our deepest condolences to our board member, Marc Rowan, on the loss of his mother, Barbara. She was loved by her children and their spouses and her adoring grandchildren, and will be greatly missed. The Mount Sinai Children's Center Foundation

O'BRIEN--Lois, So many times I have wanted your guidance and good counsel. We miss you tremendously. Rest in Peace, Beloved. Jack and Jeremiah

WALSH--Kevin J.,64, a Iongtime resident of the Upper West Side, died on June 22. Beloved husband of Molly A. McEneny, devoted father of Catherine Maeve and Brendan Denis, dearest brother to Patricia and master of Seamus, a loyal dog. Born to Beatrice (County Clare) and Denis (County Limerick) Walsh in New York City on August 6, 1949. Kevin graduated from Fordham University in 1971 and the University of Virginia School of Law in 1974. He began his legal career at Donovan Leisure Newton and Irvine and was later a partner at Kelley Drye & Warren LLP. From 2003 until his death he was a partner at Locke Lord. Kevin loved his family, friends, books and the law. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell on Tuesday from 7-9pm and Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church, 213 West 82nd Street on Thursday at 11am. Contributions in his memory to Inner-City Scholarship Fund or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center would be appreciated.

TYRRELL--Louis, of Manhattan, passed away June 18. He left a bereaved wife, Leah, daughter Mona, son Elliott, stepdaughter Debby and her husband Richard Levine. Graduated from University of Maryland, received master's degree from MIT. Served in WWII as a p51 pilot. Life's work was in television as a producer director of Candid Camera and the CBS Sports Spectacular. He will be sorely missed by family and countless friends.

TANGER--Alexander, The community of the Alexander M. and Brenda R. Tanger Hillel at Brooklyn College notes with sadness the passing of Alexander Tanger. Mr. Tanger was a generous individual, giving his time, money and energy. His support of our Hillel, in particular the naming gift for our building, has meant so much to thousands of Jewish students. We extend our condolences to Brenda and the entire Tanger family.

FEDER--Abigail Jones, died June 22. Abigail Lispenard Jones was born July 16, 1962 in Huntington, NY to Patricia Bleecker and Edward Sprague Jones. She is survived by her husband of 26 years Andrew M. Feder, their two children, Andries and Catalina, her sister, Susanna A. Jones, and her brother, Thomas Jones. She was a Managing Director of the Private Bank at J.P. Morgan, joining in 2000 as a vice president in the United States Fixed Income Group. A graduate of Phillips Academy class of 1980 and the Vassar College class of 1985, she began her career at Morgan Stanley, where she worked for fifteen years as an analyst in Investment Banking and ultimately a principal and head of enhanced cash management. At Christ Church in Oyster Bay, NY, she taught Sunday school, was chair of the Investment Committee, a member of the Vestry, and served as Senior Warden from 2011-2013. She also served on the Investment Committee for the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island. She was member of the Board of Trustees of the Havens Relief Fund Society of New York City and the Morgan Memorial Park in Glen Cove, NY. A 1977 graduate of East Woods School in Oyster Bay, she served as a Trustee from 2003 to 2008 and continued to serve on the Investment Advisory Committee. A long-time and valued volunteer for Vassar, she co-chaired annual giving for her class. She served as a Parent Fund volunteer and a class agent for Phillips Academy, Andover. A memorial service will be held at 1:30pm on Friday, June 27 at Christ Church in Oyster Bay, NY. In lieu of casseroles or flowers, donations may be made to the Havens Relief Fund Society.

DARROW--Dr. Stanley, It is with great sadness that we learned of Dr. Stanley Darrow's passing on Sunday, June 22nd. Stanley was loved by his patients, his staff and his colleagues. A professional man and a true renaissance man, he inspired people around him with a quiet confidence that made everyone feel comforted. Whether it was playing the banjo, teaching young dentists, or giving his all to his patients, his passion for life came through with his warm smile and his kind heart. Stanley was going to stay only a year in our practice at 923 Fifth Ave, but became our senior member of the team, with the grandparent-type wisdom that is so attractive to aspiring young people in our practice. Stanley is a blessed memory, and we will never forget the man that made us smile, and made us feel so good about our chosen profession to improve people's health and their smiles. He was truly 'the profession's professional' and his will be a life to remember, admire, emulate, and serve as a touchstone for 'humble humility'. His dedicated service is a bright light for all to follow. We at 923 5th, Dr. Jonathan Levine, Dr. Jeffrey McClendon, Dr. Kellen Mori, Dr. Salvatore Trentalancia and team, Enis, Christina, Elizabeth, Kristen, Georgia, Paula, Jen V, Jen R, Yerissa, Gina, Aleksandra, Cecilia, Jessica, Maria and Yvonne admired him as a professional, loved him as a friend, and will miss him like no other. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sherman Library, P.O. Box 40, Sherman, CT 06784, or to the Sherman Jewish Community Center, 9 Route 39 South, Sherman, CT 06784.

DARROW--Stanley, a New York City dentist and dental professor, died on June 22, 2014 at the age of 87. A native of the Bronx, Dr. Darrow graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School in 1944 after which he enlisted in the US Army. After serving in the Philippines, he attended college at the NYU College of Arts and Pure Science, receiving his BA degree in 1948, and the NYU College of Dentistry, from which he was awarded his DDS degree in 1953. Dr. Darrow subsequently entered the private practice of dentistry, and continued to treat patients until shortly before his death. Dr. Darrow was renowned as a compassionate and dedicated practitioner to celebrities and high profile business executives. In addition, he had a passion for teaching dental students and residents. He maintained an appointment at the NYU College of Dentistry from 1953-1976, attaining the rank of Associate Professor in the Department of Operative Dentistry, and afterward served as attending dentist in the Flushing Hospital Dental Residency Program. A member of the New York State and County Dental Societies, Dr. Darrow was a regular lecturer at the annual meeting of the First District Dental Society. His honors and awards include membership in the Omicron Kappa Upsilon Dental Honor Society and Sigma Xi Scientific Research Society, and fellowships in the American College of Dentists and the Academy of General Dentistry. Dr. Darrow maintained residences on Sutton Place in Manhattan and in Sherman, CT. He enjoyed traveling and collecting antiques with his wife, Vivienne, listening to Dixieland jazz and swing music, and playing banjo and guitar. He is survived by his sons Jonathan, David, and Andrew; grandchildren Evan, Julia, Emily, Nicole, Joshua, and Gwendolyn; and sister Phyllis. A reception celebrating Dr. Darrow's life will be held at the family residence in Manhattan on July 12 and 13 from 11am to 6pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sherman Library, P.O. Box 40, Sherman, CT 06784, or to the Sherman Jewish Community Center, 9 Route 39 South, Sherman, CT 06784.

PEI--Eileen Loo, died peacefully at home in New York City on June 20. Born on September 21, 1920, in Tientsin, China, she was the daughter of Ping Yok and Alice Chang Loo. Her father was an early Chinese graduate of MIT, earning his engineering degree in 1916. Her maternal grandfather was Yin Tang Chang, Ambassador from China to Washington beginning in 1909. Her granduncle was T'ang Shao-Yi, first Prime Minister of the Republic of China (1911-1912). Eileen Loo came to the United States in 1938 to attend Wellesley College, where she studied Art, was a Senior Wellesley College Scholar, and received her degree in 1942. Immediately after graduation, she married Ieoh Ming Pei, a young architect recently graduated from MIT's School of Architecture. He followed her to Harvard and its Graduate School of Design, where she studied Landscape Architecture and where he received his Master's Degree in Architecture in 1946. During the war years, her husband worked with the National Defense Research Committee in Princeton, NJ. Their first son, T'ing Chung, was born there in 1944. After the war, they returned to Harvard where, upon earning his degree, Mr. Pei joined the faculty. Their second son, Chien Chung (Didi), was born in 1946. Eileen and I.M. Pei moved to New York in 1948 when Mr. Pei was recruited to work for the real estate developer William Zeckendorf. A third son, Li Chung (Sandi), was born in 1949 and Eileen Pei embarked on her career of raising three boys and supporting her husband. In 1960, a daughter, Liane, was born, to the elation of the parents. Her husband's career flourished. In 1952, she sailed across the Atlantic Ocean with him to Europe on traveling fellowships he had earned while at Harvard. This was the first of many trips they would take together and with the family where everyone would benefit from her impeccable organization and preparation. Always forward thinking, she was an ardent supporter of Planned Parenthood, Channel 13 and WNYC, and an active and longtime member of the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Together with her husband, Eileen Loo Pei befriended many of the most influential artists and dealers of the time, particularly those that were concentrating in New York in the 1950's and 1960's. They were frequent participants in the broad cultural life of both New York and beyond, and intimate gatherings at the Pei home were welcomed events, memorable for their animated conversation, fine wine and her delicious cuisine. Possessed of a keen eye, unfailing taste and an abiding passion for the arts and culture, she was a constant and indispensable support to her husband and family, providing wise counsel, warmth, good humor, and practical, loving advice on all matters. She was known by all for her effortless style, elegance and grace. Eileen Loo Pei is predeceased by her eldest son, two brothers, Harry and Man Kit, and one sister, Louise. She is survived by her husband of 72 years, two sons, her daughter, two daughters-in-law, seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests with great appreciation that donations be made to Planned Parenthood, Channel 13 or WNYC.

DOUGHERTY--Genevieve, age 78, died Wednesday afternoon, June 18 at the Beverly Hospital in Beverly, MA. Born in Great Neck, NY she was the daughter of the late Hugh Dougherty and Elizabeth (Tomney) Dougherty. Miss. Dougherty worked in the airline industry for Pan Am. She leaves a sister Mary Jane Hansen of Salem, MA. She was predeceased by a sister Elizabeth Dougherty.

ROSEN--Gwen, died peacefully in her home in Whippany, NJ with her family at her bedside on June 23, 2014. A long time resident of Brooklyn, NY, she would have been 90 on September 17, 2014. She is survived by her son Harvey and his wife Lainie, by her daughter Abby Rosen Finkel and her husband Rabbi Mark Finkel and by her daughter-in-law, Lisa Rosen. She is also survived by her five grandchildren, David and Sari Rosen and Liora, Doron and Eliana Finkel. She was predeceased by her husband David, who passed away in 1981 and her son, Marc in 2005. She will always be remembered for her kindness, sweet disposition and the care and concern she showed for all those who knew and loved her. She will be dearly missed and her memory always cherished. Service 10:30am today at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

CARDOZO--Barbara. We mourn the death of our cherished and long-time member, Barbara Cardozo, and express our deepest sympathies to her family. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

PUGLISI--Alfred A.,Passed away on June 23, 2014, at 91. Born in the Little Italy section of lower Manhattan of Sicilian immigrants in 1922, loved Italy, Italian food, wine and song. WWII vet, landed with the US army infantry on Utah Beach shortly after D-Day in September 1944, earned Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Alumnus of Fordham (BS-1943) and NYU (MBA-1951). After serving as controller of Welcome Wagon Inc., and the Olivetti Corporation, co-founded Pustorino, Puglisi and Co, PC, CPAs, of which he was the managing partner from 1961-88. Named Knight of Malta (1982) and Cavalier del Lavoro by the Italian Government (1987). Dedicated to professional and philanthropic causes, serving on many committees of the New York State Society of CPAs, and was Director of the Italian American Chamber of Commerce and the Queens Chamber of Commerce. Held officer positions at the New York Athletic Club, Lions Club of Ravenswood, Cardinal's Committee for the Laity, Columbus Citizens Foundation, Variety Boys Club of Queens, the American Italian Foundation for Cancer Research and Fordham University. Survived by his devoted wife of 67 years, Denise, of Paris, France whom he met in post-war Germany, and children, Claudine Puglisi Cagwin (Thomas Cagwin), Michael (Valerie), and Catherine Puglisi (William Barcham), loving sisters, Diana Lamanno and Nina Murphy, many nieces and nephews, grandchildren, Alex and Michelle Cagwin, Suzanne Puglisi and Jeanne Puglisi Grzywacz, Raphael and Arianna Barcham, and great-grandchildren, Clint and Carson Grzywacz. A celebration of life will take place at Thomas M. Quinn and Sons, Inc, 35-20 Broadway at 35th Street, Long Island City, NY 11106, from 2-5pm and 7-9pm on Thursday, June 26th. Funeral Mass to be held at 10:30am on Friday, June 27, at St. Joan of Arc, 82-00 35th Ave at 82nd Street, Jackson Heights, NY 11372. In lieu of flowers, the family recommends donations be made: www.woundedwarriorproject.org in memory of "Alfred A. Puglisi, a WWII, Normandy-wounded warrior of the 328th Infantry Regiment of the 26th Infantry Division."
BRAHAM--Elizabeth, 82, on June 24, 2014. Beloved wife of Randolph L. Braham. Devoted mother, grandmother, best friend. Barnard class of 1953.

CARDOZO--Barbara Schaffer, 92, of Westport Connecticut, and New York City, died peacefully at her home in Westport on June 20th, five short months after the passing of her best friend: her husband of 72 years, Benjamin Mordecai Cardozo. MULLER--Lucienne, Born June 21, 1924 in Strasbourg, France. Died June 23. Narrowly escaped capture by the Nazis. Served with valor in the Maquis (the French Underground) during World War II. BRAUN--Harold S.,of Boynton Beach, FL, passed away on June 13, 2014, at the age of 91. Beloved husband of 56 years to Sonia Stan Braun; loving father of David Stan Braun (Ricki), New York City, and Paul Braun (Alexandra) of Fairfield, CT, and grandfather of Sara. Born in New York City, he grew up in Upper Manhattan. He served in North Africa and Italy in the Army Air Corps during WWII. He graduated from New York Law School and practiced law in New York City with his father, and then on his own, until his retirement. After a brief time in North Carolina, he retired to Florida where he enjoyed an active life. Harold was loved by family and friends and will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

KATES--Michael, 53, passed away June 24th. Tall dark and handsome. Beloved son of Judith. Loving Brother of Faith (Jeffrey) Kogan. Best Uncle to Dylan, Kyle and Fallon. Friend to so many. Services today 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (corner 91st Street) NY, NY. Donations can be made to ERASEMS.org

HELLER--James Albert, 65, of New York City and Westerly, RI died early Monday morning at his Rhode Island home. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother, he will be remembered for his modesty, kindness, generosity and steadfast devotion to friends and family. At the time of his death, he was a director of the Moore Company in Westerly, where he had previously served as an executive for more than two decades. He was also a board member and chairman of the audit committee of Premium Power Corporation, an alternative energy company based in Reading, MA, and the owner of Greenville Plate Services of Greenville, TN, a manufacturer of laser engraving plates. He had also served as treasurer and long-time board member of Doing Art Together, Inc., an educational organization that provides art instruction to children in New York City schools. Born and raised in Manhattan, he was the son of the late William B. and Anne C. Heller. He attended St. Bernard's School, Middlesex School and Colorado College, where he distinguished himself as editor of the student newspaper. From 1971 to 1984, he worked on the editorial staff of The Reporter Dispatch in White Plains, NY, where he earned an Associated Press award for reporting and later, as news editor, a second AP award for his page one make-up of the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II in May, 1981. It was during his newspaper stint that he met Pamela Markham, his future wife, who was a reporter at the time. They were married in 1975. In addition to his wife, Jim is survived by a sister, Susan Klee Heller, of New York, a son, William Benjamin Heller, II, and his wife Rebecca of Brooklyn, NY; a daughter, Susan Taylor and her husband Graham G. Taylor of Cambridge, MA, and grandchildren Madeleine Elizabeth Heller and James Gustavus Taylor. The family will receive visitors at his home on 2 Bayberry Road, Westerly on Thursday, June 26 from 4 to 7pm. A celebration and blessing of his life will take place at the Watch Hill Chapel, 5 Bluff Avenue, Westerly on Friday, June 27 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be sent to the Westerly Land Trust or to Doing Art Together, Inc. Gaffney-Dolan Funeral Home, 59 Spruce St., Westerly is in charge of arrangements. For online condolences, please visit www.gaffneydolanfuneralhome.com

MULLER--Lucienne, Born June 21, 1924 in Strasbourg, France. Died June 23. Narrowly escaped capture by the Nazis. Served with valor in the Maquis (the French Underground) during World War II. Came to the United Stated in 1947, and established a successful career as a custom couturier to legions of famous clients. Widow of Samuel Muller. Devoted sister of the late Henri Weintraub (Joan) and Sylvan Weintraub (Bessie). Beloved Aunt of Robin and David Berger. Services at 11:00am on June 26 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91st Street).

WALLACH--Eli. In 1992, Eli received the Lifetime Achievement Award for Performing Arts from the Guild Hall Academy of the Arts. He will be sorely missed. Ruth Appelhof, Executive Dir.; Roy Furman, President of the Academy; Martin Cohen, Chair

GALVIN--Mary Harriss, 91, died peacefully in the home she adored, surrounded by people she loved including her pal, Rodeo. She was predeceased by her husband of 52 years, Jack, her brother Robert and her sister Judith. She graduated from Convent of the Scared Heart, Maplehurst and Manhattenville College. Her memories live on in her children Abbeline Wyman, John F. Galvin IV, Maria Galvin and Robert Harriss Galvin as well as in her grandchildren Nickolas Wyman, Victoria Wyman, Andrew Wyman and Maise ""Star" Moises. She loved politics, a conspiratist she always had a theory. She loved poetry and was a poet herself for family, friends and special events. She was a friend to many who will miss her kind pure heart, her unconventional point of view and her commitment to her faith. She loved the sun, the beach, and the water and continued to love the sun until her very last days "Never goodbye, Au Revoir." Visitation will be held on Sunday from 7-9pm at the O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Rd in Southampton, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday at 10:30am at the Basilica Parish of the Sacred Hearts in Southampton, NY. Burial will be private.

FRISCHER--Leonard, of Boca Raton, FL on June 24, 2014. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Together, they shared a lifetime of love, joy and devotion to each other. Adored father of Peggy, Steve, Paul, and Julie. Cherished grandfather of Erin, Eric, Jack and Kate. He was a true gentleman - a kind and loyal friend and a loving mentor to all throughout his life. His generosity knew no bounds and his integrity stood above all. He will live in our hearts forever and always.

GWATHMEY--Anne Jones, born in 1921 in Pittsburgh, PA. A graduate from Miss. Porter's School. She lived for 65 years in Old Brookville, Long Island in a house that was always open for children, friends and friends of children. She was married to two WWII veterans, William P McGrail Jr. and Gaines Gwathmey Jr. She was the beloved mother of Daisy (Phillip Keevil), Lelia (Frank Harrington), Anne, Billy and Tommy McGrail. Cherished Grandmother of Adrian, Augusta, Peter, Anne, Charlotte, Jenny, Ford, Marina and Isabelle. Spirited Great-Grandmother of Walker, Leelee, Leila, Eleanor and Polly. Anne loved her house and her garden, and avidly needle pointed for family and friends all her life. She was sharp, playful, and a great listener. One could always find her at 6pm with vodka in hand dressed for dinner. She enjoyed lunch and dinner with friends and especially with her family. She saw the world in the age of steamer trunks, SS France and the Queen Mary and never lost her travel enthusiasm. For her the party was never over. We will miss her with all of our hearts. There will be a reception at the family house on Thursday from 6-8pm. Funeral at St. John's of Lattingtown, Friday 11am. Interment at Homewood Cemetery, Pittsburgh PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of LI, 100 Garden City Plaza, Garden City, NY 11530.

USDAN--Martin J. "Marty", died peacefully on Saturday June 21, 2014 at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. Martin lived a life of distinction and elegance. He was a true New Yorker born at Lenox Hill Hospital, he grew up in Lawrence, LI and lived on the upper East Side of Manhattan for many years with his beloved wife Jane Bergre, their two daughters Jennifer and Jill. Martin served as a Lt. in the ARMY Corps of Engineers and fought in WWII where he and his company, liberated Anzio, Italy. Martin was a leader in the Paper Converting Industry serving as President of the Paper Club of NYC, President of The NYC Junior Chamber of Commerce and many other professional roles. Martin loved opera and musical theater. He had a gift for music and was known for his deep bass voice. He performed for 40 years with the University Glee Club of New York City. Martin was an avid golfer and a member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club and Muirfield Village Golf Club. He was a past President and current Board Member of his co-op on East 71st Street. Martin was a genuinely humane person of strong character and gentle spirit and will be sorely missed by his many friends and admirers. Martin is survived by Jane, their two daughters Jennifer and Jill, his daughter Mary and son Ralph from a previous marriage, three grandchildren, his brother Nathaniel, sons-in-law Christopher McBride and Harry DeVore and many other family members. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Martin's memory to the University Glee Club of NYC or The Metropolitan Opera Club. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

FEDER--Abigail Jones, died June 22. Abigail Lispenard Jones was born July 16, 1962 in Huntington, NY to Patricia Bleecker and Edward Sprague Jones. She is survived by her husband of 26 years Andrew M. Feder, their two children, Andries and Catalina, her sister, Susanna A. Jones, and her brother, Thomas Jones. She was a Managing Director of the Private Bank at J.P. Morgan, joining in 2000 as a vice president in the United States Fixed Income Group. A graduate of Phillips Academy class of 1980 and the Vassar College class of 1985, she began her career at Morgan Stanley, where she worked for fifteen years as an analyst in Investment Banking and ultimately a principal and head of enhanced cash management. At Christ Church in Oyster Bay, NY, she taught Sunday school, was chair of the Investment Committee, a member of the Vestry, and served as Senior Warden from 2011-2013. She also served on the Investment Committee for the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island. She was member of the Board of Trustees of the Havens Relief Fund Society of New York City and the Morgan Memorial Park in Glen Cove, NY. A 1977 graduate of East Woods School in Oyster Bay, she served as a Trustee from 2003 to 2008 and continued to serve on the Investment Advisory Committee. A long-time and valued volunteer for Vassar, she co-chaired annual giving for her class. She served as a Parent Fund volunteer and a class agent for Phillips Academy, Andover. A memorial service will be held at 1:30pm on Friday, June 27 at Christ Church in Oyster Bay, NY. In lieu of casseroles or flowers, donations may be made to the Havens Relief Fund Society.

PUGLISI--Alfred A.,Passed away on June 23, 2014, at 91. Born in the Little Italy section of lower Manhattan of Sicilian immigrants in 1922, loved Italy, Italian food, wine and song. WWII vet, landed with the US army infantry on Utah Beach shortly after D-Day in September 1944, earned Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Alumnus of Fordham (BS-1943) and NYU (MBA-1951). After serving as controller of Welcome Wagon Inc., and the Olivetti Corporation, co-founded Pustorino, Puglisi and Co, PC, CPAs, of which he was the managing partner from 1961-88. Named Knight of Malta (1982) and Cavalier del Lavoro by the Italian Government (1987). Dedicated to professional and philanthropic causes, serving on many committees of the New York State Society of CPAs, and was Director of the Italian American Chamber of Commerce and the Queens Chamber of Commerce. Held officer positions at the New York Athletic Club, Lions Club of Ravenswood, Cardinal's Committee for the Laity, Columbus Citizens Foundation, Variety Boys Club of Queens, the American Italian Foundation for Cancer Research and Fordham University. Survived by his devoted wife of 67 years, Denise, of Paris, France whom he met in post-war Germany, and children, Claudine Puglisi Cagwin (Thomas Cagwin), Michael (Valerie), and Catherine Puglisi (William Barcham), loving sisters, Diana Lamanno and Nina Murphy, many nieces and nephews, grandchildren, Alex and Michelle Cagwin, Suzanne Puglisi and Jeanne Puglisi Grzywacz, Raphael and Arianna Barcham, and great-grandchildren, Clint and Carson Grzywacz. A celebration of life will take place at Thomas M. Quinn and Sons, Inc, 35-20 Broadway at 35th Street, Long Island City, NY 11106, from 2-5pm and 7-9pm on Thursday, June 26th. Funeral Mass to be held at 10:30am on Friday, June 27, at St. Joan of Arc, 82-00 35th Ave at 82nd Street, Jackson Heights, NY 11372. In lieu of flowers, the family recommends donations be made: www.woundedwarriorproject.org in memory of "Alfred A. Puglisi, a WWII, Normandy-wounded warrior of the 328th Infantry Regiment of the 26th Infantry Division."

PLOTKIN--Jason, passed away June 25, 2014 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center at the age of 46, after an 18 month battle with cancer. He is survived by his parents Leonard and Sheila Plotkin, his sisters Abby, Donna and Bonnie, as well as his brothers-in-law, nieces and nephew. For 15 years Jason worked as a senior research assistant at MSKCC, where he was a major contributor to many breakthroughs in cancer research. He was also a lover of the arts and enjoyed his time singing with the New York Grand Opera Company.

PEI--Eileen Loo, died peacefully at home in New York City on June 20. Born on September 21, 1920, in Tientsin, China, she was the daughter of Ping Yok and Alice Chang Loo. Her father was an early Chinese graduate of MIT, earning his engineering degree in 1916. Her maternal grandfather was Yin Tang Chang, Ambassador from China to Washington beginning in 1909. Her granduncle was T'ang Shao-Yi, first Prime Minister of the Republic of China (1911-1912). Eileen Loo came to the United States in 1938 to attend Wellesley College, where she studied Art, was a Senior Wellesley College Scholar, and received her degree in 1942. Immediately after graduation, she married Ieoh Ming Pei, a young architect recently graduated from MIT's School of Architecture. He followed her to Harvard and its Graduate School of Design, where she studied Landscape Architecture and where he received his Master's Degree in Architecture in 1946. During the war years, her husband worked with the National Defense Research Committee in Princeton, NJ. Their first son, T'ing Chung, was born there in 1944. After the war, they returned to Harvard where, upon earning his degree, Mr. Pei joined the faculty. Their second son, Chien Chung (Didi), was born in 1946. Eileen and I.M. Pei moved to New York in 1948 when Mr. Pei was recruited to work for the real estate developer William Zeckendorf. A third son, Li Chung (Sandi), was born in 1949 and Eileen Pei embarked on her career of raising three boys and supporting her husband. In 1960, a daughter, Liane, was born, to the elation of the parents. Her husband's career flourished. In 1952, she sailed across the Atlantic Ocean with him to Europe on traveling fellowships he had earned while at Harvard. This was the first of many trips they would take together and with the family where everyone would benefit from her impeccable organization and preparation. Always forward thinking, she was an ardent supporter of Planned Parenthood, Channel 13 and WNYC, and an active and longtime member of the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Together with her husband, Eileen Loo Pei befriended many of the most influential artists and dealers of the time, particularly those that were concentrating in New York in the 1950's and 1960's. They were frequent participants in the broad cultural life of both New York and beyond, and intimate gatherings at the Pei home were welcomed events, memorable for their animated conversation, fine wine and her delicious cuisine. Possessed of a keen eye, unfailing taste and an abiding passion for the arts and culture, she was a constant and indispensable support to her husband and family, providing wise counsel, warmth, good humor, and practical, loving advice on all matters. She was known by all for her effortless style, elegance and grace. Eileen Loo Pei is predeceased by her eldest son, two brothers, Harry and Man Kit, and one sister, Louise. She is survived by her husband of 72 years, two sons, her daughter, two daughters-in-law, seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests with great appreciation that donations be made to Planned Parenthood, Channel 13 or WNYC.

ROCKEFELLER--Dr. Richard. The David Rockefeller Family deeply mourns the sudden death of Dr. Richard Gilder Rockefeller on June 13, 2014. He was a cherished husband, father, son, brother, uncle, and grandfather who played a pivotal role in our extended family. We have been profoundly touched by the outpouring of love, admiration and support from people all over the world whose lives Richard also touched. Richard was passionate about everything he did as a physician, as an activist and as a philanthropist. He was at home in art, in music and in nature. He was intensely curious about how things work, from the physical world to the human psyche. His formal education came from the North Country School, the Choate School, Harvard College and the Harvard Medical School. But his informal learning never stopped, nor did his drive to make the world a better place. He founded, led or served many non-profit organizations (including those listed below) and gave generously to them in time and treasure. In addition, he served as president of the Rockefeller Family Fund and chairman of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. Richard's immediate family consists of his wife Nancy King Rockefeller; his son Clayton and daughter Rebecca; his grandchildren Ozzy and Elsa and Wilder; Nancy's sons Max and Griffin; his father David Rockefeller; Richards' siblings and spouses, David and Susan, Abby and Lee, Neva and Bruce, Peggy and Barry, Eileen and Paul; and numerous nieces and nephews and cousins whom he adored. We all miss him so much. The Family plans a private service of remembrance this summer, and there will be a memorial service in the fall, time and place to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Sargasso Sea Alliance (http://www.sargassoalliance.org/); Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (the PTSD project) (http://www.maps.org/); Doctors without Borders (http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/); Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative (http://www.dndi.org/); Maine Coast Heritage Trust (http://www.mcht.org/)

SIMARD--Claude,originally of Larouche, Quebec, passed away suddenly at age 57 on Tuesday, June 24. A resident of New York City since the 80's, he attended the Whitney Independent Study Program from 1983-84. Claude was the proud co-founder of Jack Shainman Gallery and a figure in the international art community. He started the gallery with his close friend Jack Shainman more than 30 years ago to enrich the lives of artists and those around them. Known for his kind words and innumerable acts of generosity, his quiet demeanor was only matched by his exuberance and expert eye. He nurtured the careers of numerous artists and touched the lives of countless individuals who credit him with their appreciation and love for art. An artist in his own right, his works and performances have been presented in the United States, Canada, Europe and Australia. He is survived by his mother, Marguerite, his sisters Guylaine, Gervaise and Nathalie, his brother Guy, and his beloved nieces and nephews Erika, Jean-Francois, Larry-Christopher, Pierre-Olivier, Anne-Julie, Anne-Catherine, Marie-Laurence, Amanda, Marc-Anthony, Alexandra, and Etienne. He will be deeply missed and may his name soon be spoken without effort.

TUCKER--Teddy. Teddy Tucker, MBE, Undersea Pioneer: May 8, 1925 June 9, 2014. The many members of his exploring and environmentalist families salute this quietly innovative, groundbreaking adventurer. In his distinctive way, Teddy went steadily about the business of opening the oceans and their many mysteries to scientific and popular knowledge. And he always had fun, probing, teaching, seeking. His many achievements earned him the Order of the British Empire from Queen Elizabeth II; he discovered over a hundred Bermuda shipwrecks; in 1955 he recovered the gold and emerald Tucker Cross from the San Pedro; he pioneered marine archeological work with the Smithsonian's Mendel Peterson and helped him perfect the grid system for surveying and conserving shipwrecks; he worked with Professor Genie Clark from the University of Maryland on six-gill sharks; and had a multi-year collaboration with Emory Kristof of National Geographic on the Beebe science project. He always said he learned a lot about the ocean the hard way, direct from the depths. Teddy used his quick-study mind on tens of thousands of hours beneath the ocean and an equal amount of time with books on nautical history and marine biology. His intimate understanding of the world's largest, oldest, and least known ecosystem and his willingness to share what he learned attracted some of the best and brightest undersea and space pioneers. Among the scientists, photographers, and astronauts who spent time with him in Bermuda: Dr. Greg Stone, Dr. Steve Katona, Dr. Clyde Roper, Steve Blasco, David Doubilet, Pete Conrad, Deke Slayton, and Kathy Sullivan. A huge part of the joy for those who shared a boat ride (or a plunge) with Teddy was partaking of the benefits of his incomparable story-telling ability. A master raconteur, he would finish a story with bell-like laughter that lit up the face of everyone within earshot. He had served in the Royal Navy in the Second World War and returned to Bermuda to start a career in marine salvage. His interest in both the practical and scientific aspects of salvage shifted to a passion for marine science. He believed that "the best education is self-taught: all you need is a head and heart hungry for information." And, most crucially, a sense of humour. His longtime friend, the author Peter Benchley, used him as an inspiration for Quint in "Jaws" and made him the central character in "The Deep." He described Teddy as "a walking encyclopedia and one of the great autodidacts in the history of science--a self taught expert on ships, coins, nautical history, underwater archeology, painting, glassware and armament." Teddy had more time beneath the sea than any explorer including Jacques Cousteau, often diving in no more than a pair of shorts and some sneakers. He was a creature of the ocean. For more than eight decades, Mother Ocean was Teddy's muse and mentor. He devoted his life to teasing out her secrets and passing them along to his friends. He believed that "we do two things in life: learn and contribute." Teddy loved Mother Ocean and she loved him back. Now they are one. Thank you shipmate, from all of us fortunate enough to share the ocean planet with you, for those good times above and below the sea. And bless you Edna and Wendy for sharing the most important man in your life.
FREUND--Lucas Samuel. The cloud , the stillness that must part The darling of my life from me Always, Mommy & Charlotte

LITTLE--Charles Eugene, born March 1, 1931, to John R. and Elizabeth (Taylor) Little, died June 20, 2014, in Albuquerque, NM. He is survived by his wife of 43 years Ila (Dawson); three beloved children of his first wife, Katharine (Smith) Dorothy (Pariot), Charles T., and Katharine (Tepe); two stepsons, Lorenzo and Andrew Traldi; grandchildren Julia (Griffenkranz) and David J. Pariot; Aidan Tepe; Arthur, Matthew, Oliver, and Rebecca Traldi; Meagan, Melanie, Drew, Maria, and Julia Traldi; and great-grandson Benjamin Griffenkranz; as well as many friends and colleagues. After attending Fountain Valley prep school in Colorado, Charles graduated from Wesleyan University in 1955 with Distinction in Creative Writing. He served in the US Army in Alaska during the Korean conflict. He was an advertising executive at Foote, Cone, and Belding until 1963, when he became chief executive officer of The Open Space Institute and published its Open Space Action Magazine with the objective of preserving areas of natural beauty in the New York metropolitan region. His entire life's work then became to devote his considerable talent and passion to the appreciation and protection of American landscapes, whether they are agricultural or urban natural areas; public parks or privately held areas of unique natural beauty. In 1972 he joined the Conservation Foundation in Washington DC, then became head of the Natural Resources Division of The Congressional Research Service, which he left in 1978 to establish the American Land Resource Association and edit its publication, American Land Forum. Charles moved to Placitas, NM in 1994, continuing to involve himself in land use issues and to write about them. He founded Voices from the American Land, a quarterly publication of poetry celebrating outstanding landscapes of North America. He is the author of many acclaimed books, among them Discover America (Smithsonian); Greenways for America (Johns Hopkins); Hope for the Land (Rutgers); An Appalachian Tragedy (Sierra Club); and The Dying of the Trees (Viking), a finalist for the LA Times's nonfiction award in 1997. Memorial services will be held at Las Placitas Presbyterian Church on Saturday, July 12th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Charles's memory to the LPPC Columbarium Fund or to Voices from the American Land.

GOLDSMITH--Clifford H. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of Clifford H. Goldsmith, an outstanding philanthropist and dedicated member of the Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees since 1980. Throughout his time on the Boards, Clifford served on the Executive, Community and Government Affairs, Finance, Public Affairs and Marketing, Compensation and Employee Benefits, and Employee Relations committees. From 1997- 2008, he chaired the Real Estate and Facilities Committee. He also led the oversight committee for the Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for Multiple Sclerosis, which he co-founded at Mount Sinai in 2000 in memory of his daughter. Clifford cared very deeply about eradicating multiple sclerosis, and was a passionate and generous supporter of such research at Mount Sinai for many years. During his more than 30 years of unflagging commitment to our institution, Clifford also lent considerable wisdom and support to key institutional initiatives, including the Campaign to Rebuild Mount Sinai and the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit Renovation, as well as to a range of other clinical and research programs. Mount Sinai has been so fortunate to benefit from his leadership and guidance for so many years. He will be dearly remembered, and dearly missed, by all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Katherine, and to his daughters, Alexandra Fallon and Audrey Kubie, and to the entire Goldsmith family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., CEO and President; Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System

MALONIS--John Adam, 50, M.D.,of Fort Worth, TX, passed away Saturday, June 21, 2014, after a fatal car accident. He and his beloved wife, Jamie, were on their way to pick up their daughter, Kate, at summer camp. Funeral: 9:30am Friday at St. Andrew Catholic Church. Interment: Greenwood Memorial Park. Visitation: Noon to 8pm Thursday at Greenwood. Rosary: 6pm Thursday in Greenwood Chapel. Memorials: In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to any of the following: John's son Jack's fundraising efforts with the Texas 4000 for Cancer charity, so he can bike from Austin to Anchorage, Alaska, in honor of his father, http://www.texas4000. org/ rider/2015/unassigned/jack-malonis/, the American Cancer Society in John and Jamie's name or the Dr. John Malonis Scholarship Fund at Harrison High School, Harrison Central School District, Attn: Treasury Department, 50 Union Ave., Harrison, NY. John was born June 19, 1964, in White Plains, NY, to Edward and Mary Malonis. He graduated from Harrison High School in Harrison, NY, in 1982, and Dartmouth College in 1986. He went on to graduate from The University of Texas Southwestern Medical School in 1990. After medical school he did his residency at John Peter Smith Hospital in Fort Worth where he was named the chief orthopedic surgery resident. Following his residency he completed a fellowship in spinal surgery at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City, Utah. He was loved by patients and staff alike at all of the hospitals with which he was affiliated. He was known as an exceptional surgeon but more importantly as a caring and compassionate doctor. John loved spending time with his family, skiing and automobile restoration. Survivors: Loving wife, Jamie Wright Malonis; three devoted children, Jack (21), Charlie (19), and Kate (9); parents, Edward and Mary Malonis; sister, Tracy Stephen; and four nieces and nephews. Greenwood Chapel Greenwood Funerals-Cremation, 3100 White Settlement Rd., 817-336-0584 View and sign guestbook at www.star-telegram.com/obituaries

GOLDSMITH--Clifford H.,died peacefully at home on June 25, 2014 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Katherine; daughters Audrey Kubie and Alexandra Fallon; grandchildren Philip Samuel Dickinson; Camille Kubie, Kimberly Harrison, Gregory Kubie; Conrad, Oliver, and Daisy Fallon; and four great-grandchildren. A man of great personal strength, integrity, and courage, Clifford dedicated his life and career to the pursuit of excellence in all his endeavors. His family and friends greatly valued his loyalty, optimism and keen sense of humor. As a devoted parent and philanthropist, he co-founded The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for Multiple Sclerosis in New York, part of The Mount Sinai Health System, named for his daughter who died of the disease. Clifford worked tirelessly for MS-related causes, and served as chairman of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Born September 6, 1919 in Leipzig, Germany, he graduated from Bradford University, Yorkshire, England, with a degree in textile engineering, and later emigrated to the United States in 1940. He served in the United States Army during World War II, and was held as a prisoner of war in Germany. In 1945 he joined the Benson & Hedges Company, ultimately becoming President of Philip Morris Incorporated from 1978 until 1984. Clifford was a long-time trustee of the Mount Sinai Health System, and on the board of directors of FOJP Service Corporation. He was Chairman Emeritus of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, as well as FOJP Service Corporation; and was a Vice Chairman of Polytechnic University, now NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for MS at Mount Sinai Health Systems. Services will be held on Monday, June 30, at 11am at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th St., New York City.

HELLER--James Albert, 65, of New York City and Westerly, RI died early Monday morning at his Rhode Island home. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother, he will be remembered for his modesty, kindness, generosity and steadfast devotion to friends and family. At the time of his death, he was a director of the Moore Company in Westerly, where he had previously served as an executive for more than two decades. He was also a board member and chairman of the audit committee of Premium Power Corporation, an alternative energy company based in Reading, MA, and the owner of Greenville Plate Services of Greenville, TN, a manufacturer of laser engraving plates. He had also served as treasurer and long-time board member of Doing Art Together, Inc., an educational organization that provides art instruction to children in New York City schools. Born and raised in Manhattan, he was the son of the late William B. and Anne C. Heller. He attended St. Bernard's School, Middlesex School and Colorado College, where he distinguished himself as editor of the student newspaper. From 1971 to 1984, he worked on the editorial staff of The Reporter Dispatch in White Plains, NY, where he earned an Associated Press award for reporting and later, as news editor, a second AP award for his page one make-up of the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II in May, 1981. It was during his newspaper stint that he met Pamela Markham, his future wife, who was a reporter at the time. They were married in 1975. In addition to his wife, Jim is survived by a sister, Susan Klee Heller, of New York, a son, William Benjamin Heller, II, and his wife Rebecca of Brooklyn, NY; a daughter, Susan Taylor and her husband Graham G. Taylor of Cambridge, MA, and grandchildren Madeleine Elizabeth Heller and James Gustavus Taylor. The family will receive visitors at his home on 2 Bayberry Road, Westerly on Thursday, June 26 from 4 to 7pm. A celebration and blessing of his life will take place at the Watch Hill Chapel, 5 Bluff Avenue, Westerly on Friday, June 27 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be sent to the Westerly Land Trust or to Doing Art Together, Inc. Gaffney-Dolan Funeral Home, 59 Spruce St., Westerly is in charge of arrangements. For online condolences, please visit www.gaffneydolanfuneralhome.com
