SULLIVAN--Joan Rigney, age 83, of Cold Spring Harbor, New York, passed away peacefully June 26, 2014, after a sudden illness. She and her husband Robert J. Sullivan were one week away from their 60th wedding anniversary. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her daughter Kathleen and sons Robert and James Sullivan, her niece Margaret Schmitt, and her grandchildren Kira, Daniel and Sean Sullivan. Beautifully elegant, athletically gifted, and possessed of an avid intellectual curiosity, she had a life force that her family experienced as nothing short of amazing, and that made all of her children and grandchildren who they are. Born in Queens, New York on January 21, 1931, she attended Our Lady of Wisdom High School and obtained a B.A. in 1953 from Queens College, where she marched in 2013 with her 60th reunion class. In the 1950s, she taught elementary school in New York City public schools and to Ojibway schoolchildren in Sault Ste Marie, Michigan, where her husband Bob was stationed in the Air Force and her daughter Kathleen was born. Upon her return to New York, she devoted herself to her family and extended family, took up tennis in her forties and golf in her fifties (winning numerous prizes in golf tournaments at the Huntington Country Club), and swam regularly into her eighties. No one could have a better wife, mother and grandmother, and all of her family are deeply grateful for the gift of her magnificent life. Donations in her honor may be made to the Cold Spring Harbor Library, 95 Harbor Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

GORDON--Kenny, on your 42nd Birthday. Not a day goes by for us without memories bringing smiles to our faces or tears to our eyes. You are missed every minute of every day. Our aching hearts are always filled with love for you. Mom, Dad, Jonny, Catherine, Kenya & Chloe

USDAN-Martin J. The fellow tenants of 3 East 71st Street are saddened by the passing of our long time neighbor and friend Martin J. Usdan. Martin was our longest standing resident, member of the Board and Chairman for many years. He brought a lot of experience and wisdom to the building and we will all miss his guidance. Our heartfelt wishes of condolence go out to his wife, Jane Bergre, their two daughters Jennifer and Jill, his daughter Mary and son Ralph and his three grandchildren.

STROBEN--Donald R. Born December 30, 1930 in Evanston, IL, died May 26, 2014 in La Jolla, CA. Chairman, CEO - Hayden, Stone Inc. 1960 - 1970, CBWL Hayden, Stone Inc., 1970-1973; Partner - Fleisher, Stroben and Co., 1973-1976; Founder, President - Acapulco Y Los Arcos restaurants, 1976-1980; Principal - Princeton, Montrose Partners 1980-1998; Chairman - Laura Scudder's Inc., 1980-1989. Survived by Martha (Thrasher) Stroben, four children, and six grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made online at www.knoxalumni.org/strobenmem.

SHOSTAK--Mitchell. Mitch, we will always cherish your gifts of love, wisdom and creativity. You have enriched all of our lives. Our love and enduring friendship go out to our beloved Carolyn. With love, Natan, Jessica, Tommy, Megan and David

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. Lincoln Center Theater is heartbroken over the death of Mary Rodgers Guettel. She was a beloved figure here. We were delighted to see her whenever she came around, and she came around a lot especially if we were producing her favorite musicals! If Mary believed in you, there was nobody more generous and loyal. The staff, the crews, the ushers indeed all who work at Lincoln Center Theater will miss this warm, funny, feisty, caring, savvy and deeply talented friend. Our sympathy to her large and devoted family. J. Tomilson Hill Chairman, Board of Directors Andre Bishop Producing Artistic Director

JACOBS--Lord Anthony, The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of it's esteemed member, Lord Anthony Jacobs, and extends sincere sympathy to his wife, children, grandchildren and other members of his family. William L. Mack, President; Warren Spector, Secretary

ROWAN--Barbara J. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul. Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the passing of Barbara Rowan, mother of our beloved friend Marc Rowan. We express our deepest sympathies to Marc and to all other members of the Rowan family.

GREEN--Charles "Chuck," passed away peacefully on June 22, 2014 at his home in Rochester, NY. He was 92 years old. A loving man who valued his family above all. Chuck served in the Army/Air Corp in WWII and then built Jack Green Men's Shop, which brought fashion to Rochester. He was the last surviving founding member of Temple Emanu-El of Rochester, NY. He was also a member of Temple B'rith Kodesh, Irondequoit and Midvale Country Clubs, Jay Lodge-Knights of Pythias and was a Master Mason in the Mason Fraternity. An incredible skier, avid golfer and tennis player. He is survived by his loving wife of 71 years, Ruth Blackman Green; children, Shelly Stoler and Michael Insalaco; and Debi and Evan Mittman; grandchildren Michael Stoler, Peter and Rachel Massa, Robert and Jennifer Massa and Tricia Mittman; great-grandchildren, Brendan and Hunter. We will all miss him and cherish all the times we had together. Funeral Services were held in Rochester, NY. Shiva will be at the home of Debi and Evan Mittman, on Sunday, June 29th 2014 from 2-8pm. Donations may be made to Foundation Fighting Blindness. BrightonMemorialChapel.com

RUDEL--Julius. Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts mourns the loss of Julius Rudel, Music Director of the Caramoor Festival from 1964 to 1976. Under Maestro Rudel's direction, Caramoor presented local premieres of Orff's Die Kluge and Britten's Curlew River, and, in 1968, Monteverdi's L'Incoronazione di Poppea. Caramoor's commitment to opera can be attributed to Maestro Rudel's enduring legacy. James A. Attwood, Jr., Chairman; Jeffrey P. Haydon, CEO; Will Crutchfield, Director of Opera

GOLDSMITH--Clifford H.,died peacefully at home on June 25, 2014 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Katherine; daughters Audrey Kubie and Alexandra Fallon; grandchildren Philip Samuel Dickinson; Camille Kubie, Kimberly Harrison, Gregory Kubie; Conrad, Oliver, and Daisy Fallon; and four great-grandchildren. A man of great personal strength, integrity, and courage, Clifford dedicated his life and career to the pursuit of excellence in all his endeavors. His family and friends greatly valued his loyalty, optimism and keen sense of humor. As a devoted parent and philanthropist, he co-founded The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for Multiple Sclerosis in New York, part of The Mount Sinai Health System, named for his daughter who died of the disease. Clifford worked tirelessly for MS-related causes, and served as chairman of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Born September 6, 1919 in Leipzig, Germany, he graduated from Bradford University, Yorkshire, England, with a degree in textile engineering, and later emigrated to the United States in 1940. He served in the United States Army during World War II, and was held as a prisoner of war in Germany. In 1945 he joined the Benson & Hedges Company, ultimately becoming President of Philip Morris Incorporated from 1978 until 1984. Clifford was a long-time trustee of the Mount Sinai Health System, and on the board of directors of FOJP Service Corporation. He was Chairman Emeritus of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, as well as FOJP Service Corporation; and was a Vice Chairman of Polytechnic University, now NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for MS at Mount Sinai Health Systems. Services will be held on Monday, June 30, at 11am at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th St., New York City.

RUDEL--Julius Maestro Rudel, 93, passed away on Thursday, June 26, 2014 at his home in Manhattan. His achievements, and contributions to the cultural life of New York City and the world, will be celebrated publicly at a later date. Maestro Rudel is preceded in death by his wife, Dr. Rita Gillis Rudel. He is survived by his brother, Ludwig, his children, Joan, Madeleine and Anthony, 7 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. At the request of the family, services will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Rita G. Rudel Foundation, c/o Rudel, 100 Landsdowne Street, Apt 1009, Cambridge, MA 02139, or the Mannes College Julius Rudel Conductors Fund, 150 West 85th Street, New York, NY 10024.

CARDOZO--Barbara Schaffer, 92, of Westport Connecticut, and New York City, died peacefully at her home in Westport on June 20th, five short months after the passing of her best friend: her husband of 72 years, Benjamin Mordecai Cardozo. For the past 45 years she has been a renowned real estate broker in Manhattan, an Executive Vice President of Douglas Elliman Real Estate. Barbara is survived by her daughters, Enid Cardozo (Ed Lamon), Ellen Sonsino (Isaac Sonsino), five grandchildren and one great grandchild. Interment was private. A memorial and celebration of her life will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street on Sunday, June 29th at 1pm. Memorial contributions may be made to Temple Emanu-El's Philanthropic Fund in her name.

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. The entire Juilliard community wishes to express our profound sadness on the passing of Mary Rodgers Guettel. A woman of extraordinary intellect, creativity, generosity, and supreme wit, we were all blessed to know her and to have her as chair of the school's board from 1994 to 2001, and a board member since 1992. Her legacy of artistic integrity, joy, exceptional support, and belief in Juilliard's young artists has made our school a more humane and better place. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mary's wonderful family. We will remember her always. Members of The Juilliard School Board of Trustees Bruce Kovner, Chairman Kenneth S. Davidson, Trustee Joseph W. Polisi, President

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers, dear friend, guide, guru, mentor, boss-extraordinaire. Music in her genes, music in her laugh, music in her smile; we are all diminished by her absence, but her generous heart, kind soul and warm presence will be with us forever. Our most profound condolences and much love to Tod, Nina, Kim, Adam, Alec and all the beloved grandchildren. Nicole, Paul, Grace, and Jake Harman

FERMAN--Eda, died peacefully at home on June 26, 2014 at 90 years. Beloved mother of Gaby and Gary. Loving grandmother of Allison, Brian, Jonathan, Michael, and Oliver. Great-grandmother of Jack and Liam. Devoted wife of the late Symon Ferman. She will always remain in our hearts. Donations may be made in Eda's memory to the American Friends of Magen David Adom (AFMDA) 352 Seventh Ave Ste 400 New York, NY 10001. The family will be receiving guests Sunday morning from 11:00 to 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Cryptside service 12:45pm at Mount Lebanon Cemetery (Glendale, NY).

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. Grateful for many, many years of Chapin/Guettel family friendship. Even more grateful for my career. Mary was generous in unique ways. Truly one of a kind. We will miss her. Ted, JoAnna, Anika and Zoe Chapin

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers, we mourn the loss of Mary Rodgers Guettel. She was an irreplaceable friend and colleague, and we will forever miss her vitality, her warmth, her wisdom and all the qualities that made her such a remarkable person. We send our love and sympathy to her children and grandchildren. Mary Ellin Barrett Linda Emmet Elizabeth Peters

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers, we mourn the passing of Mary Rodgers Guettel- a generous soul, a talented composer and author, as committed to the musical legacy of her father Richard Rodgers as she was to the cultivation of new writers and new work. We send our love and condolences to her family. Ted Chapin and everyone at Rodgers & Hammerstein

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. The Board of Directors, along with the entire Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival community, sadly mourns the loss of our dear friend Mary. Her generosity, many talents, sense of humor, irreverence, and optimism were contagious and inspirational. Mary was one of a kind and we will miss her. We send our heartfelt sympathy to her wonderful family and her many friends who loved her as we did. Ken Davidson, Chairman Marya Martin, Artistic Director Michael Lawrence, Executive Director

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts are profoundly saddened by the passing of Mary Rodgers Guettel, Chairman Emeritus of The Juilliard School, Director Emerita of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, and a guardian of her father's composer Richard Rodgers legacy. Guettel was also an accomplished composer, known for the 1959 hit musical, Once Upon a Mattress, as well as a writer of juvenile fiction. A passionate and much-honored advocate for the arts, Guettel was tireless in nurturing young artists as well as the arts in general. Her husband, Henry Guettel, former executive director of the Theater Development Fund (TDF), pre-deceased her in 2013. Guettel's passing is not only a great loss to Lincoln Center, but also to the city of New York. We offer our sincerest condolences to her children, her sister Linda Rodgers Emory, and her many friends. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. Thank you Mary for enhancing my life and giving it purpose the last several years. With love to your family and beloved grandchildren. Alice Hammerstein

CREAGHAN--George. Dearest Daddy, We see you in the sun, the moon and the stars. You are always in our thoughts, our prayers and our hearts. But, oh, how we wish you were here. Georgina, Dennis and Patricia.

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers, died June 26, 2014 at home after a long illness. Her children Tod Beaty, Nina Beaty, Kim Beaty, Adam Guettel, and Alec Guettel ask that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Juilliard School or, in the spirit of their mother's generosity, to the charity of your choice. No services are planned, but a celebration of her life will be held in the future.

WEISS--Geraldine "Geri". Beloved mother, sister, aunt, daughter, friend passed away peacefully after a long illness June 26. Geri had a successful Wall Street career. Her joy was as a mother. Survived by daughter Laura-Brooke, sister Pamela Weiss-Berger (Leonard) brother Martin Weiss (Nancy) nephew Zachary, cousin June devoted friend Tatiana. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, 4-8pm. Funeral Monday 10am. Burial at Westchester Hills Cemetery.

BUCHMAN--Arlette, age 96, died peacefully at home on June 26, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Alexander J. Buchman; loving mother of Jacqueline Botwinick and Diane Buchman; cherished grandmother of Andrew and Eric Botwinick. An artist and author who inspired many. Service Sunday, June 29, at 2pm at Temple Israel, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochelle, NY. Donation may be made in her name to The American Macular Degeneration Foundation.

FEDER--Abigail Jones. We are bereft. Abigail, our beloved daughter, sister, and aunt, was a rare jewel. We miss her terribly. May her memory be a blessing. With all our love, Arthur and Ruth Feder, Gwen Feder, Garrick and Leslie Feder Leonard, Johanna and Aviva Kohn, Bliss, Isaiah, and Calypso Leonard.
DRAKE--Rodman, The Board, staff and students of Casita Maria mourn the passing of Rodman Drake, beloved husband of Jackie and loyal supporter of our work.

COLLURA--John J. Long-time resident of Rockland County, NY, John J. Collura died on June 26, 2014 at Good Samaritan Hospital of unexpected complications related to Cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY February 19, 1947 to John and Carmella Collura, he is survived by his wife Mary Rose Collura, son John Collura, daughter Lori Collura, son-in-law Christophe Verhaegen, and seven grandchildren Riley, Kyle, Cassandra, Emma, Tyler, Ella, and John Lucas. John was a dedicated family man and an accomplished businessman. He began his career with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey when he was 23 years old. After 25 years working his way up the ranks he left as Director of Finance and COO. He held several CFO positions with major health care companies and ultimately traded his final position as CFO of Continuum Health Partners in NY, NY for retirement with his family at the age of 67. He was a member of Government Finance of America and President of the National Association of Accountants. He also held the esteemed titles of "Coach", "Dad" and "Pop" in many of life's other important activities. John's kindness and generosity were an inspiration to all who knew him. He lived his life with integrity, optimism, and an invigorating laugh. Services will be held for John on Sunday, June 29, at the Wanamaker and Carlough Funeral home in Suffern, NY from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass is Monday, June 30 at 11am in Sacred Heart Church Suffern, NY. wanamakercarlough.com

BUCHMAN--Arlette. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Arlette Buchman and extend sincere condolences to her family. James Dreyfus, President

CARDOZO--Barbara. It is with such a heavy heart that we say goodbye to our dear friend, Barbara. Barbara lost her beloved husband, Ben, a few months ago after 75 years together. Her heart was broken. And now ours too. Barbara was an Icon in Manhattan real estate and broke all records over the years. She believed our profession was worthwhile and just as meaningful as other high-level professions. She sought to always uphold a very high level of integrity in herself as well as others. Her love for Douglas Elliman was non-ending and to that we owe our gratitude to her. Our profession has lost a valuable colleague and we, a valuable friend. We will miss her. Dottie Herman, President & CEO, Douglas Elliman and all of my Douglas Elliman colleagues and friends.

BANCROFT--Ellen Coffin, "The Witch of Pitt Street," 86, died at home June 24, 2014, in Alexandria, Virginia. She is survived by daughters Elizabeth and Mary-McLean, grandsons C. Royce and Caleb Sims. Ellen was the wife of the late Frederic W. Bancroft and daughter of the late Amos Coffin and Mabel Jennie Frey. She liked shoes, dogs and Italy. Memorial Service: Friday, July 11, 10:30am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 228 S. Pitt St, Alexandria, VA.

RUDEL--Julius. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Julius Rudel, the esteemed artist who conducted more than 200 performances at the Met. Renowned for his many years of outstanding leadership of the New York City Opera, he made his debut with the Met in 1978 conducting Massenet's Werther, and conducted a wide range of repertoire at the Met over a period of 25 years. He conducted the Met premiere of Handel's Samson in 1986 and a new production of Andrea Chenier in 1990. He was greatly admired by colleagues, audiences, and critics alike throughout his distinguished career. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

RUDEL--Julius. The Board of Governors of Mannes College The New School for Music and the Board of Trustees of The New School mourn the loss and celebrate the life of our dear friend and alumnus Maestro Julius Rudel. Attending Mannes on a scholarship funded by David and Clara Mannes, Maestro Rudel met his wife, Rita, while they were fellow students. He served as member of the Mannes board continuously since 1983 and ultimately made the world a better place through music. We send our deepest sympathy to his children, Anthony, Joan, and Madeleine, and his 14 grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Linda Rappaport, Chair of the Mannes Board of Governors, David Van Zandt, President of The New School, and Richard Kessler, Dean of Mannes College.

SALZBERG--Shirley (Lee), of Westborough, MA, formerly of Hewlett, New York, passed away peacefully on June 18, 2014 at the age of 90. Lee will be dearly missed by her children, Pam (Larry) Tabb, Malcolm (Lisa) Roth, Allan (Cheryll) Salzberg and Marc (Dale) Salzberg and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her two beloved husbands, Morton Roth and Emanuel Salzberg. WEISS--Geraldine "Geri". Beloved mother, sister, aunt, daughter, friend passed away peacefully after a long illness June 26. Geri had a successful Wall Street career. Her joy was as a mother. Survived by daughter Laura-Brooke, sister Pamela Weiss-Berger (Leonard) brother Martin Weiss (Nancy) nephew Zachary, cousin June devoted friend Tatiana. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, 4-8pm. Funeral Monday 10am. Burial at Westchester Hills Cemetery.

STILLMAN-LERCHER--Carol. In memory of Carol Stillman- Lercher. December 26, 1928- June 29, 2013. Daughter of Leo Stillman and Frances Brown- Stillman. Loving mother to Andrea Lercher-Chomko. Loving grandmother to Elizabeth and Sarah Chomko and Daniel Lercher. Predeceased by her son Frederick Alan Lercher and husband Edward Lercher. You brought so much love and joy to us all. You are greatly missed.

WALLACH--Eli, The Neighborhood Playhouse mourns the death of our esteemed graduate and board member Eli Wallach: a tireless champion of our school and constant inspiration to our students. His talent and spirit will be missed. Our condolences to Anne and the family. Board of Directors, The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre

FURLAUD--Maxime Jay. My darling Max, today is your birthday; you would have been 89. You died when you were only 73. I've missed you so terribly, all day, every day. You were an award-winning screenwriter and a playwright. For about 3 years you were chairman of the Playwrights' Unit of Actors Studio. Your one-act plays Biscuit and Fitz, starring Sam Waterston and Sally Kirkland, were performed at the Circle in the Square theater. The great directors Jean Renoir and Francois Truffaut both wanted to direct your original film script L'AMOUR AU CONNECTICUT. As a Gestalt therapist in France you gave people back their lives. Now you are with your friends the Angels; you met them during your "enlightenment experience" in 1968. All my love always, Ally

WOLFE--David Emery, January 3, 1933 (Seattle, WA) - June 3, 2014 (Durham, NC). He was preceded in death in 2012 by his wife Virginia "Gia" (Segal) Wolfe. He is survived by his two children Alexander Emery Wolfe and Gillian Fraser Wolfe-Ware; and two grandchildren, Ian Xavier Ware and Imani Mairae Ware. See full obituary at www.cremationsocietync.com.

WISE--Harry H.,succumbed to lung cancer on June 12, in Stamford, CT, after two years of valiant battle against multiple illnesses. Born in Boston on October 1, 1938, to Robert and Ethel Pastan Wise, he attended Lawrence Elementary School, Brookline High School, and graduated with honors from Harvard. In his early adulthood he was a captain in the US Air Force, earned an MBA at Harvard Business School, and began a long, varied, and distinguished career in business and finance. He worked for McKinsey and Company, Citibank, American Capital Partners, several of his own companies, and various others. His commitment to education was salient throughout his life, in many philanthropic activities and his own unceasing learning. In later life he earned a masters degree from Columbia University in Organizational Psychology and Leadership. Music was central to his life, from undergraduate singing with the Harvard Gilbert and Sullivan Players, to his acclaim as a jazz pianist and certified jazz educator, his patronage of the musical arts and active engagement in many musical ensembles such as the Canterbury Choral Society and Uptown Sound. An avid sports fan and player, passionate follower of the Boston Red Sox, he also established a library endowment at Harvard to build a collection in Judaica, supported a pro-bono summer camp for the elderly, and led the establishment of the Wise-Marcus Scholarship Fund in the Syracuse University Honors Program. In countless ways large and small, visible and invisible he lived a life of constant generosity toward others. He was beloved for his swift and sparkling humor and his intense loyalty to his many friends. Wise lived in Manhattan until a recent move to Stamford, with frequent summers spent at his beach home in Sagaponack on Long Island. He is survived by his loving wife and musical partner Sheila Johnson Wise, his stepdaughter Alisa MacNeille Kuhn and stepson Eben MacNeille, his sisters Sara Kane and Cheryl Skura, his nieces and nephews Gwen Kane-Wanger, Jonathan Kane, Sam Skura, Stacey Zedeck, Rachel Burris, their families, his beloved cousins, and a very large number of devoted friends, old and new, who mourn his untimely passing. A celebration of his life will be held in Stamford on September 28.

SHOSTAK--Mitchell. One of the country's leading publication designers, died June 25 at his home in Manhattan. He was 63. The cause was Melanoma. After an illustrious career at The New York Times and Business Week, Mitch founded Shostak Studios in 1993. His firm designed for major corporations, universities, and non-profits. A graduate of and instructor at the School of Visual Arts, Mitch mentored many talented designers over his long career. He served on the board of the Society of Publication Designers and judged national design competitions. His passions outside the studio included his family, many friends, travel, fly fishing, cycling, books, jazz, single malt scotch, a great steak, and The New York Yankees. Mitch was born on August 12, 1950, in New York. He is survived by his wife, Carolyn Iu, his brother, Ed, sister, Mindy and stepbrother, Gary Birnbaum. Contributions may be made to the Visual Arts Foundation for the Mitch Shostak Scholarship Fund, 220 East 23rd St., Suite 609, New York, NY 10010. A memorial service will be held at SVA at a future date.

SULLIVAN--Joan Rigney, age 83, of Cold Spring Harbor, New York, passed away peacefully June 26, 2014, after a sudden illness. She and her husband Robert J. Sullivan were one week away from their 60th wedding anniversary. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her daughter Kathleen and sons Robert and James Sullivan, her niece Margaret Schmitt, and her grandchildren Kira, Daniel and Sean Sullivan. Beautifully elegant, athletically gifted, and possessed of an avid intellectual curiosity, she had a life force that her family experienced as nothing short of amazing, and that made all of her children and grandchildren who they are. Born in Queens, New York on January 21, 1931, she attended Our Lady of Wisdom High School and obtained a B.A. in 1953 from Queens College, where she marched in 2013 with her 60th reunion class. In the 1950s, she taught elementary school in New York City public schools and to Ojibway schoolchildren in Sault Ste Marie, Michigan, where her husband Bob was stationed in the Air Force and her daughter Kathleen was born. Upon her return to New York, she devoted herself to her family and extended family, took up tennis in her forties and golf in her fifties (winning numerous prizes in golf tournaments at the Huntington Country Club), and swam regularly into her eighties. No one could have a better wife, mother and grandmother, and all of her family are deeply grateful for the gift of her magnificent life. Donations in her honor may be made to the Cold Spring Harbor Library, 95 Harbor Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

SEAVEY--Robert W. Robert "Bob" W. Seavey, a pioneer in the development of affordable housing, died peacefully of natural causes in New York City on June 24, 2014. For 61 years, Bob was an adoring husband to the late Phyllis Mehler Seavey, who passed away last year. He is survived by his devoted children Avery Seavey and Dr. Emily Senay and Nealle and Eric Seltzer, and loving grandchildren Veronica Jean, Bryn, Harry, Lucy and Ruby, sisters-in-law Maxine Chevlowe and Harriet Seavey, devoted nieces and nephews, cousin Edward Levine as well as other cousins, numerous friends and admirers. Born on October 14, 1927, Bob was the oldest child of Ben and Essie Seavey, and brother to the late Gilbert Seavey. A life-long New Yorker, Bob graduated from City College in 1949 and Brooklyn Law School in 1952, where he was editor-in-chief of the Brooklyn Law Review and first in his graduating class. After meeting in law school, Bob and Phyllis began a wonderful life-long journey together. They were married in New York in December 1952 and soon moved to Okinawa, Japan, where Bob served as a Captain in the Judge Advocate General's Office in the US Air Force during the Korean War. Following the birth of their son in 1956, they returned to New York, where Bob had an illustrious career as a lawyer, real estate developer and public servant for over fifty years. As a developer, Bob built thousands of low-income, affordable and conventional rental, cooperative and condominium units throughout New York City, including the first rehabilitation development under the Mitchell-Lama law; the first affordable housing cooperative in Harlem; the landmark Harlem apartment complex, Esplanade Gardens; and what was at the time the tallest residential building in Queens. He was most proud to share his knowledge of real estate law and business, volunteering for many years as an Adjunct Professor at Brooklyn Law School. Bob also had a distinguished career in the public sector, serving as Chairman of Battery Park City during its early construction phase, Chairman of the Real Estate Advisory Committee for New York State's Common Retirement Fund, Chairman of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, one of the City's most prestigious organizations dedicated to housing issues, and as a member of the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York, the agency created out of the City's 1970s debt crisis. He was an early leader in the rejuvenation of Harlem and credited the start of his career to being Counsel to J. Raymond Jones, Tammany Hall's first African American leader. From that time forward Bob continued to be a respected advisor to numerous local policy makers, helping shape New York through times of social and economic change. Bob's professional accomplishments were matched only by his strong devotion to his family and friends. He inspired all who knew him with his loyalty. He was admired for his pure intelligence and his abiding interest in the world around him, including all of the people with whom he crossed paths. He was blessed with a great sense of humor and found true joy in good conversation, listening intently to the experiences of others and delighting in sharing the tales of his life. A big man with boundless energy, it was nothing for Bob to work until midnight and then pick up his family to travel hours for weekend getaways. Generous of heart and spirit, Bob always welcomed family and friends and was ready to help any of them in times of need. Above all, he was a kind person and a mentor to many, openly sharing his insight and experience. He will be deeply missed.

STROBEN--Donald R. Born December 30, 1930 in Evanston, IL, died May 26, 2014 in La Jolla, CA. Chairman, CEO - Hayden, Stone Inc. 1960 - 1970, CBWL Hayden, Stone Inc., 1970-1973; Partner - Fleisher, Stroben and Co., 1973-1976; Founder, President - Acapulco Y Los Arcos restaurants, 1976-1980; Principal - Princeton, Montrose Partners 1980-1998; Chairman - Laura Scudder's Inc., 1980-1989. Survived by Martha (Thrasher) Stroben, four children, and six grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made online at www.knoxalumni.org/strobenmem.

ARON--Roberto. Husband, father, step-father, grandfather, great-grandfather, passed away on June 24, 2014 at the age of 98. Born on November 1, 1915, he was raised in Argentina and moved to Chile where he attended University. Upon receiving his LL.B. degree from the University of Chile's Faculty of Law, he embarked on a seven decade career as an international lawyer, diplomat, law professor and the author of law textbooks and other scholarly works. While raising a family in Chile, he made Aliyah to Israel in 1957. After joining that country's bar, he entered a private law practice and endeavored to raise money for Israel's fledgling economy thru the sale of government bonds in Latin America and other Spanish-speaking countries. He made countless speaking tours as Israel's goodwill ambassador and his success was rewarded in 1974 with a position as a legal adviser with Israel's mission to the United Nations under the leadership of Ambassador Chiam Herzog. His love of learning led him to earn three Master of Law degrees at New York University in International Legal Studies in Corporate and Commercial Law and in Jewish Talmudic Law. For 14 years, Mr. Aron served as the chair of Trial Advocacy at the Law School of Tel Aviv University. He also was a guest teacher at New York University's School of Law. He co-authored four legal textbooks still used today by law school curriculums nationwide. Prolific to nearly the end of his life, he published his last scholarly book at the age of 97. With his first wife Caty, he fathered three children Jaime (Maria), Sylvia (Rafi) and Daniel (Nati), all of whom live in Israel today with their children and grandchildren. He is survived by his wife Eva, whom he married in 1969 and with whom he enjoyed a 45 year whirlwind love affair. He leaves his adoring step-daughters Aileen (Eric) and Sonia (Robert) and their children. He is also survived by his brother Luis and various nieces and nephews. Mr. Aron will be buried in Israel.

RUDEL--Julius Maestro Rudel, 93, passed away on Thursday, June 26, 2014 at his home in Manhattan. His achievements, and contributions to the cultural life of New York City and the world, will be celebrated publicly at a later date. Maestro Rudel is preceded in death by his wife, Dr. Rita Gillis Rudel. He is survived by his brother, Ludwig, his children, Joan, Madeleine and Anthony, 7 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. At the request of the family, services will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Rita G. Rudel Foundation, c/o Rudel, 100 Landsdowne Street, Apt 1009, Cambridge, MA 02139, or the Mannes College Julius Rudel Conductors Fund, 150 West 85th Street, New York, NY 10024.

SPRAGUE--Charles Wallace,died peacefully at home on June 22, surrounded by his family and friends, after a year-long battle with esophageal cancer. He was 64 and resided in Mequon, Wisconsin. Mr. Sprague grew up in Short Hills, NJ. He graduated from Pingry School (1967) and Yale College (1971, cum laude), where he majored in American History and was News Editor of the Yale Daily News and a varsity letter winner (squash). After a year of service in the New Jersey National Guard, he entered the joint JD-MBA program at New York University. He was Notes Editor of the NYU Law Review, and graduated in 1975 from the Law School with distinction (Order of the Coif), and from the Business School with distinction. After NYU, he joined Sullivan & Cromwell as a corporate associate in the firm's New York and Washington offices. He became a member of Reboul, MacMurray, Hewitt, Maynard & Kristol in 1983. In 1994, after a year in private practice, Charles relocated to Milwaukee to join Fiserv, Inc., Brookfield, Wisconsin, where he served as Vice PresidentGeneral Counsel and later Executive Vice President until his retirement in February 2014. He immersed himself personally and professionally in Milwaukee community affairs, becoming a member of the Milwaukee Public Library Foundation board, a trustee of University School of Milwaukee, and a member of the General Counsel Forum of Milwaukee. A lifelong reader, Charles was especially fluent in all things Churchillian and Shakespearean. He loved a good debate on almost any subject, and adversaries were advised to proceed at their own peril. His keen mind, cheerful disposition, sound judgment and unshakable integrity earned him the affection and admiration of his professional colleagues and his many devoted friends. Above all, Charles was a loving and beloved family member: husband, father, brother, son. He ended his days exhibiting the same courage, grace and humility with which he conducted his life. He is survived by his wife, Mary Hamilton Sprague of Mequon; his daughter, Martha Hamilton Sprague of Washington, DC; and his brother, John Arthur Sprague of New York City; and his daughter's fiance, Timothy Heitman. A memorial service will be held at a future date. The family has requested that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Milwaukee Public Library Foundation (www.mpl.org/support) or University School of Milwaukee (www.usmk12.org/ supportUSM).

SULLIVAN--Ambassador William H. 1922- 2013. Memorial Service 4pm. July 13, 2014 at River Road Unitarian Universalist, 6301 River Road, Bethesda, MD. Interment 11am. July 14, 2014 at Arlington National Cemetery. Donations may be made to The Fletcher Fund, 160 Packard Avenue, Medford, MA 02155.

ALTMAN--Hon. Benjamin, on June 25, 2014, age 95. New York State Supreme Court Judge, Criminal Court Judge, Commission of NYC Housing Dept. Served as Judicial Hearing Officer well into his 90's. Curtis Institute graduate, violinist, Philadelphia Orchestra. Beloved husband of the late Bernice and Helen. Devoted father to Sandy and his wife AnnMarie, Abby Luby and the late Carole Nachamie. Loving grandfather to Eric, Deirdre, Gwen, Arielle, Nicholas and great-grandfather to Gabe and Caleb. Services Sunday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

SIMARD--Claude, originally of Larouche, Quebec, passed away suddenly at age 57 on Tuesday, June 24. A resident of New York City since the 80s, he attended the Whitney Independent Study Program from 1983-84. Claude was the proud co-founder of Jack Shainman Gallery and a figure in the international art community. He started the gallery with his close friend Jack Shainman more than 30 years ago to enrich the lives of artists and those around them. Known for his kind words and innumerable acts of generosity, his quiet demeanor was only matched by his exuberance and expert eye. He nurtured the careers of numerous artists and touched the lives of countless individuals who credit him with their appreciation and love for art. An artist in his own right, his works and performances have been presented in the United States, Canada, Europe and Australia. He is survived by his mother, Marguerite, his sisters Guylaine, Gervaise and Nathalie, his brother Guy, and his beloved nieces and nephews Erika, Jean-Francois, Larry-Christopher, Pierre-Olivier, Anne-Julie, Anne-Catherine, Marie-Laurence, Amanda, Marc-Anthony, Alexandra, and Etienne. He will be deeply missed and may his name soon be spoken without effort. Funeral services will take place at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, on July 2 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Claude's memory should be made to the Ali Forney Center, www.aliforneycenter.org.

TEWARSON--Reginald Prabhakar, 83, of Stony Brook, NY. Born 1930 in Pauri, India, eldest of seven children of Seth and Chand Tewarson. Deeply mourned by wife Ghenwah, daughters Monique and Anita, grandchildren Katja Martine and Stefan, brothers Archibald and Naresh, sister Laxmi, as well as many friends and colleagues whose lives he touched. An extraordinarily warm, engaged, and loving person, with an endless sense of humor and unique perspective on life that drew people to him. Coming to the United States in 1957 as a Crusade Scholar, to earn his Ph.D in Mathematics at Boston University, he had a distinguished career from 1964-2000 at SUNY Stony Brook and was named Leading Professor in both Applied Math and Statistics and Physiology and Biophysics. Major achievements include pioneering research in sparse matrices, and modeling of the human kidney sponsored by the National Institute of Health. He will always be in our hearts. Services July 2, from 2-5pm at Branch Funeral Home, Smithtown, NY.

SHAH--Sumitra. Sumitra Shah, a New Canaan, CT.,resident, passed away on June 14, 2014 at Norwalk Hospital. She was surrounded by family at the time of her passing. A professor of economics at St. John's University in Jamaica, New York for the better part of three decades, Ms. Shah's passion for Keynesian and feminist economics was matched only by her sense of social justice and her fondness for all animals, which she expressed in poems. Of course, her love for her family, and particularly her grandchildren, topped everything else. Ms. Shah was born in Satara, India in 1937, and came to the United States as president's fellow to pursue a Ph.D. in economics at Columbia University, where she received her second master's degree in 1964. She later completed doctoral courses at the New School for Social Research. In 1961, Ms. Shah also met her future husband, Shashi K. Shah; they celebrated their fiftieth anniversary in 2013. Ms. Shah loved teaching young minds about the workings of the modern economy and the history of economic thought. More often than not, her students would often tell her how accessible she made a subject they initially approached with dread. Ms. Shah also had a passion for the natural world, which she expressed in poems she wrote about robins nesting in the bushes outside her New Canaan home or the remarkable devotion of dogs. Her love of music ranged from Bach to bluegrass. But her greatest love was for her grandchildren who kept her smiles always in bloom. Ms. Shah was an ethically principled person who worked well with others and greatly appreciated their presence in her life. Her family members feel fortunate to have had her among them happy, peppy and bursting with love, kindness and compassion. They shall miss her and remember her forever. Among the bereaved whom Ms. Shah leaves behind are her husband, Shashi K. Shah of New Canaan, son and daughter-in-law, Sanjit and Mary Shah of South Salem, New York, two grandchildren, Mina and Vikram Shah, her brother Sharad and his wife Sandhya Janorkar of Mumbai, India, and her nieces Anju Suvernpatki of Guelph, Ontario, Sonal Sathe of North Bergen, New Jersey, Lata Manerikar, Nandini Alawani of Mumbai, India, and their respective families. Ms. Shah also leaves behind dozens of young people who came from abroad to study in the United States to whom she served as a surrogate mother, and with whom she maintained warm relations long after they became adults. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to charitable organizations dedicated to enhancing educational and career opportunities for women, and improving the lives of animals.

USDAN-Martin J. The fellow tenants of 3 East 71st Street are saddened by the passing of our long time neighbor and friend Martin J. Usdan. Martin was our longest standing resident, member of the Board and Chairman for many years. He brought a lot of experience and wisdom to the building and we will all miss his guidance. Our heartfelt wishes of condolence go out to his wife, Jane Bergre, their two daughters Jennifer and Jill, his daughter Mary and son Ralph and his three grandchildren.

SHOSTAK--Mitchell. Mitch, we will always cherish your gifts of love, wisdom and creativity. You have enriched all of our lives. Our love and enduring friendship go out to our beloved Carolyn. With love, Natan, Jessica, Tommy, Megan and David

STEIN--Abby Ph.D.,56, died June 19, 2014. A remarkable woman of incisive wit and enormous intelligence: a drop-out from Hunter College High who became a stand-up comic, graduate of the CUNY doctoral program in Criminal Justice, member/Sexual Abuse Service Study Group at White Institute, tenured professor/John Jay College of Criminal Justice, Director/John Jay Vera Fellows Program, author of two books--Prologue to Violence and Cupid's Knife. Tattoo aficionado, body-builder, she was champion of gender and racial equality, and abused women. Wife, mother, sister, mentor, colleague, friend, her death has left a huge gap in many lives. She met her final challenge, lung cancer, with outstanding courage and characteristic humor. She is survived by her two adored children, Izzy and Sadie, husband, Robert Hechkoff, sister, Rita Knox, brother-in-law, Enos Donawald. A memorial service will be held in the fall at John Jay College.

MILLER--Madeline B.,born November 26, 1925 in Brooklyn, New York, to Rose Rosmarin and Samuel Berg, died on June 25, 2014, in La Jolla, California. Survived by her devoted husband, Leo Miller, MD, loving daughters, Llois Jeanne Miller and Wendie Miller Schwab (Mark), adoring grandchildren, Melissa Schwab Keeport (Daniel), Aaron Schwab (Hilari Kawakami Wong), great-grandson, Lev Samuel Keeport, and dedicated caregivers. Private services will be held. Condolences may be sent to Wendie Schwab, P.O. Box 2202, Wailuku, Maui, Hawaii, 96793, or wms@maui.net.

O'KEEFE--John. His death on June 7 leaves all who knew him deeply saddened. A PR genius and brilliant raconteur, he was generous, loyal, and so much fun. There was no one like him and he will be remembered by his many friends at The Metropolitan Museum of Art with enormous love and respect.
MOLYNEUX--Edward F.,Jr., 81, former New York advertising creative director, passed away on May 27th in Rhinebeck, NY. For the complete obituary, please visit: www.dapsonchestney.com

PEI--Eileen Loo, died peacefully at home in New York City on June 20. Born on September 21, 1920, in Tientsin, China, she was the daughter of Ping Yok and Alice Chang Loo. Her father was an early Chinese graduate of MIT, earning his engineering degree in 1916. Her maternal grandfather was Yin Tang Chang, Ambassador from China to Washington beginning in 1909. Her granduncle was T'ang Shao-Yi, first Prime Minister of the Republic of China (1911-1912). Eileen Loo came to the United States in 1938 to attend Wellesley College, where she studied Art, was a Senior Wellesley College Scholar, and received her degree in 1942. Immediately after graduation, she married Ieoh Ming Pei, a young architect recently graduated from MIT's School of Architecture. He followed her to Harvard and its Graduate School of Design, where she studied Landscape Architecture and where he received his Master's Degree in Architecture in 1946. During the war years, her husband worked with the National Defense Research Committee in Princeton, NJ. Their first son, T'ing Chung, was born there in 1944. After the war, they returned to Harvard where, upon earning his degree, Mr. Pei joined the faculty. Their second son, Chien Chung (Didi), was born in 1946. Eileen and I.M. Pei moved to New York in 1948 when Mr. Pei was recruited to work for the real estate developer William Zeckendorf. A third son, Li Chung (Sandi), was born in 1949 and Eileen Pei embarked on her career of raising three boys and supporting her husband. In 1960, a daughter, Liane, was born, to the elation of the parents. Her husband's career flourished. In 1952, she sailed across the Atlantic Ocean with him to Europe on traveling fellowships he had earned while at Harvard. This was the first of many trips they would take together and with the family where everyone would benefit from her impeccable organization and preparation. Always forward thinking, she was an ardent supporter of Planned Parenthood, Channel 13 and WNYC, and an active and longtime member of the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Together with her husband, Eileen Loo Pei befriended many of the most influential artists and dealers of the time, particularly those that were concentrating in New York in the 1950's and 1960's. They were frequent participants in the broad cultural life of both New York and beyond, and intimate gatherings at the Pei home were welcomed events, memorable for their animated conversation, fine wine and her delicious cuisine. Possessed of a keen eye, unfailing taste and an abiding passion for the arts and culture, she was a constant and indispensable support to her husband and family, providing wise counsel, warmth, good humor, and practical, loving advice on all matters. She was known by all for her effortless style, elegance and grace. Eileen Loo Pei is predeceased by her eldest son, two brothers, Harry and Man Kit, and one sister, Louise. She is survived by her husband of 72 years, two sons, her daughter, two daughters-in-law, seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests with great appreciation that donations be made to Planned Parenthood, Channel 13 or WNYC.

MALKIN--Marilyn, died prematurely at the age of 83 in Florida on June 25. She is survived by her daughter Candi Malkin Rowen of Tampa; her granddaughter Jessi Navarro and her husband Elio; her great-grandson "Elito" and 8/9ths of her new great-grandson; her big brother Charles and his wife Myrna; her twin brother Ken; her sisters-in-law Millie and Phyllis; her cousins; and her many nieces and nephews for whom she was their surrogate mother. A graveside service will take place at Mt. Ararat cemetery on Monday, June 30 at 11:00am.

MEAD--Sally Zurn. The inimitable and much-loved Sally Zurn Mead passed away suddenly and peacefully on Saturday, June 14, 2014 at her home in Albuquerque NM. She left the world on her own terms, just as she lived her life. Sally was born in Erie, PA, on November 8, 1930, the daughter of the late Melvin and Marian Zurn. She enjoyed a childhood of sailing, sports and a wonderful circle of friends. She graduated from The Masters School, class of 1948 and attended Northampton School for Girls. Sally then attended Denison University and left to be courted by her future husband, James M. Mead. Jim and Sally wed in August of 1953. They enjoyed fifty one years together until Jim's death in 2005. Sally made many warm and beautiful homes for her family in Charlottesville, VA, Philadelphia, PA, Princeton, NJ, Washington DC and Albuquerque, NM. Sally was an accomplished athlete and particularly enjoyed tennis and golf, competing in various events and becoming tennis champion at the Philadelphia Cricket Club and golf champion at Springdale Golf Course in Princeton among others. Sally spent many happy years at various not-for-profit organizations and especially enjoyed her manager role at the Junior League Shop of Washington DC. In 1998 she relocated to Albuquerque where she greatly enjoyed her active role of grandmother and always welcomed family to the home she shared with her beloved cats. She was a voracious reader of every imaginable type of novel, often completing several books every few days. When not reading and helping with grandchildren, she worked hard on crossword puzzles and was especially fond of the Sunday New York Times Puzzles which she usually completed. Sally, also affectionately called Dutch, was known for her complete honesty, independent thought, generosity, loyalty and her refreshing dry sense of humor. She could be counted on to "tell it like it is" and was always a source of loving advice, support and life perspectives to her children, grandchildren and many others. In addition to her parents and husband, she was predeceased by her brother John H. Zurn and her cherished aunt, Arloween Zurn Todd. Her survivors include her son, Scott (Suling) Mead of London, daughters, Sara Mead of Erie, PA and Hope (Brandon) Wynn of Albuquerque, NM. She is further survived by her grandchildren, Betsy, Amanda, Alex, Emma and Isabelle Mead, Jake Rupert, Emmett, Gus, Clay and Eleanor Wynn and her brothers, Frank, David and Roger Zurn. She is further survived by Bobbi Pollock, the daughter of her beloved stepfather, the late Samuel J. Roberts. She is also survived by her two most recent cats, Twinkie and Lulu. The family held a private service in Erie, Pa.

PERRIN--Lesley Davison, the widow of society bandleader Forrest Perrin, wrote songs for myriad musical revues, including twelve revues for Julius Monk, "Coconuts!" at the Coconut Grove Playhouse (Florida), "Varieties!" at Rainbow & Stars in New York City, and "Secrets Every Smart Traveler Should Know Off-Broadway. She wrote for such noted television shows as "Laugh-In", "The Dean Martin Show", "The Today Show," and "The Tonight Show." She contributed material to the cabaret acts of Ruth Buzzi, Jo Anne Worley, Nancy Dussault, Claiborne Cary, Anne Francine and Mabel Mercer, and to thirteen comedy record albums. "Political Party - 40 Years in Revue," her most recent CD, is a compendium of 28 revue songs written about presidential politics covering the years 1961-2001, starring Walter Bobbie, Ruth Buzzi, Mary Louise Wilson, and the casts of the Crystal Palace in Aspen, Colorado, and the Julius Monk revues. She is survived by two children, Scott Perrin and Wendy Perrin, and two grandsons.

MORAN--Valerie. The New York Design Center family has lost a kind, generous, strong, vibrant friend, an astute, innovative colleague. We and our entire Industry will miss her. James Druckman, President Daniel Farr, Managing Director

PARIS--Shirley C.,on June 27, 2014. Our grief at the loss of our mother would be insurmountable if it were not for the strength, courage and love that she gave us. This love will live on and offer solace to all who knew her. Cherished mother of her beloved children, Deanne and Dr. William Chenitz and Patti Paris, adored grandmother of Ali Chenitz, Dr. Kara Chenitz and grand son-in-law Dr. Todd Jozsa, Anne Paris Sacks, and Victoria Paris Sacks. Services will be held 10am, Sunday, June 29, 2014 at West End Temple, 147-02 Newport Ave., Neponsit, NY 11694. Donations can be made in her name to West End Temple as they continue to rebuild after Hurricane Sandy.

LITTLE--Charles Eugene, born March 1, 1931, to John R. and Elizabeth (Taylor) Little, died June 20, 2014, in Albuquerque, NM. He is survived by his wife of 43 years Ila (Dawson); three beloved children of his first wife, Katharine (Smith) Dorothy (Pariot), Charles T., and Katharine (Tepe); two stepsons, Lorenzo and Andrew Traldi; grandchildren Julia (Griffenkranz) and David J. Pariot; Aidan Tepe; Arthur, Matthew, Oliver, and Rebecca Traldi; Meagan, Melanie, Drew, Maria, and Julia Traldi; and great-grandson Benjamin Griffenkranz; as well as many friends and colleagues. After attending Fountain Valley prep school in Colorado, Charles graduated from Wesleyan University in 1955 with Distinction in Creative Writing. He served in the US Army in Alaska during the Korean conflict. He was an advertising executive at Foote, Cone, and Belding until 1963, when he became chief executive officer of The Open Space Institute and published its Open Space Action Magazine with the objective of preserving areas of natural beauty in the New York metropolitan region. His entire life's work then became to devote his considerable talent and passion to the appreciation and protection of American landscapes, whether they are agricultural or urban natural areas; public parks or privately held areas of unique natural beauty. In 1972 he joined the Conservation Foundation in Washington DC, then became head of the Natural Resources Division of The Congressional Research Service, which he left in 1978 to establish the American Land Resource Association and edit its publication, American Land Forum. Charles moved to Placitas, NM in 1994, continuing to involve himself in land use issues and to write about them. He founded Voices from the American Land, a quarterly publication of poetry celebrating outstanding landscapes of North America. He is the author of many acclaimed books, among them Discover America (Smithsonian); Greenways for America (Johns Hopkins); Hope for the Land (Rutgers); An Appalachian Tragedy (Sierra Club); and The Dying of the Trees (Viking), a finalist for the LA Times's nonfiction award in 1997. Memorial services will be held at Las Placitas Presbyterian Church on Saturday, July 12th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Charles's memory to the LPPC Columbarium Fund or to Voices from the American Land.

HIRSCH--Theodore, "Ted", died June 25. Born 1964 on the Upper West Side, he lived his professional life in Washington, DC with his beloved wife Mary and their spirited sons Harry and Isaac. He attended Fieldston, Brown and Harvard Law. At ACDA and the State Department, he specialized in disarmament and nuclear non-proliferation. He fought his cancer with grace, dignity and courage and upon retirement wrote a novel rich in metaphor and wit. Private funeral in East Hampton, a cherished childhood place. Survived by Mary Clark, Harry and Isaac Hirsch, Herbert, Felicia, Laurence, Dennis, Alice, Suzanne, Olivia, Clara, and Zander Hirsch, Edmundo Desnoes, and Jean, Don, Andrew, Michelle, Molly and Fiona Clark.

ROCKEFELLER--Dr. Richard. The David Rockefeller Family deeply mourns the sudden death of Dr. Richard Gilder Rockefeller on June 13, 2014. He was a cherished husband, father, son, brother, uncle, and grandfather who played a pivotal role in our extended family. We have been profoundly touched by the outpouring of love, admiration and support from people all over the world whose lives Richard also touched. Richard was passionate about everything he did as a physician, as an activist and as a philanthropist. He was at home in art, in music and in nature. He was intensely curious about how things work, from the physical world to the human psyche. His formal education came from the North Country School, the Choate School, Harvard College and the Harvard Medical School. But his informal learning never stopped, nor did his drive to make the world a better place. He founded, led or served many non-profit organizations (including those listed below) and gave generously to them in time and treasure. In addition, he served as president of the Rockefeller Family Fund and chairman of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. Richard's immediate family consists of his wife Nancy King Rockefeller; his son Clayton and daughter Rebecca; his grandchildren Ozzy and Elsa and Wilder; Nancy's sons Max and Griffin; his father David Rockefeller; Richards' siblings and spouses, David and Susan, Abby and Lee, Neva and Bruce, Peggy and Barry, Eileen and Paul; and numerous nieces and nephews and cousins whom he adored. We all miss him so much. The Family plans a private service of remembrance this summer, and there will be a memorial service in the fall, time and place to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Sargasso Sea Alliance (http://www.sargassoalliance.org/); Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (the PTSD project) (http://www.maps.org/); Doctors without Borders (http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/); Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative (http://www.dndina.org/); Maine Coast Heritage Trust (http://www.mcht.org/)

ROWAN--Barbara J. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul. Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the passing of Barbara Rowan, mother of our beloved friend Marc Rowan. We express our deepest sympathies to Marc and to all other members of the Rowan family.

INDENBAUM--Dorothy, died peacefully at home on June 26, 2014. Loving mother of Esther and Arthur, grandmother of Rose and Ariel, great-grandmother of Orianna. PhD New York University, M.S. Queens College, B.A. Brooklyn College, Graduate with full certification Dalcroze School of Music. Studied at Juilliard School of Music and Bank Street School of Education. Associate director and pianist with the Aviva Players. Music specialist at the Day School of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Glenview Community Center, Valley Stream Community Center and summer camps. Conducted workshops for teachers at Operation Headstart and Early Childhood Education Council, Washington University in St. Louis, Loyola University in New Orleans and Montclair Teachers College New Jersey. Professor at Hunter College New York City 1971 to 1978 and at the Dalcroze School of Music from 1960 to 1992. Member of the Musicians Club (Board of Directors), American Women Composers (Board of Directors), Bohemian Club, New York Women Composers, Sonneck Society for American Music, American Musicological Society, Music Teachers National Conference, Center for Women in Music (New York University), Study Group on Issues of Gender in Music (CUNY), Sigma Alpha Iota, American Association of University Women and Chair, Music Committee Harmonie Club. Author of "Gifted Sister The Story of Fanny Mendelsshon" and "The Story of Creation The Story of Clara Schumann". Included in Who's Who of American Musicians. Dissertation requested by and included at The Lincoln Center Music Library. Funeral Services will be held Tuesday, July 1st at 12 noon, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., at 91st Street. To honor Dorothy in her musical vision support women composers as she was passionately devoted to their advancement. She will be deeply missed by her family, friends and the entire women's music community.

LETHBRIDGE--John Dodd "Jack", passed away on June 26, 2014 at his home in Wilton, CT. He was 86 years old. The son of George M. Lethbridge and Gertrude Dodd, Jack was raised in Upper Montclair, NJ. He graduated from The Hill School in Pottstown, PA and Washington and Lee University in Lexington, VA. He served in the US Marine Corps during the Korean conflict, achieving the rank of Captain. Jack spent most of his professional career at the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation where he retired as Vice President and General Manager of the National Distillers division. Jack was predeceased by his wife of 43 years, Betsy Emmaline Lethbridge. He is survived by his daughter Leah Ovington Lethbridge, his son John D. Lethbridge, Jr. and John's wife Karen Boutelle Lethbridge, his grandson John Dodd Lethbridge, III and his granddaughter Caroline Renee Lethbridge. There will be a Memorial Service on Wednesday, July 2, 2014 at 11am at the Wilton Congregational Church, 70 Ridgefield Rd., Wilton, CT. Interment will follow at Hillside Cemetery, 165 Ridgefield Rd., Wilton, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Wilton Library Association or the Wilton Volunteer Ambulance Corps.

PUGLISI--Alfred A.,Passed away on June 23, 2014, at 91. Born in the Little Italy section of lower Manhattan of Sicilian immigrants in 1922, loved Italy, Italian food, wine and song. WWII vet, landed with the US army infantry on Utah Beach shortly after D-Day in September 1944, earned Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Alumnus of Fordham (BS-1943) and NYU (MBA-1951). After serving as controller of Welcome Wagon Inc., and the Olivetti Corporation, co-founded Pustorino, Puglisi and Co, PC, CPAs, of which he was the managing partner from 1961-88. Named Knight of Malta (1982) and Cavalier del Lavoro by the Italian Government (1987). Dedicated to professional and philanthropic causes, serving on many committees of the New York State Society of CPAs, and was Director of the Italian American Chamber of Commerce and the Queens Chamber of Commerce. Held officer positions at the New York Athletic Club, Lions Club of Ravenswood, Cardinal's Committee for the Laity, Columbus Citizens Foundation, Variety Boys Club of Queens, the American Italian Foundation for Cancer Research and Fordham University. Survived by his devoted wife of 67 years, Denise, of Paris, France whom he met in post-war Germany, and children, Claudine Puglisi Cagwin (Thomas Cagwin), Michael (Valerie), and Catherine Puglisi (William Barcham), loving sisters, Diana Lamanno and Nina Murphy, many nieces and nephews, grandchildren, Alex and Michelle Cagwin, Suzanne Puglisi and Jeanne Puglisi Grzywacz, Raphael and Arianna Barcham, and great-grandchildren, Clint and Carson Grzywacz. Funeral Services were held on June 27, 2014. In lieu of flowers, the family recommends donations be made: www.woundedwarriorproject.org in memory of "Alfred A. Puglisi, a WWII, Normandy-wounded warrior of the 328th Infantry Regiment of the 26th Infantry Division."

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. Alexander Bernstein, Jamie Bernstein and Nina Bernstein Simmons, together with The Leonard Bernstein Office, mourn the loss of Mary Rodgers Guettel: a beloved friend, a brilliant colleague, an accomplished, irreverent, thoroughly delightful woman. The world has lost a bright spark.

LaMONTE--Charles S.,died peacefully on Tuesday, June 24, 2014, following a series of strokes and resulting complications. Dr. LaMonte's intelligent practice of medicine at Memorial Sloan Kettering and at the Mid-Hudson Medical Group improved the lives of many. Chuck's determination to succeed in the face of daunting odds inspires us all. He is survived by his wife, Jody LaMonte, two daughters, Hilary and Karen LaMonte, son-in-law, Steven Polaner, and grandson, Jackson Colgan. POWELL--Ronald Eugene, Jr.,52, of Riverdale, New York, died in New York City on Wednesday, June 25, 2014 after a long battle with cancer. He was born on May 25, 1962 in Bainbridge, Maryland to the late Ronald Eugene Powell and Pauline Beverly Saxton. After graduating from Washingtonville High School, NY and serving in the Navy, he continued his education receiving his MBA from Marist College and BAA from the University of Pikeville. He enjoyed a long career in finance, working with firms such as Wasserstein Perella in Romania and Poland, JP Morgan Chase, Mellon Financial Corporation and Herald National Bank. While in Romania he met his future wife Gabriela Ferastraeru. They married in Sighisoara, Romania on June 17, 1995. Ron was a wiz with numbers, a talented cook and passionate golfer. Ron is survived by his wife, Gabriela Powell and beloved daughter, Catherine Alexandra Powell, 18, of Riverdale, NY; his mother, stepfather John Doherty, and a stepsister, Margaret Johnson. He was pre-deceased by previous stepfather John Dowd, who helped raise him, and his brother Thomas Leroy Powell. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, August 2, 2014 at 11:00am at the St. Dumitru Romanian Orthodox Church, 50 West 89th Street, New York, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to UPCI and mailed to UPMC Cancer Pavilion, Suite 1B, 5150 Center Ave., Pittsburgh, PA 15232.

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers, we mourn the passing of Mary Rodgers Guettel- a generous soul, a talented composer and author, as committed to the musical legacy of her father Richard Rodgers as she was to the cultivation of new writers and new work. We send our love and condolences to her family. Ted Chapin and everyone at Rodgers & Hammerstein

LOW--Josiah O. III, 75, died peacefully on June 20, 2014, surrounded by his family and with his German shepherd by his side. Joe was born to Katherine and Josiah O. Low Jr. on June 5, 1939 in Detroit, Michigan. He worked his way through Williams College graduating in 1961. Joe built a career as an investment banker, first at Merrill Lynch and then at Donaldson, Lufkin, & Jenrette where he led the corporate finance group for 15 years. On Wall Street he was known for his unbending integrity and unending interest in others. Colleagues he worked with 40 years ago cite his mentorship as critical to their own success. Many also recall that he kept a saddle in the trunk of his car. After leaving DLJ, he continued to serve on the board of a number of companies, including Centex Development, CoStar Group, and Rosetta Resources. In 2002, he joined Catterton Partners as a Senior Advisor. He advised CEO's of Fortune 500 Companies and later helped friends and local business people expand their businesses or find a path out of trouble. If you came in contact with Joe, you remembered him with a smile. He blew his nose with a trumpet that turned heads, and he sang along to opera and Willie Nelson, whether or not he knew the words. He entertained children with his cowboy yip and songs about cowpies. He disliked mini-golf, "a bastardization of the game", cilantro and the snapping of gum. Joe grew up working as a ranch hand at French Creek, his family's guest ranch in Wyoming's Platte River Valley. His love for the West was infectious. He introduced hundreds of friends and colleagues to Wyoming with visits to the A Bar A, a ranch down the valley from French Creek. Joe was unexpectedly friendly and sincerely interested in everyone he met. Ordering at a restaurant was always time consuming because Joe needed to learn the name and background of the waiter -- some connection could always be found. By the time dessert came, he was often sitting at another table with people he had just met. To his five grandchildren, he was Poppa Joe. The grandfather who hid a radio under your pillow so you could listen to the Giants game at night. The patient teacher who poured a little extra root beer float in your glass to demonstrate the concept of principal and interest. He did not allow whining or weak handshakes. He was irreverent, generous, joyful and loving. He let you ride the ATV despite what your parents said. He paid his six year-old granddaughter to paint his toenails. To his three sons, he was a father who arose every morning at 5:30 to provide his children with opportunities and experiences that he never had. He encouraged his sons to pursue their passions, put together a plan, and then to "get it done." He was an investor in their dreams, their advisor, and friend. Joe loved the outdoors and gave generously to the Williamstown Rural Lands Foundation. He planted hundreds of trees and was often seen mowing the meadows surrounding his home in Williamstown. He had an extensive collection of John Deere tractors. When he ran out of space for more tractors, he gave them away to friends, because "everyone needs a tractor." He shared his passion for western music by setting up concerts in Williamstown. At these events, he would often join his hero Don Edwards on stage for a duet, despite the cringes of his wife and children. He served as a Williams class agent for many years and was selected to lead his class's procession at their 50th reunion. Joe was the lead donor in the purchase and renovation of the Sand Springs Recreation Center, a historic aquatic center that now serves as community gathering place and swim academy in Williamstown. He set up a foundation to fund free swim lessons so that no child would ever be afraid of the water. He loved opera, American antiques, and Western art. His favorite fashion statement was a young woman with a ponytail poking out of the back of a baseball cap. Joe was unbeatable in horseshoes, a devious opponent in gin rummy, and he could still out drive his sons well into his 70's. He gave his wife old pick-up trucks for her birthday. Children he barely knew named stuffed animals after him. He was loved by so many. There is now a giant hole in our hearts that we will all try to fill with the openness and generosity that was Joe Low. Joe is survived by Penny (Ireland) his loving wife of 50 years, three sons Tad (Alisa), Timothy (Loriann), and Jeffrey (Stacey), five grandchildren: Ryan, Julia, Aidan, Nicholas, and Eliza, his sister Katherine, and two brothers David and Charles, and numerous nieces and nephews. There will be a private family memorial service. Gifts in Joe's honor may be made to the Williamstown Rural Lands Foundation Williamstown, MA 01267 or simply through unexpected kindness or interest in another person's life.

PETRUSKA--Alexander. January 22, 1925 - June 14, 2014. Alex was born in Lodz, Poland to a distinguished musical family. His father, Seweryn, was a violinist and conductor of the Lodz Philharmonic Orchestra and his mother, Frances, was a respected piano teacher. He was on track to be an outstanding concert pianist. But then Hitler intervened. In December 1939 the family escaped from Lodz to Ostrowiecz which then became a labor camp in October 1942. In August 1944 he was sent to Auschwitz and then to Sachsenhausen, Oranienberg, and Dachau. On May 1, 1945 Alex escaped from a death march out of Dachau which had left before its liberation by the Allies. He encountered American soldiers and proceeded to become a Polish-English interpreter, learning English in a big hurry. Two years later, with his American Army papers, he embarked to the USA along with his mother who had also survived. He received a college degree in philosophy from Yeshiva University where he also started and led their first ever orchestra. He continued his musical studies at Juilliard with Adele Marcus and Edward Steuermann, teaching his own students as well. When many of his students became teachers and performing artists, he started APPTA, the Alexander Petruska Pianist Teachers Association to help his students convey their own knowledge. Each lesson with Alex was a miracle of discovery and insight into the composer and oneself. His students left lessons transformed and elevated. His masterclasses were enriched by his knowledge of all the arts, literature, philosophy, and history. With his indomitable spirit, he brought beauty and love into a world which had given him such cruelty and ugliness. He will be inconsolably missed for his exuberant love of music, his love of life, and his ability to bring out the best in every person he encountered. His memory will be forever our guiding light. We embrace his wife, Jane, his son and daughter Gary and Gwen, and his beloved granddaughter Mina.

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. Lincoln Center Theater is heartbroken over the death of Mary Rodgers Guettel. She was a beloved figure here. We were delighted to see her whenever she came around, and she came around a lot especially if we were producing her favorite musicals! The staff, the crews, the ushers indeed all who work at Lincoln Center Theater will miss this warm, funny, feisty, caring, savvy and deeply talented friend. Our sympathy to her large and devoted family. J. Tomilson Hill Chairman, Board of Directors Andre Bishop Producing Artistic Director

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. Grateful for many, many years of Chapin/Guettel family friendship. Even more grateful for my career. Mary was generous in unique ways. Truly one of a kind. We will miss her. Ted, JoAnna, Anika and Zoe Chapin

OPATOW--Barry, MD. Institute for Psychoanalytic Education (NYU) and Psychoanalytic Association of New York (PANY) mourn the loss of Barry Opatow MD, analyst and teacher of extraordinary intellect and passion.

GOLDSMITH--Clifford H.,died peacefully at home on June 25, 2014 at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Katherine; daughters Audrey Kubie and Alexandra Fallon; grandchildren Philip Samuel Dickinson; Camille Kubie, Kimberly Harrison, Gregory Kubie; Conrad, Oliver, and Daisy Fallon; and four great-grandchildren. A man of great personal strength, integrity, and courage, Clifford dedicated his life and career to the pursuit of excellence in all his endeavors. His family and friends greatly valued his loyalty, optimism and keen sense of humor. As a devoted parent and philanthropist, he co-founded The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for Multiple Sclerosis in New York, part of The Mount Sinai Health System, named for his daughter who died of the disease. Clifford worked tirelessly for MS-related causes, and served as chairman of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Born September 6, 1919 in Leipzig, Germany, he graduated from Bradford University, Yorkshire, England, with a degree in textile engineering, and later emigrated to the United States in 1940. He served in the United States Army during World War II, and was held as a prisoner of war in Germany. In 1945 he joined the Benson & Hedges Company, ultimately becoming President of Philip Morris Incorporated from 1978 until 1984. Clifford was a long-time trustee of the Mount Sinai Health System, and on the board of directors of FOJP Service Corporation. He was Chairman Emeritus of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, as well as FOJP Service Corporation; and was a Vice Chairman of Polytechnic University, now NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for MS at Mount Sinai Health Systems. Services will be held on Monday, June 30, at 11am at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th St., New York City.

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers, died June 26, 2014 at home after a long illness. Her children Tod Beaty, Nina Beaty, Kim Beaty, Adam Guettel, and Alec Guettel ask that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Juilliard School or, in the spirit of their mother's generosity, to the charity of your choice. No services are planned, but a celebration of her life will be held in the future.

FREUND--Peter, Emeritus Professor of Sociology, Montclair State University, born New York City, died June 12, at 73, after a struggle with pancreatic and liver cancer. Peter was loved by many: his wife and lifetime soul mate, Miriam Fisher, sisters Deirdre McCarthy-King and Maureen McCarthy-Koth, brothers-in-law, Craig and Kurt, sister-in-law Diane, nephews and nieces, a host of friends and colleagues. They admired his integrity, feisty, fierce independence, authority-questioning spirit, ever-ready humor and wit. He was a generous, loyal, true friend. Peter was a sociologist, scholar, thoughtful analyst and critic of environmental issues, car-dominated transportation, impact of social organization on the body, health, health inequalities. He authored/coauthored books and numerous articles on these topics: The Civilized Body; Health, Illness and the Social Body; The Ecology of the Automobile. He was writing on violence and civilization at the time of his death, and has other work currently in press. Until his recent illness Peter was a tireless urban hiker and explorer, walked 6 miles the day before hospital admission. He loved to travel, spent summers in Europe, visited his Czech roots. He had a hearty appetite, loved and was knowledgeable about beer. Send donations to Institute for Rational Urban Mobility (IRUM), non-profit parent organization of Auto-Free New York, at IRUM, PO Box 409 NY, NY 10014. Memorial event and Manhattan Sociology Walk November 1 and 2.

FRISCHER--Leonard, of Boca Raton, FL on June 24, 2014. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Together, they shared a lifetime of love, joy and devotion to each other. Adored father of Peggy, Steve, Paul, and Julie. Cherished grandfather of Erin, Eric, Jack and Kate. He was a true gentleman - a kind and loyal friend and a loving mentor to all throughout his life. His generosity knew no bounds and his integrity stood above all. He will live in our hearts forever and always.

GUCK--John M.D.,on June 25, 2014. Beloved Husband of the late Joan (nee) Klein. Devoted Father of Joan Guck, Kathy Smith, Mary Lane, Maureen Novotne and the late Jean Guck.
