GREEN--Charles "Chuck," passed away peacefully on June 22, 2014 at his home in Rochester, NY. He was 92 years old. A loving man who valued his family above all. Chuck served in the Army/Air Corp in WWII and then built Jack Green Men's Shop, which brought men's fashion to Rochester. He was the last surviving founding member of Temple Emanu-El of Rochester, NY. He was also a member of Temple B'rith Kodesh, Irondequoit and Midvale Country Clubs, Jay Lodge-Knights of Pythias and was a Master Mason in the Mason Fraternity. An incredible skier, avid golfer and tennis player. He is survived by his loving wife of 71 years, Ruth Blackman Green; children, Shelly Stoler and Michael Insalaco; and Debi and Evan Mittman; grandchildren Michael Stoler, Peter and Rachel Massa, Robert and Jennifer Massa and Tricia Mittman; great-grandchildren, Brendan and Hunter. We will all miss him and cherish all the times we had together. Funeral Services were held in Rochester, NY. Shiva will be at the home of Debi and Evan Mittman, on Sunday, June 29th 2014 from 2-8pm. Donations may be made to Foundation Fighting Blindness. BrightonMemorialChapel.com

GAETZ--Dr. Harold Parry, "Russ," Retired Pathologist, died June 20, 2014. Born December 3, 1930 in New Haven, CT., to Dr. Thomas H. and Lella Parke Gaetz, preceded in death by both as well as sister, Ygerne Baker; and survived by sister, Geraldine DiMasi; loving wife, Sandra S. Gaetz; daughters, Martha Karasek, Tracy Manning, Heidi Trilling and Kelly Gaetz; and four grandchildren, Stephen and Anne Karasek; and Kailee and Tabetha King. Dr. Gaetz graduated from McGill University Medical School, Montreal, Canada. He completed his internship and first year of residency at The Mallory Institute, Boston, where he had the opportunity to work with some of the greats in Pathology. In July of 1963, he began working under Dr. Charlie Begg at St. Luke's Hospital. He left in February of 1984 to join Roosevelt Hospital, where he continued working full-time until December of 2007, retiring as Interim Pathology Director. In all, he served St. Luke's/Roosevelt for 45 years. He had a strong love of Pathology and contributed greatly to the education of hospital residents as well as Columbia University students. Dr. Gaetz spoke fondly of his "other family" comprised of many colleagues and students. He was fascinated by world history, especially the great wars, was passionate about cuisine from diverse cultures, and took great pleasure in his family and home life. He will be missed profoundly by all. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Columbia University, Mount Sinai Roosevelt Hospital or United Hospice or merely treat yourself to a good meal with a favorite companion. Be sure to let Russ know where you went, what you ate and how much you enjoyed it.

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers, dear friend, guide, guru, mentor, boss-extraordinaire. GARDEN--Nancy. Author of "Annie on My Mind", dead at 76. Nancy Garden (1938-2014), prolific author of over thirty books for young people including "Annie on My Mind", one of the first novels for teenagers about two young girls who fall in love, died June 23 at her home in Carlisle, Massachusetts, at the age of 76. With her was her lifelong partner, Sandy Scott. Garden and Scott were married in 2004 when same-sex marriage was legalized in their home state of Massachusetts. Garden won many awards for her work. Among them was the Robert B. Downs for intellectual Freedom Award in 2000. In 2003 she received the Margaret A. Edwards award, honoring her "significant and lasting contribution to young adult literature." She became an ardent proponent of individual rights especially gay rights because she knew firsthand the challenges faced by young people whose sexual identities were in question. She worked all of her adult life to bring acceptance to the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender communities, especially its youngest members, earning her a devoted following who found in her the hero they sought in their struggle to live their lives true to themselves. She contributed to the struggle for gay rights in the best way she knew how: through her writing. When "Annie on My Mind" was removed because of its content from a school library in Olathe, Kansas, a lawsuit was brought by kids who, in a landmark case, obtained a victory for the First Amendment rights of adolescents. Nancy lived and worked for several years in New York City, where she attended the School of Dramatic Arts at Columbia University, but her heart remained in New England and in 1972, she and her partner since high school, Sandy Scott, moved to Carlisle, Massachusetts. It was here, and in summers in Maine, that Nancy lived for the rest of her life. Services will be private. Gifts in her name may be made to the National Coalition Against Discrimination, 19 Fulton St., Suite #

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. The Board of Directors, along with the entire Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival community, sadly mourns the loss of our dear friend Mary. DRAKE--Rodman Leland, Rodman Leland Drake, 71, died peacefully on June 24, 2014 at his home in Manhattan. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. He was born in Terre Haute, IN the son of Helen Frederick, a concert pianist, and Col. Leland Rodman Drake. Rod attended The Grange School in Santiago, Chile, where his father was the United States Military attache, before matriculating at The Hotchkiss School. Rod was a member of the varsity golf team at Yale from which he graduated in 1965. After two years as a Lieutenant in the US Army's Intelligence Division, he graduated with an MBA from Harvard University in 1969. At the age of 37, Rod became the youngest CEO and managing director in the history of Cresap McCormick and Paget, a leading international management consulting firm, which he later merged with Towers Perrin. His clients included the World Bank, DK Ludwig and others all over the world, with stations in the Middle East, Mexico, and Brazil. With more than 35 years in management consulting, private equity, financial services, infrastructure development, and biopharmaceuticals, Rod continued his career as an experienced chairman, CEO and corporate director. Until his death, Rod was the chairman of the Columbia Atlantic Funds, and the Brookfield and Helios Funds, a board member and chairman of the compensation committee at Celgene Corporation, and a board member of Chimerix Inc. Until 2010, Rod served as chairman and interim CEO of Crystal River Capital, where he managed the successful sale of the company to Brookfield. Previously, he co-founded and served as managing director of Baringo Capital, a private equity group specializing in mining. Rod was co-chairman of KMR Power Company, a developer of independent power projects in Latin America. Rod was sought after as an expert in solving complex problems. He served a trustee of Animal Medical Center, created the PEN Biography Award in his wife's name. He was a passionate collector and well known for his collection of American Illustration art. He was unassuming, gracious, and sage; he marveled at the world's endless beauty, and was devoted to his family, his friends, his dogs, and thankful for the wonderful experiences in life. Rod is survived by his beloved wife of 16 years Jacqueline Weld Drake, two adored sons, Stephan Drake and Philip Drake by his first wife Lenir Drake, a sister, Joan Drake, nephews Leland Fox and Gregory Fox, an aunt, Fran Drake, his sisters-in-law, Mercedes Levin, Martha Bograd, and Estrellita Brodsky, his brother-in-law Daniel Brodsky, and their children. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. A funeral service will be held on July 1, 2014 at 2:30 pm at The General Theological Seminary of the Episcopal Church 440 West 21st New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Animal Medical Center of New York City and Casita Maria Center for Arts and Education.

BARBAS--Carlos F. (1964 2014) Carlos F. Barbas III, the Janet and Keith Kellogg II Chair professor and member of The Skaggs Institute for Chemical Biology at The Scripps Research Institute (TSRI), died June 24 after a battle with a rare form of medullary thyroid cancer. He was 49. Barbas, who grew up in St. Petersburg, Florida, double-majored in physics and chemistry while graduating with honors at Eckerd College. He earned a PhD in 1989 and conducted postdoctoral studies at Pennsylvania State University and at The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla. He joined the TSRI faculty in 1991, where he conducted studies focused on the development of new therapeutic approaches to human diseases through studies at the interface of synthetic organic chemistry, molecular biology and medicine. Some of his accomplishments include developing the first human antibody phage libraries, creating the first synthetic antibodies, developing the first artificial transcription factors capable of regulating endogenous genes, and pioneering chemically programmed antibodies. Each of these approaches has resulted in a new drug class that is currently in clinical trials or approved for the treatment of a variety of diseases. To translate his research into new therapies, Barbas founded three companies. In 1997, he co-founded Prolifaron, which was acquired by Alexion. In 2002, he started Cov-X, which was acquired by Pfizer. In 2008, he founded Zynegenia to develop the next generation of antibody-derived drugs. Barbas received national and international recognition for his work. He was the recipient of the Investigator Award from the Cancer Research Institute, the Presidential Green Chemistry Challenge Award, Arthur C. Cope Scholar Award from the American Chemical Society, a National Institutes of Health (NIH) Director's Pioneer Award and the Tetrahedron Young Investigator Award in Bioorganic and Medicinal Chemistry. He was named a scholar of The American Foundation for AIDS Research and a fellow of the American Associate for the Advancement of Science. In 2014, Barbas was named a fellow of the Academy of Microbiology. He was author on more than 330 scientific articles and was a named inventor on 58 issued U.S. patents. In a 2009 profile for his alma mater, Eckerd College, Barbas reflected on his decision to become a researcher: "It's better than I envisioned. I didn't realize when I was studying science all the other opportunities it gives you to see the world. I have a very interesting kind of job that includes traveling the world to give talks. Things that I've worked on are being tested on people, and at some point, there will probably be someone in my family or someone I know who benefits directly." In another interview [http://www.scripps.edu/newsandviews/e--20080114/covx.html], he said, "It has been a dream of mine to develop drugs that make a difference." "I extend my deepest condolences to Carlos's family," said Michael Marletta, president and CEO of TSRI. "He was a creative scientist who tackled broad-ranging and important biomedical questions to lay the foundation for new therapies. He was admired and loved by his many friends on our campus. We will miss him greatly." Carlos loved to tell jokes, to prank his friends, host legendary parties, race fast cars, go to the gym and, most of all, to spend time with his family. Memorial Service will be held in La Jolla, CA. Barbas is survived by his wife, Annica; children, Derek, Sabrina, Sixten and Viggo; mother Joanna, sister, Maureen and family: Vincent, Marissa, Annalyse; step-siblings, Donny and Tami.

COVEN--Roslyn, (nee Friedman) passed away peacefully at home in West Palm Beach, FL on Wednesday, May 21, 2014. Predeceased by her husband of 55 years, Dr. Jesse H. Coven, she is survived by her loving daughter Marie Kaplowitz (Fred), grandchildren Matthew (Jessica), Ilene Rinn (Mitch), great grandchildren Stella and Leo Kaplowitz, brother Leroy and numerous nieces and nephews. Born in Brooklyn on August 3, 1913 to Ilona and Herman, Roslyn loved school and devoted her life to education-always learning, always teaching. A woman ahead of her time, she realized the importance of a college education and in the early 50's, she began studies at Brooklyn College, receiving an MS in Education at the age of 45. Her teaching career began at PS 183 in Brownsville and she retired as Assistant Principal of PS 100 in Coney Island. Jesse closed his dental practice, and they left Brooklyn for warm Boca Raton, FL where they enjoyed almost 20 years of happiness in their new community surrounded by good friends, fine music, good books, and HAM radio. Roslyn was a great raconteur and entertained many with her stories of childhood, travels, and teaching experiences. She lived her life with dignity and grace, always "ladylike", even when tossing back a good Scotch with friends. Roslyn will be missed.
CUMMINGS--Richard. Unquestioned champion of his beliefs, he was also great company. Our deep sympathy to Mary, Benjamin and Orson. Krogius Family

BRAUN--Harold S.,of Boynton Beach, FL, passed away on June 13, 2014, at the age of 91. Beloved husband of 56 years to Sonia Stan Braun; loving father of David Stan Braun (Ricki), New York City, and Paul Braun (Alexandra) of Fairfield, CT, and grandfather of Sara. Born in New York City, he grew up in Upper Manhattan. He served in North Africa and Italy in the Army Air Corps during WWII. He graduated from New York Law School and practiced law in New York City with his father, and then on his own, until his retirement. After a brief time in North Carolina, he retired to Florida where he enjoyed an active life. Harold was loved by family and friends and will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

BROWN--Arnold, born August 18, 1927, died peacefully surrounded by his loved ones on June 19 after a brief illness. Brilliant, wise, witty, and generous, he was adored by all whose lives he touched. Arnold was a veteran of the US Navy, graduate of the Bronx High School of Science and UCLA, and former chairman of the World Future Society. A futurist and pioneer in trend research, he established the consulting firm of Weiner Edrich Brown with Edie Weiner in 1977. He is survived by his daughter Cynthia Mooney and her husband Thomas; son Derek Brown and his wife Jennifer; three grandchildren, Paul and Kira Mooney and Ava Roberts; and brother Marvin Brown. He is predeceased by his daughters Pamela Roberts and Katherine Brown. His family and work meant everything to him, and his passing leaves a tremendous hole in the hearts of many. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Visual Arts Foundation for the Pamela Roberts Memorial Scholarship at the School of Visual Arts, 220 E. 23rd St., Suite 609, New York, NY 10010.

DRANOFF--Eliott. The man who loved and lived well, innovative entrepreneur, Eliott Dranoff, of Manhattan and Garrison, New York, and Sao Paulo, Brazil, died peacefully on June 27, in his 86th year, survived by his beloved wife, Dr. Marian Dunn and his cherished children, Nicole Dranoff Borger, Michael Dranoff and Roberto Dranoff, in laws, Edgar Borger and Adriana Dranoff. He adored his eight grandchildren and step-grandchildren and they adored him. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Sunday at 9:30am and burial at Rose Hill, Putnam Valley, NY.

CARDOZO--Barbara Schaffer, 92, of Westport Connecticut, and New York City, died peacefully at her home in Westport on June 20th, five short months after the passing of her best friend: her husband of 72 years, Benjamin Mordecai Cardozo. For the past 45 years she has been a renowned real estate broker in Manhattan, an Executive Vice President of Douglas Elliman Real Estate. Barbara is survived by her daughters, Enid Cardozo (Ed Lamon), Ellen Sonsino (Isaac Sonsino), five grandchildren and one great grandchild. Interment was private. A memorial and celebration of her life will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street on Sunday, June 29th at 1pm. Memorial contributions may be made to Temple Emanu-El's Philanthropic Fund in her name.

BERKO-CONDE--Susan Irene, 55, of Manhattan. Susan was the devoted mother of Daniel, Isabel, and Elena Conde. She was the beloved daughter of Irene and Edward Berko. Susan was survived by her brothers Edward and his wife Sharon, David and his wife Tiffany, Andrew and his wife Rozana and sister Elizabeth Berko. Susan was a loving aunt to Katie, Dorothy, Anneliese, and Diana Berko. Her former husband Cristobal Conde also survives her. The family will be receiving guests at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Sunday, June 29th from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday at 11am at Saint Ignatius Loyola RC Church. Park Avenue at East 84th Street.

CARDOZO--Barbara. It is with such a heavy heart that we say goodbye to our dear friend, Barbara. Barbara lost her beloved husband, Ben, a few months ago after 75 years together. Her heart was broken. And now ours too. Barbara was an Icon in Manhattan real estate and broke all records over the years. She believed our profession was worthwhile and just as meaningful as other high-level professions. She sought to always uphold a very high level of integrity in herself as well as others. Her love for Douglas Elliman was non-ending and to that we owe our gratitude to her. Our profession has lost a valuable colleague and we, a valuable friend. We will miss her. Dottie Herman, President & CEO, Douglas Elliman and all of my Douglas Elliman colleagues and friends.

COLLURA--John J. Long-time resident of Rockland County, NY, John J. Collura died on June 26, 2014 at Good Samaritan Hospital of unexpected complications related to Cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY February 19, 1947 to John and Carmella Collura, he is survived by his wife Mary Rose Collura, son John Collura, daughter Lori Collura, son-in-law Christophe Verhaegen, and seven grandchildren Riley, Kyle, Cassandra, Emma, Tyler, Ella, and John Lucas. John was a dedicated family man and an accomplished businessman. He began his career with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey when he was 23 years old. After 25 years working his way up the ranks he left as Director of Finance and COO. He held several CFO positions with major health care companies and ultimately traded his final position as CFO of Continuum Health Partners in NY, NY for retirement with his family at the age of 67. He was a member of Government Finance of America and President of the National Association of Accountants. He also held the esteemed titles of "Coach", "Dad" and "Pop" in many of life's other important activities. John's kindness and generosity were an inspiration to all who knew him. He lived his life with integrity, optimism, and an invigorating laugh. Services will be held for John on Sunday, June 29, at the Wanamaker and Carlough Funeral home in Suffern, NY from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass is Monday, June 30 at 11am in Sacred Heart Church Suffern, NY. wanamakercarlough.com

COOPER--R. John III, died June 11 at age 72. He graduated from Amherst College, Harvard Law School and earned a doctorate in English literature from Drew University. LLOYD--Dr. Henry R.,88, of West Orange died Friday, June 27, 2014. Born in Brooklyn, Dr. Lloyd lived in West Orange, Manhattan and then Hackensack before returning to West Orange two months ago. He served in the US Army during World War II, was a former optometrist, pharmaceuticals sales representative but is best remembered as being a loving husband and father. Dr. Lloyd leaves his wife, Mary (nee Small) and his daughter, Nina.

McLAUGHLIN--Paul, on June 26, 2014 at age 40. Beloved son of Edward and Patricia. Loving brother of Andrea. Adored grandson of Violet Keniery. His infectious laugh and wonderful sense of humor will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services 4pm today at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

BUCHMAN--Arlette. The Board of Trustees of the Victor D'Amico Institute of Art/The Art Barge expresses its deep sorrow at the loss of our dear friend, artist, and fellow trustee, Arlette Buchman. Our sympathies and condolences to her family. Christopher Kohan, President

MELTZER--Beulah, on June 27, 2014. Beloved wife of Irwin. Mother of Dana, Donald, Jonathan and Roger. Grandmother of Justin, Elizabeth, Martin, Julia, Constance, Eli, Alexa, Matthew, Ryan, Aiden and the late Declan. Service today, June, 30, 2014, 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.
GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers, The Lillys are sad to learn of the death of Mary Rodgers, composer, author, wife, mother, and trailblazer. Celebrate her life with us today The Lily Award Foundation Board

WINOKER--Irma, 80, of Baldwin, New York and Palm Beach, Florida died Sunday, June 29th. Devoted wife to Sidney Winoker and caring mother to Gail Winoker and her late son David Winoker. Survived by sister, Serene Hyman, and daughter-in-law, Jillian Winoker, and grandchildren, Jared, Hillary and Allyson Winoker. Service to be held at Glenville Cemetery in Greenwich, Connecticut on Monday June 30th. Donations can be made to Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America www.ccfa.org.

WOLF--Marvin. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, records with sorrow the loss of our long time member Marvin Wolf. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Eleanor and family. Paul Kotcher, President

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. Lincoln Center Theater is heartbroken over the death of Mary Rodgers Guettel. She was a beloved figure here. We were delighted to see her whenever she came around, and she came around a lot especially if we were producing her favorite musicals! If Mary believed in you, there was nobody more generous and loyal. The staff, the crews, the ushers indeed all who work at Lincoln Center Theater will miss this warm, funny, feisty, caring, savvy and deeply talented friend. Our sympathy to her large and devoted family. J. Tomilson Hill Chairman, Board of Directors Andre Bishop Producing Artistic Director

WALLACH--Eli, The Neighborhood Playhouse mourns the death of our esteemed graduate and board member Eli Wallach: a tireless champion of our school and constant inspiration to our students. His talent and spirit will be missed. Our condolences to Anne and the family. Board of Directors, The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre
ROTHMAN--Deborah. 7/27/40 - 6/30/07 Love always, Gary and David

KAHN--Helen M.,on June 28, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Morton. Loving mother and grandmother, generous and witty friend. Survived by children Jeffry, Kenneth and Douglas, their wives and seven grandchildren. Private services.

ROSENFELD--Sylvia. UJA-Federation of New York extends its condolences on the passing of Sylvia Rosenfeld, beloved mother of Susan Winter, and mother-in-law of Ben Winter, esteemed leaders in the Jewish community, whose commitment to helping those in need is honorable. We extend our condolences to her children, her grandchildren and her great-grandchildren in the Rosenfeld, Winter and Siblin families. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

WOLF--Marvin Leonard, died peacefully at the age of 92, surrounded by those who loved him. He is survived by his wife Eleanor of 66 years, daughter Barbara Emden, son Robert and his son-in-law James Emden. He was a man of great personal strength, dignity, commitment and decency - core values that defined who he was and how he led his life. His loyalty and compassion towards his family and friends were deeply valued. As a man whose work ethic was exemplary, he built a manufacturing and import business of fine crystal, recognized around the globe. He was a dynamo, dedicated to excellence in life, family and all of his pursuits. Traveling through the communist countries for business, he saw the hardship of those living in oppression. His sense of justice caused him to quietly help those he could to defect to America and start a new life. As a long-time Trustee of South Nassau Community Hospital, he was fiercely proud of its growth and achievements over the many years. He showed courage, strength and love right up until the very end. We are overjoyed that you kept the angels waiting for a long time, and now take solace to know that you are at peace and with your beloved daughter Marcia who is there to embrace you. We thank you for letting us know that we were loved everyday of our lives, as we have loved you and will forever. Your loving family.

SALZBERG--Shirley (Lee), of Westborough, MA, formerly of Hewlett, New York, passed away peacefully on June 18, 2014 at the age of 90. Lee will be dearly missed by her children, Pam (Larry) Tabb, Malcolm (Lisa) Roth, Allan (Cheryll) Salzberg and Marc (Dale) Salzberg and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her two beloved husbands, Morton Roth and Emanuel Salzberg. She was kind, but strong, incredibly intelligent, yet humble, patient and dignified and wore a perpetual smile with an ever present twinkle in her eye.
STRUHL--Dr. Bernard. Happy Birthday. Your family misses you. Love, Judi

POLLACK--Adela Eugenia Brief, daughter of Morris and Marie Brief, wife of the late Lewis Pollack, sister of Saloma Grose and the late Paulette Liebowitz, died on June 19, age 79, from complications following surgery for a perforated colon. Her sister, in-laws, stepchildren, cousins, nieces, nephews, and many friends mourn her death acutely. Della was beloved for her warm intelligence and her rare ability to listen. Contributions in Della's name should be sent to WNYC.
WOLF--Marvin, goodbye dear friend. We will miss you. We all loved you. Carole and Marvin

NEUSTADTER--Milton. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Milton Neustadter, beloved father of Lisa and father-in-law of Lawrence Cohen, dear friends, greatly committed to helping those in need. We extend our sympathies to the entire Neustadter and Cohen families. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

MUSCAT--Erwin, Born in New York City on September 17, 1924 to Bess and Lewis Muscat, died on Monday, June 23. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School, he served in the Navy during WWII. Erwin worked for RCA and then from 1967 to 1982 taught at the Horace Mann School, winning the yearbook dedication in 1973. He was an intrepid traveler, seeking destinations off the beaten track. A quintessential New Yorker, he lived his whole life within one mile of his birthplace on the Upper West Side. He took advantage of all the city had to offer, specializing in the obscure and uncrowded. He is mourned by his wife of 59 years, Audrey; brother Robert; two sons, Daniel and Paul; six grandchildren; many cousins, nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held in the autumn.

GUCK--John M.D.,on June 25, 2014. Beloved Husband of the late Joan (nee) Klein. Devoted Father of Joan Guck, Kathy Smith, Mary Lane, Maureen Novotne and the late Jean Guck. Also survived by seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell- The Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave (81st), Monday 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola 980 Park Ave, (84th), Tuesday 10am.

BERGER--Myra J.,passed away on June 24th, 2014. Beloved wife of Leon, loving mother to Kathy (Louis Schorsch), and Roberta; proud grandmother of Alexander, Matthew, Laurence, Emilie and Olivia. Funeral services were held in Evanston, Illinois.

BERKO-CONDE--Susan Irene, 55, of Manhattan. Susan was the devoted mother of Daniel, Isabel, and Elena Conde. She was the beloved daughter of Irene and Edward Berko. Susan was survived by her brothers Edward and his wife Sharon, David and his wife Tiffany, Andrew and his wife Rozana and sister Elizabeth Berko. Susan was a loving aunt to Katie, Dorothy, Anneliese, and Diana Berko. Her former husband Cristobal Conde also survives her. The family will be receiving guests at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Sunday, June 29th from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday at 11am at Saint Ignatius Loyola RC Church. Park Avenue at East 84th Street.

ZIMMERMAN--Kenneth.Kenneth "Kenny" Zimmerman, son of Jerome and Renee Zimmerman, beloved Husband, Father, and Grandfather, passed away June 25, 2014, at his home in Edgewater, New Jersey. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Zimmerman attended Poly Prep High School and then graduated from The University of Miami in 1972. Shortly thereafter, he started Kenar Enterprises with Murray Levy. In the early 90's, Zimmerman was one of the first and one of the strongest leaders in philanthropic efforts in the Fashion Industry. He used his company's largest advertising vehicle, the billboard at One Times Square, under the Sony TV screen for 10 years. It was there that the world could see his provocative advertisements of global social issues, such as AIDS, Elisabeth Glaser's Pediatric AIDS Foundation, and Evelyn Lauder's Breast Cancer Research Foundation. His well-known supermodels, Linda Evangelista, Helena Christensen, Naomi Campbell, and Claudia Schiffer were the cause of many traffic jams in Times Square. One of his most celebrated campaigns featured an advertisement shot in Sicily with Linda Evangelista and seven Sicilian women dressed in black; limited editions of the photograph were sold with proceeds going to an AIDS education group. The International Center for Photography included it as one of the '20 most important fashion photographs" ever. Kenar opened stores world-wide, but in 1994, the New York flagship on Madison Avenue opened to much fan-fare as Mrs. Evelyn Lauder, Mayor Giuliani, Elizabeth Hurley, Linda Evangelista, and Mr. Zimmerman cut the huge Pink Ribbon dedicating a portion of Kenar's sales that October for Breast Cancer Awareness month to BCRF. After selling the brand Kenar to the Pegasus Fund, Kenny purchased other brands that were in bankruptcy and rebuilt them. Some of these brands were Schrader, St. Gillian, A.J. Bari, Freeway, In Transit, and Hero Group (Black Tie by Oleg Cassini). In 1999, Kenny formed a new venture, Emma Black and Zola Evening, producing sportswear and evening wear for major department stores around the world. Never satisfied with all of his accomplishments, in 2003, Kenny developed Calvin Klein Outerwear, a newly acquired license by Calvin Klein Corporation. He was proud to be able to support many charities and causes. Another project dear to his heart was working with The Partnership for the Homeless, along with restaurants across the city helping to feed those less fortunate. He was on the Board of The Jack Martin Fund at Mount Sinai Hospital and the Board of Directors at the JCC on the Palisades. He was also on the Advisory Board of Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. Kenny's family was more important than any of his companies or positions. Arlene Zimmerman, his beloved wife of 42 years; his proud, loving children, Nicole, Zachary, and Ryan Zimmerman; his grandchildren, Ethan and Jordan Zimmerman; and his sister, Leslie Daspin, survive him. His eldest son Matthew predeceased him in 2012.

WALLACH--Eli. The City College of New York mourns the passing of its distinguished alumnus, Eli Wallach, Class of 1938. Mr. Wallach earned a master's degree in education from City College and remained a supporter of his alma mater over the years. He gave to scholarships and the College's Annual Fund administered by The City College Fund. In 2010, the Alumni Association of The City College honored Mr. Wallach for his outstanding postgraduate achievements with its Townsend Harris Medal. To millions of fans, Mr. Wallach was a Hollywood legend who shared the screen with some of motion picture's biggest stars. To the City College, he was proudly one of ours. On behalf of our students, faculty and staff, sincerest condolences to the Wallach family. Lisa S. Coico, President

POGO--Oscar M.D.,of Pelham, NY passed away Wednesday, June 25th at the age of 86. Oscar was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina to Bernardo and Sara Pogo. While a medical resident at the University of Buenos Aires, he met his wife Beatriz Garcia Tunon, before marrying in 1956. In 1959, Oscar traveled to the United States as a Guggenheim fellow to work at Columbia University, and subsequently Rockefeller University. In 1964 Oscar permanently moved to the US with his wife and two children, Gustave and Gabriela. Oscar had a strong passion for his work as a medical researcher at the New York Blood Center, from which he retired in 2000. Oscar was a founding member of the Kimball Research Institute of the New York Blood Center, was a recipient of the Rassmussen Merit Award from the American Association of Blood Banks, and has authored over 100 peer-reviewed publications. Oscar will be remembered as a passionate, resolute, and inspiring person who loved photography, travel, the arts, as well as his family. Oscar will be missed by his wife Beatriz Pogo, M.D.; his son, Gustave and his wife Janis, his daughter Gabriela and her husband Gordon; his grandchildren Michael, Kathryn, Tyler, and Kyle; as well as his sister Beatriz Kon, who lives in Argentina. A celebration of Oscar's life will be at a later date. To send a condolence or light a candle in Oscar's memory please log onto www.pelhamfuneral.com. Pelham Funeral Home 914-738-1060.

GUETTEL--Mary Rodgers. The Dramatists Guild mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Mary Rodgers. A Guild Council member for nearly fifty years and the daughter of one of the Guild's past presidents, Richard Rodgers, Mary had a lifetime of involvement with our organization, and her intelligence, generosity and fierce support of her fellow writers will always be remembered and appreciated. As a writer who had the pleasure of working with her (on Working), I can attest to her talent, creativity and good humor as a collaborator. Our deepest sympathies to her son, Guild member Adam Guettel, and to all her family, friends and loved ones at this time. Stephen Schwartz, President The Dramatists Guild of America

LETHBRIDGE--John Dodd. John Dodd "Jack" Lethbridge, passed away on June 26, 2014 at his home in Wilton, CT. He was 86 years old. The son of George M. Lethbridge and Gertrude Dodd, Jack was raised in Upper Montclair, NJ. He graduated from The Hill School in Pottstown, PA and Washington and Lee University in Lexington, VA. He served in the US Marine Corps during the Korean conflict, achieving the rank of Captain. Jack spent most of his professional career at the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation where he retired as Vice President and General Manager of the National Distillers division. Jack was predeceased by his wife of 43 years, Betsy Emmaline Lethbridge. He is survived by his daughter Leah Ovington Lethbridge, his son John D. Lethbridge, Jr. and John's wife Karen Boutelle Lethbridge, his grandson John Dodd Lethbridge, III and his granddaughter Caroline Renee Lethbridge. There will be a Memorial Service on Wednesday, July 2, 2014 at 11am at the Wilton Congregational Church, 70 Ridgefield Rd., Wilton, CT. Interment will follow at Hillside Cemetery, 165 Ridgefield Rd., Wilton, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Wilton Library Association or the Wilton Volunteer Ambulance Corps.

GOLDSMITH--Clifford H. FOJP Service Corporation and its Board of Directors record with sincere sorrow the passing of Clifford Goldsmith, who served on our board for 29 years. Our deepest sympathy is offered to the entire Goldsmith family. Michael Zimmerman Chairman, FOJP

McNICOL--Donald E.,92, died peacefully on June 29, at his home in Oyster Bay Cove, NY after a short illness. He is survived by his devoted wife of 28 years, Carmen Gallego, his five children and their spouses: Elaine and John Postley, Janet and Tony Barton, Dr. Donald McNicol, Christena and Paul McNicol and Andrea Gallego McNicol, his grandchildren: John Postley, Scott and Chris Barton, Will and Katie McNicol and Campbell McNicol, and his great grandchildren: Beatrix and Griffin Postley, Oscar and Hunter Barton, and Henry and Charlotte Barton. Don McNicol was a gentleman, an athlete and a scholar. He was a great Harvard football player, War Class of 1943. He married the late Doris Egues in 1943, became a father in December, 1944 and went to War 10 days later. He was 23. 15 months later, he returned, graduating from the Harvard Law School in 1947. He joined the esteemed firm of Davis, Polk, Wardwell, Sunderland & Kendall as an associate. Later he formed his own distinguished firm, Hall, McNicol, Hamilton & Clark. Throughout his life, he served on numerous business, philanthropic and club boards, including the Harvard Club of New York City, the Boys & Girls Club of America, American Maize-Products Company and currently, the Thomas Publishing Company. He loved the game of golf, playing at home and at the world's great courses (including the great Scottish Link courses) with his two sons. Fishing was a passion in Montauk, Canada, Europe, Florida and the Carribean, imbuing his sons with the same enthusiasm. He loved his boat, "Man O War" and the "Mosquito Fleet," a small flotilla comprised of his sons, his pals and his brave wife, Carmen, which "cruised" around "intrepidly" in bad weather and worse seas. All in good fun. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Don's name would be gratefully received by Friends of the Bay, 2 Town- send Sq. 2, Oyster Bay, NY. 11771 or the Community Fund of Oyster Bay at 200 Sunset Rd, Oyster Bay, NY 11771. Visitation: Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., July 1, from 6-9pm. Funeral: St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave, July 2 at 10am. Memorial Service being planned for late August.

KING--Rollin White, passed away peacefully on Thursday, June 26, 2014 in Dallas, Texas from complications of a stroke. Mr. King was born in Cleveland, Ohio on April 10, 1931 to Griffin and Elizabeth King. He graduated from Shaker Heights High School in Ohio, received his BA from Case Western Reserve and an MBA from Harvard Business School. Mr. King was an amazing entrepreneur who famously came up with the idea for Southwest Airlines, the world's most successful airline. His idea for better service, low cost air travel was revolutionary and changed air travel worldwide. He was the Founder and first Chairman and President of Southwest Airlines Co. and was a Director and an Executive Committee member from the formation of the company until he retired from the Board after 40 years in May 2006 at the age of 75. After leaving the management of the airline Mr. King engaged in other business ventures as well as led executive education seminars and he did consulting as a principal of Rollin King Associates until his retirement on December 31, 1995. Subsequently he was principally engaged in private investing. Mr. King had a passion for hunting and fishing, which he shared with his children and grandchildren. In particular he loved Africa, its people and wildlife. He went on more than 20 safaris during which he often enjoyed sitting around the fire listening to or telling stories with family and friends. He was happy to donate generously to a village school in Tanzania. He also was an avid golfer his entire life. He was a member of Brook Hollow Golf Club in Dallas, The Old Baldy Club in Saratoga, Wyoming; and Eldorado Country Club in Indian Wells, California, and served on the Board of Visitors for UT Southwestern University Hospitals and Clinics. He is a former member of Little Sandy Hunting and Fishing Club and the Chevaliers du Tastevin. At various times, he was a trustee of the Dallas Symphony, St. John's College of Annapolis, Maryland and Santa Fe, New Mexico, and the Dallas Museum of Art for which he served on the Executive Committee. He also was President of the Board of the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, New Mexico and Chairman of the Executive Committee of the College of Santa Fe. He was an Honorary Life Member of the Board of Directors of the School of American Research in Santa Fe and the Southwest Outward Bound School. He is survived by his children Rollin W. King, Jr. of San Antonio, and Edward P. King and his daughter-in-law Wendy of Dallas, stepchildren Claire Dewar, Tony Dewar and wife Juli, and Molly Froelich and husband Henry; grandchildren Ann E King, Rollin W. King, III, Ellie King, Prescott King, Charlie King, Grace Dewar, Johnny Dewar, Ella Froelich, and Hal Froelich; his sister Betty King of Washington DC and his friend and companion in his later life Anne Reed Rooth. He is predeceased by his wife Mary Ella Ownby King and first wife Marcia Gygli King and grandchild Will Froelich. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be directed to Southwestern Medical Foundation, Reagan Place at Old Parkland, 3963 Maple Avenue, Suite 100, Dallas, TX 75219 or online at www.swmedical.org to support the Rollin and Mary Ella King Fund for Research and Treatment of Liver Diseases., or to the charity of your choice. A memorial service will be planned in the fall in Dallas.

WISE--Harry H.,succumbed to lung cancer on June 12, in Stamford, CT, after two years of valiant battle against multiple illnesses. Born in Boston on October 1, 1938, to Robert and Ethel Pastan Wise, he attended Lawrence Elementary School, Brookline High School, and graduated with honors from Harvard. In his early adulthood he was a captain in the US Air Force, earned an MBA at Harvard Business School, and began a long, varied, and distinguished career in business and finance. He worked for McKinsey and Company, Citibank, American Capital Partners, several of his own companies, and various others. His commitment to education was salient throughout his life, in many philanthropic activities and his own unceasing learning. In later life he earned a masters degree from Columbia University in Organizational Psychology and Leadership. Music was central to his life, from undergraduate singing with the Harvard Gilbert and Sullivan Players, to his acclaim as a jazz pianist and certified jazz educator, his patronage of the musical arts and active engagement in many musical ensembles such as the Canterbury Choral Society and Uptown Sound. An avid sports fan and player, passionate follower of the Boston Red Sox, he also established a library endowment at Harvard to build a collection in Judaica, supported a pro-bono summer camp for the elderly, and led the establishment of the Wise-Marcus Scholarship Fund in the Syracuse University Honors Program. In countless ways large and small, visible and invisible he lived a life of constant generosity toward others. He was beloved for his swift and sparkling humor and his intense loyalty to his many friends. Wise lived in Manhattan until a recent move to Stamford, with frequent summers spent at his beach home in Sagaponack on Long Island. He is survived by his loving wife and musical partner Sheila Johnson Wise, his stepdaughter Alisa MacNeille Kuhn and stepson Eben MacNeille, his sisters Sara Kane and Cheryl Skura, his nieces and nephews Gwen Kane-Wanger, Jonathan Kane, Sam Skura, Stacey Zedeck, Rachel Burris, their families, his beloved cousins, and a very large number of devoted friends, old and new, who mourn his untimely passing. A celebration of his life will be held in Stamford on September 28.
PHILIPS--Beatrice Mellicker, died June 27, 2014, at age 90. Wife of the late Alvin. Mother of Marian, Rick, Carl, Julie, Wendy. Grandmother, aunt, cousin, friend. Memorial in New York in the fall.
RICHTER--Blanche, on July 1st. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Richter. Cherished mother of Elinor Richter. Services private.
RICHTER--Blanche. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to her family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

ROWAN--Barbara. Our sympathy and condolences to the Rowan family. Our cousin Barbara was an exceptional individual who will be remembered for her sweetness, kindness, perseverance in adversity and devotion to her immediate family, extended family and many friends. Barbara will be missed and thought of often. Joy and Walter Samuels

COHEN--Elias A. Although 62 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1st, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 96th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc.Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President

RUDEL--Julius. The Department of Neurology at Columbia University Medical Center is greatly saddened by the death of our long-time friend and supporter, conductor Julius Rudel. After the untimely death in 1984 of his wife, Dr. Rita Rudel, a distinguished neuropsychologist at Columbia and New York Presbyterian Hospital, Maestro Rudel established the annual Rita Rudel Lecture to showcase the most impressive advances in neuropsychology and cognitive neuroscience. In 2013, he established the Rudel Prize for Neuropsychology Research to support a junior investigator at Columbia whose research is judged to be of high quality and among the most promising in terms of impact. Maestro Rudel's presence at the Rudel Lecture will be sorely missed, and we extend our condolences to his family.
COHEN--Elias A. Ever present in our thoughts, we lovingly recall our E.A.Cohen who left us 62 years ago on July 2, 1952. The Cohen Family The Elias A. Cohen Foundation

SEAVEY--Robert W.,Bob Seavey was my friend and business associate. His word was his bond and I enjoyed many hours in his company at dinner, negotiating deals and especially at his compound in East Hampton where Bob and his wife Phyllis so graciously entertained. I was privileged to have known and worked with Bob for many years and he will be greatly missed. My sincere condolences to Avery, Emily, Nealle and Eric Seltzer. Hank Sopher

VAN ETTEN--Robert, our hearts ache for our honorable, honest and compassionate friend, Bob. He deeply mourned the loss of many friends on 9/11. Bob served the Treasury Department, US Customs, the Federal Criminal Investigators Association, and the Port Authority with impeccable integrity and leadership. Our hearts go out to Terri, Rob and David on their loss. We were proud to be his dear friends. Nancy and Peter Brown

GOODMAN--Bernard, 88, passed away June 30, 2014. Many complimentary words have been used to describe my wonderful husband of 64 years - my Bernie. He was a kind, sweet, true gentleman and excelled in all he did through hard work and possession of "Yiddisher Kop." He formed an international engineering and construction corporation that occupied three floors in the World Trade Center. Bernie won a math medal at City College and played on their varsity sports teams and he just loved golf. He was a past president of Menorah Home and Hospital in Brooklyn. But his true loves were his family: his two daughters, Alyce and Sue and her husband, Bob; his granddaughter, Rae and her husband Evan; and his grandsons Ben and David. He was so looking forward to welcoming a great-grandchild in the fall. His love also encompassed his wonderful friends, brother-in-law, cousin, nieces and a nephew who all greatly respected him and returned his affection. Graveside service will be 11am Monday, July 7, 2014 at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. www.levitt-weinstein.com Rest in peace, my darling. Mimi.

NOLTE--Henry R. Jr.,died on June 30, 2014 in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan at the age of 90. He was born in New York City on March 3, 1924. He attended Duke University in 1941 and joined the US Navy. He served in the Pacific during World War II on an attack transport as a Lieutenant J.G. He graduated from Duke in 1947 and received an L.L.B. from University of Pennsylvania Law School in 1949. He joined Cravath, Swaine & Moore as an associate. In 1961 he joined Ford Motor Co., becoming General Counsel of Philco, a Ford subsidiary, in 1962. He then returned to the Ford headquarters as Assistant General Counsel of Ford. In 1967 he went to Europe as General Counsel of Ford of Europe, which consolidated the various European Ford divisions. This was a wonderful opportunity for him and his family to enjoy living abroad. In 1974 he became Vice President and General Counsel of Ford Motor Co.; this was an extremely fulfilling job with many challenges which he enjoyed. He retired from Ford in 1989 and became Chairman of Miller Canfield, a Michigan law firm, for five years. He was a director of Charter One Bank and on the Board of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, the Cranbrook Education Community, Gulfstream Golf Club, and the Ocean Club of Florida. He is survived by his beloved wife Frances of 63 years, and four adoring children: his son Henry Reed Nolte, and daughters Gwynne Conn, Jennifer Stevens, and Suzanne Saunders. In addition, he is also survived by eight grandchildren: Diana Conn; Hannah, Emma, and Henry Nolte; Suzanna and Alexandra Stevens; and Isabella and Ethan Saunders. He was a wonderful family man, and a great father and grandfather. He loved bird shooting in England, Denmark and Spain with his wife, who did watercolor painting. He also loved playing tennis and golf with his children and having wonderful family holidays in Florida at their house at the Ocean Club.

EFRON--Hyman, Beloved husband of late Frances. Loving father of Leah (Scott), Martin and Amy Shapiro. Cherished grandpa of Gabrielle, Joshua, Ally and Justine. Devoted brother of Judy (Frank) Wolf. Services 1pm today at Congregation Mt. Sinai, 250 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn.

DONNELLY--Maureen,We at Penguin Random House are deeply saddened by the death of Penguin Books Vice President and Director of Publicity Maureen Donnelly. In her thirty-four years at the company, Maureen was a mentor to many, a kind, generous, gentle person who inspired everyone she worked with, both inside and outside Penguin. Her irreverent sense of humor, unfailing optimism, and dedication to family and coworkers were second to none. Maureen worked tirelessly to promote reading, bringing attention to countless books and authors in both her professional and personal life: she was a trustee of the Roselle Library Board in Roselle, NJ, and a founding member of the Friends of the Roselle Library. Our hearts go out to her beloved husband, Joe, her beautiful daughters Julia and Bridget, her devoted mother, Dorothy, and sisters Susan and Janet. It was an honor to be her friend and colleague, and we are better people for having known her.

MANDELL SCHENKER--Leonore, on July 1, 2014, at age 95. Born in Brooklyn, Leonore spent much of her life in Hewlett, New York, and later in West Palm Beach and Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. The beloved wife of the late Herbert Mandell and later Jack Schenker, Leonore was a generous philanthropist, skillful golfer, voracious reader, talented flower arranger and gracious hostess. Her playfulness, vitality, and humor will be missed by her many friends as well as by her devoted and grateful children Richard Mandell, James Mandell, and Margery Mandell Sugarman and their spouses as well as by her grandchildren Matthew, Erin, Joshua, Allison, Jake, Alix and Katie and her great-grandchildren Max and Julia.

BOULOS--Mary McDonald, 78, beloved wife of Alfred and mother, passed away June 23, 2014, in Houston, TX. Mary was devoted to her family, had a beautiful smile and personality, a strong faith, and elegant style. Born in Toronto, Ontario, Mary spent her life as a nurse and mother in New York, London, UK and Houston. Mary is survived by her six children: Mary, Lizzie, John, Peggy, Katie, and Suzie, and 11 grandchildren. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated Thursday, July 17 at 4pm, The Lady Chapel, St. Patrick's Cathedral, NYC.

KOCH--Peter, on July 1, surrounded by his family. Beloved father of Jackie and David Ellenson, Danny and Nicole, and Robert and Colleen. Cherished by his grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Loving partner of Elinor Silverman. Long time owner of the Town Shop, he was himself an Upper West Side institution. Devoted to the New York Giants, horse-racing, the Fieldston School, and his weekly poker game. Funeral services on Thursday, July 3 at 11am, Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions to the Fieldston School or the Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute at Mt. Sinai Hospital.

BERKWITS--Frances Estelle, MS, CSW, died the morning of June 29, 2014, seven weeks before her 92nd birthday. Her funeral will take place at 9:30am on Wednesday, July 2, 2014, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at the corner of East 81st Street and she will be interred at the New Montefiore Cemetery, at 11:30am. She will be irreplaceably missed by her children, Roberta Kolar and Dr. Kieve Berkwits and his wife Linda Berkwits and her grandchildren, with whom she had a special closeness, Amos Elberg and Jacob Elberg and his wife Lacey Elberg, David Berkwits and Abby Berkwits. Her love and joy in her great-grandchildren Anna Sophie Elberg and Zoe Esther Elberg were a bookend for a life well-lived. She will be missed as well by her many friends, and the countless people she worked with over a career of more than fifty years. Shiva will begin after the burial until 9:00pm, Wednesday evening, on Thursday from 1:00 to 4:00pm and 6:00pm to 9:00pm, and on Friday from 12:00 to 2:00pm, at 181 East 73rd Street, Apt. 10 D, New York, New York.

LEDERMAN--Harold N.,died July 1, 2014, of complications from cardiac amyloid disease. He was born July 12, 1934 in New York City. He was a graduate of New York University and New York Law School. Harold was a devoted family man. He was married to his first love, Adele Tutnauer Lederman, from 1957 until her untimely death in 1992. He was blessed a second time in 1994 when he married Lila Rifkin Lederman, with whom he shared an equally joyous life. Harold is survived by his three sons and their spouses, Bruce and Sheri Lederman, Jeffrey and Carol Lederman and Steven and Laurie Lederman. He is also survived by Lila's children and their spouses, Shelley and David Pearlberg and Robin and Andrew Rifkin. He is lovingly remembered by 12 grandchildren and step-grandchildren, Ben, Jason, Alex, Addie, Emily, Ashley and Joseph Lederman, as well as Amanda Pearlberg, Jamie and Allison Rifkin, and Jennifer and Rachel Halper. Harold was loved and respected by an enormous number of friends, clients and colleagues as well as his family. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him.

BARASH--Irvin, Born in Philadelphia on August 13, 1938 to Benjamin and Beatrice Barash, passed away peacefully on Monday, June 30. A graduate of Drexel University and Columbia Business School, he was President of Vencon Management, Inc., a venture capital firm, which has been involved in all aspects of renewable energy. In the early 80's, he provided his expertise to such companies as Atlantic Richfield. In the mid 90's, under contract to the US Department of Energy, he created a venture initiative, the NREL Growth Forums for new renewable energy ventures. Prior to VMI, he was Director of Planning for BASF Corporation, responsible for mergers and acquisitions at W.R. Grace, and Assistant to the President of Belco Petroleum. He has also been on numerous US Government panels regarding the commercialization of alternative energy, photonic and other technologies. During the early 1970's, he was Director of Economic Studies for the Price Commission, a White House initiative to stabilize pricing. He is mourned by his wife of 44 years, AnneMarie, and his daughter, Lisa.

JOSEPHSON--Cynthia, age 83, passed on June 30, 2014 in New York City. Cynthia was devoted to her family and was passionate about her many years spent in her beloved New York City. Beloved wife of the late Gabe and devoted mother to her four children, Mark, Seth, David and Julie and mother-in-law to Mike, Susan, Jeanne and Debra. Cherished grandmother to her 10 granddaughters, Nicole, Samantha, Olivia, Cara, Anna, Rachel, Isabella, Sophia, Nina and Ruby. Loving sister of Leonora Schaefer. Services Thursday, July 3rd, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

INTRILIGATOR--Michael, an internationally renowned UCLA economist, died in Los Angeles June 23, age 76. He was an expert in economic theory, econometrics, health economics, strategy and arms control, peace and security, and transitioning economies. He wrote, edited, or co-edited more than 300 published papers, journal articles, and books, including the 28-volume Handbook of Economics series and the influential, enduring textbook Mathematical Optimization and Economic Theory. He was a passionate educator and a much sought-after public speaker. Among his many honors, he was the only US economist to be elected a Foreign Member of the Russian Academy of Sciences. He was also a member of both the International Institute for Strategic Studies and the Council on Foreign Relations, as well as a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the Econometric Society. Mike was a warm, gentle, and generous man. He loved family, teaching, colleagues, classical music, and coconut cake. Born in Freeport, NY, he received degrees from MIT and Yale. He is survived by his wife Devrie, their four sons, nine grandchildren, and his brother Marc. Donations may be made in his name to Economists for Peace and Security (epsusa.org) or to the American Cancer Society.
HIRSCH--Theodore "Ted." Dearest Ted, forever a deep part of our lives, you will always be in our hearts. Love from all the Emmerichs

ADLER--Norma, 84, of Framingham, formerly of Manhattan, died peacefully on June 30, 2014, at home. Born in Philadelphia on November 30, 1929, the daughter of the late William Greenberg and Ida (Charney) Greenberg, Norma graduated from Philadelphia High School for Girls and Drexel Institute of Technology. She pursued a career in advertising, and later developed an advertising and marketing industry executive search business in Manhattan. Following her love of art, she enrolled in the Art Students League of New York at the age of 60, and found her passion in abstract art and a community. She lived life fully, enjoying theater, travel, social action and a circle of close friends. She leaves behind her dear cousins, Karen Margolis and Victor Nussbaum of Framingham, and their children (her grandchildren) Leah, Daniel and Jared, and her dear friend Ina Torton. She is survived by her loving sister Annette Bodzin, and nieces and nephew, Kate Scheinman, Robert Scheinman and Wendy Kadens. She was predeceased by her son, John Adler. Graveside services will be held July 3, 2014, 11:30am at Roosevelt Memorial Park, Trevose, PA. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be sent to The Art Students League of New York to help fund the Norma Adler Scholarship.
RICHTER--Blanche, on July 1st. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Richter. Cherished mother of Elinor Richter. Services private.

REVENTLOW--Margaret (Peggy) Astor Drayton, of Litchfield, CT; Vero Beach, FL and formerly New York City, peacefully passed away on June 14, 2014. She was 98 years old and lucid and laughing until the day she died. Peggy was born in London, England on December 20th, 1915. Her father, William Astor Drayton, was a great grandson of John Jacob Astor, the English emigrant who created the first corporate trust in America and built a fur trading empire that eventually extended into Canada. In 1942, Peggy became Countess Margaret Reventlow when she married Danish Count Court Haugwitz-Hardenberg Reventlow. In 1974, she started a pilot program of recording books for the blind in Litchfield. This later became known as the Connecticut Volunteer Services for the Blind and Handicapped, for which Peggy was Founder and President until 2011, when she was 95 years old. She was a long-standing member of the Colony Club in New York City. Peggy's mission was to provide blind and handicapped persons with the same range and quality of reading materials available to sighted public library patrons and she tirelessly and selflessly dedicated herself to the pursuit of this mission for 37 years. Peggy was also an exceptionally gifted and internationally recognized sculptress and painter. Her art has been exhibited in New York, Palm Beach, London, Connecticut and Nantucket, including exhibitions at The Alwyn Gallery in London and at Hammer Galleries and at Tiffany and Co. in New York. She is survived by her daughter, Alida "Binky" Albright of Pinehurst, NC and her son Richard Haugwitz-Reventlow of Palm Beach FL.; two granddaughters, Leslie Merrell Zimmerman and her husband Mark of Chapel Hill, NC and Ashley Cox Good of Sydney, Australia and five great-grand children. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the charity Peggy was closely involved with for so much of her life: CVSBH, Inc. Oliver Wolcott Library, South Street Litchfield, CT 06759 Phone: (860) 567-8578.

CAMOGLU--Ishik, The Women's Forum of New York records with sorrow the death of our colleague Ishik Camoglu, a brilliant businesswoman, an astute advocate of international affairs and a passionate philanthropist. Deepest sympathy to her children, Etkin and Eser. Ami Kaplan, President Rita B. Crotty, Executive Director

COWLES--Nancy Cardozo, died on Wednesday, July 2, 2014, at the age of 94. Nancy was a poet, short story writer, and biographer. She was a great beauty and a creator of beauty in her writing, her gardens, and her house in New Milford, CT. She was born Nancy Cardozo in New York City on Oct. 31, 1919. She attended the Dalton School and Swarthmore College. Her writing career spanned many decades in which she published short stories in the New Yorker, three books of poetry, and a biography of Maud Gonne, Irish revolutionary and muse of the poet Yeats. Nancy was married twice, to Jim Egleson and Russell Cowles, both of whom predeceased her. She is survived by her partner of many years, Dr. Aileen Ward, two sons, Nick Egleson and Jan Egleson, four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Memorial service to be announced.

DONNELLY--Maureen,We at Penguin Random House are deeply saddened by the death of Penguin Books Vice President and Director of Publicity Maureen Donnelly. In her thirty-four years at the company, Maureen was a mentor to many, a kind, generous, gentle person who inspired everyone she worked with, both inside and outside Penguin. Her irreverent sense of humor, unfailing optimism, and dedication to family and coworkers were second to none. Maureen worked tirelessly to promote reading, bringing attention to countless books and authors in both her professional and personal life: she was a trustee of the Roselle Library Board in Roselle, NJ, and a founding member of the Friends of the Roselle Library. Our hearts go out to her beloved husband, Joe, her beautiful daughters Julia and Bridget, her devoted mother, Dorothy, and sisters Susan and Janet. It was an honor to be her friend and colleague, and we are better people for having known her.

GOLDBERG--Rebecca. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Rebecca Goldberg, beloved daughter of Irene and Andrew Goldberg. We extend our deepest condolences to Rebecca's parents; her siblings Alana, Gabrielle, Dahlia, Ari, and Lora; and to her entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO
SKLAR--Robert, Dec 3, 1936-July 3,2011 "So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past. Love from family and friends Adrienne

KOCH--Peter, on July 1, surrounded by his family. Beloved father of Jackie and David Ellenson, Danny and Nicole, and Robert and Colleen. Cherished by his grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Loving partner of Elinor Silverman. Long time owner of the Town Shop, he was himself an Upper West Side institution. Devoted to the New York Giants, horse-racing, the Fieldston School, and his weekly poker game. Funeral services on Thursday, July 3 at 11am, Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions to the Fieldston School or the Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute at Mt. Sinai Hospital.
WEILER--Gerald E. 5/8/28 -7/3/05 - Still charming us all. Loved and missed every day. With love, Helen

MANDELL SCHENKER--Leonore, on July 1, 2014, at age 95. Born in Brooklyn, Leonore spent much of her life in Hewlett, New York, and later in West Palm Beach and Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. The beloved wife of the late Herbert Mandell and later Jack Schenker, Leonore was a generous philanthropist, skillful golfer, voracious reader, talented flower arranger and gracious hostess. Her playfulness, vitality, and humor will be missed by her many friends as well as by her devoted and grateful children Richard Mandell, James Mandell, and Margery Mandell Sugarman and their spouses as well as by her grandchildren Matthew, Erin, Joshua, Allison, Jake, Alix and Katie and her great-grandchildren Max and Julia.

RUDEL--Julius. The Department of Neurology at Columbia University Medical Center is greatly saddened by the death of our long-time friend and supporter, conductor Julius Rudel. After the untimely death in 1984 of his wife, Dr. Rita Rudel, a distinguished neuropsychologist at Columbia and New York Presbyterian Hospital, Maestro Rudel established the annual Rita Rudel Lecture to showcase the most impressive advances in neuropsychology and cognitive neuroscience. In 2013, he established the Rudel Prize for Neuropsychology Research to support a junior investigator at Columbia whose research is judged to be of high quality and among the most promising in terms of impact. Maestro Rudel's presence at the Rudel Lecture will be sorely missed, and we extend our condolences to his family.

LUBLINER--Seymour. Seymour "Simcha" Lubliner, Holocaust survivor and treasured father and grandfather, passed away July 2 at the age of 102. Formerly of Rockaway Beach, NY via Lodz, Poland, his thunderous voice, vivid stories, and utter selflessness continue to inspire. He rests in peace with his daughter Zysele, his wife Chana, and is survived by his loving daughters Shirley and Charlotte, and his grandchildren Jaime, Melissa, Russell and Jeffrey. Funeral July 3. russrubin@gmail.com for info.

VAN ETTEN--Robert, our hearts ache for our honorable, honest and compassionate friend, Bob. He deeply mourned the loss of many friends on 9/11. Bob served the Treasury Department, US Customs, the Federal Criminal Investigators Association, and the Port Authority with impeccable integrity and leadership. Our hearts go out to Terri, Rob and David on their loss. We were proud to be his dear friends. Nancy and Peter Brown

GARMENT--Martin, age 95, of Westport, CT and Longboat Key, FL, on July 3, 2014. Beloved father of Susan (Jeffrey), and John (Adriana); adored grandfather of Elyse, Jillian, Natalia, and Martin. Predeceased by beloved wife Sylvia, and by brothers Charles and Leonard.

INTRILIGATOR--Michael, an internationally renowned UCLA economist, died in Los Angeles June 23, age 76. He was an expert in economic theory, econometrics, health economics, strategy and arms control, peace and security, and transitioning economies. He wrote, edited, or co-edited more than 300 published papers, journal articles, and books, including the 28-volume Handbook of Economics series and the influential, enduring textbook Mathematical Optimization and Economic Theory. He was a passionate educator and a much sought-after public speaker. Among his many honors, he was the only US economist to be elected a Foreign Member of the Russian Academy of Sciences. He was also a member of both the International Institute for Strategic Studies and the Council on Foreign Relations, as well as a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the Econometric Society. Mike was a warm, gentle, and generous man. He loved family, teaching, colleagues, classical music, and coconut cake. Born in Freeport, NY, he received degrees from MIT and Yale. He is survived by his wife Devrie, their four sons, nine grandchildren, and his brother Marc. Donations may be made in his name to Economists for Peace and Security (epsusa.org) or to the American Cancer Society.

SLIVE--Seymour, The Board of Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the passing of Trustee Emeritus, Seymour Slive. Seymour Slive was a devoted Trustee, distinguished authority on seventeenth-century Dutch art, eminent scholar, beloved professor, and friend to many. Seymour enriched the Guggenheim through his leadership of the Art and Museum Committee and his wise counsel strengthened our collections. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Zoya and their family. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Honorary Chairman; William L. Mack, Chairman; and Jennifer Blei Stockman, President, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation; Richard Armstrong, Director, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation.

VAN ETTEN--Robert, our hearts ache for our honorable, honest and compassionate friend, Bob. He deeply mourned the loss of many friends on 9/11. Bob served the Treasury Department, US Customs, the Federal Criminal Investigators Association, and the Port Authority with impeccable integrity and leadership. Our hearts go out to Terri, Rob and David on their loss. We were proud to be his dear friends. Nancy and Peter Brown

ZEKAUSKAS--Raymond Andrew. Retired engineer, died peacefully on June 12th, 2014 in Hackensack, NJ. He was 92. Born in Kingston, PA in 1922, Mr. Zekauskas served in World War II and the Korean War. He graduated from Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy and Columbia University. He was married in 1944 to Felicia Cutrone who passed away August 21, 2006. He is survived by his children, Dr. Raymond Zekauskas, Jeffrey Zekauskas, Felicia Zekauskas, six grandchildren and one great-grandson.

HOFFMAN--Hedwig. Mother, grandmother, and former president of Nichibei Fujinkai passed away peacefully at her home on Wednesday, surrounded by her beloved family - Stuart, Haruka, and Wolfgang - shy of her 80th birthday. Services are scheduled for Saturday July 5 from 3-7pm at Fox Funeral Home at 98-07 Ascan Ave. in Forest Hills. For those wishing to express sympathy, in lieu of flowers, the family requests donations made to Doctors without Borders or The Queens Federation of Churches Emergency Food Service.

KOCH--Peter. The Board of Directors and staff of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel wish to express their sincere condolences to board member Rabbi Jackie Koch Ellenson on the loss of her father Peter Koch. May his memory forever be a blessing. Harold H. Handler, President.
SKLAR--Robert, Dec 3, 1936-July 3,2011 "So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past. Love from family and friends Adrienne

GOLDING--Phyllis, A longtime resident of Larchmont, passed away July 3, 2014. Retired Lecturer in Romance Languages at Queens College. HAGENDORF--Scott. 1958 - 2006 Happy Birthday Little Brother! We celebrate your life TODAY and EVERYDAY! You are the Wind Beneath our Wings. MISS YOU MADLY. Sheryl, Sonny, Barry and Kathy

HUTTER--Dr. Robert V.P.,a renowned pathologist died July 2, surrounded by his wife and children in New Jersey, at 85, after years with Alzheimer's disease. A past president of the American Cancer Society, former chairman of the department of pathology at St. Barnabas Medical Center, former editor-in-chief of the journal Cancer, he shaped cancer prevention strategies nationally and internationally. At the ACS, he helped to launch the society's first nutrition guidelines. He was the rare pathologist sought out by cancer patients for advice and what they got in return was a compassionate expert with sensitivity and honesty. Born May 25th, 1929 in Yonkers, NY, he attended Syracuse University on scholarship, played football for Coach F. Ben Schwartzwalder, graduated from SUNY Health Science Center at Syracuse, did his residency at Yale University and at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, served two years of active duty in the Navy, returned to Memorial, then to Yale and became a tenured professor of pathology at the age of 39. In 1970, he served for three years as chairman of pathology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and subsequently moved to St. Barnabas. He is survived by his wife, the former Ruth Lauterbach, son Andrew (Barbara), daughters Randi (Stuart) and Edie, and ten grandchildren.

BOTTICELLI--James C.,of Cortlandt Manor, NY, New York City and Nantucket, MA died suddenly on June 29, 2014. He is survived by Adele M. O'Grady, his wife of 22 years. A member of Miacomet Golf Club, his passion was family and friends. Visitation Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St., Sunday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass on Monday at 10am at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington at 66th St. Interment in Nantucket. In lieu of flowers, please give to the charity of your choice.

SWEITZER--John, 62, passed away peacefully on June 29 at his home in Forest Hills, NY. Born June 12, 1952, John was a graduate of Boston College in Chestnut Hill, MA, where he was awarded a BA degree in English in 1974. He also earned an MBA degree in Marketing from Baruch College of the City University of New York and worked for many years in marketing for several luxury goods companies in New York City. He is survived by his brother, Raymond, a Jesuit priest in residence at Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx, NY, and his passing is mourned by his extended family and many friends. He was pre-deceased by his parents, Raymond and Mary Sweitzer of Queens. A wake will be held from 2pm to 5pm and from 7pm to 9pm on Sunday July 6 at the Fox Funeral Home at 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY. On Monday July 7, a Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10am at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, at 110-06 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY 11375. Burial will follow at St. Charles Cemetery (Pinelawn) in Farmingdale, New York.

JACOBSON--Sylvia Goldberg, died peacefully in her home on July 4, 2014. She would have been 103 years old on September 22. She was predeceased by her husband Sam Goldberg and son Dr. Jack Goldberg. She is survived by her son, Dr. Edward Goldberg and his wife Barbara Neufeld; her daughters, Jo Anne Landi and Ruthie Cohen; 11 grandchildren; and 15 great-grandchildren. Among her many accomplishments, she was past President of Manhattan Chapter of Brandeis University National Women's Committee and President's Councilor of Brandeis University. This extraordinary woman was adored and held in the highest esteem by all who were fortunate enough to know her. The Funeral will be held 12:45pm, Sunday, July 6, 2014 at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expy., Fresh Meadows.
