Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 6, 2014.

NELSON--Lawrence A.,of Scottsdale, AZ formally of New York and Sag Harbor, NY died June 22, 2014. Born in 1934 in Detroit, graduated from Michigan State University and came to New York City to pursue a career in advertising. He is survived by his wife, Joan Shelt Nelson and two nephews Richard (Ronda) Swanson of Plano, TX and Eric (Dana) Swanson of Ann Arbor, MI. Burial will be in the family plot in Detroit.

SCHON--Herbert Mayer. 1931-2014, avid cyclist, skier and baker of rugelach, died on June 30 after suffering a massive stroke. Herb was born in Newark, NJ, and lived for many years in New York City, where after a career in advertising he founded Grandma's Recipe Rugelach, a specialty bakery. He retired to Santa Fe, NM, in 1997, and within a few years had revived the brand. At age 75, Herb cycled from California to New Hampshire, and from Oregon to Southern California at 80. He rode in numerous 100-mile races throughout the U.S., including one with the helicopter crew who had saved his life after a catastrophic bicycle crash in 2010. When not on his bike, he could be found skiing, working out at the gym or making rugelach deliveries to his many customers. Herb was known for his integrity and humor, but it was his fierce tenacity and love for life that will continue to inspire his friends. He is survived by his wife, Irene Jackson-Schon; his son, Peter; daughter-in-law, Amanda, and granddaughter, Greta.

SULLIVAN--Ambassador William H. 1922- 2013. Memorial Service 4pm. July 13, 2014 at River Road Unitarian Universalist, 6301 River Road, Bethesda, MD. Interment 11am. July 14, 2014 at Arlington National Cemetery. Donations may be made to The Fletcher Fund, 160 Packard Avenue, Medford, MA 02155.

TENER--Gerard M.,on July 3, at age 57, after a courageous battle with cancer our cherished brother has left for an eternal fishing trip. He will always be in our hearts and thoughts. Through his years in the real estate industry he made many friends and had many professionally interesting positions. From Helmsley Spear in the early years, to management of an island resort in the 1990's, to family businesses in the final years, he always embraced a new frontier. An ardent Giant and Ranger fan, he followed his teams faithfully. A skilled boatsman and fisherman, his nieces and nephews will miss his leadership and guidance at sea. He will be remembered by all for his great heart, his wit and devotion to family and friends. Beloved brother of Marian, Richard, Martin, Terence, Damien, and Thomas. Adored uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. He is survived by his wife, Moira and daughters Angie and Bridget. Wake will be held Tuesday July 8 at Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Avenue, Mineola, 3 to 7pm. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's RC Church, Garden City, Wednesday, 10am.

ZIELINSKI--Mikael, 58, died in Stockholm, Sweden on June 26. Former Vogue and Liz Claiborne Art Director. Miki's love, creativity, style, dry wit and wicked banter enriched our family gatherings. Irene, Jack, Drew & Leona

STEINBOOK--Nathan, former resident of New York City on July 4, 2014. He owned and operated barber shops in the New York transit system before retiring. Beloved husband of the late Helen Steinbook, devoted father Dr. Melvin Steinbook (Susan Avny) and the late Linda Grossman, dear father-in-law of Ted Grossman and cherished grandfather of Matthew, Benjamin, Andrew and Michael. Services Wednesday, 12pm at Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 1534 Pennington Road, Ewing, NJ, 609-883-1400. Contributions to the American Cancer Society.

SCHAPIRO--Donald. We mourn the death of our cherished member and express our deepest sympathies to Linda and her entire family. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to Donald's life. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York
SCHAPIRO--Donald. We remember Don, beloved father, grandfather, advisor, and friend. With love, Jane, Robert, Josh, Abigail, and Kate
SLIVE--Seymour. Deepest sympathy to Zoya and the family on Seymour's passing from a devoted former student and grateful mentee. Liz Prelinger

SACHS--Joseph D. (1918-2014). Uncle Joe passed away on Monday morning. Affectionately known as "Yoshe" he lived life to the fullest for 96 years. On Saturday he bought four bathing suits for upcoming summer trips to Turks and Caicos and a cruise on the Mediterranean. He had friends and family on three continents. His six nieces and nephews were his sons and daughters, his 17 grandnieces and nephews were his grandchildren and each had a special place in his heart feeling loved and important. A Veteran of World War II and graduate of New York University, he spent productive years at Emerson Radio, Oppenheimer and ADP maintaining continued close relationships with many of his former colleagues. He loved his cozy apartment on East 63rd Street and was able to be worldly and independent thanks to his ever caring companion Coach Steve Mandl. So many stories, so many people touched, he will be both missed and always a part of the lives of everyone who knew him. A celebration of his life will be planned for the fall.

ROAMAN--Richard A.,on June 29, 2014. Beloved husband of Barbara; loving father of Mark and Laura, Eric and the late Lisa Roaman Fox. Cherished grandfather of Emily, Sandra and Danny. Devoted brother of Adrienne and the late Dr. David B. Karlin, Joyce and the late Alan Roaman. Richard lived a full and happy life with Barbara as a businessman, world traveler and photographer and was very active in civil rights in the 1960's in Roslyn, LI. Services private. Family will receive visitors Wednesday July 2, 2014 from 4:30pm to 6:30pm at the Amsterdam at Harborside, Port Washington, New York.

SCHAPIRO--Donald, passed away peacefully at home on July 3, 2014, at the age of 88. Born to John Max Schapiro and Lydia Chaitkin Schapiro in New York City, he graduated from Townsend Harris High School, Yale College '44, where he became an instructor in the department of economics, followed by Yale Law School '49, where he developed a course in legal accounting, which he continued to teach as a visiting professor for some 25 years. Joining the firm of Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, he left after two years to go to Washington, D.C., as Assistant Chief Counsel to the U.S. House of Representatives Ways and Means Subcommittee on Administration of the Internal Revenue Laws. Returning to New York, he became a partner at Barrett, Smith, Schapiro, Simon, & Armstrong. In 1988, he joined Chadbourne & Parke, where he worked as a senior tax partner until his death. Don is survived by his beloved wife Linda of 21 years; his loving children, Jane Schapiro and Robert Schapiro (Lillian), and stepchildren, Joshua Solomon (Geula), Abigail Solomon (Jason Teuscher), and Kate Solomon (David Wasserman); and his cherished grandchildren Rebecca Schapiro, Ruth Schapiro, and Sarah Schapiro and Rachel Solomon, Benjamin Solomon, Jacob Solomon, Jasper Teuscher, Rush Slivjanovski, Sekana Slivjanovski, and Solomon Wasserman. He was predeceased by his late wife Ruth Goldman Schapiro and by his brother Stephen Schapiro. Donations in Don's memory may be made to Yale Law School, P.O. Box 208341, New Haven, Connecticut 06520, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, July 8, at 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. The family will receive friends at their residence from 5pm to 8pm on Tuesday, July 8, Wednesday, July 9, and Thursday, July 10.

SHAPIRO--Ruth (Ginsburg), of New York, NY on June 29, 2014 at age 95. Predeceased by husband Joseph D. Shapiro, brother Allen Gilbert, sister Doris Fogelman. Survived by her children Edward Shapiro, Elaine Berman and son-in-law Bruce Berman, grandchildren Daniel Berman (Elin Raymond), and Erica Berman Chapnick (Adam), and great-grandchildren Sofia and Eli Berman and Alana and Avery Chapnick, and a loving extended family. A special woman who will be missed.

TANNENBAUM--Abraham J.,90, passed peacefully Monday, June 30, 2014. Beloved husband of Annette, father of Alisa and Elliot Schiff, Moshe and Chana Tannenbaum, Nina and Mark Roisman. grandfather of 12, great-grandfather of two. Professor Emeritus, Teacher's College, Columbia University.

YEN--Pao Ming, one of the founders of the Summit Group and President of Summit Industrial Corporation, passed away peacefully on June 29, 2014, with his family at his side. He was born March 27, 1917 in Gulangyu Island, Amoy/Xiamen, in southern China. He was the eldest son of six sisters and three brothers, the child of Jian Chien Yen and Hsu Fung Ling. Having experienced the early passing of his father when he was a teenager, he attended the prestigious Tsing Hua University in Bejing, majoring in chemical engineering, which he continued after receiving a full scholarship to MIT in Cambridge, MA. It was at MIT where he met his future Summit partners C.C. Wang and J.T. Shaw (and later Dr. C.D. Shiah). After graduating in 1944 and after the communist revolution in China in 1949, he had to remain in the United States., finding work with the Firestone Co. A few years later, after becoming a U.S. citizen, he then started the Summit Group with the aforementioned classmates. Summit was an amalgam of the phrase "Sum of MIT," reflecting their common alma mater. Summit specialized in trade with Asia, acting often as middle man for companies in the U.S. that wanted to do business with Asian companies. As the company grew in the 1950s, 60s and 70s, it was involved in such diverse areas as crude oil, pharmaceuticals, computers, food stuffs, and electronics and has partnerships with major companies such as Motorola, General Motors, British Petroleum, Caltex, C.Itoh, and Singapore Petroleum Co. At its height, it had offices in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Bangkok, Tokyo, Okinawa, Saigon, Penang (Malaysia), Singapore, and Bermuda. In 1953 he met Caroline Wang, and after she immigrated to the U.S. to attend college, they married in 1955 at Trinity Church in New York City. They had their first son, Victor (now a real estate businessman) in 1956 and followed with a second son, Vincent (now an endocrinologist at Beth Israel Hospital in NYC) in 1959. Mr. Yen is survived by his wife and two sons; along with a remaining sister; brother; and various nephews and nieces. Services will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st St.), NY, NY 10028 with a viewing on Monday, July 7 between 4pm and 7pm and the funeral services on Tuesday, July 8 at 10:30am. Interment will follow thereafter at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to favored charities: St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. Web: www.stjude.org/donate. By phone: 1-800-805-5856. By mail: St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105 or National Parkinson Foundation. Website: www.parkinson.org/donate. By phone: 1-800-473-4636. By mail: National Parkinson Foundation, Gift Processing Center, P.O. Box 5018, Hagerstown, MD 21741-2018.

PROWELL--Richard Pickering, Jr. of Hadlyme, Connecticut died on June 17, 2014. Rich is survived by his son, Tyler Prowell of Charleston; his nieces, Elizabeth Mitchell of Indianapolis, Eleanor Prowell of Brooklyn and Ann Prowell of Cedar Rapids, Iowa; his grandnephew, Warner Mitchell; his sister, Leonora Prowell of New York City and his brother, William Prowell of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Rich was a lover of people and all things outdoors and there was no better companion for any adventure. Services will be held at Saint Ann's Church, 82 Shore Road, Old Lyme, CT on Saturday, July 12 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Rich's name to the Transplant Program, Hartford Hospital, Attn: Fund Development, 80 Seymour Street, Hartford, CT 06102-5037 or on-line: giving.harthosp.org. For more information visit fultontherouxoldlyme.com.

SWEITZER--John, 62, passed away peacefully on June 29 at his home in Forest Hills, NY. Born June 12, 1952, John was a graduate of Boston College in Chestnut Hill, MA, where he was awarded a BA degree in English in 1974. He also earned an MBA degree in Marketing from Baruch College of the City University of New York and worked for many years in marketing for several luxury goods companies in New York City. He is survived by his brother, Raymond, a Jesuit priest in residence at Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx, NY, and his passing is mourned by his extended family and many friends. He was pre-deceased by his parents, Raymond and Mary Sweitzer of Queens. A wake will be held from 2pm to 5pm and from 7pm to 9pm on Sunday July 6 at the Fox Funeral Home at 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY. On Monday July 7, a Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10am at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, at 110-06 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY 11375. Burial will follow at St. Charles Cemetery (Pinelawn) in Farmingdale, New York.

TANGUAY--Robert Thomas, died suddenly at age 52 on July 1st, 2014. Devoted son of the late John and Genevieve Tanguay. Beloved brother of Felicia Collins (John), Karen Graf, M.Tamara Szuma, Patricia O'Neil (Kevin) and Catherine Tanguay Labadie (Scott). Loving nephew of Navada Hambrick and uncle of Michael Graf, Andrew Collins, Laura Spicuzzi, Neil, April and Miles Szuma, Megan and Sean O'Neil. He was a partner at Deloitte and Touche. Friends may call Thursday, July 10, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St.

WOLF--Marvin Leonard, died peacefully at the age of 92, surrounded by those who loved him. He is survived by his wife Eleanor of 66 years, daughter Barbara Emden, son Robert and his son-in-law James Emden. He was a man of great personal strength, dignity, commitment and decency - core values that defined who he was and how he led his life. His loyalty and compassion towards his family and friends were deeply valued. As a man whose work ethic was exemplary, he built a manufacturing and import business of fine crystal, recognized around the globe. He was a dynamo, dedicated to excellence in life, family and all of his pursuits. Traveling through the communist countries for business, he saw the hardship of those living in oppression. His sense of justice caused him to quietly help those he could to defect to America and start a new life. As a long-time Trustee of South Nassau Community Hospital, he was fiercely proud of its growth and achievements over the many years. He showed courage, strength and love right up until the very end. We are overjoyed that you kept the angels waiting for a long time, and now take solace to know that you are at peace and with your beloved daughter Marcia who is there to embrace you. We thank you for letting us know that we were loved everyday of our lives, as we have loved you and will forever. Your loving family.

WOLFSON--Monte, a retail executive who had a key role in engineering some of the most important innovations of the modern apparel industry, died at Calvary hospice in the Bronx on July 2nd after a brief illness. He was 91. As a senior apparel buyer at Macy's in the late 1950's, Mr. Wolfson was a member of the first team of retailers that traveled to Asia to successfully source import apparel programs to the US. In the 1970s, while President of the Netco apparel division of Zayre, he devised breakthrough models of distribution center efficiency well before the advent of automated warehouse equipment. As the increase of import apparel programs created overages too large for conventional retailers to handle, he then conceived the model for TJ Maxx, the first retail chain to specialize in closeout apparel. Mr. Wolfson was a US Government advisor on the retail textile industry since 1982, and in 1990 he formed Monte Wolfson Associates, a retail consulting firm. Mr Wolfson was born and raised in the Bronx, son of Irving and Helen Wolfson: he graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School in 1941. In the fall of 1941 he attended the University Of Illinois and participated in their ROTC program. In 1942 he was called into active service in the United States Army and was stationed at Ft. Sills, Oklahoma. He was honorably discharged and returned to the University of Illinois in 1944, where he earned his B.S. degree. He later earned an M.B.A. from New York University. In addition to his passion for business, he loved sports, theater and history; citing Willie Mays, William Shakespeare and Barbara Tuchman as three of the people he most admired. He was an avid tennis player known for his wicked cross-court forehand, and a long time member of the East Hampton Tennis Club. He enjoyed traveling, skiing with his family, and rooting for his beloved Knicks, Football Giants and Mets. In 1981 he was honored by The City Of Hope Medical Center and received their 'Spirit Of Life' award. Mr Wolfson's wife of 47 years, the former Doris Elaine Hertz, died in 2000. He is survived by their three children, Robert, Suzanne and Jon; Jon's wife Katherine; grandchildren Jayne, Tom, Grace and Lena; sister Muriel Oppenheimer; nephews Michael and David Oppenheimer; niece Amy Oppenheimer and his loving companion Laurel Isaacs. Memorial service Wednesday, July 9th, 4:30pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, New York City.

GOODMAN--Bernard, 88, passed away June 30, 2014. Many complimentary words have been used to describe my wonderful husband of 64 years - my Bernie. He was a kind, sweet, true gentleman and excelled in all he did through hard work and possession of "Yiddisher Kop." He formed an international engineering and construction corporation that occupied three floors in the World Trade Center. Bernie won a math medal at City College and played on their varsity sports teams and he just loved golf. He was a past president of Menorah Home and Hospital in Brooklyn. But his true loves were his family: his two daughters, Alyce and Sue and her husband, Bob; his granddaughter, Rae and her husband Evan; and his grandsons Ben and David. He was so looking forward to welcoming a great-grandchild in the fall. His love also encompassed his wonderful friends, brother-in-law, cousin, nieces and a nephew who all greatly respected him and returned his affection. Graveside service will be 11am Monday, July 7, 2014 at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. www.levitt-weinstein.com Rest in peace, my darling. Mimi.
MORRISON--George, 86, died June 28, 2014. A master acting teacher and long valued friend. Ziva Kwitney

MILLER--John Merriman, age 76, of Knoxville, formerly of Washington D.C. and Denver Colorado, died on Thursday, June 12, 2014, after a brief illness. Mr. Miller was graduated from Duke University in 1959 and Wake Forest University Law School in 1962. He was an unabashed, unrepentant fan of Duke athletics and he was a substantial contributor to the Iron Dukes. He grew up in Durham, North Carolina; Charlottesville, Virginia; and Knoxville, Tennessee. Mr. Miller, a highly respected attorney, had a uniquely distinguished career in the government and in the private sector, principally in Washington, D.C. and he was admitted to the Bars of Washington, D.C., North Carolina, and Colorado. As a government lawyer, from 1962 to 1982, Mr. Miller worked for the United States Comptroller of the Currency in Washington, D.C., first as commissioned national bank examiner and then in the law department, completing his tenure as Deputy Chief Counsel and Acting Chief Counsel for the banking agency, which is the primary regulator of national banks. He dynamically led the agency's law department during some of the most challenging eras in American banking and he was an early pioneer in consumer protection. In 1982, he left the government to join Kirkland & Ellis as a partner in the firm's banking practice in Denver, Colorado, and in Washington, D.C. where he was instrumental in breaking down geographical barriers to interstate banking. He returned to Washington, D.C. in 1984 and he continued his banking practice in other large law firms where he represented commercial banks, investment banks, and life insurance companies, and he advised insurgents in their hostile takeover of a multi-billion holding company. In 1995, he was appointed deputy to the first Special Trustee for American Indians at the U.S. Department of the Interior, to help the Special Trustee reform the broken, century old, multi-billion dollar Individual Indian Trust and enable the United States to begin to discharge trust duties that it has owed more than 500,000 individual Indian trust beneficiaries since 1887. In 2002, Mr. Miller retired from the Interior Department and in 2007, he returned to the home in Knoxville where he spent part of his childhood. He was preceded in death by his father, Charles H. Miller Jr., mother, Audrey Glenn Johnson Beck. He is survived by his family; brother and sister-in-law, Charles H. (Chuck) Miller III and wife Patricia of Loudon, Tennessee; nieces and nephews, Alicia A. O'Connor, Charles H. Miller IV and wife Angie, Timi L. Smith and husband Charles, Lindy Curtsinger, Lisa Houser; great nieces and nephews, Keagan Mac O'Connor, Sydney Smith, Lindy Smith, Bryce Curtsinger, Blake Curtsinger, Callie Houser, Nikki Miller, Charles H. (Chase) Miller V; cousin, who was like a brother, Lattis Merriman Johnson and wife Shirley of Oak Island North Carolina.

GARMENT--Martin, age 95, of Westport, CT and Longboat Key, FL, on July 3, 2014. Beloved father of Susan (Jeffrey), and John (Adriana); adored grandfather of Elyse, Jillian, Natalia, and Martin. Predeceased by beloved wife Sylvia, and by brothers Charles and Leonard.

HAZZI--Jacqueline S.,on July 1, 2014. Beloved wife of Charles. Loving sister of Rose Rabbat and the late Huguette Zariffa. Devoted aunt of Rafik Rabbat and Nabil and Nohad Zariffa. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call Sunday, July 6, 2-5pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Religious service Monday, July 7, 10am at St. Nicholas Cathedral, State and Bond Streets, Brooklyn, NY.

JOYCE--Bernard F.,"Bernie," 83, passed away peacefully on July 3, 2014 with his family by his side in Spring Lake, NJ. Bernie was born on July 8, 1930 in New York City to Mary (Kane) and James Joyce. He married his high school sweetheart, Veronica, "Vera," (nee Fenty) in 1952. They enjoyed 62 years together while raising eight children in New Rochelle, NY and Briarcliff Manor, NY. They retired to Spring Lake, NJ. Bernie was a graduate of Regis High School ('48), Fordham University ('52) and Fordham Law School ('58). While working as an accountant, he attended night school and earned his JD from Fordham and an LLM in Taxation from NYU. He proudly served in the U.S. Army from 1952-1954. Bernie enjoyed a highly successful legal career at Emmet, Marvin and Martin, LLP, where he was the firm's longest serving managing partner, holding this position from the 1960's through 1989. He guided the firm through three decades of growth as it evolved from a family law practice to a modern financial services law firm. Bernie embodied the Jesuit ideal of a life lived in the "service of others". He served on the Board of Directors of several Catholic charities, including St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center and Nazareth Life Center. He was also honored to serve as a trustee of the George Link Jr. Foundation and the George Link Jr. Charitable Trust. Bernie's greatest joy was his family and he cherished the times spent with them in Spring Lake. He was an outstanding husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend. Bernie is survived by his wife Vera, his eight children: Deborah Drake, Sharon Chichester, Veronica Topp, Colleen Joyce, Brian Joyce, Deirdre Glascott, Sean Joyce and Liam Joyce; their spouses and 22 grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Mary Sawyers, and his brothers, James and Thomas and was predeceased by his brothers, John, Michael and Vincent. The family will receive friends on Monday, July 7, 2014, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Rd., Katonah, NY. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Tuesday, July 8, 2014, at 10am at St. Theresa's Church, 1394 Pleasantville Rd, Briarcliff Manor, NY. Burial to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting contributions be made in his memory to Regis High School, www.regis.org. For more information visit: www.clarkassociatesfuneral home.com.

INTRILIGATOR--Michael, an internationally renowned UCLA economist, died in Los Angeles June 23, age 76. He was an expert in economic theory, econometrics, health economics, strategy and arms control, peace and security, and transitioning economies. He wrote, edited, or co-edited more than 300 published papers, journal articles, and books, including the 28-volume Handbook of Economics series and the influential, enduring textbook Mathematical Optimization and Economic Theory. He was a passionate educator and a much sought-after public speaker. Among his many honors, he was the only US economist to be elected a Foreign Member of the Russian Academy of Sciences. He was also a member of both the International Institute for Strategic Studies and the Council on Foreign Relations, as well as a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the Econometric Society. Mike was a warm, gentle, and generous man. He loved family, teaching, colleagues, classical music, and coconut cake. Born in Freeport, NY, he received degrees from MIT and Yale. He is survived by his wife Devrie, their four sons, nine grandchildren, and his brother Marc. Donations may be made in his name to Economists for Peace and Security (epsusa.org) or to the American Cancer Society.

JACOBSON--Sylvia Goldberg, died peacefully in her home on July 4, 2014. She would have been 103 years old on September 22. She was predeceased by her husband Sam Goldberg and son Dr. Jack Goldberg. She is survived by her son, Dr. Edward Goldberg and his wife Barbara Neufeld; her daughters, Jo Anne Landi and Ruthie Cohen; 11 grandchildren; and 15 great-grandchildren. Among her many accomplishments, she was past President of Manhattan Chapter of Brandeis University National Women's Committee and President's Councilor of Brandeis University. This extraordinary woman was adored and held in the highest esteem by all who were fortunate enough to know her. The Funeral will be held 12:45pm, Sunday, July 6, 2014 at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expy., Fresh Meadows.

LAUFER--Barbara. With deep love and profound sadness we convey the death of our sweet Wife, Mother and friend, at the age of 84. Born in the Bronx, Barbara was an elementary school teacher. Known for her gregarious, enquiring spirit, a selfless, caring optimism, love of food, cooking, arts, antiques and superlatives, Barbara will be keenly missed. She is survived by her husband Ira, children Tina and David, grandchildren Tess, Faye, Iain and Ruby, and many other family and friends in whose lives she continues to live. Donations may be made in her honor to NY Public Radio.

LEDERER--Richard Becker, 96, actor and activist, passed away June 8, 2014. Richard was a long time member of Actors Equity, serving as a Councillor and member of many Committees. He was an instigator for the creation of Manhattan Plaza, a federally subsidized, 1,688 unit apartment building in Hell's Kitchen for people in the performing arts. Beginning in 1949, he played feature roles on stage well into his 80's, where he reprised the role of King Pellinor from Camelot. Richard was old, but never acted that part. He lived with graciousness, dignity, and wit until the moment of his death. Richard is remembered fondly by friends and colleagues. The son of the late Florence B. and Irving G. Lederer, Richard is survived by his sister, Margery "Butch" Philipsborn, and three devoted nephews, Dr. Daniel Philipsborn (Rhonda), Andrew Philipsborn (Jane Bilger) and Clancy Philipsborn (Mary Brooks), and nine great-nieces and nephews, and one great-great-nephew and niece. Contributions may be made to The Actors Fund, New York.

KUVACIC--Mary Vidovich, 91, on July 1, 2014. A proud graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College '44. Mary shared 28 years with her late husband Ljubomir. She is survived by her daughter Adriane (Nick); her beloved granddaughter Paressa Poulikidis; sister Lorraine Loughlin and extended family in the United States, Canada, Greece and Croatia. Her family will receive friends on Monday, July 7 from 2-5pm and 79pm at Quinn Funeral Home, 35-20 Broadway, Astoria, NY 11106. A Funeral Mass will be held on Tuesday, July 8 at 10:30am at Most Precious Blood RC Church, 32-52 37th Street, Astoria, NY 11106. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Memory of Mary Kuvacic to VNS of New York, Hospice, 107 East 70th St, 5th Fl., New York, NY 10021.

GOERS--Bruce West, 71, died Sunday, June 22, 2014 in Palm Springs, California after a brief illness. He was born February 12, 1943 to Mahala Emma and Robert Glee Goers in La Porte, Indiana. He is survived by his brother, Dennis Goers and his sister-in-law, Grace, of La Porte and one nephew, Jeffrey. Bruce attended the Chicago Academy of Fine Arts where he studied interior design and where he met his life's partner Wayne Williamson who died in 2009 after a 47 year relationship and partnership in business. Together they founded the firm of Insight Environmental Designs in Chicago and the iconoclastic retail shop, "Insight" in Highland Park, Illinois. It was groundbreaking in its conceptions and content. Many years after it closed, it's aesthetic influence has effected the manner in which ethnic, traditional and modern objects and art could be successfully integrated. Bruce and Wayne ultimately established the design firm Insight West in Palm Springs. Bruce continued a partnership in Chicago with Anne Kaplan whom he had know for 48 years at the time of his death. Bruce was an accomplished designer who carried himself with grace, and elegance punctuated strongly by his youthful good looks. He was a true professional who treated trades people, venders, clients and friends with respect and was appreciated and loved for his vitality, humor, and kindness as well as for his Unparalleled design sensibility. He is survived by his loving friends, Maria, Manuel, Johnny and Marijane Alaniz, Josh Hancock and Anne Kaplan and will be missed by many. A memorial gathering is planned for the fall. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center, KUSC public radio or the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago.

HARGITAY--Dr. Bartholomew (Bertalan), internationally renowned scientist, active in Hungarian cultural circles, passed away in White Plains, July 2, at age 89. An expert in the biochemical development of polymers and reverse osmosis kidney dialysis, his work had profound effects in the medical field. He spent most of his life as a scientist for Union Carbide. A proud family man, he was husband to his late wife, Elinor for 34 years, and was devoted to her loving memory. He was a caring father, grandfather, and an art and photography enthusiast. Born in Arad, Romania, he received a degree from University of Budapest in 1945, a Scholarship in Basel Switzerland, and his PhD at Harvard before making his home in White Plains. He was stepfather to Sandor Borsiczky, and the late Veronika Mann, and is survived by seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in his name to UNICEF.
GELWICK--Richard, The Reverend Doctor. Died June 29, 2014. Theologian, Polanyi scholar, social activist. Full obituary: www. directcremationsofmaine.com

BANCROFT--Ellen Coffin, "The Witch of Pitt Street," 86, died at home June 24, 2014, in Alexandria, Virginia. She is survived by daughters Elizabeth and Mary-McLean, grandsons C. Royce and Caleb Sims. Ellen was the wife of the late Frederic W. Bancroft and daughter of the late Amos Coffin and Mabel Jennie Frey. She liked shoes, dogs and Italy. Memorial Service: Friday, July 11, 10:30am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 228 S. Pitt St, Alexandria, VA.

DERRICK--John. October 16, 1932, Bennettsville, South Carolina- June 19, 2014, New York City. The son of Oscar Derrick and Pauline Liles Derrick. John Richard Derrick "Dickie" to his family and Dick to his school friends--grew up in Bennettsville obsessed with Hollywood musicals, especially the dancing. After high school and a few local jobs in a building supply and lumber yard, in a cinema etc., he entered the United States Air Force. While stationed in Tampa he used every minute of his spare time off base to study with Gail Armour, a well-known ballet mistress in Florida. Ms. Armour saw a potential "danseur noble" in John with his tall good looks and supple yet muscular body. At the end of his military service, and under the guidance of Ms. Armour, he applied for, and won, a scholarship to the renowned Marie Rembert School of Ballet in London. The application involved sending a 16mm film of his performance for Marie Rembert's consideration. He trained with Rembert for two years and then found work in Italy with regional companies, chiefly in Rome where he continued working with private teachers. On returning to the United States he spent time with The Metropolitan Opera which led to a call from The Miami Ballet with which he had a long association that continued even after his primary residence was established in New York. Being a jack-of-all-theatrical-trades, including acting, he appeared frequently in musicals, dramatic and comic plays. His life partner, Milton Beyer, worked in theatrical production and at a certain point the men bought a pleasant apartment in Greenwich Village and opened a vintage goods store on Christopher St., "keep the wolves away between jobs" Milton proclaimed. It was successful for many years and allowed John to take theatrical engagements as they came along. Milton preceded John in death in 1995. John (Dickie) is survived by his sister, Barbara Derrick Crosland, brother-in-law, James Crosland, and numerous nephews, nieces, great-nephews and great-nieces. As per his wish, John has been cremated. Later there will be a gathering of friends to remember John and his wonderful life in the theater.

ALBRECHT--Hilda. The Board of Directors of the Association of Wall Ceiling & Carpentry Industries of New York mourns the passing of Hilda Albrecht, beloved mother of Marguerite DeLollis and mother-in-law of our colleague and friend John DeLollis, the Association's Executive Director. We extend our deepest sympathies to Maggie, John, and the entire DeLollis and Albrecht families.

BEIM--Martin. Age 78. Former Ad Executive passed away June 29, 2014 after long years of dealing with retinitis pigmentosa, spinal problems and heart valve replacement. He is survived by his partner of 38 years Rita Dulberg, brother Norman, brother-in-law Rey Altberg, June, wonderful nieces Marla and Merrill and their fine spouses Phil Greiper and Marc Rappaport and Anastasia. He was a fighter for survival. Rest In Peace.

BACH--Ellen, born in St. Louis, MO July 19, 1920. Married to Lt. Robert Bach for 50 years. Robert passed away 27 years ago. Ellen has one daughter, India Ramacher in Lodi, California. Also a son, Andrew Bach who lives in Poundridge, NY. There are three grandchildren, Amy, Jennifer and Christopher who has two sons. All family in California. Donations please to the New York Times Neediest Cases in my name.

BOLGER--William J. (Bill), died peacefully in Princeton, NJ on June 25, 2014 at the age of 88. A dedicated, wise, and generous husband, father, family man and friend, he lived a long and fulfilling life. Bill was predeceased by his parents, John and Coby Bolger of Sewickley, PA, and by his first wife of 53 years, Eugenie Claire Wagner. Bill was a graduate of Northfield-Mount Hermon prep school in 1944. With the nation still at war, he enlisted in the Navy's V-12 training program. This led him to Princeton University from which he was graduated in 1948. Bill enjoyed a diverse and successful career in general management and commercial real estate consulting before starting his own consulting firm, which he continued until his retirement. He enjoyed challenges, family gatherings, clever jokes, a good debate, old friends, a smart game of cards, travel, the stock market, suspense novels, and more. Bill was a provider: he looked after those he loved and helped many people without attaching strings or seeking attention, and was always guided by his integrity. He is survived by his second wife, Eva Heidmann; his two sons Stephen (Lillian Laserson) and Bruce (Shawn Sparks); grandchildren Kate, Chris, and Elizabeth; Eva's daughters Sofia Ardalan and Lily (John) Scott; siblings Betty (Robert) Fleming, David, Barbara (William) Collett, and Daniel (Linda) Bolger, and many nephews and nieces. He lives on in the many ways he has positively touched so many people and in the memories of his rich and spontaneous personality. Services will be held July 14 at Trinity Church, Princeton, NJ at 1pm followed by a reception at the Nassau Club. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Nature Conservancy.

BOTTICELLI--James C.,of Cortlandt Manor, NY, New York City and Nantucket, MA died suddenly on June 29, 2014. He is survived by Adele M. O'Grady, his wife of 22 years. Mr. Botticelli worked in Corporate Affairs for 28 years at Philip Morris Cos., Inc. He attended Stephinac and Bowling Green University. A member of Miacomet Golf Club, his passion was family and friends. Visitation Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St., Sunday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass on Monday at 10am at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington at 66th St. Interment in Nantucket. In lieu of flowers, please give to the charity of your choice.

BOWER--Jean. 78, of Washington, D.C.,on June 30th of complications of ALS. She was born in Queens on November 25th, 1935, to Claude and Myrtle Ramsay, and was a graduate of Vassar College and Georgetown University Law School. A lifetime love of poetry, pursued first at Vassar (she interviewed Ezra Pound for her thesis paper), blossomed in later life when she served on the Folger Poetry Board (as its chairman from 2002-2006) and wrote poetry herself, contributing to the anthology "In a Certain Place." Jean lived every day with a devotion to literature and the arts that enriched the lives of all who came in contact with her. In addition to avidly supporting various cultural institutions (NPR, the MET, the Kennedy Center), she regularly opened her Georgetown home for wonderful parties that continued to her last year of life. As an attorney, Jean relentlessly fought for the rights of abused and neglected children, serving as the director of the Counsel for Child Abuse and Neglect of the D.C. Superior Court, from 1978 until her retirement; in 1984 she received the Beatrice Rosenberg Award from the District of Columbia Bar Association for Excellence in Government. Jean was known for her kindness, wit, generosity and her devotion to her friends. Jean's first marriage, to Ward Swift Just, ended in divorce; a loving second marriage to Robert Turrell Bower ended with Bob's death in 1990. She is survived by her brother, William Ramsay; two children, Jennifer Ramsay Just and Julia Barnett Just, and a step-son, Stephen Bower; and four grandchildren. She will be deeply mourned by her family and many dear friends in Washington, D.C., and Quogue, Long Island. The funeral will be held on Saturday, July 12, at 11am at the Church of the Atonement in Quogue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Family Matters of Greater Washington.

GAVIGAN--James, T.,76, of Mahwah, NJ, passed on June 30 surrounded by his family. Jim was predeceased by his wife, Virginia Hendricks and his brother Monsignor Peter Gavigan. He is survived by his wife Beatrice, brother Jack, children Mark, Laura, and Andy, grandchildren Delia, Samantha, Stanley, Peter, Kayleigh, and Ella. Father-in-law to Larry, Barbara, and Maria. Born in Washington Heights, Jim attended Incarnation Grammar School, Manhattan Prep, then graduated from Manhattan College in 1959. Jim "had a good run." He will be dearly missed. Funeral Service information at: www.vanemburghsneider.com

BELLAMY--Charlotte (Sheindi) Tokayer, March 14th 1929: June 16th 2014 died at home surrounded by her loving family. Her long career in early childhood education improved countless lives through direct service, teaching and organizational contributions. She was a fountain of love and inspiration for family and friends around the world and lives brightly in many hearts. Survived by children Laurie Tatarsky, Andrew Tatarsky, Miles Bellamy, and their wives Wendy Miller and Leah Kreger, grandchildren Alexandra and Lucas Tatarsky and Delilah Bellamy and brothers Norman and Samuel Tokayer. Donations can be made to: Bronx Community College Early Childhood Ctr., ATT: Jitinder Walia, 2155 University Avenue, Bronx, NY 10453.

CAMERON--Dr. John M.,the Founder, Chairman, and President of ProCure Treatment Centers, the country's leading provider of proton-based cancer treatment, died on Thursday in Bloomington, Indiana. He was 73. Dr. Cameron, a nuclear physicist, was a pioneer in developing proton therapy as an alternative to traditional radiation treatment for advanced cancer. At ProCure, he oversaw the development and operation of four proton therapy centers in the United States that currently treat thousands of patients annually. Dr. Cameron also established the ProCure Cancer Foundation, which provides financial aid to enable pediatric patients to travel with their families to receive this less invasive form of cancer treatment. Prior to founding ProCure, Dr. Cameron had a long and distinguished career in nuclear physics, medical technology, research and administration. He received his Ph.D. in physics from the University of California, Los Angeles in 1967 and then joined the physics faculty at the University of Alberta in Edmonton, Canada. For nearly 20 years, he served as Professor of Physics at Indiana University, during which time he also directed the University's Cyclotron Facility. He played a pivotal role in creating the Midwest Proton Radiotherapy Institute at Indiana University in 2004. Dr. Cameron was elected Fellow of the American Physical Society in 1987. Dr. Cameron was born on his family's farm in Coleraine, Northern Ireland. He received his undergraduate degree in 1962 from Queens University, Northern Ireland. He is survived by his loving wife of 50 years, Cathleen Cameron; his son, Kevin Cameron and daughter-in-law Amy Busch; his daughter, Caitlin Denker and son-in-law Christopher Denker; his sisters Linda Beattie and Claire Kee; and his brother, Gilmore Cameron. He is also survived by his four beloved grandchildren, Sean, Emma, Ian, and Oliver. A celebration of life is planned for later this year, and in lieu of flowers, gifts may be sent to the Cardinal Stage Company in Bloomington, Indiana.

CASPER--Laurence.92, New York, died peacefully surrounded by his family on June 24. Adoring father of Pamela with his first wife Selma, and doting father of Nicole and Hillary with beloved wife Brett of 37 years, proud grandfather of Sebastian and Viola, cherished father-in-law, brother-in-law and uncle. Graduated Boys High in Brooklyn at 16, kicked out of Brooklyn College where he was too engrossed in the library studying his own choice of books, but not before winning the boxing championship! He served proudly in the Army Air Corps in WWII as an officer and bombardier navigator with the B-24 Liberators, received his BA at Kent State under the GI bill. At the NYU Institute of Fine Arts he melded his passion of history and art. His expertise in sculpture, graphics and paintings stretched from Old Masters to contemporary art. Prior to founding Casper Fine Arts & Appraisals, Inc., he joined the Danenberg Galleries and ACA Gallery as Director of Exhibitions and served as President of the Appraisers Association of America. With his insight, intellect and profound understanding of art aesthetics, he initiated fresh interest in the early American modernists: John Marin, Charles Burchfield, Georgia O'Keefe and Joseph Cornell. In '68, he pioneered an exhibition of Norman Rockwell, signaling a shift in the art world's view of him from illustrator of the Saturday Evening Post to fine artist. This pivotal exhibition was shown in ten museums around the country. He remained committed to championing Rockwell's work and was sought for his expert opinion on the artist's paintings and market. His presence on Madison Avenue, in the great auction houses and museums, was highly respected. Ever the teacher, he generously shared his time and knowledge. He cultivated an interest in medicine with such zeal, ordering tests and analyzing results, that doctors often thought he was a doctor himself. His attorney father discouraged him from pursuing law, but he successfully represented his clients in litigation proceedings, advised their attorneys, gave expert testimony in US Tax Court, and most recently represented his wife against the injustices of parking violations. Even in his nineties, he could be found studying Russian and Japanese on tape. A true renaissance man, his overflowing library contains tomes on history, medicine, law, art, Jewish humor, bridge, philosophy, chemistry, astronomy and more. A football, soccer, baseball, golf, wrestling aficionado, he was a men's singles tennis champ, beating men 20 years his junior. He relished being a father, overcome with emotion each time he spoke of his daughters; he wanted for them only what they would want for themselves. His profound generosity, sensitivity, stubbornness, humor, openness, honesty and utmost integrity touched those around him; he was cherished and will be deeply missed by all.

ALCOSSER--Elliott. November 20, 1941--July 2, 2014. After a successful career in the Garment Center, Elliott's part time interest in the stock market became a full time endeavor, at which he excelled. He was a long time member of the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst and Lawrence Men's Tennis Club. Survived by his wife Marilyn; devoted son David and wife Stefani; loving grandfather to Ava and Eli; sister Joyce Cooper.

BERMAN--Herbert E.,on July 6, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Loving father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Devoted New York City Councilman and public servant. Services Tuesday July 8, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

DAITZ--Stephen G.,died June 19, 2014 at home. He was Professor Emeritus of the Department of Classical Languages and Hebrew at The City College and the CUNY Graduate Center. His principal interest was the oral reading of ancient Greek and Latin, with great attention given to the "restored pronunciation" of those languages as well as the metrics of their poetry. Silent reading had no place in the study of the Classics, he maintained; their literature was composed to be recited aloud. He recorded the entire Iliad and Odyssey, Euripides' Hekabe, Aristophanes' Birds, Plato's Portrait of Sokrates, as well as selections of ancient Greek poetry and oratory. His recordings, made between 1978 and 1998, are still available from Bolchazy-Carducci Publishers, as are those teaching the pronunciation and reading of Ancient Greek and Classical Latin. He gave recitals and workshops at universities and scholarly meetings throughout North America and Europe as well as in Australia and Argentina. In 1999 his recital of Greek literature was presented at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to celebrate the opening of the newly restored halls displaying ancient Greek art. He was the first president of SORGLL, the Society for the Oral Reading of Greek and Latin Literature (see their web site). A group of students and teachers studied the Homeric hexameter with him on Saturday mornings in his Upper West Side apartment. Stephen Daitz's education at Yale, the Sorbonne, and Harvard initially lead him to the publication of critical editions, but his love of music underpinned his resuscitation of the sounds of Classical literature. He taught at CUNY from 1957 to 1991 and at the University of Paris in 1971-73 and 1979-80. His teaching at the Ecole Normale Superieure inspired the creation of Theatre Demodocos, which presents staged productions of Classical drama in the original language. A confirmed Francophile, he spoke French at home, teaching all his children to speak the language. A lifelong outdoorsman, reaching the summits of the Matterhorn and Mont Blanc were among his proudest achievements. He spent forty-five summers at Great East Lake in Acton, Maine, near New Hampshire's White Mountains, where he enjoyed hikes with family and friends. Stephen Daitz was born on August 16, 1926 in New York City. He is survived by his wife, Mimi S. Daitz of New York City, his son Maurice and daughter-in-law Sharon Jaycox Daitz of Scarsdale, NY, his son Benjamin of New York City and Gardiner, NY, and his sister, Sonia Lazar of Culver City, CA. He was predeceased by his daughter, Francesca. A memorial gathering will be held Sunday, afternoon, September 21, 2014, place to be announced.

TANGUAY--Robert Thomas, died suddenly at age 52 on July 1st, 2014. Devoted son of the late John and Genevieve Tanguay. Beloved brother of Felicia Collins (John), Karen Graf, M.Tamara Szuma, Patricia O'Neil (Kevin) and Catherine Tanguay Labadie (Scott). Loving nephew of Navada Hambrick and uncle of Michael Graf, Andrew Collins, Laura Spicuzzi, Neil, April and Miles Szuma, Megan and Sean O'Neil. He was a partner at Deloitte and Touche. Friends may call Thursday, July 10, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St.

GOULD--Mary Middleton, age 82, of New York City, died of respiratory failure Saturday, July 5th, 2014, at Mount Sinai St. Luke's Hospital, Manhattan, NY. Mary was born December 21st, 1931, in Kansas City, MO, the daughter of Thomas Michael Middleton and Eleanor Serat Middleton. She grew up in Danbury, CT, and was a graduate of Vassar College. For a decade she was assistant society editor of the Chicago Tribune, then married another Tribune writer, Gordon Gould, June 28th, 1963. They moved to New York where he became an actor with the APA Repertory Company and she, a skilled seamstress, worked in costumes. As their family grew, she retired from backstage and devoted herself to enthusiastically supporting various arts organizations where her characteristic laugh will be missed. Mary is survived by her husband of 51 years, two children, John Gould and Eleanor Gould, two grandsons, Cooper and Griffin Gould, and her sister Katherine Middleton Brock. She was preceded in death by her brother T. Michael Middleton Jr.

ALBRECHT--Hilda. The Board of Directors of the Association of Wall Ceiling & Carpentry Industries of New York mourns the passing of Hilda Albrecht, beloved mother of Marguerite DeLollis and mother-in-law of our colleague and friend John DeLollis, the Association's Executive Director. We extend our deepest sympathies to Maggie, John, and the entire DeLollis and Albrecht families.

POPOV--Peter Nicholas. On June 29, 2014, beloved husband of Lela Love; devoted father of Nicole and Brad Doppelt; loving grandfather of Hunter; wonderful friend to all who knew him. His love for Great Bay led to the preservation of large tracts of land in New Hampshire. As a maritime attorney he took joy in connecting people around the world, resulting in many successful shipping arrangements. He left far too soon and will be greatly missed. Memorial service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street on Wednesday, July 9. Family will receive visitors starting at 3pm, service at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Nature Conservancy.

SEXTON--Fredda, died on June 25th, 2014 at the age of 105 years old. A champion of the arts. She died peacefully at her home in New York. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Thursday, July 17th, 2014 at the Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York NY 10128.

GRAVES--Dr. Oscar N.,July 18, 1921-June 26, 2014. Dr. Oscar Nathaniel Graves aka "Duke" departed this life June 26, 2014. Born July, 18 1921 in the family home in Brooklyn, NY to Moses and Louise Graves, he was the youngest of seven children. A graduate of Boy's High in Brooklyn, Lincoln University in Pennsylvania, and Howard Medical School in Washington, DC. He began his internship in 1949 at Harlem Hospital in internal medicine and cardiology, which was interrupted by service in the Korean War (1952-54) as a General Medical Officer, discharged at rank of Lieutenant. Upon return to Harlem Hospital he obtained board certification in anesthesiology and was part of the Anesthesiology Department until he retired (1955-86). Dr. Graves was a founding member of the Westchester Clubmen and its charitable branch the Foundation of Westchester Clubmen. He was also a member of the Guardsmen's Organization and Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc. (1942 Beta Chapter). He is predeceased by two spouses-Margaret, and Yvonne (member of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc.). He is survived by four children, three daughters-in-law, eight grandchildren and a great-grandson. He is also survived by his sister and many nieces, nephews and cousins. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, July 19th 2014, 10:30am at Grace Episcopal Church, 33 Church St., White Plains, NY 10601. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations are appreciated to the Foundation of the Westchester Clubmen, Inc., c/o 35 Old Tarrytown Rd., White Plains, NY 10603. Services entrusted to: Lee's Funeral Home, LLC, White Plains, NY 10606 for more information please visit: www.LeesFuneralHome.com

KROSNEY--Pam, The Board of Governors and Members of The Elberon Bathing Club mourn the sudden passing of our dear friend and long time member Pam Krosney. Her late husband, Dr. Neil Krosney served with distinction as our Club President and Chairman for many years. Her broad, warm smile and cheery hellos as she walked briskly into EBC are things we will always remember. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Hilary and Judson and her entire family. She is already sorely missed. Robert Fagenson, President Douglas Schwartz, Secretary

CASELLA--Elsie T. 85, died peacefully on July 4th, 2014 after a brief illness. Born on September 7th, 1928 in New York City, to Alfred and Hedwig Heck, Elsie was raised in Manhattan and Queens, New York. After she married Alfred M. Casella in 1956, the family moved to Rosedale, New York, where they raised their son, Mark. In 1987, Elsie and Fred purchased a home in the Hemlock Farms Community in Lords Valley, PA, where they spent many happy years. Elsie and Fred were active members of the Hemlock Farms community and were regulars at the weekly bocce tournaments and bingo nights. Elsie also greatly enjoyed the time she spent volunteering at the Hemlock Farms library and her involvement in the Happy Hookers knitting and crocheting group, which she joined in 1994. She loved having her family, and especially grandchildren, visit in the summer. Elsie is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Clara and George Adame, of Antrim, New Hampshire, her brother-in-law, Arnold Klingsberg, of Bayside, NY, her son and daughter-in-law, Mark and Ann, of Waccabuc, NY, one nephew, Nelson Adame, of Simsbury, CT, and his family, two nieces, Jane Mishra, of Great Neck, NY, and Joan Klingsberg, of Bayside, NY, and their families, and three grandchildren, Adam and Madeleine, both of New York, NY, and Aaron, of Waccabuc, NY. She was predeceased by her loving husband, Fred. The family is holding a private memorial service on July 7th, 2014 in New York, NY.

HAEFLINGER--Jacqueline, 58, passed away unexpectedly Wednesday July 2, 2014. Jacqueline is survived by her fathers Fred Haeflinger and Daniel Minerva, siblings Tom Haeflinger, Dawn Orazem, and Darlene Kase, neices Julya Haeflinger-Massa, Nicole and Danielle Rickards and numerous cousins, aunt and cousin. In addition to her loving family she is survived by Many close friends and extended family of New York University where she was Director of University events for over 20 years. Jacqueline is pre-deceased by her mother Lillian Connor. Services will held on Tuesday at 10am at St Francis Xavier church located on 16th St in Manhattan.

SCHAPIRO--Donald, passed away peacefully at home on July 3, 2014, at the age of 88. Born to John Max Schapiro and Lydia Chaitkin Schapiro in New York City, he graduated from Townsend Harris High School, Yale College '44, where he became an instructor in the department of economics, followed by Yale Law School '49, where he developed a course in legal accounting, which he continued to teach as a visiting professor for some 25 years. Joining the firm of Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, he left after two years to go to Washington, D.C., as Assistant Chief Counsel to the U.S. House of Representatives Ways and Means Subcommittee on Administration of the Internal Revenue Laws. Returning to New York, he became a partner at Barrett, Smith, Schapiro, Simon, & Armstrong. In 1988, he joined Chadbourne & Parke, where he worked as a senior tax partner until his death. Don is survived by his beloved wife Linda of 21 years; his loving children, Jane Schapiro and Robert Schapiro (Lillian), and stepchildren, Joshua Solomon (Geula), Abigail Solomon (Jason Teuscher), and Kate Solomon (David Wasserman); and his cherished grandchildren Rebecca Schapiro, Ruth Schapiro, and Sarah Schapiro and Rachel Solomon, Benjamin Solomon, Jacob Solomon, Jasper Teuscher, Rush Slivjanovski, Sekana Slivjanovski, and Solomon Wasserman. He was predeceased by his late wife Ruth Goldman Schapiro and by his brother Stephen Schapiro. Donations in Don's memory may be made to Yale Law School, P.O. Box 208341, New Haven, Connecticut 06520, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, July 8, at 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. The family will receive friends at their residence from 5pm to 8pm on Tuesday, July 8, Wednesday, July 9, and Thursday, July 10.
SCHAPIRO--Donald. We remember Don, beloved father, grandfather, advisor, and friend. With love, Jane, Robert, Josh, Abigail, and Kate

TENER--Gerard M.,on July 3, at age 57, after a courageous battle with cancer our cherished brother has left for an eternal fishing trip. He will always be in our hearts and thoughts. Through his years in the real estate industry he made many friends and had many professionally interesting positions. From Helmsley Spear in the early years, to management of an island resort in the 1990's, to family businesses in the final years, he always embraced a new frontier. An ardent Giant and Ranger fan, he followed his teams faithfully. A skilled boatsman and fisherman, his nieces and nephews will miss his leadership and guidance at sea. He will be remembered by all for his great heart, his wit and devotion to family and friends. Beloved brother of Marian, Richard, Martin, Terence, Damien, and Thomas. Adored uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. He is survived by his wife, Moira and daughters Angie and Bridget. Wake will be held Tuesday July 8 at Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Avenue, Mineola, 3 to 7pm. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's RC Church, Garden City, Wednesday, 10am.

WASSEM--Charles F. On July 1, 2014. Beloved husband of Jean. Loving dad, uncle and Pop Pop. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City. Mass Wednesday 10am St. Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City, In lieu of flowers, Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York, NY.

HART--Allen M. Hart. July 6, 2014 age 89. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. An indomitable spirit who leaves a body of American Expressionist art, that has and will continue to inspire people for generations. Funeral service: Temple Beth Shalom, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, 11:00am on Tuesday, July 8. Celebration of his life to be announced.

KUHN--Harold W.,loving husband, father, and grandfather, and professor emeritus of mathematics and economics at Princeton University, died at home on July 2. A pioneer in game theory and nonlinear programming, esteemed mentor to generations of students, staunch advocate for progressive causes and human rights, he conducted his life as a game of skill, yet knew it is a game of chance. He is mourned by his wife of 64 years, Estelle (nee Henkin), sons Cliff, Nick, and Jonathan, daughters-in-law Kathie, Beth and Michele, and was beloved "Grumpa" to Mike, Josh, Jeremy, Gabe, Lee, Emily and Jeffrey. No public service is planned; donations in his memory may be made to the ACLU.

BERDOW--Robert Henry, was born in Philadelphia on October 4th, 1939 and died on July 5th 2014. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a BA in English and from Wharton with an MBA. Robert became a devoted New Yorker and worked for several major investment houses including DLJ, Inc. and Dillon Reed, Inc. He was a successful institutional broker and private investor. Robert was also an active member of the New York Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center, an indefatigable world traveler, and for the last seven years, attended every semester of the Columbia University School of Continuing Education, studying history. He is survived by a sister, Marilouise Berdow, of Ocean City, NJ and two nephews. His friends request that any donations be made in Robert's name to either the LGBT Community Center or Columbia University.

van ECK--John C.,Jr., Mutual Fund Pioneer, died peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, Florida, on July 1, 2014. He was 98 years old. Mr. van Eck founded Van Eck Global, a mutual fund manager, in 1955. A pioneer of international investments, Mr. van Eck was early to recognize the potential for value in the post-war economic recoveries of Europe and Japan, and founded International Investors Incorporated in 1955 to provide a convenient investment vehicle for Americans to invest in foreign growth stocks. In 1968, after studying under the Austrian economist Ludwig von Mises at New York University, Mr. van Eck launched the country's first gold-oriented mutual fund in time to participate in the great gold bull market of the 1970s. Mr. van Eck was always a great believer in sound money and was wary of the powers of the Federal Reserve Bank. International Investors Gold Fund remains the oldest mutual fund to concentrate in precious metals mining shares. Today, Van Eck Global manages over $35 billion. Mr. van Eck was a relentless optimist, full of "joyful noise." He was flirtatious and a kind soul to the end. He hewed to his family's "Dutch" values of tolerance and openness to other ways and customs. Last, he was a Californian, having spent his early days there when sugar farmers and gold miners still loomed large and bulls ran on the beaches. Mr. van Eck received a BA from Williams College in 1936 and an MBA from Harvard University in 1938. From 1941 to 1945, he served in the U.S. Navy. He began his career as an investment banker at Morgan Stanley in 1946 where he remained for four years. He was a partner of Steckler & Moore, a New York Stock Exchange firm, from 1951 to 1955. During the course of his 50-year career, Mr. van Eck served as Chairman of the Foreign Analyst Committee of the New York Society of Security Analysts, Associate Editor for the Financial Analysts Journal, and as President of the New York Association of Foreign Analysts. He also served as a director of several corporations such as The Henley Group, Inc., Wheelabrator-Frye Inc., and the Eclipse Financial Trust. Mr. van Eck was born in San Francisco in 1915. His father, J.C. van Panthaleon Baron van Eck, was the founder of Shell Oil Co. in the United States and Managing Director of Royal Dutch Oil Co. Mr. van Eck is survived by his wife, Sigrid van Eck, his sisters Agnes Reed and Henriette Warfield, and his son Jan van Eck, who serves as Chief Executive Officer of Van Eck Global. He was predeceased by his other son, Derek van Eck. He is also survived by his two daughters-in-law, Cynthia van Eck and Deborah S. van Eck and six grandchildren.

YOON--Linda Lee. SG Partners deeply mourns the loss of our former colleague and dearest friend Linda Lee. Linda was beautiful inside and out; her intelligence, wit, warmth and zest for life inspired us all. She was a true friend and a fabulous colleague for eight years and she will be sorely missed by everyone who knew her. Our hearts go out to David and her darling girls and her entire family for their loss. Sheri Gellman, Emily Grad, Andi Grossman, Dianne Hurley, Anne Byrne and the SG Partners team

SCHAPIRO--Donald, passed away peacefully at home on July 3, 2014, at the age of 88. Born to John Max Schapiro and Lydia Chaitkin Schapiro in New York City, he graduated from Townsend Harris High School, Yale College '44, where he became an instructor in the department of economics, followed by Yale Law School '49, where he developed a course in legal accounting, which he continued to teach as a visiting professor for some 25 years. Joining the firm of Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, he left after two years to go to Washington, D.C., as Assistant Chief Counsel to the U.S. House of Representatives Ways and Means Subcommittee on Administration of the Internal Revenue Laws. Returning to New York, he became a partner at Barrett, Smith, Schapiro, Simon, & Armstrong. In 1988, he joined Chadbourne & Parke, where he worked as a senior tax partner until his death. Don is survived by his beloved wife Linda of 21 years; his loving children, Jane Schapiro and Robert Schapiro (Lillian), and stepchildren, Joshua Solomon (Geula), Abigail Solomon (Jason Teuscher), and Kate Solomon (David Wasserman); and his cherished grandchildren Rebecca Schapiro, Ruth Schapiro, and Sarah Schapiro and Rachel Solomon, Benjamin Solomon, Jacob Solomon, Jasper Teuscher, Rush Slivjanovski, Sekana Slivjanovski, and Solomon Wasserman. He was predeceased by his late wife Ruth Goldman Schapiro and by his brother Stephen Schapiro. Donations in Don's memory may be made to Yale Law School, P.O. Box 208341, New Haven, Connecticut 06520, or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, July 8, at 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. The family will receive friends at their residence from 5pm to 8pm on Tuesday, July 8, Wednesday, July 9, and Thursday, July 10.

Margaret, Lawrence, Madeline, Lisbeth

SCHAPIRO--Donald. The employees of Hugo Neu Corporation are deeply saddened by the passing of Donald Schapiro, who has been a valued outside counsel to the company over a period of more than 50 years. Don was a brilliant attorney and strategic advisor who exemplified the highest standards of business integrity and brought an enthusiasm to the practice of law that was unparalleled. He provided expert assistance in conceptualizing and implementing a variety of complex transactions that aided in the growth and success of Hugo Neu Corporation.
