JOHNPOLL--Leona. The friends of Leona Johnpoll are deeply saddened by her passing on June 13, 2014. A remarkable woman, a valued friend and colleague. We celebrate her memory, her long and influential career in politics and government, and all that she did for us. The friends of Leona Johnpoll

MYERS--Walter Dean, died July 1, 2014, at the age of 76 after a brief illness. Walter is mourned by all of us at Scholastic who were honored to work with him and to publish more than 25 of his 100 plus books for children. During a distinguished career spanning more than 45 years, Walter's contribution to children's and young adult literature included picture books, poetry, fiction and nonfiction titles, which were recognized with numerous honors, including two Newbery Honor medals, three National Book Award Finalists, and six Coretta Scott King Awards/Honors. Among his award-winning titles are hard-hitting novels about war: Fallen Angels (1988), about the Vietnam War, Sunrise Over Fallujah (2008) about Iraq and, most recently, Invasion (2010) set in World War II. Two of his picture books published by Scholastic, Harlem (1997), which won a Caldecott Honor, and Shadow of the Red Moon (1995), were illustrated by his talented son, author/illustrator, Christopher Myers. In 2012, Walter Dean Myers was appointed the National Ambassador for Young People's Literature by the Children's Book Council and toured the nation promoting the importance of reading for children of all ages. Walter changed the face of children's literature by representing the diversity of the children of our nation in his award-winning books. He was a deeply authentic person and writer who urged other authors, editors and publishers not only to make sure every child could find him or herself in a book, but also to tell compelling and challenging stories that would inspire children to reach their full potential. Our favorite quote from Walter is a clarion call to embrace the power of books to inform and transform lives he said, "Once I began to read, I began to exist." He will be missed by us all. Richard Robinson Chairman, President and CEO, Scholastic Inc.

SCHAPIRO--Donald. All of us at Chadbourne & Parke LLP, the firm to which he devoted the last 26 years of his distinguished career, wish to express sorrow on the loss of our beloved partner, colleague and friend Donald Schapiro, who passed away peacefully on July 3 at the age of 88. Don was a leading practitioner and our active partner until his passing on Thursday, literally closing transactions, planning and structuring for opportunities and providing sophisticated advice to his clients until recent months. This was only a small part of his many achievements during a long and remarkable career. Don graduated from Yale College in 1944 (Phi Beta Kappa), Yale Law School in 1949 (Order of the Coif) and was a visiting professor at the Yale Law School for some 25 years (where he taught Legal Accounting to some of today's recognized lawyers and business leaders). After a brief period at the Paul Weiss law firm, he became Assistant Chief Counsel to the United States House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee on Administration of the Internal Revenue Laws. Don then became a member and a name partner in the law firm Barrett Smith Schapiro Simon & Armstrong until 1988 when he and many of his then partners joined Chadbourne & Parke LLP. He was Chairman of the New York State Bar Association Tax Section, was on the Boards of numerous organizations and received many awards and acknowledgements in the legal community. Don was an absolutely brilliant lawyer (and not just tax lawyer, as he often said). And throughout his distinguished career he was a continuing mentor and confidant to young lawyers, business executives, government representatives, and his numerous and great clients, friends and colleagues. Our thoughts and prayers are with his loving family during this most difficult time. We will all miss Donald Schapiro. The Lawyers and Staff of Chadbourne & Parke LLP

WEBSTER--Elizabeth "Lisa" McGraw, 88, died Saturday June 28th at her home in Sun Valley, ID. Born in New York City to Elizabeth Murtland Woodwell and Curtis Whittlesey McGraw. Lisa was a long time resident of Princeton, NJ. She attended Miss Fine's School, Foxcroft and Finch College. In the summer of 2011, Lisa made a difficult emotional decision, due to being a "Princeton girl" at heart, to move her residence to Idaho, where she had maintained houses in the Sun Valley area for decades. She still was able to make a few trips to visit Princeton after that, but lived the rest of her years being able to see the beautiful mountains of Idaho and enjoy the summer skating programs. Lisa's great passions were figure skating and her beloved Cavalier King Charles Spaniels. She was very active in the figure skating world and supported many promising skaters some of whom became Olympic, national and international champions. Lisa is survived by her daughters, Lisette Stoltzfus Edmond and Marian Stoltzfus Paen and her son Curtis McGraw Webster, their spouses, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A Memorial service will be held at Nassau Presbyterian Church, Princeton, NJ, Saturday July 26, 2014 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: Hospice and Palliative Care of The Wood River Valley, P.O. Box 4320, Sun Valley, ID 83340 or SAVE, A Friend to Homeless Animals, 900 Herrontown Road, Princeton, NJ 08540.

BERMAN--Herbert. The members of Department of Surgery mourn the loss of Mr. Herbert Berman, beloved father of Dr. Russell Berman. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Berman and his family on their loss. H. Leon Pachter M.D. F.A.C.S The George David Stewart Professor and Chair Department of Surgery NYU School of Medicine

AZAROFF--Leonid V.,an internationally known crystallographer, died in Naples, Florida, on July 3 at age 88. A graduate of Tufts University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he later affiliated with the faculties of the Armor Research Institute and the Illinois Institute of Technology. In 1965, he was appointed as the founding Director of the Institute of Material Sciences at the University of Connecticut, from which he retired in 1992. Dr. Azaroff was the author of numerous textbooks, scientific papers, and books, including his most recent, "Physics Over Easy Breakfasts with Beth and Physics." He is survived by his wife Beth Sulzer-Azaroff, his sister, three children, two nieces, two grandchildren, a grandniece, and a great-grandniece.

BERMAN, Herbert E. The Graduate Center, CUNY, deeply mourns the loss of Herbert Berman, a wise and valued colleague and an unflagging supporter of New York City and the Graduate Center's mission and programs. His energy, commitment and irrepressible good cheer will continue to inspire and guide us. We send heartfelt condolences to his family. Chase F. Robinson, President, The Graduate Center

BERMAN--Herbert E.,on July 6, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Loving father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Devoted New York City Councilman and public servant. Services Tuesday July 8, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

EISNER--Eugene, 91, of Manhattan, "The Mayor of 57th Street," died on July 3, 2014. He gave himself that name because during his time as a pharmacist on that major city thoroughfare his clients were among Gotham's glitterati. A graduate of Columbia University's pharmacy school, he was a dedicated professional and went the extra step with his customers in the age before chain drug stores. A Veteran of World War II, he served as a cryptographer in North Africa. His daughter, Robin Eisner, will always remember him and continue his legacy of being "hungry to learn (HTL)," of sharing knowledge and of cherishing his beloved city's hometown newspaper, The New York Times.

BLOOMBERG--Gerry, 86, who believed an event only truly happened once it was reported in The New York Times, died peacefully in New York City on June 25th. Gerry was a key force in turning The Youngstown Playhouse in Ohio into one of the top regional theaters in the country. In 1980, she moved to New York and became a theatrical agent and, subsequently, the writer of ABC's "Home Show" newsletter. Gerry was larger than life with a passion for the arts, which she passed on to her grateful son, Stuart, whom she leaves along with three grandchildren, Lily, Thea and Peter, and two great-grandchildren, Mary and George.

EDDEY--Beth M.,71, of New York City, died peacefully on Sunday, July 6, 2014 after a lengthy illness. Beloved sister of George and Janice, Gary, Wynn and Roy Eddey and many nieces and nephews. Memorial visitation at Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St., New York City on Wednesday, July 9, 2014 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm.

HOBBY--Diana. Diana Poteat Stallings passed away the 4th of July 2014 in Houston, with her family by her side. She was born on the 22nd of April 1931, in New York City to Helen Poteat and Laurence Tucker Stallings. She graduated from Chatham Hall School in 1948 and Radcliffe College in 1952 (Phi Beta Kappa). She was working for Chatham Hall when she married Ensign William P. Hobby, Jr., on the 11th of September, 1954. The wedding took place at Forest Home, the Poteat family home near Yanceyville, NC. he and Bill lived in Washington, D.C. where he was stationed until 1957. While in Washington she earned an M.A. in English Literature from Georgetown University and worked for the Experiment in International Living and the Central Intelligence Agency. In Houston, she was book editor of the Houston Post in the 1950s and 1960s. She earned her Ph.D. in English Literature from Rice University in 1981. She was a William Butler Yeats scholar and wrote her dissertation on his work. She was associate editor of Studies in English Literature from 1979-1991, and associate editor emerita thereafter. She had a great love of the English language, a passion for literature, was a supporter of libraries, and a lifelong patron of the humanities in Texas. Diana served on the boards of St. John's School, Memorial Park Conservancy, Friends of Hermann Park, Harry Ransom Center, Texas Institute of Letters, Chihuahuan Desert Research Institute in Alpine, and Wolf Trap Foundation for the Performing Arts in Virginia, among others. She was a founding board member of the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center and was on the selection committee for the Lady Bird Johnson Highway Beautification Awards that honored people working to restore and preserve Texas' natural treasures. Diana was committed to the conservation of air, water, and wildlife in addition to natural beauty. Many of her happiest times were spent at Forest Home in North Carolina. She loved riding horses and walking in the woods with her family, her friends, and her dogs. Diana is survived by her husband of 60 years, Bill Hobby, their children and their spouses, Laura and John Beckworth, Paul and Janet Hobby, Andrew and Teresa Hobby, Kate and Steve Gibson, and their grandchildren Will, Carter, and John Beckworth, Grace, Walker and Eric Hobby, Caroline, Carson, and Wheeler Gibson, and Spencer Gourley. She is also survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Sylvia and Will Lowe of Alexandria, VA. Services handled in Houston are under the direction of Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, the Funeral Directors Since 1936, 713-789-3005, geohlewis.com. The funeral service is to be conducted at half-past ten o'clock in the morning on Tuesday, the 8th of July, at Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church, 6221 Main Street in Houston, where the Rev'd Neil Alan Willard, Rector, the Rev'd Sam R. Todd, Jr., Assisting Priest, and the Rev'd Kit Wallingford, Assisting Priest, are to officiate. The family will gather for a private interment at Glenwood Cemetery. In lieu of customary remembrances, contributions in Diana's memory may be directed to the charity of one's choice.

BERDOW--Robert Henry, was born in Philadelphia on October 4th, 1939 and died on July 5th 2014. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a BA in English and from Wharton with an MBA. Robert became a devoted New Yorker and worked for several major investment houses including DLJ, Inc. and Dillon Reed, Inc. He was a successful institutional broker and private investor. Robert was also an active member of the New York Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center, an indefatigable world traveler, and for the last seven years, attended every semester of the Columbia University School of Continuing Education, studying history. He is survived by a sister, Marilouise Berdow, of Ocean City, NJ and two nephews. His friends request that any donations be made in Robert's name to either the LGBT Community Center or Columbia University.

BERMAN--Herbert E. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Herbert E. Berman, former New York City council member and chair of the council finance committee as well as special assistant for government relations to the president at the CUNY Graduate School and University Center. Mr. Berman was a stalwart champion of CUNY's educational mission during his distinguished public service career and beyond. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family and friends. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson CUNY Board of Trustees James B. Milliken, Chancellor

COLEMAN--Beatrice, Widow of Chester, died on July 5, 2014 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. She will be missed by those who loved her, Martin, Enid, Gail, Alina and all of the music students whose lives she touched.
BERMAN--Herbert. A devoted father, brother and dear and special friend. He ennobled public service. To know him was to admire and respect him. He will be missed. Martin Begun

ZIEGLER--Monroe S.,died peacefully July 3 at the age of 88. A decorated vet, his aircraft surplus store on Canal St. was a known landmark in the 60s-80s. He retired in 1990 to Escondido, CA and was predeceased by loving wife, Joan in 2007 and survived by sons Sam, Larry, and four grandchildren.

YOON--Linda Lee. SG Partners deeply mourns the loss of our former colleague and dearest friend Linda Lee. Linda was beautiful inside and out; her intelligence, wit, warmth and zest for life inspired us all. She was a true friend and a fabulous colleague for eight years and she will be sorely missed by everyone who knew her. Our hearts go out to David and her darling girls and her entire family for their loss. Sheri Gellman, Emily Grad, Andi Grossman, Dianne Hurley, Anne Byrne and the SG Partners team

WENDY--Calvin, Died July 7, 2014, after a brief illness. Dear and loving husband and best friend to his wife Diane. Devoted father to Meg and son-in-law Guy Geslin. Proud grandfather to Matt and Chris. A good, fine and happy person to all who knew him. Visitation, Frank E. Campbell Chapel, NYC, Thursday, July 10th. Contributions in his memory: Sala Institute for Child & Family Centered Care at NYU Medical Center.

WOLFSON--Monte. We record with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Monte Wolfson. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

TOW--Claire, visionary, courageous, wise, generous, kind, accomplished, loyal and incomparable friend. Claire's dimpled, wholehearted smile embraced all in her sphere. Her personal warmth nurtured us and so many others. She was the exemplar of humanism and lovingness, and taught us much. Her strategic philanthropy repairs the world and will continue to make a difference. We hold her in our hearts. With love to Len, the children and all the family, Sandra and Arnold Gold

TOW--Claire, The Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend and benefactor, Claire Tow. Claire was a devoted supporter of the Gold Foundation, embracing humanism in medicine because she herself was the ultimate humanitarian. She approached her life and the people in it with intelligence and enthusiasm. Through her unique ability to see connections among the organizations she supported, Claire championed networks of like-minded activists to advance and amplify their work. Claire and her husband, Len, never forgot the opportunities afforded them, which propelled them to make opportunities for others. We were so proud and delighted when Claire chose to honor Len by endowing the Leonard Tow Humanism-in-Medicine Awards at our Foundation, helping to establish a generation of exemplars of humanistic practice. We express our deepest condolences to Len, Emily, Andrew, Frank and the entire Tow family. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D. Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D. President/CEO

TOW--Claire. The students and faculty of the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism offer their condolences to Leonard Tow on the death of his cherished wife and to Emily Tow Jackson, Frank Tow, and Andrew Tow on the loss of their beloved mother and to the extended family, loving caretakers, and countless friends of Claire Tow. The Tow Foundation, established by Claire and Leonard Tow, showed a willingness to support our school and its public educational mission at a very early stage of our development. Thanks to their generosity, we were able to establish the Tow-Knight Center for Entrepreneurial Journalism. We are grateful to the Tows for their early support and are honored that the CUNY J-School has a center bearing the Tow family name. Sarah Bartlett, Dean Stephen B. Shepard, Founding Dean Jeff Jarvis, Director, Tow-Knight Center for Entrepreneurial Journalism

TOW--Claire. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of WNET, we note with deep sorrow the passing of Claire Tow. Together with her husband, WNET Trustee Leonard Tow, she played an instrumental role in creating a strong public television presence in the New York tri-state area. Her passionate devotion to culture, arts and education will never be forgotten. Our thoughts are with her family and we join them in mourning the passing of a wonderful contributor to our community. James S. Tisch, Chairman Neal Shapiro, President & CEO

TOW--Claire. The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter is deeply saddened by the passing of Claire Tow, whose courageous 14-year battle with ALS was an inspiration to us all. Our heartfelt condolences to her devoted family Len, Emily, Frank and Andrew. Allen Popowitz, Chairman Dorine Gordon, President & CEO

TOW--Claire. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts are saddened by the passing of Claire Tow, a long-standing friend of the performing arts, and Lincoln Center Theater in particular where her generous support led to the naming of its newest theater in her honor. The loss of her caring spirit leaves a void, but her legacy - philanthropic, professional and personal - will remain. We extend our sympathies to her husband Leonard and three children and eight grandchildren, her extended family, and her many dear friends. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

TOW--Claire. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Claire Tow, an extraordinary supporter and advocate of Hospital programs through The Tow Foundation. As the founding benefactor of the Hospital's David Z. Rosensweig Genomics Research Center, The Tow Foundation has enabled promising research with the potential to transform the lives of patients affected by autoimmune and inflammatory diseases. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Leonard and to the entire Tow family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief and Medical Director Hospital for Special Surgery

TOW--Claire L. The Boards of Overseers and Managers of Memorial Sloan Kettering are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and generous benefactor, Claire L. Tow. Together with her husband, Leonard, and The Tow Foundation, she provided generous support for a wide range of high-profile initiatives, including a state-of-the-art pediatric day hospital and pediatric inpatient unit that are named in her honor. Despite her own struggle with illness, Mrs. Tow remained a committed, skilled, and foresighted philanthropist, never forgetting the suffering of others and working tirelessly to alleviate it. Her visionary altruism, wise counsel, and friendship will be deeply missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, children, and grandchildren. Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman Craig B. Thompson, MD President and CEO Richard J. O'Reilly, MD Chair, Department of Pediatrics Claire L. Tow Chair in Pediatric Oncology Research

TOW--Claire. With heartfelt sadness, the Trustees and Administration of Barnard College mourn the passing of Claire Tow, who was a devoted friend and benefactor of the College, together with her husband Leonard Tow and their daughter Emily Tow Jackson '88, a Barnard alumna and trustee. In recent years, the Tow Foundation has established multiple funds to support important Barnard initiatives, including the Tow Foundation Public Service Internship Program, the Tow Research Fellowships, the Tow Professorships for Distinguished Scholars and Practitioners, and the Tow Award for Innovative and Outstanding Pedagogy at the College. In all of these realms, our faculty and students have benefited beyond measure from Claire's love of education and spirit of giving. Barnard honors the memory of this wonderful woman and extends its deepest sympathies to Leonard, Emily, granddaughter Molly (Barnard '15), and their entire family. Jolyne Caruso-FitzGerald Chair, Board of Trustees Debora Spar, President

TOW--Claire. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Claire Tow. She was an elegant and accomplished person, and we will miss her. Claire loved the theater, and we are so proud that the newest performance space on the Lincoln Center campus is named after her. She joins Vivian and Mitzi in the great pantheon of women who truly believed that the theater is a force for good. We send sympathy and love to her husband Leonard, a beloved Vice-Chairman of our Board of Directors, and to the entire Tow family. J.Tomilson Hill, Chairman Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director
SCHAPIRO--Donald. The Waterside Plaza family mourns the death of Donald Schapiro, its partner and mentor. His wisdom and unending humanity will be sorely missed.

SCHAPIRO--Donald. All of us at Chadbourne & Parke LLP, the firm to which he devoted the last 26 years of his distinguished career, wish to express sorrow on the loss of our beloved partner, colleague and friend Donald Schapiro, who passed away peacefully on July 3 at the age of 88. Don was a leading practitioner and our active partner until his passing on Thursday, literally closing transactions, planning and structuring for opportunities and providing sophisticated advice to his clients until recent months. This was only a small part of his many achievements during a long and remarkable career. Don graduated from Yale College in 1944 (Phi Beta Kappa), Yale Law School in 1949 (Order of the Coif) and was a visiting professor at the Yale Law School for some 25 years (where he taught Legal Accounting to some of today's recognized lawyers and business leaders). After a brief period at the Paul Weiss law firm, he became Assistant Chief Counsel to the United States House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee on Administration of the Internal Revenue Laws. Don then became a member and a name partner in the law firm Barrett Smith Schapiro Simon & Armstrong until 1988 when he and many of his then partners joined Chadbourne & Parke LLP. He was Chairman of the New York State Bar Association Tax Section, was on the Boards of numerous organizations and received many awards and acknowledgements in the legal community. Don was an absolutely brilliant lawyer (and not just tax lawyer, as he often said). And throughout his distinguished career he was a continuing mentor and confidant to young lawyers, business executives, government representatives, and his numerous and great clients, friends and colleagues. Our thoughts and prayers are with his loving family during this most difficult time. We will all miss Donald Schapiro. The Lawyers and Staff of Chadbourne & Parke LLP

SCHAPIRO--Donald. The employees of Hugo Neu Corporation are deeply saddened by the passing of Donald Schapiro, who has been a valued outside counsel to the company over a period of more than 50 years. Don was a brilliant attorney and strategic advisor who exemplified the highest standards of business integrity and brought an enthusiasm to the practice of law that was unparalleled. He provided expert assistance in conceptualizing and implementing a variety of complex transactions that aided in the growth and success of Hugo Neu Corporation. We will miss him greatly and offer our heartfelt condolences to his devoted wife, Linda, and his children and stepchildren and their families. Wendy Kelman Neu, President and CEO

SCHAPIRO--Donald. The Dorot Foundation mourns the death of Donald Schapiro, cherished counselor, trusted advisor and dear friend. We will miss the expertise, thoughtfulness and zest for life that he brought to all our interactions. We send our deepest sympathies to Linda and the entire family. May his memory be a blessing and a comfort to all who knew him.

MYERS--Walter Dean, died July 1, 2014, at the age of 76 after a brief illness. Walter is mourned by all of us at Scholastic who were honored to work with him and to publish more than 25 of his 100 plus books for children. During a distinguished career spanning more than 45 years, Walter's contribution to children's and young adult literature included picture books, poetry, fiction and nonfiction titles, which were recognized with numerous honors, including two Newbery Honor medals, three National Book Award Finalists, and six Coretta Scott King Awards/Honors. Among his award-winning titles are hard-hitting novels about war: Fallen Angels (1988), about the Vietnam War, Sunrise Over Fallujah (2008) about Iraq and, most recently, Invasion (2010) set in World War II. Two of his picture books published by Scholastic, Harlem (1997), which won a Caldecott Honor, and Shadow of the Red Moon (1995), were illustrated by his talented son, author/illustrator, Christopher Myers. In 2012, Walter Dean Myers was appointed the National Ambassador for Young People's Literature by the Children's Book Council and toured the nation promoting the importance of reading for children of all ages. Walter changed the face of children's literature by representing the diversity of the children of our nation in his award-winning books. He was a deeply authentic person and writer who urged other authors, editors and publishers not only to make sure every child could find him or herself in a book, but also to tell compelling and challenging stories that would inspire children to reach their full potential. Our favorite quote from Walter is a clarion call to embrace the power of books to inform and transform lives he said, "Once I began to read, I began to exist." He will be missed by us all. Richard Robinson Chairman, President and CEO, Scholastic Inc.

LEVY--Barbara Voorhis. Born May 30, 1925 in Englewood NJ, passed away June 27, 2014 in New York City. WWII-helped make Norden Bomb Sites. Columbia University School of General Studies, 1948 B.A., active and 1st president of alumni association Member: Friends of School of General Studies, Congregation Daat Elohim, board member and Vice President emeritis. Editor at Columbia University Press and IBM. 1959ff rehabbed with husband Upper Westside brownstones into private dwellings, successfully opposed (later aborted) Riverside-Amsterdam urban renewal project. President P.S.9 Parents Association; 1975/6-elected to district school board. On January 9, 1960 married Herbert. Leaves husband, sons David and Alec (Lucretia), granddaughters Hannah, Ariel and Miryam, brother Russell, nieces Susan (Hugh), Alison and Nancy (Ted) and their children. Memorial Service: Sunday, July 13 at 3pm, Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and W. 91st St., NYC.

KAMBERG--Stephen, age 80, lost his valiant battle to Pancreatic Cancer July 8th, 2014. Beloved husband of Judy for 49 years. Father to Mark, and Jeffrey, Father-in-Law to Marci, adoring Opa to Alexa and Adam. Founder of S. Kamberg & Company, Stephen was successful in business and a true good friend to many. He will be remembered forever. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, July 10th, at "Schwartz Brothers." 114-03 Queens Blvd. Forest Hills, New York.
IDE--Linda Ann Weinstein, on July 7, 2014. Loving mother of devoted sons T. Jay and Mark. Cherished daughter of Joyce and the late Dr. Robert Weinstein. Admired sister of Susan and John.

HOLLANDER--Anne, died on July 6, 2014 at her home in New York at the age of 83. She is survived by her husband, Thomas Nagel, her daughters, Martha Hollander and Elizabeth Hollander, her grandsons Adam and Noah Bumas, and her granddaughter Lucy Archibald. The funeral will be Thursday, July 10, at 11:30am, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, New York, Tel. 212-288-3500.
FRISCHER--Barry. To Ilene and family; we remember Barry, a beautiful person with a love of life. With love, Libby, Charlie, Abigail and Sara Frischer

EDDEY--Beth M.,71, of New York City, died peacefully on Sunday, July 6, 2014 after a lengthy illness. Beloved sister of George and Janice, Gary, Wynn and Roy Eddey and many nieces and nephews. Memorial visitation at Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St., New York City on Wednesday, July 9, 2014 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm.

DEMOS--Emanuel George, passed away on July 4th, 2014. Born on November 7, 1938 in New Britain, Connecticut to George and Angeliki Demos, he graduated from Yale University magna cum laude, majoring in economics and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He received his Juris Doctorate from Yale Law School and clerked on the Connecticut Supreme Court. Thereafter he served on the faculty of Harvard Law School for two years. In New York, he practiced law at the firm of Shearman & Sterling and then joined the tax practice of White & Case. He then became an executive at two oil companies and a partner in several petroleum ventures. He served as the pro bono general legal counsel for the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America for the last 15 years. He also was a former president of the Archdiocesan Cathedral in New York, an Archon of the Ecumenical Patriarchate, chairman of the Cathedral School Board, a former trustee of Hellenic College and of the Archbishop Lakovos Library, and founder and President of the Kallinikeion Foundation. He also served on the advisory council of the Byzantine and Modern Greek Studies Program at Queens College. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Helen (Kocolatos) Demos, his son and daughter-in-law George and Chrysanthy Demos, a daughter, and grandsons, Michael, Emanuel, and Angelo. The viewing will be Thursday July 10th from 6 to 9pm with a Trisagion service at 7:30pm and the funeral will be Friday, July 11th at 11am, both at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral in New York at 319 East 74th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Holy Trinity Cathedral.

COLEMAN--Beatrice, Widow of Chester, died on July 5, 2014 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. She will be missed by those who loved her, Martin, Enid, Gail, Alina and all of the music students whose lives she touched.

BERGER--Ronald M.,Age 81 of Boca Raton, Florida, passed away on July 4, 2014. Devoted husband of Gloria and the previously-deceased Myra, beloved father of Karen Blumenthal (Ivan), Steven Berger (Nicole) and stepfather of Chaim Jaffe (Esa), loving grandfather of nine and beloved brother-in-law of Judy Bernstein. He dedicated his life to his family, his work and his synagogue. He will live in our hearts forever.

AZRIELI--David Joshua, C.M.,C.Q., M. Arch. The Yeshiva University family and the Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University mourn the passing of its Trustee Emeritus and honorary degree recipient, David J. Azrieli, an Architect, Builder and Developer, a billionaire, who with his wife, Stephanie Lefcort, a former librarian and an artistic painter, is a Yeshiva University Benefactor. He named the Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration in 1982 with a gift of $1 million (US funds) and has since made additional major Benefactor level gifts to his school, most recently in July 2012, with a $10 million (CAD) gift to establish the Azrieli Scholarships Program at the Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration made by the Azrieli Foundation Inc., of which his daughter, Dr. Naomi Azrieli, is the Chair. These combined gifts to Yeshiva University are among the largest of the total of more than $100 million the Azrieli family has donated to educational and other projects over the past 23 years. David Azrieli relinquished his Chairmanship of The Azrieli Group Ltd. In Israel last week due to failing health and his daughter, Danna Azrieli, has been appointed Acting Chair overseeing the 13 Israeli Malls for which he coined the name Canion which combines the Hebrew words for purchasing and parking. The Icon Mall is the Azrieli Towers in Tel Aviv renowned for its three iconic geometric designs. He also was a major industrialist with subsidiaries in energy, water and environment industries and had significant holdings in banking and the credit card business. He was President in Canada of, Canpro Investments, a privately held real estate development and management company with headquarters in Montreal. The Azrieli Foundation Inc. focuses primarily on education, donating large amounts to schools and universities, also funding Holocaust education and creating programs for early education and intervention, among others. As Presidents of Yeshiva University during the time since David J. Azrieli was our foremost leader in Canada, we were privileged to enjoy his friendship and sage advice which he also shared with the Deans of the Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration, Dr. David J. Schnall and the new Dean Dr. Rona Novick. He was especially close to Rabbi Dr. Herbert C. Dobrinsky, Vice President for University Affairs who serves as our University's liaison officer with Canadian Jewry, and our National Director of Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University, Stuart Haber. All of us extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Stefanie Azrieli, their children and grandchildren: Rafael (Rafi) Azrieli, Sharon and Avi Perez, Matthew and Solomon Azrieli; Dr. Naomi and Francois Blanc, Joseph, Gabriel and Madeleine Blanc; Danna and Danny Hakim, Galia and Ella. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus Jeremy Magence, National President CFYU

ANGELOWITZ--Moses. Moses grew up on the lower east side during the great depression. He served in the Armed Forces during the Korean war, went to culinary school and into banquet management, working for years at Temple Israel in Great Neck. He moved on to a successful career in the field of automobile leasing. He was loved by all those with whom he interacted, professionally and personally. He was the wise man of his neighborhood. He was a wonderful storyteller, among the best at telling jokes and making others laugh. He was a devoted son, dedicated and responsible father, father-in-law, and friend who was always there when needed. He was blessed with enjoying his retirement of 20 years, coming to enjoy gardening and reading. As he now passes from this earth, he joins Pearl, his beloved wife of 56 years in everlasting rest and peace.

WILLIAMS--David T. Internationally renowned interior designer for the hotel and hospitality industry for over 65 years peacefully passed away at his home in New York City on July 5, 2014. Born in Burlington, IA on April 10, 1918, David, a Veteran of World War II began his career as an interior decorator at Marshall Field & Company in Chicago, Il. It was in 1946 when hotel magnet, Conrad N. Hilton through Marshall Fields hired David to decorate the Stevens Hotel in Chicago (renamed The Conrad Hilton in 1951). Impressed by his extraordinary talent and creative ability, Hilton hired David to work at the Hilton Hotels Corporation as Vice President and Director Statler Hilton Studios. When Conrad Hilton purchased The Waldorf-Astoria in 1949, David moved to New York to work on the decor of both The Waldorf and The Plaza Hotels. David's genius for design was soon found in hotels around the world. His success continued and in 1958 he established his own company David T. Williams Inc. His business flourished with the addition of new hotel companies and clients; Loews, Canadian Pacific, Forte, Hyatt, the corporate offices of Hilton Hotels, the Cornell Club in New York to name a few. In November 1996 in celebration of his 50 years of decorating for Hilton Hotels, David was inducted into The Waldorf-Astoria Distinguished Alumni. On the occasion Barron Hilton, the son of Conrad and former Chairman of Hilton Hotels Corporation wrote to David "the standards that you set at the many flagship Hilton Hotels still stand today as examples of your outstanding interior design work. The mark of design excellence which you have left imprinted throughout the world has been a great tradition in the hotel industry and will be long remembered." David was preceded by his parents - Nora and Edward Williams; his brother, Clarence Williams and sister, Lillian Gamet. He leaves his brother William E. Williams and sister-in-law Doddie Williams of Spokane, WA along with several nieces and nephews. As per his wish, David has been cremated and will be buried with his parents in Missouri. Later there will be a gathering of friends to remember David T. and his wonderful life.

WENDY--Calvin, Died July 7, 2014, after a brief illness. Dear and loving husband and best friend to his wife Diane. Devoted father to Meg and son-in-law Guy Geslin. Proud grandfather to Matt and Chris. A good, fine and happy person to all who knew him. Visitation, Frank E. Campbell Chapel, NYC, Thursday, July 10th. Contributions in his memory: Sala Institute for Child & Family Centered Care at NYU Medical Center.

TOW--Claire L. The Boards of Overseers and Managers of Memorial Sloan Kettering are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and generous benefactor, Claire L. Tow. Together with her husband, Leonard, and The Tow Foundation, she provided generous support for a wide range of high-profile initiatives, including a state-of-the-art pediatric day hospital and pediatric inpatient unit that are named in her honor. Despite her own struggle with illness, Mrs. Tow remained a committed, skilled, and foresighted philanthropist, never forgetting the suffering of others and working tirelessly to alleviate it. Her visionary altruism, wise counsel, and friendship will be deeply missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, children, and grandchildren. Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman Craig B. Thompson, MD President and CEO Richard J. O'Reilly, MD Chair, Department of Pediatrics Claire L. Tow Chair in Pediatric Oncology Research

TOW--Claire. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Claire Tow. She was an elegant and accomplished person, and we will miss her. Claire loved the theater, and we are so proud that the newest performance space on the Lincoln Center campus is named after her. She joins Vivian and Mitzi in the great pantheon of women who truly believed that the theater is a force for good. We send sympathy and love to her husband Leonard, a beloved Vice-Chairman of our Board of Directors, and to the entire Tow family. J.Tomilson Hill, Chairman Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

TOW--Claire. Claire Tow, age 83, died peacefully on July 7th at Norwalk Hospital with her loving family by her side after a 14 year struggle with Lou Gehrig's Disease (ALS). Born on August 29, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY, she was the daughter of the late Sigmund and Sadie Schneider. Claire brought joy and friendship to countless people during her life. She was known for her fun loving spirit, optimistic outlook, caring advice, good companionship and deep love of her friends and family. Claire's relationships were not casual and many lasted a lifetime. Despite the challenges of ALS, Claire continued to regularly attend concerts and theater events in CT and NY, luncheons with her friends and was present at milestone events in the lives of all of her children and grandchildren. Claire was born to challenging circumstances on the eve of the Great Depression to immigrant parents. She attended NYC public schools, Brooklyn College and became an elementary school teacher. Claire met her husband Leonard at Brooklyn College in 1949 and they enjoyed a wonderful life-long romance and partnership of 65 years. Through good times and bad they pursued their ambitions and followed their spirit of adventure, which led them on journeys to all corners the globe, and later to successful business ventures and careers devoted to deep and impactful philanthropy. Claire was a co-founder, with her husband, of the cable television company Century Communications Corporation and the cellular telephone company Centennial Cellular Corporation. She served as a director and active executive of both companies, where she also had a long successful career developing a human resources department with the emphasis on "human." Valued as a fair and caring employer, she was known for her problem solving skills and wise counsel. She created a unique work environment, the memory of which longtime employees still treasure. In addition to her professional career, Claire was a generous philanthropist. She devoted much of her time and skills to the many institutions that were dear to her. She was the president of The Tow Foundation, the charitable foundation she and her husband founded in 1988. Through grants from the Foundation, Claire offered opportunities for personal success and joy, and helped to alleviate pain and suffering for countless individuals. Claire guided the family's philanthropy to address the needs of the disadvantaged, medical research, treatment and care, the cultural arts, and higher education. Claire and Leonard are members of the Giving Pledge. Claire is survived by her loving and devoted husband of 62 years, Leonard, her three children and their spouses Frank Tow and Ronnie Klein, Andrew and Kathleen Tow and Emily Tow Jackson and Dean Jackson, as well as eight grandchildren: Cameron Tow, Molly Tow, Olivia Tow, Celia Tow, Grace Tow, James Jackson, Benjamin Jackson and Hope Jackson. Claire will be remembered as a beloved friend, confidant, colleague, tennis partner, party planner extraordinaire, and most of all for her generous heart and beautiful smile. She will be missed by many far and wide. Contributions in Claire's name may be made to the ALS Association Greater New York Chapter.

POTTER--Annette. Our beloved mother and grandmother passed away on July 8, 2014 at the age of 92. She was devoted to and proud of her family - husband, Lester Potter, who died in 2007, children Bonnie, Tina and Robert Potter, son-in-law Andrew Freireich , daughter-in-law Mirjam Potter, grandchildren Alix Freireich, Anya and Nina Potter. We will love and miss her always. Funeral services Thursday, July 10th at 11:00am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Manhattan. Donations may be made to Metropolitan Jewish Hospice or American Jewish World Service.

MARTIRANO--Christopher M.,on July 8, 2014. Beloved companion of Dennis, Nikko, Tess, Abby, Anthony, and Luis. Loving brother of Colleen (Jerry) Dance, Vivian (Michael) Chambers, Michael Brady, Kevin Brady, and Robert Dancey. Christopher was the devoted son of Irene and the late John Brady. He was the proud owner of Capri Cleaners NYC Corp. Friends will be received Friday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave (at 81st) Mass of Christian burial Saturday at St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church 11:30am.

LEVY--Barbara Voorhis. Born May 30, 1925 in Englewood NJ, passed away June 27, 2014 in New York City. WWII-helped make Norden Bomb Sites. Columbia University School of General Studies, 1948 B.A., active and 1st president of alumni association Member: Friends of School of General Studies, Congregation Daat Elohim, board member and Vice President emeritis. Editor at Columbia University Press and IBM. 1959ff rehabbed with husband Upper Westside brownstones into private dwellings, successfully opposed (later aborted) Riverside-Amsterdam urban renewal project. President P.S.9 Parents Association; 1975/6-elected to district school board. On January 9, 1960 married Herbert. Leaves husband, sons David and Alec (Lucretia), granddaughters Hannah, Ariel and Miryam, brother Russell, nieces Susan (Hugh), Alison and Nancy (Ted) and their children. Memorial Service: Sunday, July 13 at 3pm, Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and W. 91st St., NYC.

KAMBERG--Stephen, age 80, lost his valiant battle to Pancreatic Cancer July 8th, 2014. Beloved husband of Judy for 49 years. Father to Mark, and Jeffrey, Father-in-Law to Marci, adoring Opa to Alexa and Adam. Founder of S. Kamberg & Company, Stephen was successful in business and a true good friend to many. He will be remembered forever. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, July 10th, at "Schwartz Brothers." 114-03 Queens Blvd. Forest Hills, New York.

JAFFE--David, retired Chairman of the Music Department at Tilden High School, was born in Brooklyn, NY on May 17, 1926 and died on July 7, 2014 in Great Neck, NY. David is survived by his wife of 48 years, Ellen S. Jaffe, his daughter and son and their spouses and his two granddaughters.

HOLLANDER--Anne, died on July 6, 2014 at her home in New York at the age of 83. She is survived by her husband, Thomas Nagel, her daughters, Martha Hollander and Elizabeth Hollander, her grandsons Adam and Noah Bumas, and her granddaughter Lucy Archibald. The funeral will be Thursday, July 10, at 11:30am, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, New York, Tel. 212-288-3500.

HALL--Lewis Rutherfurd Morris, 85, a resident of New York, NY, and Morris, NY, died peacefully at New York Presbyterian Hospital on Sunday, July 6, 2014. Mr. Hall was the son of the late Katherine and John H. Hall of Hartsdale, NY, and the grandson of the late Dr. and Mrs. Lewis R. Morris of New York City and Manor House Farms in Morris. He was the direct descendant of Lewis Morris, a New York signer of the Declaration of Independence and General Jacob Morris, one of the earliest settlers of the Butternut Valley immediately following the American Revolution. Lewis was also related to Gouverneur Morris, responsible for the Preamble and editor of the Constitution and an abolitionist well before the Civil War. He was the great-grandson of William Andrews Clark, who was a Senator from Montana and a noted art collector. Lewis was born in New York City, May 7, 1929, and raised in Hartsdale, NY. He attended the Thomas School and Arizona Desert School in Tucson, AZ, and the Salisbury School in Salisbury, CT. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Colgate University. He received a Masters Degree in Business and a second Masters Degree in History both from New York University. After completing his degrees, Lewis taught Cultural History at the Brooklyn Friends School. Lewis was a multi-faceted man: a writer, author, lecturer and historian. He was a noted opera historian with a special interest in the French style of singing. His vast collection of 78 phonographic records covered singing from the early 20th Century. In recent years, he produced many CDs around specific themes or artists from his collection. He was on the Board of the Vocal Record Collectors' Society, for which he produced a number of programs devoted to the early singers of the French Opera House in New Orleans, one of the oldest opera houses in the Unites States. He was also an avid collector of opera memorabilia that included librettos, scores, photographs, sketches and more, which recently was accepted by the Morgan Library. He served on the Board of the Glimmerglass Opera and he was Chair of the Music Policy Committee. For over 20 years, he also assembled for them the annual summer exhibition from his extensive collection on opera history. Lewis is survived by his wife of 51 years, Gemma Stagni Hall, daughter Angelica Romano, and two grandchildren, Isabella and Luca Romano. You may pay your respects to Lewis at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Thursday, July 10th from 4-6pm. A funeral service will take place at All Saints Chapel in Morris on Saturday, July 19. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the Glimmerglass Opera, Cooperstown, NY or Zion Church, Morris, NY.

FRIEDFELD--Fredrick. The Friedfeld family deeply mourns the loss of their patriarch Fredrick Friedfeld who passed away July 4th at the age of 87. Freddy, as he was affectionately known, proudly served in the US Navy, and became an optician on the GI Bill. Following his education, he worked several years in NYC learning the optical trade. With a $3,000 loan from an uncle and the blessings of his employer, he founded ClearVision Optical in 1949. Working tirelessly, Fred grew his one man organization and today ClearVision is amongst the largest family owned eyewear distributors in North America. The business was both his occupation and passion. He had a true knack for selling, and never gave up. His unique skill was listening, and knowing the customer's needs. His customers became his friends, and as he grew older he became a mentor to many in the business. However his true love was family. Fred's marriage in 1955 to young Mimi Forman started on a blind date where he proposed at the top of the Empire State Building and she accepted. Married within six months (during a slower selling season), Fred and Mimi had a 59 year romance that was obvious to all who witnessed their affection for one another. Fred had a soul mate in Mimi, a business partner, a wife, best friend, and mother of four great kids. Whenever not working, he was playing. He played at cards winning most of the time, golf where he loved breaking 100 the honest way, deep sea fishing and travelling the world with Mimi, friends, and his family. Throughout his life he enjoyed collecting stamps and coins, managing his stock portfolio on his iPhone, but what he loved most in his later years was playing with, and teaching his nine grandchildren. He relished the success and activities of his nine grandchildren, who each claim to be his favorite, a mathematical formula only Fred was capable of. In addition to his wife, Mimi, Friedfeld is survived by his son, David and Vicki Friedfeld, and their four children-- Jacob, Samuel, Faith and Lucas; by Peter Friedfeld and Patrick McLaughlin; by Dr. Douglas and Cari Friedfeld and their children-- Charlie and Hannah; and by daughter Elizabeth Friedfeld-Gebaide, her husband, Eric, and their three children, Sophie, Daniel and Izzy. As a salute to his service in the US Armed Forces, the family will be establishing a fund to assist in rehabilitative and educational services to members of the US Navy. Those interested in supporting the Navy-Marine Corps Relief Society please visit nmcrs.org to donate. In addition, the family is establishing a Fred Friedfeld Scholarship at the SUNY College of Optometry which can be supported by donations to the school's Optometric Foundation. Donations and inquiries about the scholarship fund can be sent to the attention of Ann Warwick, VP of SUNY Optometry and executive director of the school's Optometric Center of New York at awarwick@sunyopt.edu.

DEMOS--Emanuel George, passed away on July 4th, 2014. Born on November 7, 1938 in New Britain, Connecticut to George and Angeliki Demos, he graduated from Yale University magna cum laude, majoring in economics and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He received his Juris Doctorate from Yale Law School and clerked on the Connecticut Supreme Court. Thereafter he served on the faculty of Harvard Law School for two years. In New York, he practiced law at the firm of Shearman & Sterling and then joined the tax practice of White & Case. He then became an executive at two oil companies and a partner in several petroleum ventures. He served as the pro bono general legal counsel for the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America for the last 15 years. He also was a former president of the Archdiocesan Cathedral in New York, an Archon of the Ecumenical Patriarchate, chairman of the Cathedral School Board, a former trustee of Hellenic College and of the Archbishop Lakovos Library, and founder and President of the Kallinikeion Foundation. He also served on the advisory council of the Byzantine and Modern Greek Studies Program at Queens College. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Helen (Kocolatos) Demos, his son and daughter-in-law George and Chrysanthy Demos, a daughter, and grandsons, Michael, Emanuel, and Angelo. The viewing will be Thursday July 10th from 6 to 9pm with a Trisagion service at 7:30pm and the funeral will be Friday, July 11th at 11am, both at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral in New York at 319 East 74th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Holy Trinity Cathedral.

CLEARY--Frances M.,aged 90, passed away on July 7, 2014. Beloved daughter of the late Bridget and Michael Cleary. Devoted sister of the late Margaret and Catherine Cleary. Mass of Christian Burial Friday July 11, 2014 at 10am at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Friends of Liturgical Music at Corpus Christi.

BLUM--Alan. Moses & Singer LLP mourns the passing of our friend and colleague Alan Blum. Alan was as a partner in our Intellectual Property Practice and a trusted legal advisor to many clients. He was a source of inspiration and knowledge to the attorneys and staff at the Firm. He will be sorely missed and we extend our sincere condolences to Alan's family.

O'CONNELL RASHID--Mary Ellen. In Memoriam. Seven years in Heaven. Your family and your friends miss you and love you.

TOW--Claire. The Brooklyn College community mourns the loss of our benefactor and alumna Claire Schneider Tow. Claire and Leonard Tow met while students at Brooklyn College, and have generously supported the college over the years through the Tow Foundation, which has provided endowments for internship programs, scholarships, and faculty travel fellowships, as well as undergraduate travel stipends for students conducting research outside of the United States. But the Tows' most lasting legacy on campus will be the Leonard & Claire Tow Center for the Performing Arts, a rehearsal, production, and performance space that their unfailing generosity has made possible. Faculty and students, both now and in the future, owe Claire Tow a debt of gratitude. Karen L. Gould, President, Brooklyn College

TOW--Claire. Young Concert Artists mourns the loss of amazing Claire, whose dedication to young artists and indomitable spirit will be sorely missed. Our love and sympathy to her devoted husband Leonard, YCA Trustee, and to the entire Tow family. Susan Wadsworth, Director Michael Ambler, Chairman

TOW--Claire. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Claire Tow. She was an elegant and accomplished person, and we will miss her. Claire loved the theater, and we are so proud that the newest performance space on the Lincoln Center campus is named after her. She joins Vivian and Mitzi in the great pantheon of women who truly believed that the theater is a force for good. We send sympathy and love to her husband Leonard, a beloved Vice-Chairman of our Board of Directors, and to the entire Tow family. J.Tomilson Hill, Chairman Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

SIMUNEK--G. Nicholas, on July 10, 2014. He was 76 years old. He was born in London, England and came to America 40 years ago. He was a movie producer as well as a Vice Chairman to two movie production companies: Helmdale and Gateway Films. He was also President of Remarkable Partners; which is owned by his wife Terry Allen Kramer who is a Broadway Theatrical Producer as well as Broadway and London theater owner. As a young man living in London, he was a member of The Coldstream Guards and was in the British Army. He attended McGill University prior to living full time in New York City. Besides his wife surviving him are his sister Kate in London and two stepchildren and seven step grandchildren. Service: Monday, July 14, 11am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street.

QUIRK--James Stephen, died on July 6, 2014 at home in Richmond, VA following a brief illness. He was the founder and chairman, until 2007, of the Alliance of Dedicated Cancer Centers. The Alliance served to network and address common Medicare funding and governmental and administrative issues within the Cancer Centers of the United States designated as "Comprehensive" by the US government. Jim was one of the five members of the task group who formed the National Cancer Center Network, a body which developed authoritive treatment guidelines for the majority of cancers. He worked for over twenty-five years at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City where he served as Senior Vice President for Research Resources Management. He retired in 2006. Jim was born in Johnstown, PA. June 25, 1938, son of Dr. Thomas C. Quirk and Ruth Pyle Quirk. He was graduated with an MA degree from the University of Pittsburgh and first worked at the Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases at NIH as a grants officer. While at NIH, he was called to be a staff member on President Lyndon Johnson's special committee to study health care demographics. After leaving NIH, Jim was the administrator of the Cancer Center at Columbia University. Jim is survived by his wife of 52 years, the former Barbara Pensinger also from Johnstown, PA. He is also survived by two sons: Dr. J. Stephen Quirk, ll, husband of Dr. Anne Nelson of Alpharetta, GA and Andrew S. Quirk, husband of Joan Quirk of Brentwood, TN and five grandchildren: Zachary and Amanda of Alpharetta and Erynn, Sarah, and Liam of Brentwood. Jim is survived by three brothers: Thomas C., Jr. of Pittsburgh, PA, Richard F. of Richmond, VA, and Dr. George P. of Houston, TX. and nine nieces and nephews. Jim is remembered for his willingness to help people, often finding physician referrals for strangers who were given his name for assistance in finding health care. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 11am, Monday, August 25, 2014 at Saint Bridget's Catholic Church 6006 Three Chopt Road, Richmond, VA. 23226. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Central Virginia Food Bank 1415 Rhoadmiller St. Richmond, VA. 23220.

PARNESS--Stanley. The partners, associates and staff of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan LLP note with sadness the passing of their colleague, the Hon. Justice Stanley Parness. Justice Parness was Of Counsel at Stroock for 15 years after his retirement from the bench and was a leading figure in the Tax Certiorari department. He was enormously accomplished and a loyal friend to his colleagues. During a long and distinguished tenure as a Supreme Court Justice, Justice Parness served 18 years on the Appellate Term, First Department, the last four of which he spent as the Presiding Justice of that court. Justice Parness also presided for 15 years over all tax certiorari and condemnation cases in New York County. Prior to being elected to the Civil Court of the City of New York, he had served as Law Clerk to the Hon. Hyman Korn. Justice Parness is survived by his wife Harriet and brother Howard. Funeral services were private.

MARTIRANO--Christopher M.,on July 8, 2014. Beloved companion of Dennis, Nikko, Tess, Abby, Anthony, and Luis. Loving brother of Colleen (Jerry) Dance, Vivian (Michael) Chambers, Michael Brady, Kevin Brady, and Robert Dancey. Christopher was the devoted son of Irene and the late John Brady. He was the proud owner of Capri Cleaners NYC Corp. Friends will be received Friday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave (at 81st) Mass of Christian burial Saturday at St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church 11:30am.

HARDEE--Stella, passed away peacefully on June 11th at the age of 88. She was born in Tampa, FL in 1925. The granddaughter of bank founder T.C. Taliaferro, she graduated from William and Mary, wed and had two children, Martin and Carson. Borneo, the Antarctic, Kenya, in fact all seven continents were under her feet at one point. An avid bird watcher, she treasured nature, Central Park, Carnegie, The Met, and her beloved AMNH, which she called "my museum". In addition to her children, she is survived by the love of her life, Michael Lacton, who has been by her side for over three decades. Her spirit will live on in us all. A Memorial Service is scheduled for Friday, July 18th at St. Bartholomew's Church on 50th and Park, at 3pm. She would have loved you to give donations to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th Street, NY, NY 10022

FRIEDFELD--Fredrick. The Friedfeld family deeply mourns the loss of their patriarch Fredrick Friedfeld who passed away July 4th at the age of 87. Freddy, as he was affectionately known, proudly served in the US Navy, and became an optician on the GI Bill. Following his education, he worked several years in NYC learning the optical trade. With a $3,000 loan from an uncle and the blessings of his employer, he founded ClearVision Optical in 1949. Working tirelessly, Fred grew his one man organization and today ClearVision is amongst the largest family owned eyewear distributors in North America. The business was both his occupation and passion. He had a true knack for selling, and never gave up. His unique skill was listening, and knowing the customer's needs. His customers became his friends, and as he grew older he became a mentor to many in the business. However his true love was family. Fred's marriage in 1955 to young Mimi Forman started on a blind date where he proposed at the top of the Empire State Building and she accepted. Married within six months (during a slower selling season), Fred and Mimi had a 59 year romance that was obvious to all who witnessed their affection for one another. Fred had a soul mate in Mimi, a business partner, a wife, best friend, and mother of four great kids. Whenever not working, he was playing. He played at cards winning most of the time, golf where he loved breaking 100 the honest way, deep sea fishing and travelling the world with Mimi, friends, and his family. Throughout his life he enjoyed collecting stamps and coins, managing his stock portfolio on his iPhone, but what he loved most in his later years was playing with, and teaching his nine grandchildren. He relished the success and activities of his nine grandchildren, who each claim to be his favorite, a mathematical formula only Fred was capable of. In addition to his wife, Mimi, Friedfeld is survived by his son, David and Vicki Friedfeld, and their four children-- Jacob, Samuel, Faith and Lucas; by Peter Friedfeld and Patrick McLaughlin; by Dr. Douglas and Cari Friedfeld and their children-- Charlie and Hannah; and by daughter Elizabeth Friedfeld-Gebaide, her husband, Eric, and their three children, Sophie, Daniel and Izzy. As a salute to his service in the US Armed Forces, the family will be establishing a fund to assist in rehabilitative and educational services to members of the US Navy. Those interested in supporting the Navy-Marine Corps Relief Society please visit nmcrs.org to donate. In addition, the family is establishing a Fred Friedfeld Scholarship at the SUNY College of Optometry which can be supported by donations to the school's Optometric Foundation. Donations and inquiries about the scholarship fund can be sent to the attention of Ann Warwick, VP of SUNY Optometry and executive director of the school's Optometric Center of New York at awarwick@sunyopt.edu.

CHERMAYEFF--Jane Clark, 64, died peacefully at home of brain cancer. Born in Poughkeepsie, New York, she was a long time resident of New York City. As a curator and planner Jane dedicated her professional career to the arts, museums and children, cherishing the quote "life without a swing is a misunderstanding." Her work and life took her to diverse places; Cambodia, Germany, Puerto Rico, and most recently, Val-Kill, the Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site and Chicago's Millennium Park. In all of these places Jane brought to bare her expertise on learning. She founded the Architectural Playground Equipment Inc. and was a member of numerous professional associations; the New York Studio School, the Museum Group, The Conservation Trust of Puerto Rico and the Century Association among others. Jane will be remembered for her boundless love and intense generosity of spirit. Jane is survived by her husband Ivan, son Sam, brother Tom, sister Ann, stepchildren Catherine, Maro and Sasha, as well as five grandchildren. In lieu of customary remembrances, contributions in Jane's memory may be directed to the charity of one's choice. She herself loved a great many things, people and places.

YEN--Pao-Ming. The partners and staff of Funaro & Co., PC extend our sincerest condolences to Caroline Yen on the loss of her husband, and to Victor and Vincent Yen on the loss of their father, Pao-Ming Yen. He was an inspiration to us all and we cherish the more than sixty year business relationship and personal friendship shared with him and your family. We honor his memory as a brilliant leader and industrialist, esteemed friend and devoted family man.

TOW--Claire. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Claire Tow. She was an elegant and accomplished person, and we will miss her. Claire loved the theater, and we are so proud that the newest performance space on the Lincoln Center campus is named after her. She joins Vivian and Mitzi in the great pantheon of women who truly believed that the theater is a force for good. We send sympathy and love to her husband Leonard, a beloved Vice-Chairman of our Board of Directors, and to the entire Tow family. J.Tomilson Hill, Chairman Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

STOKER--Patrick McGillycuddy.Born on Christmas Day 1920. Surrounded by family, Paddy Daddy died peacefully on 5 July, 2014 at the age of 93. Paddy is survived by his wife Josephine Hadley, his sons, Thornley (Susan), Dermot (Tracy), his daughter Carlotta (Ralph Difiore), his eight grandchildren, Harrison, Bram, Cayley, Patrick, Paige, Thomas, Francesca, Michael, his stepchildren Deb Mcmeniman (Bill), Tim Lantier, Tony Lantier (Stephanie) and their children Christopher, Jennifer, Johnathan, Eric, Matthew, Simone and Gabrielle. Paddy joined the RCAF in 1942, during his studies of architecture at McGill University. He served overseas in the Yorkshire 6th Group bomber squadron. Returning to McGill, Paddy graduated in 1951 and practiced until he retired in 1992. A private family service has been held and a celebration of Paddy's life will take place in the fall.

SCHOEFFLER--Max S. Born in Berlin, Max escaped to the US with his family in 1939, grew up in Bayonne, and lived most of his life in New Jersey. He graduated from Rutgers and earned his PhD in experimental psychology from Indiana U. At Bell Labs, his intellect and creativity led to several patents and many advances in telecommunications, including telephone redial, international numbering conventions, and intelligent systems. He will be warmly remembered by his many family members and friends for his humility, kindness, and zest for life.
SCHLECHTER--Selma, on July 10. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Loving mother of Ellin Ruffner and John Kramon. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and many great-grandchildren. Services private.

LEVINE--Dr. Milton L. 84, of Elmont and Shelter Island, New York, passed away on July 10, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Eileen, adored sons Dr. Benjamin (Mindy), Dr. Daniel (Myrna) and Arthur Levine Ferrante (Anthony), and eight cherished grandchildren. He is predeceased by his sister, Florence Goodman. Born in Brooklyn to Samuel and Lillian Levine, Milton attended Tilden High School, received a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics from Columbia University in 1950, and graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1954. He interned in surgery at Mt. Sinai Hospital, and then served for two years as the Medical Officer and advisor to the Jewish Chapel Squad at West Point. Returning to New York City, Milton completed his training in medicine at NYU and a fellowship in gastroenterology on the Cornell Service at Bellevue Hospital and Memorial Sloan Kettering. He was in the first class of applicants to obtain board certification in the then new subspecialty of gastroenterology. Milton was a passionate physician who truly loved his work. He practiced internal medicine and gastroenterology on Long Island for nearly fifty years, including many years as Chief of Gastroenterology at Franklin General Hospital. He developed an endoscopic technique to treat achalasia that is still popular today, and published several articles on the subject. Milton served on the faculty of Long Island Jewish Hospital and was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians, a Fellow of the American College of Gastroenterology, and a past President of the Long Island Gastroenterology Society. He was an enthusiastic singer, from his undergraduate days as a member of the Columbia Kingsmen a cappella group to his many years as a member of The Franklin Trio. No family gathering was complete without a performance of show tunes by Milton. He loved a good joke and a bad pun. He was also an avid tennis player and outdoorsman, enjoying windsurfing, sailing, swimming and running in the annual 10-K at his beloved Shelter Island. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association, the Perlman Music Program, or the charity of your choice. A Chapel Service will be held on Sunday, July 13, 2014 at 12:00 noon at Jewish Memorial Chapel of Long Island at 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY. The burial will follow at Beth David Cemetery Elmont, New York.

LEVINE--Dr. Herbert J.,age 85, of Newton, MA, on Friday, July 11. Beloved husband of Sandra (Yenkin). Devoted father of Andrew Levine and his husband Vidal Sotelo and Rachel Levine Foley and her husband Michael Foley. Cherished grandfather of Sam, Will and Luke Foley. Levine Foundation for Cardiovascular Clinical Research, Tufts Medical Center, 800 Washington St., Boston, MA 02111.

KURSHAN--Phyllis, of Princeton, NJ, on Thursday, July 10, 2014, at age 88. Daughter of the late Jack and Beatrice Sterman. Beloved wife of Jerome Kurshan. Loving mother of Neil (Alisa) Kurshan and Rachel Kurshan. Dear sister of Alex Sterman. Grandmother of five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Funeral service Sunday, July 13, 2014, 9am at The Jewish Center, 435 Nassau Street, Princeton, NJ. Burial Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

KAZICKAS--Joseph P. Joseph P. Kazickas passed peacefully at home in East Hampton, NY on July 9, 2014 at the age of 96. A devoted family man, a statesman, a generous philanthropist, he led a wonderfully full, productive and exciting life. Born in 1918 on the steppes of Russia where his ancestors had been banished from their homeland of Lithuania by the Czars, he returned to Lithuania as a young boy but was forced to flee again in 1944 when Communists invaded. After three years in displaced persons camps in Germany, he won a fellowship to Yale University to study for his doctorate in economics, and with his wife Alexandra and daughter Jurate settled happily in America. He had a successful career as a businessman and entrepreneur and was always grateful for the opportunities his new country gave him. But he never forgot his homeland during the nearly 50 dark years of Soviet occupation. He worked relentlessly to help secure its freedom - lobbying US government officials and supporting the independence movement Sajudis. When Lithuania was an independent country again, he helped bring in global business, established the first cellular phone company and created a family foundation to support educational, cultural and social causes. For his many good works, he received numerous honors from universities, organizations, and the Lithuanian government. But family was his first and foremost enduring love and pride. He adored his beloved Alexandra who died at age 91 three years ago just weeks before their 70th wedding anniversary. He was a loving father to Jurate and sons Joseph, Michael and John and suffered the loss of Alexander who died in 1976. He was a doting, playful grandfather to 11 wonderful grandchildren, inspiring them and sharing his advice and wisdom. He will always be remembered for his enthusiastic love of life, his charm, his many friendships, and his never-ending gratitude to God Almighty for the countless blessings in his life. Wake will be held Sunday from 4-6 at Yardley and Pino Funeral Home and a Mass on Monday 11am at Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Lithuanian Foundation; 14911 127th Street; Lemont, IL 60439.

HARDEE--Stella, passed away peacefully on June 11th at the age of 88. She was born in Tampa, FL in 1925. The granddaughter of bank founder T.C. Taliaferro, she graduated from William and Mary, wed and had two children, Martin and Carson. Borneo, the Antarctic, Kenya, in fact all seven continents were under her feet at one point. An avid bird watcher, she treasured nature, Central Park, Carnegie, The Met, and her beloved AMNH, which she called "my museum". In addition to her children, she is survived by the love of her life, Michael Lacton, who has been by her side for over three decades. Her spirit will live on in us all. A Memorial Service is scheduled for Friday, July 18th at St. Bartholomew's Church on 50th and Park, at 3pm. She would have loved you to give donations to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th Street, NY, NY 10022

Caravaglia--Tom, The Paul Taylor Dance Company dancers and administration mourn the passing of our friend and professional colleague, Tom Caravaglia.
