PICNIC Written and illustrated by John Burningham. 32 pp. Candlewick. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5) 
 
Burningham, one of the great British children’s illustrators, brings a gentle interactivity to his latest book, in which a boy and girl invite their animal friends to join them for a picnic lunch. Along the way Burningham asks his young readers to find things (a scarf, a ball) hidden in the pictures, adding to the fun of “Picnic,” which is equally about the excitement to be had outdoors and the pleasures of returning home.
MEPPEN--Samuel and Edith. Dear parents, grandparents, and great-grandparents. We cherish their memory.

BERSIN--Victor. (Mayer Moshe ben Shachner) You passed from this world 40 years ago, July 14, 1974, the 24th of Tammuz. You are constantly in our hearts with your wisdom and compassion. A true friend to all. Shalom, Your loving family Neil, Sylvia & Erica
BERNSTEIN--Ruben William. Always loved. Always missed.

ZIELINSKI--Mikael, 58, died in Stockholm, Sweden on June 26. Former Vogue and Liz Claiborne Art Director. Miki's love, creativity, style, dry wit and wicked banter enriched our family gatherings. Irene, Jack, Drew & Leona

YEN--Pao-Ming. The partners and staff of Funaro & Co., PC extend our sincerest condolences to Caroline Yen on the loss of her husband, and to Victor and Vincent Yen on the loss of their father, Pao-Ming Yen. He was an inspiration to us all and we cherish the more than sixty year business relationship and personal friendship shared with him and your family. We honor his memory as a brilliant leader and industrialist, esteemed friend and devoted family man.

WITKIN--Nathan, age 98, died July 12, 2014. Born April 9, 1916 in New York City, he was a life-long resident of Perth Amboy. The son of the late Morris and Rebecca Witkin, he was predeceased by his brothers Ira and Paul Witkin and his sister Ida Attinger. He is survived by his wife of 67 years, Norma Stein Witkin, children Eric (Regina Bilotta) of Harrison, NY, Jane (Charles Tutino) of Maplewood, NJ, and Marc of Middlebury, VT, grandchildren Daniel and Sarah Witkin and Emily and Will Tutino. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army Signal Corps attaining the rank of First Lieutenant in the Philippines. In 1951, he founded Witty's Liquors and ran it for more than 30 years with stores in Perth Amboy, Rahway and South River, NJ. His contributions to civic life included service as President of the Perth Amboy Y.M.H.A and on the boards of Temple Beth Mordecai, Congregation Shaarey Tefiloh, The Proprietary House, and the Jewish Federation of Greater Middlesex County. He was Treasurer of Concerts by the Bay. He also served on the Perth Amboy Zoning Board of Adjustment, as a lay member of the New Jersey Supreme Court Fee Arbitration and Attorney Ethics Committees, and as a Commissioner of the Perth Amboy Redevelopment Board. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Jacqueline M. and Robert N. Wilentz Cancer Center at Raritan Bay Medical Center in Perth Amboy. Services will be held at Flynn & Son, 422 East Avenue, Perth Amboy, at 11am on Monday, July 14. Shiva will be observed at the family residence.

WILLIAMS--David T. Internationally renowned interior designer for the hotel and hospitality industry for over 65 years peacefully passed away at his home in New York City on July 5, 2014. Born in Burlington, IA on April 10, 1918, David, a Veteran of World War II began his career as an interior decorator at Marshall Field & Company in Chicago, Il. It was in 1946 when hotel magnet, Conrad N. Hilton through Marshall Fields hired David to decorate the Stevens Hotel in Chicago (renamed The Conrad Hilton in 1951). Impressed by his extraordinary talent and creative ability, Hilton hired David to work at the Hilton Hotels Corporation as Vice President and Director Statler Hilton Studios. When Conrad Hilton purchased The Waldorf-Astoria in 1949, David moved to New York to work on the decor of both The Waldorf and The Plaza Hotels. David's genius for design was soon found in hotels around the world. His success continued and in 1958 he established his own company David T. Williams Inc. His business flourished with the addition of new hotel companies and clients; Loews, Canadian Pacific, Forte, Hyatt, the corporate offices of Hilton Hotels, the Cornell Club in New York to name a few. In November 1996 in celebration of his 50 years of decorating for Hilton Hotels, David was inducted into The Waldorf-Astoria Distinguished Alumni. On the occasion Barron Hilton, the son of Conrad and former Chairman of Hilton Hotels Corporation wrote to David "the standards that you set at the many flagship Hilton Hotels still stand today as examples of your outstanding interior design work. The mark of design excellence which you have left imprinted throughout the world has been a great tradition in the hotel industry and will be long remembered." David was preceded by his parents - Nora and Edward Williams; his brother, Clarence Williams and sister, Lillian Gamet. He leaves his brother William E. Williams and sister-in-law Doddie Williams of Spokane, WA along with several nieces and nephews. As per his wish, David has been cremated and will be buried with his parents in Missouri. Later there will be a gathering of friends to remember David T. and his wonderful life.

WELLS--David I.,86, died on July 11, 2014. Born in Manhattan, he grew up in the Bronx and moved to Fresh Meadows, Queens when he married his wife, Phyllis, nee Toiv. As Associate Director of the Political Department of the ILGWU, David was an early pioneer in the fight to protect democracy from corrupt voter districting practices. In 1969 he won his case before the Supreme Court, Wells vs. Rockefeller, a one person-one vote victory. A New York Times editorial named him "one of the nation's leading experts on reapportionment." (1970) He lectured widely and wrote countless articles on apportionment and districting and served as a member of the 1991 New York City Districting Commission. He authored an entry on the subject for the 2005 Encyclopedia of New York State. His papers are archived at Cornell University. A kind and gentle man of great intelligence, wit and integrity, David was a political scientist with expertise in American and European History and world geography as well as apportionment/districting and the Electoral College. He was loving and dearly loved by his wife Phyllis of 50 years, his three daughters, Vicki Wilson, Ruth Markunas, Dara Edmonson, his three sons-in-law, seven grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Their lives are diminished by his death.

WEPPLER--Margaret T.,on July 10, 2014 of Manhasset. Beloved wife of Robert G. Loving mother of Robert J. (Christy) and the late Brian S. Weppler. Cherished grandmother of Catherine, Sarah and Lauren. Visitation will be on Monday from 3-5pm and 7-9pm at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset. Funeral Mass will be Tuesday, 10am, Our Lady of Fatima Church, Manorhaven. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Donations may be made to St Francis Hospital Foundation, 100 Port Washington Blvd., Roslyn, NY 11576.

WEISINGER--Dr. Martin Warren, of Boynton Beach, FL, died July 6, 2014 at age 81. He is survived by his beloved wife, Roberta Perlman Weisinger, his dear children, Dr. Andrew, Lynn and Barbara, and his adoring grandchildren, Jacob, Dylan, Abigail and Arin. He was a loving father-in-law to Mary Ann Weisinger and James Dean, and a devoted brother to Dr. Barbara Weisinger. A graduate of NYU Dental School, he enjoyed a wonderful life and will be greatly miss by his many friends and family.

WEBSTER--Elizabeth "Lisa" McGraw, a philanthropist and renowned supporter of American figure skaters, died on Saturday, June 28 at her vacation home in Sun Valley, Idaho. She was 88. Ms Webster was born in New York City to Elizabeth Murtland Woodwell and Curtis Whittlesey McGraw, president of McGraw Hill Publishing from 1950-53. She was the granddaughter of James McGraw, founder of the publishing house. Ms Webster lived her entire life in Princeton, New Jersey, where she attended Miss Fines School. She went on to Foxcroft School in Middleburg, VA and Finch College in New York City. Ms Webster had a deep love for figure skating, and served on the board of The Skaters Fund, an organization that provides assistance to skaters and coaches in need due to illness, disability or age. Additionally, over some four decades, she sponsored numerous national and Olympic champions including Nancy Kerrigan, Paul Wylie, Steven Cousins, David Liu, Parker Pennington, Derrick Delmore, Jeremy Abbot, Alex Akin and others. In recognition for her commitment to the sport she was nominated for the Figure Skating Hall of Fame. Ms Webster also supported figure skating on the local level. She was a charter member of The Princeton Skating Club and her contributions built the club's state-of-the-art Lisa McGraw Skating Rink at Princeton Day School. Ms Webster was active throughout the Princeton community, serving on the board of directors of Princeton Hospital, and holding memberships at the Nassau Club, Bedens Brook Golf Club and the Pretty Brook Tennis Club. She was a founder and charter member of the Contemporary Garden Club of Princeton. She also established the Curtis W. McGraw Foundation and the Lisa McGraw Figure Skating Foundation, both in Princeton. Ms Webster was married twice, to James Stoltzfus and George Webster; both marriages ended in divorce. She is survived by two daughters, Lisette Stoltzfus Edmond and Marian Stoltzfus Paen; a son, Curtis McGraw Webster; grandchildren Elizabeth Edmond, Victoria Edmond, Alexandra Edmond, Nicolas Edmond, Antony James Maricich, Alexander McGraw Maricich, Anastasha Tatiana Maricich, and Theo McGraw Webster; sons- and daughters-in-law, and great- grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Nassau Presbyterian Church, 61 Nassau Street, Princeton, on October 11, 2014. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: the Lisa McGraw Figure Skating Foundation, Post office Box 627, Princeton, NJ 08542-0627, or The Skaters' Fund, 202 Park Knoll, Princeton, NJ 08540.

TRATTLER--Belle Hammerschlag. 100 years, died peacefully on July 6, 2014. She was the beloved mother of Stephanie H. Bernheim and Paul E. Hammerschlag, MD, grandmother of Erica Bernheim and Claudia Bernheim, and grandmother-in-law of Leo Raphaely, and great-grandmother of Grey and Linus Raphaely. She survived her late husbands, Max L. Hammerschlag, MD, and S. Carlyle Trattler, MD and dearly beloved brother, Herbert Stessin. She was a pianist, loved classical music, theatre, and had a zest for travel. She was intensely devoted to her family. She was an excellent example of successful parental advocacy for children with hearing loss. Her outgoing, enthusiastic personality will be missed. A memorial service will be planned for future date. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services (JBFCS), 135 West 50th St, New York, NY 10020, or the Center for Hearing and Communication, 50 Broadway, New York, NY 10004.

TOW--Claire. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Claire Tow. She was an elegant and accomplished person, and we will miss her. Claire loved the theater, and we are so proud that the newest performance space on the Lincoln Center campus is named after her. She joins Vivian and Mitzi in the great pantheon of women who truly believed that the theater is a force for good. We send sympathy and love to her husband Leonard, a beloved Vice-Chairman of our Board of Directors, and to the entire Tow family. J.Tomilson Hill, Chairman Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

TOW--Claire. The students and faculty of the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism offer their condolences to Leonard Tow on the death of his cherished wife and to Emily Tow Jackson, Frank Tow, and Andrew Tow on the loss of their beloved mother and to the extended family, loving caretakers, and countless friends of Claire Tow. The Tow Foundation, established by Claire and Leonard Tow, showed a willingness to support our school and its public educational mission at a very early stage of our development. Thanks to their generosity, we were able to establish the Tow-Knight Center for Entrepreneurial Journalism. We are grateful to the Tows for their early support and are honored that the CUNY J-School has a center bearing the Tow family name. Sarah Bartlett, Dean Stephen B. Shepard, Founding Dean Jeff Jarvis, Director, Tow-Knight Center for Entrepreneurial Journalism

TOW--Claire, The Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend and benefactor, Claire Tow. Claire was a devoted supporter of the Gold Foundation, embracing humanism in medicine because she herself was the ultimate humanitarian. She approached her life and the people in it with intelligence and enthusiasm. Through her unique ability to see connections among the organizations she supported, Claire championed networks of like-minded activists to advance and amplify their work. Claire and her husband, Len, never forgot the opportunities afforded them, which propelled them to make opportunities for others. We were so proud and delighted when Claire chose to honor Len by endowing the Leonard Tow Humanism-in-Medicine Awards at our Foundation, helping to establish a generation of exemplars of humanistic practice. We express our deepest condolences to Len, Emily, Andrew, Frank and the entire Tow family. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D. Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D. President/CEO

TOW--Claire. The President and Trustees of Columbia University mourn the loss of Claire Tow, a visionary humanitarian and beloved member of the Columbia community. Together with her husband Len (Columbia Graduate School of Arts and Sciences '52 and '60), Claire supported vast initiatives across the University in the fields of health, medical research, neuroscience, journalism, and the arts that will improve and advance human life in profound ways for years to come. We send our deepest condolences to Len, their daughter Emily Tow Jackson (Barnard '87), their sons Frank and Andrew Tow, and their eight grandchildren. President Lee C. Bollinger and the Trustees of Columbia University

TOW--Claire. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Claire Tow, beloved wife of Leonard Tow, University benefactor, member of the Board of Advisors at the College of Physicians and Surgeons and of the Board of Overseers at the Mailman School of Public Health. The Tows' extraordinary generosity has been responsible for the establishment of our Motor Neuron Center, a cornerstone of our Neuroscience Initiative and our efforts to combat ALS. We send our deepest sympathies to Len and his family on their loss. Claire Tow's contributions will continue to enrich our institution and our lives. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University Linda P. Fried, MD, MPH Dean, Mailman School of Public Health, Columbia University

TOW--Claire, visionary, courageous, wise, generous, kind, accomplished, loyal and incomparable friend. Claire's dimpled, wholehearted smile embraced all in her sphere. Her personal warmth nurtured us and so many others. She was the exemplar of humanism and lovingness, and taught us much. Her strategic philanthropy repairs the world and will continue to make a difference. We hold her in our hearts. With love to Len, the children and all the family, Sandra and Arnold Gold

SPALTER--Harold, MD. The faculty and staff of the Department of Ophthalmology at Columbia University Medical Center mourn the loss of Harold Spalter, MD, a revered, longtime colleague. A fine gentleman and outstanding retina clinician, he contributed to stunning advances in vision research and care over five decades. He was world renowned for his pioneering contributions to the laser treatment of diabetic macular edema. He will also be remembered for his gifts of time and energy throughout his career at Columbia and for the impact of his personal commitment to vision research. Our sympathies are extended to his wife Diane and his family. George A. Cioffi, MD, Chairman Stanley Chang, MD, Chairman Emeritus

SPALTER--Dr. Harold F.,passed away peacefully at home at his wife Diane's side on July 4, 2014. Born and raised in New York City, he attended Stuyvesant High School and attended Brown University (A.B. 1951). He graduated Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1955 and completed his internship at Presbyterian Hospital and his residency in ophthalmology at The Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in 1959. He served as a Captain in the United States Air Force and was honorably discharged in 1961. Dr. Spalter then completed a fellowship at the Institute of Ophthalmology at Moorsfield Eye Hospital in London before returning to The Harkness Eye Institute. He was appointed as Professor Emeritus of Clinical Ophthalmology in 2009. Dr. Spalter later worked as The Ophthalmology Medical Coordinator for The Office of Professional Conduct (OPMC) for the State of New York until 2011. He proudly served as The Chairman of The Scientific Advisory Board for Research to Prevent Blindness (RPB). He was an illustrious member of The American Ophthalmological Society, The Retina Society, and was a past-President of The New York Ophthalmological Society. Dr. Harold Spalter developed a huge retina practice and earned the deepest respect, admiration, and affection from his family, friends, colleagues, and patients. He is survived by his devoted wife Diane. He is also survived by his children Alan, Jonathan, Michael, and Elizabeth Iino and nine grandchildren. He was a wonderful person and shall be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to Research to Prevent Blindness (RPB)or The Maurice Spalter Memorial Fund of P.H., Columbia University Department of Ophthalmology.

SIMUNEK--G. Nicholas, on July 10, 2014. He was 76 years old. He was born in London, England and came to America 40 years ago. He was a movie producer as well as a Vice Chairman to two movie production companies: Helmdale and Gateway Films. He was also President of Remarkable Partners; which is owned by his wife Terry Allen Kramer who is a Broadway Theatrical Producer as well as Broadway and London theater owner. As a young man living in London, he was a member of The Coldstream Guards and was in the British Army. He attended McGill University prior to living full time in New York City. Besides his wife surviving him are his sister Kate in London and two stepchildren and seven step grandchildren. Service: Monday, July 14, 11am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street.

SICHEL--Alexandra "Alex", passed away peacefully on June 23rd after three years of courageous fight with breast cancer. Born on July 31st, 1963, in Manhattan, Alex is survived by her husband, Erich Hahn Jr., her beloved daughter, Anastasia, her parents, Peter and Stella Sichel, and two sisters, Bettina and Sylvia. She adored them all. Alex was a gifted director and writer who worked in film, documentary and television. She directed and wrote (with her sister Sylvia) the much-lauded feature film, All Over Me (1996), and her short film, Amnesia (1992) won top honors at numerous festivals. Alex's other films included Tree Shade (1998) and Anemone Me (1990). At the time of her death, Alex was finishing a feature-length hybrid documentary about her struggle to come to terms with her illness. A beloved professor, Alex taught directing at NYU and Columbia. She received Macdowell and Yaddo Fellowships, was a member of the Directors Guild of America, and earned an M.F.A. from Columbia University and a B.A. from Brown University. A long-time practitioner of Buddhism, Alex was a pioneering, compassionate and brave soul, and she was blessed by a large number of loving friends and family who helped her enjoy life and ease her death. If a will could cure, Alex would have been cured. There will be a memorial service on September 20th at 3:00pm at The Lafayette Presbyterian Church 85 South Oxford Street in Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a contribution to "Women Make Movies/ The Movie About Anna" or the Kadampa Meditation Center in New York City.

SHENITZ--George, 92, in Manhattan, July 10, after a brief illness. Husband of 65 years to Adelee, father to Charles and Bruce, brother of Pauline, predeceased by sisters Rebecca and Beatrice. He was a CPA and attorney in New York City well into his 80's, a World War II veteran, an original tenant of Stuyvesant Town, and served as President of Town & Village Synagogue. Private service and interment.

SCHULZ--Eva, 92, of Riverdale and Sleepy Hollow, NY died July 5, 2014. Wife of the late John W. Schulz. Educator, gardener, opera lover, matriarch; tireless supporter of Wave Hill, Riverdale Mental Health, Riverdale Neighborhood House, Riverdale Senior Services, the Bronx Opera and many other community organizations. Loving mother of Catherine Benison (Diane), Elizabeth Schulz (Theresa Roche), and Andrew Schulz (Mauri Small). Adoring grandmother of William Small Schulz. Contributions to any of the above organizations would be appreciated. A Memorial will be planned.

SCHOEFFLER--Max S. Born in Berlin, Max escaped to the US with his family in 1939, grew up in Bayonne, and lived most of his life in New Jersey. He graduated from Rutgers and earned his PhD in experimental psychology from Indiana U. At Bell Labs, his intellect and creativity led to several patents and many advances in telecommunications, including telephone redial, international numbering conventions, and intelligent systems. He will be warmly remembered by his many family members and friends for his humility, kindness, and zest for life.
SCHLECHTER--Selma, on July 10. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Loving mother of Ellin Ruffner and John Kramon. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and many great-grandchildren. Services private.

SCHINELLER--Richard. Richard J. Schineller, Sr. of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Bronxville and Tuxedo Park, NY and Kinnelon, NJ, passed away on June 24, 2014. He is survived by his wife Eileen; sons Rich, Bill, and Erik; daughters Diane Sulimirski and Elena Matlack; and ten grandchildren.

SCHIMMEL--Erwin, on July 11, 2014, died in Westhampton Beach, New York at the age of 79. He was the beloved husband of Myrna Schimmel, the love of his life, with whom he shared 54 wonderful years of marriage. He will be desperately missed by her. He was the devoted father of Douglas, Aimee, Lori, Julie, Holly and Erin and the proud and loving grandfather of Hailey, Elizabeth, Logan and Charlie. His unique ability to make others feel welcome and cared for will be his ongoing legacy. His family and friends will always cherish his gentle, kind, and endearing disposition and the joy he brought to everyone he encountered. He was an avid tennis player and proud alumnus of Penn State University. The funeral will be by private arrangement. Shiva, to which friends and family are welcome, will be held at his home in Manhattan until noon on Friday.

POTTER--Annette. Our beloved mother and grandmother passed away on July 8, 2014 at the age of 92. She was devoted to and proud of her family - husband, Lester Potter, who died in 2007, children Bonnie, Tina and Robert Potter, son-in-law Andrew Freireich , daughter-in-law Mirjam Potter, grandchildren Alix Freireich, Anya and Nina Potter. We will love and miss her always. Funeral services Thursday, July 10th at 11:00am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Manhattan. Donations may be made to Metropolitan Jewish Hospice or American Jewish World Service.

PARNESS--Judge Stanley, The Partners and Associates of Marcus & Pollack LLP mourn the passing of Judge Stanley Parness. He presided over all tax certiorari and condemnation cases in New York County during his 21 years as a Supreme Court Justice. Among his precedent setting cases was One New York Plaza which determined the effect of the presence of asbestos on the valuation of real property. Our deepest condolences to his wife Harriet. Joel R. Marcus Robert M. Pollack Marcus & Pollack LLP

PARKER--Morten, film director, writer, producer, and educator, beloved by his family and friends, passed away in New York City on May 26th. He had some fifty documentary and narrative films almost all of which he wrote and directed to his credit. His numerous, distinguished national and international awards included: two Academy Award nominations; First Prize, Venice Film Festival; four CINE Golden Eagle Awards; two First Awards and Film of the Year Award, Canadian Film Awards; and First Prize, Associated Film Writers Competition. Mr. Parker was a former senior producer-director at the National Film Board of Canada and later co-founded Parker Film Associates with his wife, filmmaker Gudrun Bjerring Parker (Officer of the Order of Canada). He served as a United Nations Expert in Film Production and, for three years, was UNESCO Film Advisor to the State of Israel. He further served as Special Advisor on Communications to the Prime Minister of Jamaica. In the political field, Mr. Parker directed, wrote and produced films, TV spots and radio spots, often serving as general media manager, for political campaigns. The Paley Center for Media, New York City, has his political work in its permanent collection. He was Associate Professor of Film at New York University, where he was awarded the NYU Award for Teaching Excellence, and held the same position at CUNY. Engaged and involved until the end of his life creating, writing, teaching, mentoring - Mr. Parker had begun principal photography on a new film with his producing partner and friend, Paula Orndoff. He is survived by his wife Gudrun Parker, his daughter Julia Parker and her husband Edward Struzik all of Edmonton, Alberta; his daughter Martha Parker and her husband Adam Gopnik of New York City; and grandchildren Jacob, Sigrid, Luke and Olivia. Born in Winnipeg, Manitoba, he would have been 95 on July 27.

NICOLOSI--Vincent F.,born July 30, 1939 died on July 11, 2014, survived by his beloved wife of 28 years, Maureen Lynch Nicolosi; his son Ryan Nicolosi who is a senior at New York Law School; daughter Maura Nicolosi Nassirian who was his law partner; daughter; Carolyn Nicolosi Greene; sons Vincent Nicolosi Jr. Robert Nicolosi and their respective spouses; sisters Mary Buscemi, Camille Robinson and Nancy Cavanagh; and nine grandchildren. He dearly loved each and every member of his family. He was a distinguished member of the New York State Assembly from 1973 through 1980 and a Commissioner of the New York State Commission of Investigation from 1998 to 2009. Family and friends will be received at Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York on Sunday and Monday, July 13th and 14th between 3:00pm and 5:00pm and 7:00pm to 9:00pm. Funeral Mass will be held at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, New York on Tuesday, July 15th at 10:00am. Donations may be made in his honor to Saint Francis Hospital Foundation.
MYERS--Walter Dean, Teachers & Writers Collaborative remembers Walter's contributions to young people's literature, to the African American legacy, and to our organization.

MILLS--Dorothy Ordway, passed away Saturday June 28, 2014. Mrs. Mills was born February 1916. She was 98. She married Charles J. Mills in 1936 who predeceased her in 1986. Her two sons George P. Mills and Samuel O. Mills and his wife Adelle survive her. Also three grandchildren Jennifer, Ben and Katie, Jennifer's husband Peter and two great-grandchildren Harper and Wiley.

McCARTHY--Mary Ann, died on July 7, 2014 at the age of 72. She is survived by her brother Arthur, his wife Clare, nieces Jennifer and Lauren and three great-nieces. Mary Ann enjoyed a long career at New York Magazine. Later there will be a gathering of friends to remember Mary Ann and her wonderful life.

LEVINE--Dr. Herbert J.,age 85, of Newton, MA, on Friday, July 11. Beloved husband of Sandra (Yenkin). Devoted father of Andrew Levine and his husband Vidal Sotelo and Rachel Levine Foley and her husband Michael Foley. Cherished grandfather of Sam, Will and Luke Foley. Services at Levine Chapels, Brookline, on Monday, July 14 at 11:00am. Remembrances may be made to the Dr. Herbert J. Levine Foundation for Cardiovascular Clinical Research, Tufts Medical Center, 800 Washington St., Boston, MA 02111.

LARGE--Edward W.,Jr. Edward W. Large, Jr, of Boca Raton, FL and formerly of Hartford, CT, beloved husband of the late Madeleine S. Large, died Friday June 20th peacefully at his home. Born March 9, 1930 in Collingswood, NJ the son of the late Edward Wilson and Katherine Basler Large, he was raised in New Jersey, then Redding, PA, the third of three children. Ed served in the US Navy for two years before attending Marshall College in Huntington, WV. He received his J.D. from the University of Virginia School of Law where he was a member of the Law Review, the Raven Society and the Order of the Coif. In 1955, Ed joined Shearman & Sterling, where he practiced corporate law and where he met his wife, Madeleine. In 1960, Ed and Madeleine moved to the Hartford area where he joined United Technologies Corporation's predecessor, United Aircraft. During his 30-year tenure at UTC, Ed's positions included staff attorney, general counsel, vice president, senior vice president, executive vice president of legal and corporate affairs and executive vice president of corporate development, member of the UTC board and special advisor to the Chairman. Ed served UTC during a period when the corporation experienced extraordinary growth, spearheading important acquisitions including Otis Elevator and Carrier Air Conditioner. His wise counsel and business acumen strengthened and advanced the corporation's position as a global industrial leader. In addition to his distinguished career at UTC, Ed served as a member of the board of the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce and TRC in Windsor, CT and as chairman of the board of Society for Savings in Hartford, CT. He was a devoted father to his five children, Edward W. Large III, Christopher M. Large, Gregory L. Large who predeceased him in 1997, Gustavus A. Large and Jennifer Large Bowman and a loving grandfather to his 10 grandchildren. He is also survived by his twin sisters, his son and daughters-in-law, many nieces, nephews, friends and his beloved companion Rhoda Charlse. A memorial service will be held Thursday, July 24th at 11:30am at The Country Club of Farmington, 806 Farmington Avenue, Farmington, CT. In lieu of flowers please send donations to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, www.stjude.org.

LANDIS--Erica, who loved Paris, V. S. Pritchett, The Nation and The New York Times, died July 8, seven weeks after her husband, of pneumonia. Erica, whose father managed resort hotels in Miami and New York, recalled spending time as a young girl with the staff in Catskills kitchens, listening to their stories. Her mother was a Russian emigre. Erica studied literature at the University of Miami. While working in public relations in New York City, she met and married Bernard Landis, her husband of 58 years. Erica spent much of her married life in Larchmont, New York. She was an ardent opponent of the Vietnam War, attended protest marches in Washington, DC, and attended her daughter's college graduation wearing a white armband. Later she became a biofeedback therapist and worked in research that yielded three published papers. Erica was always fascinated by other people's life stories, and bonded closely with the nurses who gave her round-the-clock care. She loved food, theatre, music and cats. She is survived by her daughter, Dylan Landis Baquet; her son-in-law, Dean Baquet; her grandson, Ari Baquet; and her sister-in-law, Elaine Breiger.

KURTZ--Diane (Dede) J. Barkan, 86, on July 9. Daughter of the late Murray and Minna Barkan, wife of the late Milton Kurtz. Survived by beloved daughter Dana and her husband Rob Mackenzie, son Glenn and his girlfriend Alys George, daughter-in-law Cynthia, grandson David. Son Roger predeceased her in 2005. Graveside services Sunday, July 13, 11am, Mt. Hebron; gathering to follow, contact Riverside: 516-487-9600.

KAZICKAS--Joseph P. Joseph P. Kazickas passed peacefully at home in East Hampton, NY on July 9, 2014 at the age of 96. A devoted family man, a statesman, a generous philanthropist, he led a wonderfully full, productive and exciting life. Born in 1918 on the steppes of Russia where his ancestors had been banished from their homeland of Lithuania by the Czars, he returned to Lithuania as a young boy but was forced to flee again in 1944 when Communists invaded. After three years in displaced persons camps in Germany, he won a fellowship to Yale University to study for his doctorate in economics, and with his wife Alexandra and daughter Jurate settled happily in America. He had a successful career as a businessman and entrepreneur and was always grateful for the opportunities his new country gave him. But he never forgot his homeland during the nearly 50 dark years of Soviet occupation. He worked relentlessly to help secure its freedom - lobbying US government officials and supporting the independence movement Sajudis. When Lithuania was an independent country again, he helped bring in global business, established the first cellular phone company and created a family foundation to support educational, cultural and social causes. For his many good works, he received numerous honors from universities, organizations, and the Lithuanian government. But family was his first and foremost enduring love and pride. He adored his beloved Alexandra who died at age 91 three years ago just weeks before their 70th wedding anniversary. He was a loving father to Jurate and sons Joseph, Michael and John and suffered the loss of Alexander who died in 1976. He was a doting, playful grandfather to 11 wonderful grandchildren, inspiring them and sharing his advice and wisdom. He will always be remembered for his enthusiastic love of life, his charm, his many friendships, and his never-ending gratitude to God Almighty for the countless blessings in his life. Wake will be held Sunday from 4-6 at Yardley and Pino Funeral Home and a Mass on Monday 11am at Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Lithuanian Foundation; 14911 127th Street; Lemont, IL 60439.

KATZ--Bernard. James and Marian mourn their father Bernard Katz, who died in New York City on June 30, 12 years after his Alzheimer's diagnosis. Professor of Counseling Psychology at NYU, Bernie's passions were teaching, psychotherapy, progressive causes, sports, and his family. Personally and professionally, he was generous, enthusiastic, and provocative. A walk with him through Greenwich Village meant frequent stops to chat with students, colleagues, shopkeepers, and friends. Born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on July 10, 1932, his proudest achievement was establishing a free storefront counseling center on Manhattan's Lower East Side. He lost his wife of 45 years, Dolores, to lung cancer in 2004. No public service is planned; donations in his memory may be made to The Left Forum or the Alzheimer's Association.

IDE--Linda Ann Weinstein, on July 7, 2014. Loving mother of devoted sons T. Jay and Mark. Cherished daughter of Joyce and the late Dr. Robert Weinstein. Admired sister of Susan and John. Donations may be made to Dr. Francis Lee's Sarcoma Research, payable to Columbia Orthopedics and mailed to Orthopedic Research, 650 W. 168th St, Floor P&S, 11-401, NYC 10032.

HORTON--James Bawden, (1930-2014). Jim, beloved husband of Ines, father of Elizabeth, Jennifer, and Christiana, and grandfather of Nicole, passed away on June 29 at age 84. Jim had a varied and distinguished career as a magazine executive, turning troubled magazines into successful and profitable icons of their decades. He graduated from Brooklyn Friends School (1946) and Columbia College (1950) and earned his MBA from NYU (1960). He spent his early career at the Wall Street Journal, Curtis Publishing Company, and Young & Rubicam. Jim combined his belief that a magazine's mission is to teach and inspire with a keen business sense. As Vice President of CRM, Inc. and general manager of its magazine publishing division (1969-73) he turned Psychology Today from a losing operation into a highly profitable magazine, and also launched Intellectual Digest. He was general manager of Dow Jones' National Observer (1975-76) and group Vice President for business affairs at Playboy Enterprises (1976-78), where he launched Food & Wine magazine. As president and CEO of HAL Publications (1980-86) he took Working Woman from bankruptcy to one of America's "hottest" magazines, as recognized by AdWeek in both 1982 and 1983, and acquired Success! magazine. Generous with his knowledge, he was an adjunct professor of publishing at NYU (1980-86). He was a member of Ex-Members of Squadron A, Veteran Corps of Artillery, Sigma Chi (a Significant Sig), and the University Club. Jim did everything with style and a fresh boutonniere in his lapel. He loved New York for its jazz clubs of the 1950s, Orpheus at Carnegie Hall, opera and ballet at Lincoln Center; he loved Mozart and Gilbert & Sullivan; he admired the ancient Greeks and the classics. He created a magical childhood for his children, with Oz stories and summers on the Massachusetts farm, evenings on the lawn at Tanglewood, visits to Disneyland, and road trips exploring the wonders of the West. Jim faced many physical challenges in his final years, yet always managed the sweetest of smiles. He was gentle, funny, kind, and a talented storyteller. A celebration of his life will be held on September 18 at 6pm, at Trinity Baptist Church, 250 E. 61st Street, New York, NY.

HOFFMAN--Lee. In Memory of Lee Hoffman on his Birthday. Born July 13, 1942. Died July 8, 2014. Our dear friend Leonard Lee Hoffman of Philadelphia, PA has sadly, suddenly passed on Tuesday. He is survived by his nephew Ryan Hoffman and his family of Colorado. Also survived by his closest friends, Frank Williams of New York City, Donald S. Howard of Little Silver, NJ, and Richard Bassi of Hoboken, NJ, as well as Jeff Smith of Dallas, TX, and Nick Lieb of Montana and Alex Lieb of Philadelphia, PA. Lee was a scholar and an artist of incredible talent and a true Renaissance man who will be deeply missed. He was an inspiration to us all; a loving, caring and creative man. May he Rest in Peace now. God Bless. We will always love him and he will always be in our hearts. "To live in hearts we leave behind Is not to die." - Thomas Campbell. Please visit Lee's website to see his extraordinary talent and volume of work at: www.leehoffmanart.com May his legacy continue to inspire everyone.

HALL--Lewis Rutherfurd Morris, 85, a resident of New York, NY, and Morris, NY, died peacefully at New York Presbyterian Hospital on Sunday, July 6, 2014. Mr. Hall was the son of the late Katherine and John H. Hall of Hartsdale, NY, and the grandson of the late Dr. and Mrs. Lewis R. Morris of New York City and Manor House Farms in Morris. He was the direct descendant of Lewis Morris, a New York signer of the Declaration of Independence and General Jacob Morris, one of the earliest settlers of the Butternut Valley immediately following the American Revolution. Lewis was also related to Gouverneur Morris, responsible for the Preamble and editor of the Constitution and an abolitionist well before the Civil War. He was the great-grandson of William Andrews Clark, who was a Senator from Montana and a noted art collector. Lewis was born in New York City, May 7, 1929, and raised in Hartsdale, NY. He attended the Thomas School and Arizona Desert School in Tucson, AZ, and the Salisbury School in Salisbury, CT. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Colgate University. He received a Masters Degree in Business and a second Masters Degree in History both from New York University. After completing his degrees, Lewis taught Cultural History at the Brooklyn Friends School. Lewis was a multi-faceted man: a writer, author, lecturer and historian. He was a noted opera historian with a special interest in the French style of singing. His vast collection of 78 phonographic records covered singing from the early 20th Century. In recent years, he produced many CDs around specific themes or artists from his collection. He was on the Board of the Vocal Record Collectors' Society, for which he produced a number of programs devoted to the early singers of the French Opera House in New Orleans, one of the oldest opera houses in the Unites States. He was also an avid collector of opera memorabilia that included librettos, scores, photographs, sketches and more, which recently was accepted by the Morgan Library. He served on the Board of the Glimmerglass Opera and he was Chair of the Music Policy Committee. For over 20 years, he also assembled for them the annual summer exhibition from his extensive collection on opera history. Lewis is survived by his wife of 51 years, Gemma Stagni Hall, daughter Angelica Romano, and two grandchildren, Isabella and Luca Romano. You may pay your respects to Lewis at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Thursday, July 10th from 4-6pm. A funeral service will take place at All Saints Chapel in Morris on Saturday, July 19. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the Glimmerglass Opera, Cooperstown, NY or Zion Church, Morris, NY.

GRAGNANO--Gloria, 88, of Somers, NY, formerly of Washington Township, NJ, died July 11, 2014. Beloved wife of 61 years of Edward Martin Gragnano; devoted mother of Alison Gragnano Cilia and the late Edward Gragnano; dear mother-in-law of Robert Cilia and adored grandmother of Juliette and Ava. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Monday, July 14, 2014 at 11:30am at St. Joseph's RC Church, 95 Plum Brook Road, Somers, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to: www.childrenscancerfund.org.

GOLDSCHMID--Maurice, 83, of Boca Raton, FL passed away on Friday, July 11 surrounded by his devoted wife and loving family. He is survived by his wife, Irma; children, Keith (Betsy), Cliff (Deborah) Jill (Jimmy); grandchildren, Ashley, Casey, Edward, Samantha, Zachary. Loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. Maurice was a fixture in the garment industry and on the golf course for over 50 years. Graveside service on Sunday, July 13 at 1:00pm at New Montefiore Cemetery -1180 Wellwood Ave, West Babylon, NY, 11704. The family will be sitting Shiva at Jill and Jimmy Musiker's residence following the burial and Monday-Wednesday starting at 3pm.

GIAMANCO--Joe, entered into eternal peace surrounded by his loving family on Thursday July 10, 2014. He is survived by his wife, Mollie of 46 years, his three sons Victor, Christian and Joseph, their wives and nine grandchildren. Joe was a member of the American Stock Exchange and senior partner at GHM, Inc.

FISHER--Ann. The Board and team of the National Center for Learning Disabilities would like to express our heartfelt condolences to the Fisher family. Ann served as a dedicated member of the Board of Directors from 1992-2003. She was a passionate and committed advocate for children with learning disabilities and we will miss her greatly. Anne Ford, Chairman Emerita James H. Wendorf, Executive Director
FIERSTEIN--Richard. We will miss you 100%. With all our love, Ellen and Stan Lattman

FIERSTEIN--Richard, 66, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL passed away on Thursday, July 10, 2014 surrounded by his devoted wife and loving family. He is survived by his wife, Penny; children and step-children, Leigh (Jason) Amster, Russell, Lori (Keith) Handler, David Veis; grandchildren, Alexis, Jesse, Benjamin, and Blair. Rich was a co-founder ARC Excess and Surplus, LLC. Morris at Star of David Cemetery of The Palm Beaches, 9321 Memorial Park Road West Palm Beach, FL 33412 (561) 627-2277
EISENBERG--Mitchell, passed away on July 10. Son of the late Arthur and Estelle, brother of Alan (Robin) and Gary (Maria), uncle of Amanda and Jaime. There is nothing more whole than a broken heart.

DIEZ--German, 90, of New York, passed away peacefully in his sleep on the morning of July 9th 2014 in New York City. Born in Havana, Cuba on June 18, 1924. He was the youngest of six boys born to Maria Neito Ozores and Antonio Diez Alonso. He married Doris Cunningham of San Diego, California in 1940 in New York City and had a son Alexander German Diez. After graduating with highest honors from the Iranzo Conservation de Musica in Havana, where he won the National Music Award Competition for studies in foreign countries. In 1945, he came to the United States to study with Claudio Arrau. He performed in the West Indies, Cuba, the US and appeared on radio and television. He began his career as a pedagogue in 1948, taught winners of piano competitions, juried prestigious competitions as The William Kapell Piano Competition and National Fulbright Awards Screening Committee. Greenwich House Music School faculty since 1950 and chair since 1968, as well as piano faculty of Bard College, SUNY Purchase, Hunter College and The Brooklyn Conservatory. In 1997 honored by Greenwich House by establishing a fund for German Diez Piano Scholarship. Most recently he has been credited with assisting in every phase of the development of the book "Piano Lesson with Claudio Arrau" by Victoria A. von Arx. He is survived by his son Alexander G. Diez of New York, his brother Alfredo Diez Nieto of Havana, Cuba, his niece Alicia Diez of New York and the legacy of many accomplished pianists that he has taught. Respects can be paid between the hours of 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm on Friday July 11th at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleeker Street, NYC. An interment service will be held on Saturday 2pm July 12th at Trinity Cemetery 770 Riverside Dr.

DELYNN--Ruth Elow. October 16, 1926 - July 8, 2014. Ruth Elow DeLynn, 87, of Sarasota, died July 8, 2014. She is survived by her daughter, Nina (Donald) Berk of Newton, MA; son, William (Donna) DeLynn, of Rye Brook, NY; granddaughters, Kimberly, Amy Julia, and Robin. Ruth was born and raised in New York. She raised her own family in Westchester, spending 15 years as a taxidermist at The Museum of Natural History. She retired to Sarasota with her loving husband, Hubert, who predeceased her. Mrs. DeLynn spent the last 30 years passionately engaged in Marine Mammal Research at Mote Marine Laboratory, where she became known as "The Bone Lady". Her legacy remains at Mote in the Ruth DeLynn Cetacean Osteological Collection. Memorial donations may be made in Ruth's name to Mote Marine Laboratory, earmarked for "Strandings". A celebration of her life will be held at a later date.

COYNE--Jerome "Jerry" J.,Sr., 79, of Wyckoff, NJ passed away on Sunday, July 6th, 2014. Jerry is the beloved husband of Elizabeth (nee Hynes) and loving, proud father to Suzanne (Sean), Jerry, Jr. (Victoria), Jim (Pam), and Lizanne and devoted to his nine grandchildren Jerry III, Jimmy, William, Patrick, Andrew, Elizabeth, Daniel, Molly, and Luke. Jerry grew up in the Bronx, graduated from Cardinal Hayes High School, received a B.A. in Philosophy from Maryknoll College, and a MBA from Fairleigh Dickinson University. Jerry served in the National Guard and taught history at John Adams High School before joining IBM in May 1960. He retired in 1993 after thirty-three successful years in both sales and marketing executive positions at IBM. Jerry served on the Board of Directors of the United Way of Bergen County then worked for the United Way, Premier Teleconferencing, and taught at Ramapo College.

COLANTUONO--William, passed away on July 11, 2014 at 76 years of age. Beloved husband of Louise Kuflik. Dear father of Hollyrose Mueller and Daniel. Adoring grandfather of Katie, Carolyn and Danny Joe. Loving brother of Jay (Olga), Donna (Bill) and Lee (Julie) and brother-in-law of Abigail and Robert.

CHERMAYEFF--Jane. We deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Jane. She brightened every room she entered with her infectious laughter, sharp wit, irrepressible curiosity and expansive capacity for love. We will miss her in so many ways. We send great affection to our dear friend, Ivan and to Sam, Catherine, Maro and Sasha. Wendy Keys and Donald Pels

CHERMAYEFF--Jane Clark, 64, died peacefully at home of brain cancer. Born in Poughkeepsie, New York, she was a long time resident of New York City. As a curator and planner Jane dedicated her professional career to the arts, museums and children, cherishing the quote "life without a swing is a misunderstanding." Her work and life took her to diverse places; Cambodia, Germany, Puerto Rico, and most recently, Val-Kill, the Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site and Chicago's Millennium Park. In all of these places Jane brought to bare her expertise on learning. She founded the Architectural Playground Equipment Inc. and was a member of numerous professional associations; the New York Studio School, the Museum Group, The Conservation Trust of Puerto Rico and the Century Association among others. Jane will be remembered for her boundless love and intense generosity of spirit. Jane is survived by her husband Ivan, son Sam, brother Tom, sister Ann, stepchildren Catherine, Maro and Sasha, as well as five grandchildren. In lieu of customary remembrances, contributions in Jane's memory may be directed to the charity of one's choice. She herself loved a great many things, people and places.

CHAPLINE--Sheila Burrows died on May 16, 2014 in New York at age 95. Born in 1918 in Belleville, Ontario, she grew up in Glanmore, a National Historic Site of Canada her maternal grandfather built in 1883. Her father Sanford Rattray Burrows was an insurance executive and her late sister Philippa Faulkner a prominent painter whose work was exhibited in the diamond jubilee at the Royal Library of Windsor Castle. Sheila earned a certificate at New York School of Interior Design in 1940 where she worked for 45 years as registrar, lecturer in color, career counselor, and events planner. She co-wrote with Olga Menaker the chapter on color theory in Sherill Whiton's Interior Design and Decoration (4th edition). After retiring in 1992 Sheila volunteered at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House and St. James' Church. She is survived by her daughter Jane Philippa Chapline of New York City. A memorial service will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sheila Chapline Scholarship Fund, New York School of Interior Design.

BLENNER--Phyllis Gordon Teitelbaum, 91, on July 10 in Boca Raton. Loving mother of Larry Teitelbaum (Amy) Anne Manasse (Howard), Karen Teitelbaum and Zoe Teitelbaum Myerson; beloved grandmother of Jorden, Carlen, Matthew, RJ, Alex and Zachary; devoted sister of Leonore Levine and Dolly Himoff and constant companion to her precious dog, Sugar. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made online: www.breastcancer.org Graveside service, Sunday, July 13, 10am at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Lindenhurst, NY.

BERG--Fred. On June 24, 2014. Dearest, darling, beloved, husband of Illene - so lucky to have each other. Loving, caring dad of Barb, Amy and David and their wonderful spouses Danny, Kenny and Maggie - so proud of his children. Adoring grandpa to Jesse and Jagger. A light-up personality, an incomparable sense of humor, loving, kind, caring, sensitive, devoted, honorable, straightforward. Simply put - a wonderful man.

BERGER--Ronald M.,Age 81 of Boca Raton, Florida, passed away on July 4, 2014. Devoted husband of Gloria and the previously-deceased Myra, beloved father of Karen Blumenthal (Ivan), Steven Berger (Nicole) and stepfather of Chaim Jaffe (Esa), loving grandfather of nine and beloved brother-in-law of Judy Bernstein. He dedicated his life to his family, his work and his synagogue. He will live in our hearts forever.

AZAROFF--Leonid V.,an internationally known crystallographer, died in Naples, Florida, on July 3 at age 88. A graduate of Tufts University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he later affiliated with the faculties of the Armor Research Institute and the Illinois Institute of Technology. In 1965, he was appointed as the founding Director of the Institute of Material Sciences at the University of Connecticut, from which he retired in 1992. Dr. Azaroff was the author of numerous textbooks, scientific papers, and books, including his most recent, "Physics Over Easy Breakfasts with Beth and Physics." He is survived by his wife Beth Sulzer-Azaroff, his sister, three children, two nieces, two grandchildren, a grandniece, and a great-grandniece.

ARKWAY--Richard B.,87, a leading dealer in antiquarian maps and rare books, died on July 10 in Manchester, VT following a long illness. He was the son of the late Olga (Bunim) and Samuel Arkway and was born on February 7, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY where he spent his childhood. He is a graduate of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School and the University of Connecticut. After a career in retail menswear, Arkway turned his hobby of map collecting into a successful business, first in Providence, Rhode Island and then in New York City. In time, Richard B. Arkway, Inc. became one of the most respected antiquarian bookshops in the world and many important transactions in the trade took place there. The 69 catalogs he issued between 1982 and 2008 are noted for the high quality of their content and their scholarship; they are still revered in the trade. He was well-known for the depth of his knowledge and especially for his integrity. Those who worked for him often went on to establish rare-book businesses of their own. He is survived by his wife, Angela Arkway; his daughter Ellen Bisshopp and grandson Edward Bisshopp of Sharon, Massachusetts; his stepson Paul Grigaux and wife, Gail and their children Olivia, Sophie and Julien of Ladera Ranch, California; his stepdaughter Claire Grigaux and her husband Eric Savranksy and their children David and Isabelle of Westfield, NJ. He was predeceased by his son Andrew. A celebration of Richard's life will be held at the Dorset Inn, Dorset, VT on Sunday July 20 between 3 and 5pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Campaign for Female Education (CAMFED) at camfed.org.

PERKINS--Ruth Bergengren, of Princeton, NJ, and Blue Mountain Lake, NY, died on July 7, 2014, age 98. She was a magnificent force in many lives including those of her children, Cecilia Mathews, Mea Kaemmerlen, Pamela Aall McPherson and Christian Aall. She will be missed.

PAPAVASILIOU--Dimitra, on July 12 beloved wife of the late Elias. Loving mother of Connie, and Chrisos, and stepmother of Anastasios and Constantinos Papavasiliou. Cherished grandmother of Michael Hammond, Zoe Papavasiliou, Chloe Constas, and James Papavasiliou. She was a loving friend and relative to many here in the USA and in Greece and will be missed by all who knew her. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery Hastings-on-Hudson, New York.

MORSE--Lewis D.,on July 10, beloved husband of Vivian (predeceased in 2013) loving father of Marjorie M. (Gavin) Bell, adoring grandfather of Megan, Collin, Hayley, and Sean Bell. Born in 1924 in New York City, graduated Stuyvesant High School 1942. Served in US Army during WWII '42-'45, liberated Belgium, France and Buchenwald concentration camp. Earned BS and MS in Polymer Chemistry on GI Bill. Worked at Merck & Co. 22 years in the field of micro- encapsulation receiving several patents and helped invent time-release medication. Member of American Chemical Society 60 years. Memorial Service at Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc. Pittsburgh on Saturday, July 26, 2014 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Heart Association or American Diabetes Association appreciated.

Goldsmith--Edith Eva, nee Crane, of New York City, died at the age of 104 on July 12, 2014. Edith was the loving mother of Linda, The beloved wife, of 68 years, of the late David and sister to Ann Kurlan, both of whom predeceased her. A talented pianist, a champion scrabble player a lover and skillful tennis player and a kind and caring friend, Edith was an amazing woman who led a rich and full life. She will be greatly missed by her nieces, nephews, great nieces and great nephews and all those blessed by her friendship. Burial occurred on Sunday at the Old Montifiore Cemetery, NY.

WEISSMAN--Lilian Vera, 91, of Fresh Meadows, NY. Beloved mother of Simone (Peter Levitt), Antique Grandma of Jonathan and Zoe. Service Monday 11am at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave. Shiva Monday-Wednesday, 5-8pm at Simone's apartment. Contributions may be made to DorotUSA.org.

WEBSTER--Elizabeth "Lisa" McGraw, a philanthropist and renowned supporter of American figure skaters, died on Saturday, June 28 at her vacation home in Sun Valley, Idaho. She was 88. Ms Webster was born in New York City to Elizabeth Murtland Woodwell and Curtis Whittlesey McGraw, president of McGraw Hill Publishing from 1950-53. She was the granddaughter of James McGraw, founder of the publishing house. Ms Webster lived her entire life in Princeton, New Jersey, where she attended Miss Fines School. She went on to Foxcroft School in Middleburg, VA and Finch College in New York City. Ms Webster had a deep love for figure skating, and served on the board of The Skaters Fund, an organization that provides assistance to skaters and coaches in need due to illness, disability or age. Additionally, over some four decades, she sponsored numerous national and Olympic champions including Nancy Kerrigan, Paul Wylie, Steven Cousins, David Liu, Parker Pennington, Derrick Delmore, Jeremy Abbot, Alex Akin and others. In recognition for her commitment to the sport she was nominated for the Figure Skating Hall of Fame. Ms Webster also supported figure skating on the local level. She was a charter member of The Princeton Skating Club and her contributions built the club's state-of-the-art Lisa McGraw Skating Rink at Princeton Day School. Ms Webster was active throughout the Princeton community, serving on the board of directors of Princeton Hospital, and holding memberships at the Nassau Club, Bedens Brook Golf Club and the Pretty Brook Tennis Club. She was a founder and charter member of the Contemporary Garden Club of Princeton. She also established the Curtis W. McGraw Foundation and the Lisa McGraw Figure Skating Foundation, both in Princeton. Ms Webster was married twice, to James Stoltzfus and George Webster; both marriages ended in divorce. She is survived by two daughters, Lisette Stoltzfus Edmond and Marian Stoltzfus Paen; a son, Curtis McGraw Webster; grandchildren Elizabeth Edmond, Victoria Edmond, Alexandra Edmond, Nicolas Edmond, Antony James Maricich, Alexander McGraw Maricich, Anastasha Tatiana Maricich, and Theo McGraw Webster; sons- and daughters-in-law, and great- grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Nassau Presbyterian Church, 61 Nassau Street, Princeton, on October 11, 2014. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: the Lisa McGraw Figure Skating Foundation, Post office Box 627, Princeton, NJ 08542-0627, or The Skaters' Fund, 202 Park Knoll, Princeton, NJ 08540.

SCHOEFFLER--Max S. Born in Berlin, Max escaped to the US with his family in 1939, grew up in Bayonne, and lived most of his life in New Jersey. He graduated from Rutgers and earned his PhD in experimental psychology from Indiana U. At Bell Labs, his intellect and creativity led to several patents and many advances in telecommunications, including telephone redial, international numbering conventions, and intelligent systems. He will be warmly remembered by his many family members and friends for his humility, kindness, and zest for life.

SCHINELLER--Richard. Richard J. Schineller, Sr. of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Bronxville and Tuxedo Park, NY and Kinnelon, NJ, passed away on June 24, 2014. He is survived by his wife Eileen; sons Rich, Bill, and Erik; daughters Diane Sulimirski and Elena Matlack; and ten grandchildren.

POTTS--Martin Sydney, 61, died July 12th after a brief illness and in the loving care of his family in Munster, Germany. Martin was born in Yorkshire, England and became an accomplished artist, a contractor, a creative designer and a dedicated cook. He studied at the Bath Academy of Art in Corsham, Wiltshire, the Slade School of Art in London, and was a Rome Scholar. He came to New York in 1978 to continue painting and to assist English artist Richard Smith. He also designed and built many memorable living and working spaces for his fellow artists, designers and friends. He is survived by his parents, Sydney and Eileen Potts of Leeds, two brothers, his son Oscar and daughter Mathilde Bauermeister-Potts in Munster. Martin was loved and respected by everyone who had the pleasure of knowing him, and he will be greatly missed.
