WHALEN--Edward James. Formerly of Short Hills, NJ and a current resident of Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida passed away peacefully on July 11, 2014 in Morristown, NJ after a brief illness. He was in his 91st year. Ed's career was an example of the post-WWII American Dream at its best. Born in 1923 into a hard working family of modest means, Ed rose out of the steel mills of Youngstown, Ohio to become a highly respected businessman. More importantly he was a beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather, a doting husband to his wife, Betsy Whalen, for 29 years, and after her too early death from ovarian cancer in 1979, a loving companion to Suzanne Yeaw for the last 32 years of his life. Endowed with brains, good looks and the gift of blarney and fashioning himself a gentleman and a scholar, Ed accomplished a great deal. Disqualified from service in WWII by working in the essential steel industry, Ed attended both St. Vincent College in Latrobe, PA and The Ohio State University before graduating from Youngstown University. He then received his law degree from the University of Cincinnati, graduating in 1948. Ed then worked briefly with the Ohio Securities Commission before entering the Army both as an officer and a member of the Judge Advocate General's Corps. While on duty in Washington he introduced himself to a beautiful young New Zealand lady who was sunning herself on the rooftop of the same apartment building in which they both lived. Family lore is and witnesses confirm that, upon meeting Betsy Proud, Ed immediately asked for her hand in marriage. She, however, preferred a date or two first. Whatever the facts, they were married on November 18, 1950 and began a love affair that would only end by Betsy's death at the age of 57. During their honeymoon, Ed was ordered to Korea where he spent three years at the front, including the Chosin Reservoir and Inchon, enforcing the laws of military justice. He was awarded the Bronze Star for valor. The Korean War brought hardship but also opportunity. Ed, as was his habit, was befriended by certain members of the "top brass" and soon found himself with an offer to join a little known but growing company, International Telephone and Telegraph (ITT), as an attorney. As ITT went, so did Ed Whalen, becoming successively corporate secretary, North American General Counsel, and the chief operating officer of the Far East and Pacific Group. He moved his family, which now included two children, from Belleville, NJ to West Orange and then to Short Hills where he was an early Saturday morning regular at Canoe Brook Country Club and a Sunday morning regular at St. Rose of Lima Church. Retiring from ITT in 1981, he practiced law privately in Washington DC for several years before moving to Hilton Head Island and later to Ponte Vedra Beach. Ed will be forever loved by his "Suzy" of Madison, NJ; his beloved daughter Jessica Whalen Haverstick and, her husband, Alec, of Short Hills, NJ, his devoted son, Jeffrey Woodney Whalen of Seattle, WA, his four lucky grandchildren, Emily Umbdenstock ( Tyler) ;Samuel A. Haverstick III (Casey) and Genevieve Haverstick, all of New York City, and Abigail Woodney Wachter (John) of Princeton, NJ. Ed is also survived by five great grandchildren under the age of four, all of whom attended his 90th birthday: Liam, Luke, Izzy, Sadie and Wyatt. We will remember summers at Hilton Head; Christmases in Short Hills; the whale emblazoned wardrobe; the twinkling blue eyes; the golden hair; many family graduations, weddings and births; "I haven't seen anything like that since the war!" ; "Lucky Bucky"; many happy returns of the day and the immense love he showed us all. We cherish his large intelligence, his devotion to honor, honesty and his own moral code, his work ethic, and his sparkling sense of humor, and will try to carry these traits in our own lives as his lasting legacy. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Ed's memory may be made to St. Vincent College, Latrobe, PA or the Madison Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Prospect Street, Madison, NJ 07940. A funeral mass will be held at St. Vincent's Church, Madison, NJ at 10am on Thursday July 17th. The Family of Edward J. Whalen.

WARREN--Peter K.,Former Pepsi International CEO, PepsiCo Board Member, dies at 94. Peter K. Warren, active in the beverage industry for almost 70 years and the man responsible for Pepsi Cola's market entry into more than 100 countries over three decades died on Monday in Wilton, CT. He was 94. Recognized by friends and business associates from around the world as a true beverage industry icon and an inspirational global business leader, Peter possessed the charisma and business acumen to meet the formidable challenges faced by many companies entering international markets for the first time. His cultural sensitivity and interpersonal skills enabled him to build strong and lasting partnerships wherever he planted the Pepsi flag. Although Peter began his career with Coca Cola, he quickly moved to Pepsi in 1950 when it was still a one product company. He was promoted to President of Pepsi Cola International in 1963 after having served as VP of Marketing the previous four years. He ran Pepsi's international business, later as its CEO of International, for decades as well as served on Pepsi's Board of Directors. Upon Peter's retirement in 1985, Pepsi enjoyed revenues in excess of $7.5 billion, employed over 137,000 employees, and marketed products in 150 countries and territories. Social responsibility and a desire to help the youth within the many countries that Pepsi entered was always a focus point of Peter's approach. For example, in 1972 when Brazilian soccer star and "national treasure" Pele was approaching retirement, Peter signed the athlete to a global agreement to represent Pepsi while also providing a platform on which, according to Peter, "Pele could play an active role in programs aimed to service the youth through a game played in 115 countries". After retiring from PepsiCo in 1985, Peter continued in the beverage industry as Chairman of Monsieur Henri Wines, Ltd., (brand developer of Stolichnaya Vodka), as well as its successor company, MHW, Ltd., currently an industry leader in beverage alcohol import and distribution services. Peter Warren grew up in New York City, "a product of the depression", as he often commented. He enlisted in the army during World War II, leaving as a Captain seven years later at the war's conclusion. While developing his business career, Peter and his cherished wife, Maria, combined their love of travel with a passion for the fine arts and collecting. From travelers to collectors to Antiquarians, they established Maria and Peter Warren Antiques. Following Maria's death in 1991, Peter remained active in the antiques business, now joined by his beloved daughter AJ, who continues to run the business today. Creativity, vision, charm, wit, formidable negotiation skills, and social responsibility are just a few of the attributes that come to mind when describing Peter. Aside from work and hobbies, Peter also generously supported his local community. In particular he served as a two-term President of the Wilton Historical Society. He was also very active in supporting higher education and served as the former Chairman of the Council of Governing Boards in New York State. In that capacity he helped push legislation for affordable tuition at 110 independent colleges in the state. In 1984, Peter was awarded a Commendation for his support of secondary education by President Reagan. Most important of all, Peter was a beloved husband, father and grandfather and uncle in a remarkable family whom he treasured dearly. Following the loss of his beloved wife Maria in 1991, Peter was able to achieve newfound happiness when he married Holly Wright in 2009. Holly brought energy, love, and devotion to their daily life in Wilton, CT. Peter recently dealt with the loss of his daughter Carmen following her 22 year battle with cancer. He considered Carmen a true hero in every sense of the word and an inspiration to those who love life and bravely fight for every day that God allows. In addition to his wife Holly, Peter is survived by his children: Peter and AJ Warren; former daughter-in-law Peggy Warren; grandchildren, Joshua Allen, Peter Alexander and Christopher Aiden Warren of Kalispell, MT, Downers Grove, IL and Witon, CT; son-in law Ritch Robinson of City Island, NY; sister-in-law Christina Bracho; nieces and nephews Juan, Pablo, Monica and Diana Bracho of Houston, TX and Mexico City, DF; Giles and Hugh Parker of Medford, MA and Daytona Beach, FL and Ingrid and Kirby Warren of Tuxedo Park, NY. Services will be held on Thursday, July 17, 4:00-8:00pm at the Bouton Funeral Home, 31 W. Church St., Wilton CT, (203) 544-8461. The funeral mass will be held at Our Lady of Fatima Church, 229 Danbury Rd., on Friday, July 18 at 1:00pm with the burial to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, 110 North St., Ridgefield, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Wilton Historical Society, St. Jude Children's Research Hospital or The National Breast Cancer Fund. For anyone who would like to attend, we will be serving "high tea" in memory of Peter--not just a dealer and a collector of English, Japanese and Chinese Period Tea Pots but also an avid tea drinker. The reception will be held after the burial at Wilton Historical Society, 224 Danbury Rd, Wilton, CT.

WALKER--Edward J.,died suddenly on July 12, 2014 at home in Ossining, New York at age 87. Alumnus of Cooley High School, Detroit; University of Michigan (MA); United States Army; Yale (PhD); IBM Research Center (1960-87). Westinghouse Science Scholar, songster, sailor, skin-diver, machinist, cyclist, Homebrew member, anti-war activist, Pepysian, SIA enthusiast, storehouse of poems. Survived by wife Barbara; brother George and his wife Edith; daughter Anna and husband Geoff Reiss; grandsons Walker and Jack Reiss. Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas.

SANDERS--Arthur, age 102. Formerly of New York, NY, a Parasitologist. Preceded in death by parents James H. and Sarah I. Sanders nee Berkowitz and beloved wife of 52 years Sarah S. Sanders. Survived by children, Stuart Sanders and Farrel Braunstein; three grandchildren. Shiva 555 Mt. Curve Blvd, St. Paul, MN 55116.

ROSENBERG--Abraham "Bud", 90, of St. Petersburg, FL died June 28, 2014. Son of Leon Louis and Martha Feingold Rosenberg and loving husband of the late Harriet Sherman Rosenberg, he is survived by his daughter Linda, her husband Anthony Caracciolo and his granddaughter, Sofia Chunlu Caracciolo. A engineering graduate of the University of Alabama, he was vice president at Rosco Tools, Inc., originally known as Rosenberg Brothers & Co., founded by his father and uncles. An active member of the Academy of Senior Professionals at Eckerd College in Florida and former Commodore of the South Bay Cruising Club on Long Island, he was an avid sailor, golfer, nautical model maker, woodworker and food enthusiast. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends.

PERKINS--Ruth Bergengren, of Princeton, NJ, and Blue Mountain Lake, NY, died on July 7, 2014, age 98. She was a magnificent force in many lives including those of her children, Cecilia Mathews, Mea Kaemmerlen, Pamela Aall McPherson and Christian Aall. She will be missed.

NAFTALIS--Alan, age 67, of New York City, on July 11, 2014. Attorney. Predeceased by his brother Richard. Survived by his brother Gary, sister-in-law Donna, nieces Sarah, Erika, nephews Benjamin, Joshua, Daniel and Bryan, cousins Phyllis, Pamela, Gerri, Barry, Natalie, Paula and Philip. Services Wednesday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

MAAZEL--Lorin. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Lorin Maazel, one of the world's great conductors, whose Met career spanned 51 years. Maestro Maazel made his Met debut in 1962 conducting Mozart's "Don Giovanni" and led a total of 28 Met performances, most recently Verdi's "Don Carlo" in 2013. In addition to his work as an artist, we remember Maazel as an esteemed colleague who led the New York Philharmonic from 2002 to 2009. We offer our sincere condolences to his family, friends, and many admirers. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

MAAZEL--Lorin. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the passing of Lorin Maazel, our brilliant and acclaimed Music Director, 200209. During his tenure Maestro Maazel and the Philharmonic commissioned and premiered nine works, including John Adams's Pulitzer Prize and Grammy Awardwinning On the Transmigration of Souls, commemorating the victims of 9/11. He led the Orchestra around the world, including the historic performance in Pyongyang, North Korea, the first there by an American orchestra, and the re-consecration of Dresden's Frauenkirche, destroyed during World War II. At home Maestro Maazel, a sensitive and singular interpreter, led complete symphonic cycles of Mahler and Beethoven, and memorable opera-in-concert performances of Ravel's L'Enfant et les sortileges, Puccini's Tosca, and Strauss's Elektra. He hired 19 Philharmonic musicians and conducted the Orchestra's inaugural performances in the DG Concerts series -- a groundbreaking initiative to offer live Philharmonic concerts exclusively as downloads. From his debut in 1942, at the age of 12, until his last appearance in 2013, he led the Philharmonic in 619 performances. "I am deeply saddened and shocked by the news of Lorin Maazel's death," said New York Philharmonic Music Director Alan Gilbert. "For decades he was a major force in the musical world, and truly an inspiration for generations of American musicians. Personally, I am grateful to him, not only for the brilliant state of the Orchestra that I inherited from him, but for the support and encouragement he extended to me when I took over his responsibilities." All of us in the New York Philharmonic family send our love and sympathy to his wife, Dietlinde Turban Maazel, and their children, Orson, Leslie, and Tara; his daughters, Anjali Maazel, Daria Maazel Steketee, and Fiona Maazel; his son, Ilann Maazel; and his four grandchildren, Kiran, Owen, Calypso, and Sahara.

MAAZEL--Lorin. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts mourn the passing of legendary conductor, composer and musician Lorin Maazel. A brilliant member of the Lincoln Center family, he held the podium as Music Director of the New York Philharmonic from 2002-2009. His global impact on classical music is immeasurable, and his interpretations of the classical music repertoire will live on forever. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Dietlinde, his family and many friends and admirers. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
MAAZEL--Lorin. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Lorin Maazel, and send condolences to his family.

LUSKER--Ron, of DeBruce, NY. Ron died peacefully on Saturday, July 12, 2014, surrounded by his family, his devoted wife, Marilyn, daughter Ianine and devoted assistant, Edwin Pubil after a courageous battle with cancer. He was 77 years of age. The son of the late Joseph Lusker and Irene Jorgensen Lusker, he was born on January 28, 1937 in Chicago, IL. He was predeceased by two brothers, Gerry and Bill Lusker. Ron was an artist, an inventor and a conservator of old buildings. He, together with his wife Marilyn, restored the century old building now known as "DeBruce Country Inn", located in the Catskills of New York State. A Celebration of Ron's Life will be on Wednesday, July 16 from 5-8pm at DeBruce Country Inn, 982 DeBruce Rd., DeBruce, NY 12758. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Thursday, July 17 at 10am at St. Peter's Church, 264 N. Main St. Liberty, NY. Burial will follow the mass at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Sleepy Hollow, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to NYU Langone Medical Center, 550 First Ave., New York, NY 10016; Wounded Warrior Project, PO Box 758517, Topeka KS 66675 or to Hospice of Orange & Sullivan Counties, 800 Stony Brook Court, Newburgh, NY 12550. Funeral services handled by Ramsay's Funeral Homes Inc. Liberty, NY. To send a condolence or for further information, please visit ramsaysfuneralhome.com.

JUSTER--Doris. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed Founding Member. We extended deepest sympathy to her sons Howard and Gary and to the entire family. Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Emeritus Israel Singer, Cantor Martin Rogowsky, President

JUSTER--Doris R.,died peacefully in her sleep on July 12, 2014, one week after her 92nd birthday. Daughter of the late Harry and Margaret Levy, and sister of the late Sheldon Levy. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Martin Juster, daughter, Ann Juster, and longtime companion, Milton Walsey. She will be lovingly remembered and forever in the hearts of her devoted sons, Gary and Howard, cherished daughters-in-law, Karen and Beth, and adored grandchildren, Michael, Michelle, Joshua and Matthew. Graveside services held at Sharon Gardens on Tuesday, July 15th, at 11am. Donations in her memory may be made to the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, NY.

HARTSTEIN--Sam. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of our former colleague, Sam Hartstein, z'l, a graduate of the Isaac Breuer College of Hebraic Studies in 1941 and Yeshiva College in 1943, who went on to serve with distinction as Yeshiva University's Director of the Public Relations Department for more than sixty years. He was deeply devoted to our institution. He will be sorely missed by those who knew him. Burial is in Israel. Heartfelt condolences to his wife, Rachel, his children, Dr. Gila (Yoni) Heimowitz and Jonathan (Carol) Hartstein. May the entire family be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

HANNA--Alistair. We mourn the passing of Fountain House Board Member, Alistair Hanna. Mr. Hanna was elected to the Board in 2005, and until his death, tirelessly served in many capacities. His sage advice was invaluable on many issues over the last two decades. He was a brilliant man and a loving human being. He brought clarity and vision to Fountain House. The Fountain House community will miss him greatly, but his contributions will be a lasting gift to us all. Nancy Farrell Board Chair, Fountain House Kenneth Dudek President, Fountain House

HAMMERSCHLAG--Belle. Jewish Board of Family & Children's Services joins our dear friend and long-standing Trustee Stephanie Bernheim and her family in mourning the loss of her mother. Belle died on Sunday, July 6 after a full century of living. May Stephanie, Ralph, her children and the entire family be comforted by memories of Belle's long and richly lived life.

FIORENZA--Alfred A.,on July 13, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Joan. Loving father of Larry, Maryellen, Lisa and John. Cherished grandfather of Sara, Emily, Marie, Julia, Ben and Grace. Friends may call Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave, New Hyde Park, NY. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:15am at Notre Dame RC Church, New Hyde Park. Interment Mt. St. Mary Cemetery.

FERTIK--Greta R.,of New York, died at home on July 14, 2014 at age 72 after battling lung cancer for twenty years. She is survived by her husband, Bill Fertik; sons, Joshua and Michael; daughter, Lily; sister, Liz Selkowe; daughters-in-law, Melleta Marx and Elena Kohl; and three grandchildren, Eliana, Navon and Sava. Greta received an undergraduate degree in English and education from Hunter College. She earned a master's degree at the California State Polytechnic College at San Luis Obispo, and completed a second master's degree and doctoral courses in psychology at The New School for Social Research in New York. She practiced as a Forensic Psychologist at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital in New York, specializing in methadone replacement therapy - the basis of her doctoral thesis. At the 92nd Street YMCA, Greta lectured, taught and ran groups in parenting and problems encountered by career-oriented mothers. She also had a private practice. Greta frequently traveled with her husband and family to Europe, especially Italy. In Milan, she became an activist for the nascent Progressive Jewish Synagogue, eventually becoming one of the founding members of the first Reform Jewish Movement in Italy. Today, there are more than five Reform/Progressive Synagogues in northern Italy. Greta will be missed for her brilliant mind, keen insight, critical thinking, sharp sense of humor and fierce loving embrace. Services will be held on Thursday, July 17, at 12 noon, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St., NYC.

COHN--Gerald L.,85, of Aventura, FL and Doylestown, PA died on July 14, 2014. Survived by loving wife, Florence Smerconish Cohn, devoted daughters Shelley Cohn Schmidt (Bennett Schmidt) of New York City and Cynthia Cohn Hierbaum (Randy Hierbaum) of Laguna Beach, CA and adored grandfather of Clayton and Blake Schmidt and Samuel and Molly Starr. Dear brother of Martin Cohn and Marilyn Bergstein, and uncle to several nieces and nephews. Born in Easton, PA and long-time resident of Hazleton, PA and Aventura, FL, Jerry was a successful businessman, financier and investor who founded several companies including Nautilus Industries, which pioneered the development of the non-vented kitchen range hood. Following the sale of Nautilus to the Tappan Industries in 1964, Jerry founded Agmet, Inc, a large recycler of precious metals and scrap steel. In 1980, Agmet was sold to the French conglomerate, Empain Schneider. In addition to his business interests, Jerry was a cofounder of the Hannah S. and Samuel A. Cohn Memorial Foundation, created to honor his parents, which for twenty years has generously supported Jewish charities and other causes in Pennsylvania, where he grew up. Jerry's dedication to helping others was legendary and he will be sorely missed by his colleagues, friends and especially his family. Donations can be made to the Hannah S. and Samuel A. Cohn Memorial Foundation, c/o National Penn Investors Trust Co, 12 E. Broad St, Hazleton, PA 18201, attention: Rhonda Lescowitch.

Caravaglia--Tom, The Paul Taylor Dance Company dancers and administration mourn the passing of our friend and professional colleague, Tom Caravaglia. Tom's love of Mr. Taylor's work combined with his skills as a brilliant photographer made him an integral part of our operation. Tom loved dance. So many companies, both established or just emerging, were able to find this generous genius ready to work with them to capture magical moments with his camera. He will be sorely missed.

BECK--Gustav J.,MD (94), of Foulkeways at Gwynedd, PA, formerly of Tenafly, NJ, died on July 13, 2014. He was the son of Oskar and Helene Beck. Surviving are Rita Levitiss Beck, his wife of nearly 70 years; son, Edward (Esther) Beck: grandchildren, Rishona (Scott) Myers of Abington, PA, Avi (Anat) Beck MD of Harrisburg, PA. Samantha (Rob) Masabny of Holbrook, MA and four great grandchildren, Elle and Michael Beck and Amanda and Sarah Myers. He was predeceased by his son, Andrew P.(Leslie Debrocky Fusfeld) Beck, Ph.D. Born in Vienna, Austria, he and his parents fled the Nazis. He attended City College of New York; graduated from Columbia University and New York University School of Medicine. He was a US Army Veteran, serving in the Medical Corps. Specializing in Internal Medicine, Allergy, Immunology and Pulmonology, he served on the faculties of Columbia University School of Physicians and Surgeons and New York University and on the staffs of Lenox Hill Hospital, St. Clare's Hospital, Goldwater Memorial Hospital and Englewood Hospital. An accomplished medical researcher in pulmonary and respiratory rehabilitation whose research contributed to the development of the pulmonary function machine, aerosol inhalers and other major advances, he was a Fellow of the American Medical Association, American Thoracic Society, American College of Physicians, American College of Chest Physicians, American Association for Clinical Immunology and Allergy, American Geriatric Society and Aerospace Medical Association and served on the boards and committees of numerous national, state and local medical and scientific societies. He also served on setting up the Respiratory Therapy programs at Lenox Hill Hospital and Bergen Community College and was active with the North Jersey Cultural Council and other local community committees. He is the author of his memoirs, "Success By Overcoming Adversity" and "The Adventures of Helene," his mother's memoirs. Retired, he served on many committees and offices at Foulkeways at Gwynedd where he served as chair of the Residents Committee. Gutterman Musicant, Hackensack, NJ are handling funeral services at the convenience of the family. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Foulkeways at Gwynedd, 1120 Meetinghouse Road, Gwynedd, PA 19436 or charity of your choice.

BALINT--Sandor. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Sandor Balint, a violinist in the Met Orchestra for 58 years. In addition to playing in the Orchestra's first violin section, Sandy was elected a member of the Orchestra committee in 1959 and served as chairman for contract negotiations from 1977 to 2000. An admired and beloved colleague, Sandy will be sorely missed by his coworkers. We offer our sincerest condolences to his wife Joyce, also a member of the Met Orchestra, and all his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

APPEL--Carl, on July 12, 2014, age 92, died peacefully, after a long illness, surrounded by his family. He was predeceased by his wife of 70 years, Rose, and is survived by his children Joseph (Patty), David (Sally) and Sharon, and his grandchildren Naomi, Jonathan, Jacob, Elizabeth and Julia. Carl lived the American dream; he arrived from Poland at age 13, graduated from Lincoln High School, served in the Air Force during WWII and then returned to New York to build a successful family and business over the next 60 years. His kindness, wisdom and generosity touched the lives of family and friends the world over. He will be terribly missed by all those who were so fortunate to have crossed his path. In lieu of flowers, donations to UJA would be appreciated.

ALLEN--Deborah, 90, died peacefully at home July 13 after a short illness. She leaves her husband of 66 years, Oliver Allen; her children Frederick Allen, Henry Allen M.D., Lili Allen and Jennie Dwight Allen; her grandchildren Lindsay Allen, Benjamin Allen, Elizabeth Murphy, John Murphy and Matthew Morgan; and her great-grandchildren Steven Jupiter Allen and Olivia Allen. A graduate of Smith College, class of 1946, she served as co-founding editor of Industrial Design Magazine in the early 1950s. In 1971 she joined the administrative staff of the College for Human Services (later renamed the Metropolitan College of New York), serving as a key aide to that institution's founder, Audrey Cohen, and helping to create and define the institution's unique educational program. After her retirement from that post she was elected a member of the College's Board of Trustees, which came to value her wise judgment and progressive thinking. Concluding her service on the board recently, she was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters by the College on June 14 of this year. A memorial service will be scheduled for a few weeks from now.

YOUNG--Bradden Hamilton, 39, born in Oxford, England, passed away suddenly on July 4 at his home in Washington, DC. He was the Founder and CEO of Young & Inspired, an Executive Producer of the Global Poverty Project Citizen Festival, and CSO of "Noise4Good." His passion was to promote and raise support for worthy causes. His warm, creative and caring spirit will be missed by many. A Service of Thanksgiving will be held in Washington, DC, on Friday, July 18 at Christ Our Shepherd Church at 2pm.

WILLIAMS--Margaret P.,(nee Rooney), "Mickey," 75, of Plandome, NY, on July 14, 2014. Beloved wife of Morgan "Lloyd" for 53 years. Devoted mother of Lloyd (Meaghan) and John Williams and Christine Labrecque (Thomas). Doting grandmother of Morgan, Fiona and Abigail Williams and Margot and Thomas Labrecque. Born in Astoria, NY, President of the 1960 class of Queens College (BA) and graduate of New York University (MA). A Past President of the Plandome Women's Club, Mickey was active in the Village as well as being an avid bridge player, voracious reader and expert in crewel embroidery. Visitation to be held Thursday 3-5pm and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. Funeral Mass Friday 10am, Church of St. Mary, 1300 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Manhasset Women's Coalition Against Breast Cancer.

SICHEL--Alexandra "Alex", passed away peacefully on June 23rd after three years of courageous fight with breast cancer. Born on July 31st, 1963, in Manhattan, Alex is survived by her husband, Erich Hahn Jr., her beloved daughter, Anastasia, her parents, Peter and Stella Sichel, and two sisters, Bettina and Sylvia. She adored them all. Alex was a gifted director and writer who worked in film, documentary and television. She directed and wrote (with her sister Sylvia) the much-lauded feature film, All Over Me (1996), and her short film, Amnesia (1992) won top honors at numerous festivals. Alex's other films included Tree Shade (1998) and Anemone Me (1990). At the time of her death, Alex was finishing a feature-length hybrid documentary about her struggle to come to terms with her illness. A beloved professor, Alex taught directing at NYU and Columbia. She received Macdowell and Yaddo Fellowships, was a member of the Directors Guild of America, and earned an M.F.A. from Columbia University and a B.A. from Brown University. A long-time practitioner of Buddhism, Alex was a pioneering, compassionate and brave soul, and she was blessed by a large number of loving friends and family who helped her enjoy life and ease her death. If a will could cure, Alex would have been cured. There will be a memorial service on September 20th at 3:00pm at The Lafayette Presbyterian Church 85 South Oxford Street in Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a contribution to "Women Make Movies/ The Movie About Anna" or the Kadampa Meditation Center in New York City.

SCHULZ--Eva, 92, of Riverdale and Sleepy Hollow, NY died July 5, 2014. Wife of the late John W. Schulz. Educator, gardener, opera lover, matriarch; tireless supporter of Wave Hill, Riverdale Mental Health, Riverdale Neighborhood House, Riverdale Senior Services, the Bronx Opera and many other community organizations. Loving mother of Catherine Benison (Diane), Elizabeth Schulz (Theresa Roche), and Andrew Schulz (Mauri Small). Adoring grandmother of William Small Schulz. Contributions to any of the above organizations would be appreciated. A Memorial will be planned.

ROTH--Stanley Jr.,on July 14, 2014. Devoted father of Steven and his wife, Ellen Freeman Roth. Cherished grandfather of Joshua and Madeline. Companion of Patricia Erpf. A proud veteran of WWII. After graduating from Yale University he became a retail executive. A lifetime lover of jazz, art and the New York Giants. Service private.

ROSENBURGH--Carleton F.,of Reston, VA, on July 7, 2014, a senior journalism executive, died at the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore. He had turned 75 on July 1. After graduating from Yale in 1961 and serving briefly in the Army, Carleton embarked on a life-long career in the production, circulation, distribution and business aspects of newspapers. He started at the New York Daily News in 1962, working in production, distribution and circulation of all of its publications. In 1978, he moved to Philadelphia, where he became Vice President of the Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News. In 1986, he was hired by Gannett at which he became Senior Vice President of the Newspaper Division, responsible for all departments except editorial. A consummate and well-respected professional, Carleton served on the Board and in other capacities at the Audit Bureau of Circulation, a standard setting organization for the print journalism and advertising businesses. Although he excelled at business, what truly distinguished him was his ability to develop strong personal bonds and his mentorship of those around him. A fervent believer in "management by walking around," he cared deeply about the career development of those who worked for him. He will be missed by many. A citizen of generous spirit, Carleton served and raised money for his church, various schools, the United Way, and other causes. His retirement took him to Scottsdale, Arizona where he became active in Arizona Musicfest and was a Board Member of the Walter Cronkite School of Journalism at Arizona State University, where he also taught, sharing his vast knowledge of and experience in the newspaper industry. Carleton was blessed to meet and marry Louise Ravenel Marshall, who was his loving wife and devoted friend for more than 50 years. Together they had three children who loved him dearly, Laura, Andrew and Cynthia. Their six grandchildren loved and will miss "Grandpa Zona". People wishing to send remembrances are encouraged to make a donation in his memory to Saint Thomas Episcopal Church, 8991 Brook Road, McLean, VA 22102 or to Deerfield Academy, at 7 Boyden Lane, PO Box 87, Mailbox No. 305, Deerfield, MA 01342. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas Episcopal Church at the address above on Saturday, July 19 at 3:00pm.
PINTO--Dr. Karl, 84, passed July 13, 2014. Graduate of Belleville, Rutgers, Northwestern University. Loved by his wife Frances, son Glenn, daughter Carol, Christine and five grandchildren.

MESSEX--Marvin G.,Died July 10, 2014 in Vero Beach, FL. Born in Kentucky, he moved to California in his youth. He completed his education with a Master's degree in Public Health from the University of California at Berkley. He worked for the Santa Barbara County Department of Public Health. He moved to New Canaan, CT in 1979 and to Vero Beach in 1990. Marvin is survived by his wife 35 years, Jean (Palmer-McCrum); brother, Monte Messex (Shan); sons, Montgomery (Kim) and Michael (Tina); five grandchildren; six McCrum step-children, Hanna Henderson (Kris), Lindsay, Elizabeth, Bo (Barbara), Kate and William and five step-grandchildren. A service will be held in Blue Hill, ME at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Blue Hill Memorial Hospital, Blue Hill, ME. An online guestbook may be signed at www.coxgiffordseawinds.com.

MAAZEL--Lorin. The faculty, staff, students, and alumni of The Perlman Music Program mourn the loss of Maestro Lorin Maazel. A dear friend, generous patron, and mentor to many, we offer our most heartfelt sympathies to his family.

KRUEGER--Dana. April 6, 1940-July 12, 2014. With sadness and much love we mark the death of Dana Krueger Grossman. A lifelong resident of Washington, DC, her career in opera and theater was fostered by the great Todd Duncan. She performed many comic and dramatic roles with the Houston Grand Opera, Washington National Opera, New York City Opera, and Central City Opera. She debuted roles in world premiere productions of operas by Leonard Bernstein, Gian-Carlo Menotti, and Peter Schickele, with whom she toured in The Intimate PDQ Bach and made two Grammy-winning recordings. Her Augusta Tabor in The Ballad of Baby Doe was a favorite role. Her DC-area work at Signature Theatre and Arena Stage included roles in Candide, The Women, Sweeney Todd, Sunday in the Park With George, and Follies. Her portrayal of stroke victim Emily Stilson in Wings at Signature won her a Helen Hayes Award in 1995. Dana's kindness, generosity, wit and humor were boundless. She was a great cook, crossword puzzler, and a seriously funny person who appreciated the spark in others. We laughed long and hard together. Her friends and family will miss her terribly. Husband Milton Grossman, daughter Abigail/Eric Wallgren, sister Ellen Siesel/Fred, Hanna.

KAWARA--On. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the loss of On Kawara, whose work represents a truly significant contribution to the history of modern and contemporary art. Through radically restricted means, Kawara's art marks a unique engagement with the personal and historical consciousness of place and time. Often associated with the rise of Conceptual art, in its complex wit and philosophical reach his work stands apart. Equally remarkable was his stunning commitment to the practice of painting. An exhibition of Kawara's work at the Guggenheim this fall has been in the planning. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to the artist's family on the occasion of this untimely loss. William L. Mack, Chairman; Jennifer Blei Stockman, President; Richard Armstrong, Director; Nancy Spector, Deputy Director and Jennifer and David Stockman Chief Curator; and Jeffrey Weiss, Senior Curator, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation
KAPLAN--Gloria Shatsky, age 83. Beloved wife of Marshall G. Kaplan. Devoted aunt and great-aunt. Services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY today at 1:15pm.

JUSTER--Doris R.,died peacefully in her sleep on July 12, 2014, one week after her 92nd birthday. Daughter of the late Harry and Margaret Levy, and sister of the late Sheldon Levy. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Martin Juster, daughter, Ann Juster, and longtime companion, Milton Walsey. She will be lovingly remembered and forever in the hearts of her devoted sons, Gary and Howard, cherished daughters-in-law, Karen and Beth, and adored grandchildren, Michael, Michelle, Joshua and Matthew. Graveside services held at Sharon Gardens on Tuesday, July 15th, at 11am. Donations in her memory may be made to the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, NY.

HANNA--Alistair. The partners of McKinsey & Co. deeply mourn the passing of our cherished colleague and friend, Ali Hanna, who was an esteemed and valued member of our Firm for 23 years. Ali joined McKinsey in 1974 from Harvard Business School, having already earned a Ph.D. in nuclear physics from Queens University in Belfast. He was elected a Principal in 1979 and a Director in 1986, retiring from McKinsey in 1997. Following his productive tenure at McKinsey, Ali devoted much of his time to serving Alpha North America, a non profit that provides training programs to improve the health of churches. Ali was a brilliant and inspiring counselor to a wide array of client leaders. He provided insightful and seminal thinking in our microeconomic practice, leading our Firm's Microeconomic Center from 1984 to 1990, and our Stamford Office from 1993 to 1996. As an innovative and prescient leader, Ali had a profound impact on our Firm and the professional development of its partners and associates. He was a beloved mentor and loyal friend to a generation of McKinsey colleagues. Ali's countless contributions to our Firm, his entrepreneurship and contagious energy, his warm and humorous collegiality, and his caring friendship created an enduring legacy that will always be appreciated. We offer our deepest condolences to Ali's wife Nancy, his daughter Anne, and to his entire family, and we join them in mourning the loss of a truly remarkable man.

GERSTLER--Joan, 70, of New York, died peacefully at home on July 14, 2014. Devoted mother of Deborah Gerstler Spanierman, doting grandmother of Sarah and Ethan and loving partner to Alex Rutman. COVINGTON--Treadwell Downing, of Southampton, LI died at home on July 9, 2014 on his 89th birthday. A partner in Total Television Productions, Inc., a member of ASCAP and the University Club in New York. Survived by two daughters, Caroline Armistead Gordon Covington and Coline Elizabeth Covington; as well as grandsons Justin and Charles Kesser. Interment at Magnolia Cemetery in Charleston, SC. A Memorial Service will be held in September at the Dune Church in Southampton. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978.

COHN--Gerald L.,85, of Aventura, FL and Doylestown, PA died on July 14, 2014. Survived by loving wife, Florence Smerconish Cohn, devoted daughters Shelley Cohn Schmidt (Bennett Schmidt) of New York City and Cindy Cohn Hierbaum (Randy Hierbaum) of Laguna Beach, CA and adored grandfather of Clayton and Blake Schmidt and Samuel and Molly Starr. Dear brother of Martin Cohn and Marilyn Bergstein, and uncle to several nieces and nephews. Born in Easton, PA and long-time resident of Hazleton, PA and Aventura, FL, Jerry was a successful businessman, financier and investor who founded several companies including Nautilus Industries, which pioneered the development of the non-vented kitchen range hood. Following the sale of Nautilus to Tappan Industries in 1964, Jerry founded Agmet, Inc, a large recycler of precious metals and scrap steel. In 1980, Agmet was sold to the French conglomerate, Empain Schneider. In addition to his business interests, Jerry was a cofounder of the Hannah S. and Samuel A. Cohn Memorial Foundation, created to honor his parents, which for twenty years has generously supported Jewish charities and other causes in Pennsylvania, where he grew up. Jerry's dedication to helping others was legendary and he will be sorely missed by his colleagues, friends and especially his family. Donations can be made to the Hannah S. and Samuel A. Cohn Memorial Foundation, c/o National Penn Investors Trust Co, 12 E. Broad St, Hazleton, PA 18201, attention: Rhonda Lescowitch.

CHERMAYEFF--Jane. The New York Studio School extends its deepest sympathy to the Chermayeff family for the loss of dearest Jane Chermayeff, longtime trustee. We send our heartfelt condolences.

WILLIAMS--Margaret P.,(nee Rooney), "Mickey," 75, of Plandome, NY, on July 14, 2014. Beloved wife of Morgan "Lloyd" for 53 years. Devoted mother of Lloyd (Meaghan) and John Williams and Christine Labrecque (Thomas). Doting grandmother of Morgan, Fiona and Abigail Williams and Margot and Thomas Labrecque. Born in Astoria, NY, President of the 1960 class of Queens College (BA) and graduate of New York University (MA). A Past President of the Plandome Women's Club, Mickey was active in the Village as well as being an avid bridge player, voracious reader and expert in crewel embroidery. Visitation to be held Thursday 3-5pm and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. Funeral Mass Friday 10am, Church of St. Mary, 1300 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Manhasset Women's Coalition Against Breast Cancer.

WERTHEIM--Gunther Klaus, 87, died unexpectedly on July 14 at his home in Morristown, NJ. Born in Berlin, Germany, he lived in the United States from age 12 and enlisted in the U.S. Army during World War II. He earned a Ph.D. in physics from Harvard University (1955) after undergraduate studies at Stevens Institute of Technology (1951). He conducted research at Bell Telephone Laboratories for 40 years and continued to consult with other physicists after his retirement. His wife, Lee Hilles, died in 1995. He is survived by his brother Michael, his daughter Lisa Fraebel, sons Frederick and Charles and two grandsons. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on July 23 at the Presbyterian Church in Morristown. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Endowed Fund in Memory of Lee Hilles Wertheim '51 at Smith College.

USCHER--Ida G.,died peacefully at home on July 14th surrounded by her loving family. She was born on a farm in Monroe, CT, raised in Bridgeport, and graduated from Smith College. Ida received MSW from NYU and worked as a therapist for many years. Adored mother of Nancy (Bill) and Janet (Brett). Cherished grandmother of Alessandra, Jessica and David. Beloved sister of Rose, sister-in-law, aunt and great- aunt to many who loved and admired her. Celebration of Life service will be held on July 19th at 1pm at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to benefit children in need would be appreciated.

SILK--Caroline, 52, died on July 1. She grew up on the Upper West Side and attended PS-166 and Franklin before graduating from Columbia Grammar ('79). She earned a BA in Economics from Binghamton University and moved to Buffalo for law school, where she served on the law review. After finishing in 1986, Caroline moved back to New York and took a job as an associate at Dewey Ballantine. In 1991, now living in Brooklyn, she gave birth to her first son, Jeremy, and five years later, her second, Jake. In 1993, Caroline began work at the NYC Law Department first in Real Estate Litigation, then Commercial Litigation, and finally as a contract lawyer in the Contracts & Real Estate Division. She loved working in the latter and did so for 14 years, making many of her best friends, before being diagnosed with leukemia in January. Caroline's loved ones remember her sense of humor; her smile; her love of her dog, Molly, and cats, Toby and Oliver; her gift for putting people at ease; and her care for friends in need. Her devotion to her two boys, Jeremy and Jake, was matched by their constancy, attentiveness and good humor in the final months of her life. Caroline is survived by her sons; her parents, Robert and Susan Silk; her half-sister, Nina Silk; and many close friends and relatives. Memorial service at Riverside Memorial Chapel Sunday, July 20 at 3pm.

Betty shared her beautiful voice in operatic productions, recitals, and as the soloist at many churches including Riverside, in New York City. At 55, she attained a Bachelor's Degree in Psychology, and worked at the Department of Social Services for ten years. Visitation will be on Sunday, July 20 at Dwyer Funeral Home, 90 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, to please make contributions to the Lustgarten Foundation.

HANNA--Alistair. The partners of McKinsey & Co. deeply mourn the passing of our cherished colleague and friend, Ali Hanna, who was an esteemed and valued member of our Firm for 23 years. Ali joined McKinsey in 1974 from Harvard Business School, having already earned a Ph.D. in nuclear physics from Queens University in Belfast. He was elected a Principal in 1979 and a Director in 1986, retiring from McKinsey in 1997. Following his productive tenure at McKinsey, Ali devoted much of his time to serving Alpha North America, a non profit that provides training programs to improve the health of churches. Ali was a brilliant and inspiring counselor to a wide array of client leaders. He provided insightful and seminal thinking in our microeconomic practice, leading our Firm's Microeconomic Center from 1984 to 1990, and our Stamford Office from 1993 to 1996. As an innovative and prescient leader, Ali had a profound impact on our Firm and the professional development of its partners and associates. He was a beloved mentor and loyal friend to a generation of McKinsey colleagues. Ali's countless contributions to our Firm, his entrepreneurship and contagious energy, his warm and humorous collegiality, and his caring friendship created an enduring legacy that will always be appreciated. We offer our deepest condolences to Ali's wife Nancy, his daughter Anne, and to his entire family, and we join them in mourning the loss of a truly remarkable man.

HANNA--Alistair Matthew. Alistair Matthew Hanna, 69, of Manhattan and Lawrence, NY, died on July 12, 2014, of cancer. Born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, in 1945, Ali earned a B.Sc in Physics in 1968 and a Ph.D in Nuclear Physics in 1972, both from Queen's University, Belfast. In 1974, he received an MBA from Harvard Business School and joined McKinsey & Company where he became a Director and served as Managing Partner of the Stamford Office. Ali led the Firm's microelectronics and software practices and was a leader in the telecommunications and aerospace groups. Since retiring from McKinsey in 1997, Ali founded the non-profit organization, Alpha North America which offers the Alpha Course to churches in the U.S. to help them bring people to faith in Christ. In 2004, he brought Alpha to Latin America. With his wife, Nancy, he owned and operated Ardtara Country House Hotel in Upperlands, Northern Ireland. With partners, he was developing Bushmills Dunes Golf Resort outside Bushmills, Northern Ireland. Bushmill Dunes was the culmination of a life dream, combining Ali's passions for golf and for the people of Northern Ireland. Ali also served on the Boards of Fountain House, New York City; Trinity Church Wall Street; and Queen's University Foundation. He was president of U.S. Friends of Queen's. Beyond Ali's many professional contributions, Ali inspired and warmed almost every one he met. His kindness and love of life, his Irish way and humor, his respect for people and his deep faith and humility -- these characteristics, coupled with Ali's brilliance and perseverance, made him one of a kind. Ali was for so many a dear and loyal friend and to his family, a beloved and devoted husband, father, brother and uncle. Ali is survived by his wife, the Reverend Nancy W. Hanna, and her daughter, Anne Warner Lee (Hocheong Lee); his brother, David Hanna (Linda), and their children, Paul (Whitney) and Patricia (Neil). The funeral will be on Tuesday, July 22, 2014, at 1pm at St. Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Avenue (51st Street). In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Alistair Matthew Hanna can be made online to Alpha Latin America at www.alphausa.org/alihanna or to the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation (Meso Foundation) at www.curemeso.org/ donations (select Tribute Wall option).

GITLOW--Abraham Leo, 95, of Miami Beach, FL, passed away at New York University Hospital on July 15, 2014. Born in the Bronx, NY to Samuel and Esther Gitlow, he lived in New York City and Spring Valley, NY until moving to Miami Beach in 1982. Dr. Gitlow served in the Air Force during WWII from 1943-1945. He received a Ph.D. from Columbia University in Economics and Anthropology. He was a Dean at New York University Stern School of Business from 1965 until his retirement in 1985. He had a chair established in his honor at the NYU Stern School of Business, and recently completed his 15th book, which is scheduled to be published in October. His passions were research and writing and was known for his excellence as a teacher and dean. Dr. Gitlow was the beloved husband for 59 years to the late Beatrice May Alpert Gitlow; loving father of Allan Gitlow (Deanna) of Woodland Park, NJ and Howard Gitlow (Shelly) of Miami, FL; cherished grandfather of Jessica Jacobs (Steven), Elissa Gitlow (Jason Hecker) and Ali Gitlow (Nick Shea); devoted great-grandfather of Maren and Nathan Jacobs and Ian Gitlow-Hecker. A funeral service will take place at 11:00am on Friday at Gutterman-Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ 07601. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus. Memorial donations may be made in Abraham Gitlow's name to the NYU Stern School of Business.

Acrostic answer for October 6, 2013
GLICKSMAN--Albert, Aly - dearest husband, missing you every moment since July 18th, 2005, but still sharing my life with you. Love, Fran
CITRANO--Rose. In honor of the 50th anniversary of her death. Her loveliness is still remembered.

ZWEIG--Miriam, 96, born in Brooklyn, NY; died peacefully on July 15, 2014. Devoted wife of Irving. Dear sister of Murray and Julian Laub. Beloved mother of Stephen, Michael, Sherrie, and Richard and grandmother of Ami, Julia, Jonathan, Alexandra, Zachary, Hannah, and Ilana. Funeral services on July 18 at 10am, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains NY.

YOUNG--Ilene. Dr. Ilene Young was an esteemed member of the Contemporary Freudian Society, where she served as a past member of the Board of Directors, and was a Training and Supervising Analyst as well as a member of the Faculty. She was an Adult, Adolescent and Child Psychoanalyst, and intimately involved with the Child Psychoanalytic Training Program. She was a longstanding member of the Curriculum and Admissions Committees and was deeply devoted to excellence in education and learning. Ilene was respected and cherished by her colleagues, students and friends for her wisdom, kindness and strength. Her capacity to be a calm and thoughtful presence in the midst of conflict was unique and irreplaceable. She will be deeply missed. A private memorial service is being planned for the fall. Contemporary Freudian Society

STRITCH--Elaine. The Town Hall mourns the passing of one of the unique artists of our time, who we so honored in 2010 with our Friend of the Arts Award. Our deepest sympathy goes out to her family, friends and all who loved this great lady of our town and of every town. The Trustees and Staff of the Town Hall Foundation.
STRITCH--Elaine. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and friend, Elaine Stritch and send condolences to her family.

STEIN--Bob. March 4, 1924 - July 9, 2014. Beloved husband, loving stepfather to Stephanie Weiss. He loved: writing, politics, old movies, picking strawberries, his 285-year-old house, simple pleasures, taking care of the people he loved. He was caring, generous, my best friend, the love of my life. I was privileged to be his wife for 25 years. He was the best of everything. Lois Brenner

SCHWEITZER--Jacqueline, age 85, died peacefully at home in Riverdale after a long illness, July 15; survived by loving husband Frederick, daughter Elyse Jenkins, and stepson Manfred. Funeral 1:00pm, Monday, July 21, Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Ave.

SCHICK--Ron. Mitchell and Amy Kaneff mourn the loss of their dear friend, Ron Schick. Only 47 years old when he passed away on July 3rd, he left this world too soon. Ron's larger than life personality, his kindness and generosity, his devotion to his friends, his unbounded passion for music, and his intense love for his children all contributed to his uniqueness and made him who he was: an authentic, special, and good man. A memorial service celebrating Ron in stories and music will be held in the Kaneff household on July 29th from 6pm to 8pm. For additional information, please email info@arkay.com. R.I.P., Ron. We miss you more than words can say.

POTTS--Martin Sydney, 61, died July 12th after a brief illness and in the loving care of his family in Munster, Germany. Martin was born in Yorkshire, England and became an accomplished artist, a contractor, a creative designer and a dedicated cook. He studied at the Bath Academy of Art in Corsham, Wiltshire, the Slade School of Art in London, and was a Rome Scholar. He came to New York in 1978 to continue painting and to assist English artist Richard Smith. He also designed and built many memorable living and working spaces for his fellow artists, designers and friends. He is survived by his parents, Sydney and Eileen Potts of Leeds, two brothers, his son Oscar and daughter Mathilde Bauermeister-Potts in Munster. Martin was loved and respected by everyone who had the pleasure of knowing him, and he will be greatly missed.

O'BRIEN--Patrick. The Juilliard School mourns the loss of Patrick O'Brien, lute and theorbo professor in the Historical Performance Program since 2012. Pat was one of the most important and influential teachers of historical plucked instruments in America, and was revered as a generous and thoughtful mentor to an entire generation of performers working today. He will be sorely missed. Our condolences go out to his wife, Mary Lou, and his daughter, Elanor. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Robert Mealy, Director, Juilliard Historical Performance Benjamin Sosland, Administrative Director, Juilliard Historical Performance

O'BRIEN--Pat, beloved Papa of the Lute World, has died. He leaves his loving wife, Mary Lou, cherished daughter, Elanor, beloved son-in-law, Jeff Falen, and acres of grandbroccoli. A Memorial Service will be planned.

METTER--Harold, 99, of Pompano Beach, FL, formerly of New Hyde Park, NY. Devoted husband and father, he was preceded in death by his wife, Ronnie, and is survived by his children, Joel (Barbara) and Andrew (Wendy), and grandchildren, Rachel, Daniel and Jordan. Graduate of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute (now NYU). Vice President Executone, Inc. Avid sailor (member KYC), adventurer, skier and amateur radio operator since the 1930s (W2DHH). Services at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY, Sunday noon.

MARTIN--Harriett, of WPB FL, formerly of NYC, on July 15. Wife of the late Harvey E. Martin, mother of Tami S. Martin (Roger Day), grandmother of Avery and Hallie Martin-Chadwick. Service July 18, 12pm, Beth Israel Cem., Woodbridge, NJ.

LANGER--Morton, on July 17, 2014 at 73 years of age. Loving husband of Renee. Devoted father of Dana Langer and Rachel Herman (Neal). Cherished grandfather of Mia. Dear brother-in-law of Norman and Ellen Oksman. He managed his own hedge fund, Langer Capital Management, and was the former Director of Research at Bear Sterns. Services private.

KHAZANEH--Fatemeh "Rafat," The family of Fatemeh "Rafat" Khazaneh announces with great sadness the death of their beloved mother and grandmother, who passed away peacefully on July 16, 2014, at the age of 90. Mrs. Khazaneh was known for her personal elegance, her many acts of kindness, and her devotion to her family who was the light of her life. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Abbas Khazaneh, with whom she was married for 50 years. She is survived by her four children Amir, Manda, Ali, and Mamad; her son-in-law Mehrdad; daughter-in-law Heather; and her grandchildren Fatima, Alexander, and Christopher.

HASHIM--Kathleen C.,83 of Dobbs Ferry passed away on July 16, 2014, Born in Brooklyn to Frank and Helen Conaty. Kathleen graduated from St. Elizabeth's College in New Jersey where she majored in English Literature. She was an avid Reader, Ice Skater and creator of Poetry. Kathleen is survived by her husband Sami Hashim M.D., Son Paul (Mary Lynn) Hashim, daughter Susan (Steven) Ringler and grandchildren Nicholas, Olivia and Anthony Hashim and Lilah and Noah Ringler. Mass of the Resurrection Saturday 10:00am Church of St. Matthew's, Hastings-on-Hudson. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, New York. Memorial Contributions in Kathleen's name may be made to St. Jude Children's Hospital.

HAIR--Robert A.,on July 16. Retired Deputy Inspector of the New York Police Department; Professor at John Jay College. GITLOW--Abraham L. The Board of Directors and management and staff of Bank Leumi USA mourn the loss of its esteemed former director and loyal friend, Abraham L. Gitlow. GARRIGLE--William Aloysius, of Moorestown and Strathmere, New Jersey passed away on July 15, 2014 after a long battle with illness. He was with his wife, Rosalind Chadwick Garrigle and his bulldog, Sir Winston Churchill. He will be missed greatly by all those who loved and knew him. Born in Camden, New Jersey on August 6, 1941, Mr. Garrigle is predeceased by his parents John Michael and Catherine Ebeling Garrigle. Mr. Garrigle has three daughters, Maeve Garrigle Ciccotosto Vogan (Frank) and Emily Garrigle Leonard (Richard) from his marriage to Jeannette R. Regan (div.), and Susan Chadwick Garrigle Mallaney (Hugh) with Mrs. Chadwick Garrigle. He has one granddaughter, Emma Ciccotosto. His kindness and love of life, his Irish way and humor, his respect for people and humility -- these characteristics, coupled with Bill's brilliance and perseverance, made him one of a kind. Mr. Garrigle graduated as part of the second graduating class from Bishop Eustace Preparatory School in 1959. He graduated from LaSalle University Summa Cum Laude in 1963. He was President of Student Government and President of his fraternity, Delta Sigma Pi, Epsilon Sigma Chapter. He was elected to the Alpha Epsilon Honor Society and was elected to Who's Who in American Colleges and Universities. He attended Boston College Law School on a Presidential Scholarship. He graduated in the top quarter of his class in 1966 with an LL.B. Mr. Garrigle was a prefect in the undergraduate dorms and won the Insurance Law Award from Am Jur as a 3L. Mr. Garrigle led an illustrious 48 year law career in the Philadelphia area as a Certified Trial Attorney. He frequently appeared before the Appellate Division and argued before the New Jersey Supreme Court on several cases. He was a member of numerous law organizations including, International Association of Defense Council (Membership Chair), American Board of Trial Advocates (Diplomat, President Southern New Jersey Chapter) and Camden Inns of Court. He received the Special Continuing Legal Education Award from the Camden County Bar Association in 1993, honored by the American Inns of Court Foundation and Camden Inns of Court for his years of service as President in 1996. Mr. Garrigle served in the United States Army Reserves from 1960 to 1968 and completed the New York City Marathon in 1978. He was an avid gardener, golfer and reader - reading the New York Times daily until the week before he passed. He was also an active member of Tavistock and Atlantic City Country Clubs. In lieu of flowers, donations in the memory of Bill can be made to the Bishop Eustace Preparatory School Brick Fundraising Campaign, 5552 Route 70, Pennsauken, NJ 08109-4798. Relatives and friends are invited to attend his Funeral Mass on Saturday at 11:00am from The Catholic Community of Christ our Light Church 402 Kings Highway North, Cherry Hill, NJ. Burial will be private.

BYRNE--The Hon. John Noel, on July 17, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Ann. Devoted father of Tara and Linda. Cherished grandfather of Jack and Delia. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, July 21, 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 404 E. 87th St., NYC.

BAKALAR--Ruth Beck, 98, of Riverdale, NY, died at home on July 11, 2014. A former Executive Editor of Gourmet Magazine and food writer, she was the editor of the first edition of The Gourmet Cookbook, published in 1950, and the author of The Complete Potato Cookbook. Loving wife of the late Alan Bakalar, loving mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, she leaves three sons, James and his wife Susan Milmoe of Cambridge, MA, Nicholas and his wife Francine Cournos of Riverdale, and Kenneth and his wife Lee Bakalar of Gaithersburg, MD; three grandchildren, Elizabeth Bakalar and her husband Geoffrey Kirsch of Juneau, AK, Dana Bakalar and her fiance David Roberts of Brooklyn, and Matthew Bakalar of San Francisco; and two great-grandchildren, Paige and Isaac Kirsch. A dear friend to many all her life, she also leaves her beloved recent companions Palma Moore and Carleen Russell.

SOLLANO--Rosemarie, 52, passed away peacefully on July 17th. She was surrounded by family, friends, and love during her battle with cancer. A devoted Herricks middle school language teacher, she shared her love for Spanish and Italian languages with her students. In life, she taught us how to laugh. In illness, she taught us to be brave. And in death, she taught us how it is never too late to be a better person. She taught us all. Survived by Richard and Josephine, her loving brother and sister and her many friends and family. For service information visit www.boyd-spencer.com. In lieu of flowers, donations to Melanoma Research Foundation, 1411 K St., NW Suite.

SMITHDAS--Dr. Robert J.,author, lecturer and poet, passed away today at the age of 89. Dr. Smithdas was the former Director of Community Education for Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths & Adults (HKNC). (A full bio including his list of honorary degrees and achievements can be found at www.helenkeller. org). A resident of Port Washington, NY, Dr. Smithdas is survived by his wife Michelle. The Board of Trustees and staff of Helen Keller Services for the Blind and HKNC are deeply saddened by the passing of this remarkable human being. A memorial scholarship fund for HKNC students has been created in Dr. Smithdas' memory. In lieu of flowers, please send any donations to: Marina Carroll, Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths & Adults, 141 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point, NY 11050 or via email, marina.carroll@hknc.org.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC. Interment private.

BAKALAR--Ruth Beck, 98, of Riverdale, NY, died at home on July 11, 2014. A former Executive Editor of Gourmet Magazine and food writer, she was the editor of the first edition of The Gourmet Cookbook, published in 1950, and the author of The Complete Potato Cookbook. Loving wife of the late Alan Bakalar, loving mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, she leaves three sons, James and his wife Susan Milmoe of Cambridge, MA, Nicholas and his wife Francine Cournos of Riverdale, and Kenneth and his wife Lee Bakalar of Gaithersburg, MD; three grandchildren, Elizabeth Bakalar and her husband Geoffrey Kirsch of Juneau, AK, Dana Bakalar and her fiance David Roberts of Brooklyn, and Matthew Bakalar of San Francisco; and two great-grandchildren, Paige and Isaac Kirsch. A dear friend to many all her life, she also leaves her beloved recent companions Palma Moore and Carleen Russell.

WERTHEIM--Gunther Klaus, 87, died unexpectedly on July 14 at his home in Morristown, NJ. Born in Berlin, Germany, he lived in the United States from age 12 and enlisted in the U.S. Army during World War II. He earned a Ph.D. in physics from Harvard University (1955) after undergraduate studies at Stevens Institute of Technology (1951). He conducted research at Bell Telephone Laboratories for 40 years and continued to consult with other physicists after his retirement. His wife, Lee Hilles, died in 1995. He is survived by his brother Michael, his daughter Lisa Fraebel, sons Frederick and Charles and two grandsons. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on July 23 at the Presbyterian Church in Morristown. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Endowed Fund in Memory of Lee Hilles Wertheim '51 at Smith College.

WEINTHAL--Silvia, (Greenberg) of Brighton, NY on July 17, 2014 at the age of 85. Predeceased by her husband, Henry. BrightonMemorialChapel.com

WALKER--Edward J.,died suddenly on July 12, 2014 at home in Ossining, New York at age 87. Alumnus of Cooley High School, Detroit; University of Michigan (MA); United States Army; Yale (PhD); IBM Research Center (1960-87). Westinghouse Science Scholar, songster, sailor, skin-diver, machinist, cyclist, Homebrew member, anti-war activist, Pepysian, SIA enthusiast, storehouse of poems. Survived by wife Barbara; brother George and his wife Edith; daughter Anna and husband Geoff Reiss; grandsons Walker and Jack Reiss. Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas.
