STRAUSS--Nancy Bloch, 86, of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of New York City, died unexpectedly on July 16. Predeceased by her loving husband, William L. Strauss II. Survived by her children: Bob (Laurie), Judy (Edward) and Barbara (Peter). Grandmother of Jarrett (Jason), Jessica, Lauren (Ryan), Christine, and Lisa. Sister of Alan (Suzanne). Avid reader and stamp collector. A memorial service to be held at a future date.

STEIN--Bob. March 4, 1924 - July 9, 2014. Beloved husband, loving stepfather to Stephanie Weiss. He loved: writing, politics, old movies, picking strawberries, his 285-year-old house, simple pleasures, taking care of the people he loved. He was caring, generous, my best friend, the love of my life. I was privileged to be his wife for 25 years. He was the best of everything. Lois Brenner

SMITHDAS--Dr. Robert J.,author, lecturer and poet, passed away today at the age of 89. Dr. Smithdas was the former Director of Community Education for Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths & Adults (HKNC). (A full bio including his list of honorary degrees and achievements can be found at www.helenkeller. org). A resident of Port Washington, NY, Dr. Smithdas is survived by his wife Michelle. The Board of Trustees and staff of Helen Keller Services for the Blind and HKNC are deeply saddened by the passing of this remarkable human being. A memorial scholarship fund for HKNC students has been created in Dr. Smithdas' memory. In lieu of flowers, please send any donations to: Marina Carroll, Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths & Adults, 141 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point, NY 11050 or via email, marina.carroll@hknc.org.

SCOTT--Virginia, 76, of Bronx, NY passed away on June 30, 2014. She taught literature and creative writing at Lehman College, CUNY (1965-2001). Virginia was an award-winning poet and she authored several books. She created Sunbury Poetry Magazine and established Sunbury Press (19731986).

SCHWARTZ--Herbert F.,78. The lawyers and staff of the law firm of Ropes & Gray (successor by merger in 2005 to the firm of Fish & Neave) mourn the passing of Herbert F. Schwartz. Herb was one of the leading intellectual property trial lawyers of his generation, a trailblazer in the development of intellectual property law, and a mentor and colleague to hundreds of lawyers and law students who learned from him. After receiving his degree in electrical engineering from MIT in 1957, he received an M.A. in business and an L.L.B. from the University of Pennsylvania in 1964, where he was an editor of the Law Review. He was a partner from 1971 until his retirement in 2007, and served as managing partner of Fish & Neave from 1985 until 1991. Herb served as lead trial counsel in many cases for such prominent companies as Polaroid, Purdue Pharma, AstraZeneca, Digital Equipment and Motorola, among many others. His landmark victory for Polaroid against Eastman Kodak preserved Polaroid's exclusive position in instant photography. He was recognized for his courtroom excellence by being elected a fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. In addition to his litigation accomplishments, Herb worked outside the courtroom to advance the law, having served as a professor at both Penn and NYU law schools and as a 25-year member of the American Law Institute. He was the principal author of Patent Law and Practice, an oft-cited treatise originally prepared for use by federal judges. Herb also was a renowned sailor, having won many major regattas, such as the Swan American trophy, the New York Yacht Club Sesquicentennial and the Marblehead to Halifax race, and having won his class in the 2000 Newport to Bermuda race. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club, Riverside Yacht Club, the Cruising Club of America, the Greenwich Cove Racing Association, and was a trustee at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute. Herb is survived by his wife Nan Chequer, his children Wendy, Karen, and Peter, his stepchildren Elizabeth, Anne and Laura, and eight grandchildren. The family will host a celebration of Herb's life at noon on August 24 at Riverside Yacht Club and welcomes gifts in Herb's honor to support a crew shell for the MIT men's heavyweight crew program (donations payable to MIT, mailed to Bonny Kellerman, Director of Memorial Gifts, 600 Memorial Drive, W98-500, Cambridge, MA 02139).

SCHICK--Ron. Mitchell and Amy Kaneff mourn the loss of their dear friend, Ron Schick. Only 47 years old when he passed away on July 3rd, he left this world too soon. Ron's larger than life personality, his kindness and generosity, his devotion to his friends, his unbounded passion for music, and his intense love for his children all contributed to his uniqueness and made him who he was: an authentic, special, and good man. A memorial service celebrating Ron in stories and music will be held in the Kaneff household on July 29th from 6pm to 8pm. For additional information, please email info@arkay.com. R.I.P., Ron. We miss you more than words can say.

SANDEN--Kenneth, 65, of New York, passed away July 14. Son of the late Kenneth Sanden and Norma Sanden of Birmingham, MI, and Boynton Beach, FL. Brother of the late Judith Sanden Rogers of Boynton Beach, FL. Uncle of Jennifer Rogers of New York. Project Manager, CUNY Department of Design and Construction. Harvard, Master of Architecture, 1975. Yale, Class of 1971. Donations in his name may be made to JDRF and the NYC LGBT Center.

ROTH--Stanley, Jr. "Jim" We note with sorrow the passing of a great friend, a man of gentle style and quick wit. Our condolences to our dear Aunt Patsy Erpf and to Steven Roth and family. We will miss Jim always. Ward Blum and Family

ROTH--Stanley Jr.,on July 14, 2014. Devoted father of Steven and his wife, Ellen Freeman Roth. Cherished grandfather of Joshua and Madeline. Companion of Patricia Erpf. A proud veteran of WWII. After graduating from Yale University he became a retail executive. A lifetime lover of jazz, art and the New York Giants. Service private.

RICHTER--Marcel Kessel (Ket), University of Minnesota professor of economics, died July 11, 2014. Born in New York, NY in 1932; raised in Leonia, NJ; and graduated from Birch Wathen School, Swarthmore College, and MIT. Marcel used mathematical logic and set theory to develop methods for understanding fundamental questions of consumer preference, rationality, choice, coalition formation, competition, and equilibrium. His seminal work on revealed preference is widely used to analyze and predict behavior by rational agents. Preceded in death by his wife, Sheila Mills Richter, and parents, Maurice N. Richter and Brina H. Kessel Richter. Survived by daughters Cynthia Reis-Richter (Martha) and Leila Fiester (Reid); grandchildren Solea Fiester and Carlos Reis-Richter; and brothers Maurice N. Richter, Jr. and Wayne Richter (Anne White).

RETTER--Dorothea Bracht. 76, died peacefully in her Florida home on July 2 in the embrace of her children, Claudia and Edwin, after a short battle with cancer. Born in Brooklyn, she traveled the world with her husband, architect Henry H. Retter, whom she met while working at the Austin Company in Manhattan. Their love story lasted over 50 years and continues in his heart. She enjoyed a fulfilling career as an executive secretary while raising a family. Her joys were simple and beautiful: cooking, gardening, reading and spending time with family, including Molly, her beloved yellow Lab. She will be remembered for her kindness, grace, elegance, and vibrant view of life. She is greatly missed.

RAMPANELLI--Mario, of Middle Village, Queens. Employed at The New York Times for 43 years and retired for 23 years. Passed away in his 84th year with us on July 12, 2014. He was a proud Veteran of the Korean War and a loving husband to Rose who predeceased him. Survived by step-son Joseph Messina, his brothers Charles and his wife Rose, Michael and his wife Bette. Dear Uncle to his nieces and nephews, Mark and Samantha Rampanelli and Steven and Kim Rampanelli. Great-uncle to Theresa, Nicole and Michael Rampanelli and Arianna Rodas. Mario was a man who said what he meant and did what he said in kind. Interment was at St. Charles Cemetery, Babylon, NY. He will be deeply missed by everyone who knew and loved him.

PARKIN--Michael, 81, died peacefully on July 14th at the summer home in Hampton Bays, NY, that he shared with his husband, Frederick Rappaport. A celebration of Michael's life will be held this fall in New York City.

OLIVIERI--Betty. Beloved Mother, Grandmother and Great-Grandmother, passed away at the age of 84 on July 14, 2014, at her home in Tarrytown, NY. She was predeceased by her Husband, Silven Olivieri, in 2005. Betty is survived by her children, Lori Hagen Ennis, David Hagen, George Hagen, Judy Hagen, Susan Olivieri, Steven Olivieri and Stevie Holland, son-in-law Gary William Friedman, grandson Douglas O'Rourke, granddaughter-in-law Catherine O'Rourke, and three great-grandchildren, Jacob, Sara and Cate. Betty shared her beautiful voice in operatic productions, recitals, and as the soloist at many churches including Riverside, in New York City. At 55, she attained a Bachelor's Degree in Psychology, and worked at the Department of Social Services for ten years. Visitation will be on Sunday, July 20 at Dwyer Funeral Home, 90 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, to please make contributions to the Lustgarten Foundation.

O'BRIEN--Pat. The New York Continuo Collective is bereft at the death of Pat O'Brien, the most remarkable musician, teacher, mentor, and friend. Pat was world renowned for his understanding and practical application of performance practice, from early instruments to modern guitar. He was a compendium of musical knowledge; an impeccable scholar. Pat's performances were exquisitely elegant, be it on lute or blues guitar. There was hardly a subject of any kind in which Pat was not conversant. He cared deeply about people and the fate of the world. We share the sorrow of his loss with his beloved wife, Mary Lou, cherished daughter, Elanor, as well as the entire Early Music community.

NORD--Jill Ann, doctor of Infectious Diseases, dedicated environmentalist, and loyal friend, passed away on July 15, 2014. She was 67. Jill was more than the first female chief of Saint Vincent Hospital's inpatient AIDS unit; she was a mentor to dozens of young physicians, a fierce advocate for her patients, and a source of advice and support to her colleagues. She had an encyclopedic memory for medicine and a calm, reassuring bedside manner. She worked tirelessly and with love. Her passion continues to inspire. To her friends and family, Jill was a reminder that kindness, laughter, friendship, and love are what matter. She led by example, as she volunteered at local park clean ups, donated her time to social movements, and was always there for those in need. She lived a joyous, intense, uncompromising, and remarkable life. She was beautiful. There will never be another Jill. She is survived by her life partner, Gary Comorau, three children, a loving extended family, and many caring friends. They smile when they think of her. They have never known a better person. Perhaps somewhere, she smiles back.

MILLER--Richard, 83, of Weston, CT and Palm Beach, FL, died on July 18 surrounded by his loving family. Born in Brooklyn, he graduated from Erasmus Hall High School, New York University, and the New York University School of Business. He attended Officer's Candidate School in Newport, RI, was commissioned as an Ensign, and served in the United States Navy from 1953-1956. He was discharged as a Lieutenant JG, and began a career in real estate. In 1984, he moved to Weston, CT and became active in civic affairs, serving three terms on the Weston Board of Selectmen. Well-loved by friends and family, and respected by his peers, Richard Miller is survived by his wife of 59 years, Lois nee Hirsch; his son Evan Miller; daughter Jill Miller Goldberg; grandchildren Leif Miller, Hayley Miller, Brett Goldberg, and Nikki Goldberg; daughter-in-law Nancy Hedin; and son-in-law Richard Goldberg. Donations in his memory may be made to the Zena & Michael A. Weiner Cardiovascular Institute, or the Robert & John Bendheim Parkinson's and Movement Disorder Center, both at Mt. Sinai Medical Center.
MIESEL--Victor H.,Sr., age 85. Born October 12, 1928 in Detroit, died July 13, 2014 in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Professor Emeritus, History of Art University of Michigan.

MARKS--Lois B.,on July 14, 2014. Beloved wife of Seymour (Sy), devoted mother of Roger (Andrea), cherished grandmother of Sophia. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral services were private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Leukemia Fighters at New York Hospital.

MacDONALD--David K. died June 11, age 79. He graduated from Boston University and Sloan School of Management. He retired as president of NYT Cable TV. Intellectualism, altruism and love for family defined him. He was born with few of the advantages he gave his sons. He found these values for himself. They were simply a part of him. Dave enjoyed playing golf and always liked a good debate. Rest in Peace Dear Dave. In addition to a loving extended family, he is survived by wife Patricia Harrington of 52 years and four devoted sons and families. David (Brandi Kenney), Douglas (Julie Dube), Scott and Ross (Jennifer Greenman) and six grandchildren who brought him such joy: Hannah, Margaret, Benjamin, Skylar, Patrick and Ian born June 6, 2014.

LUNNING--Elizabeth, 66, a beloved member of Houston's arts community, died Tuesday, the 1st of July 2014, after a brief illness. Liz grew up in Manhattan, surrounded by artists and craftspeople that were friends of her family, who owned the Georg Jensen shop in New York for many years an experience that helped shape her well-known extraordinary visual sense. The family's creation of the Lunning Prize (1951-1970) greatly increased awareness of Scandinavian design in the United States and abroad. Liz received her conservation training at the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University. She began her paper conservation career at the Oberlin Intermuseum Laboratory before working at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston for many years. During this period until the 1990s, she also served as a consultant paper conservator at the Toledo Museum of Art. In 1990, she was appointed paper conservator at the Menil Collection in Houston and, in time, became Chief Conservator heading the museum's conservation laboratory, from which she retired in 2006. Liz was preceded in death by her parents, Just and Winifred Wittmann Lunning, and is survived by her brother and nephew, Frederick and Just Lunning, both of New York. Her circle of friends around the world will miss her great gifts as a conversationalist, her inquisitive mind in both the sciences and the arts, and the generosity with which she shared the wide range of people whom she had befriended. A memorial service in Houston is being planned for this Fall; details will be made available at a later date. Contributions may be made to the animal rights or animal rescue charity of your choice.
LEHMAN--Ruby, Fashion Merchandiser 1946-1996, passed July 10, 2014 of natural causes. Born November 5, 1921.

LEE--Knute Diedrich, 85, of Fair Hill, MD, died peacefully at day's end in Colora, MD, on July 13, 2014. Son of the late Arthur and Frederika Lee, he is survived by his dear companion Ellen Torrey, his children Arthur Jeduthan Lee, Lucile Adele Lee, Julia Lee Carlson, Robin Andrew Lee, and five grandchildren. Knute is preceded in death by his wife, Nancy Wellington Lee, and sister, Ingeborg Lee Muller. A veteran, Knute served as a lieutenant in the United States Army during the Korean War. Passionate about art, life, and especially sailing, Knute was a past US Sailing Judge and Umpire. A life member of the New York Yacht Club and the International Star Class YRA, Knute was a member of The Catboat Association, past member of North East River YC, Bellport Bay YC, and The Corinthians. Possessed of a joyful zest for living, Knute brought vibrancy to everything he did: he is deeply missed. A memorial service will be held in Bellport, NY, August 9, 2014, at 1:00pm. Donations in his memory may be made to US Sailing Youth Programs, at www.ussailing.org, or PO Box 1260, Portsmouth, RI, 02871. R. T. Foard Funeral Home, 410-658-6030.

KRUEGER--Dana. April 6, 1940-July 12, 2014. With sadness and much love we mark the death of Dana Krueger Grossman. A lifelong resident of Washington, DC, her career in opera and theater was fostered by the great Todd Duncan. She performed many comic and dramatic roles with the Houston Grand Opera, Washington National Opera, New York City Opera, and Central City Opera. She debuted roles in world premiere productions of operas by Leonard Bernstein, Gian-Carlo Menotti, and Peter Schickele, with whom she toured in The Intimate PDQ Bach and made two Grammy-winning recordings. Her Augusta Tabor in The Ballad of Baby Doe was a favorite role. Her DC-area work at Signature Theatre and Arena Stage included roles in Candide, The Women, Sweeney Todd, Sunday in the Park With George, and Follies. Her portrayal of stroke victim Emily Stilson in Wings at Signature won her a Helen Hayes Award in 1995. Dana's kindness, generosity, wit and humor were boundless. She was a great cook, crossword puzzler, and a seriously funny person who appreciated the spark in others. We laughed long and hard together. Her friends and family will miss her terribly. Husband Milton Grossman, daughter Abigail/Eric Wallgren, sister Ellen Siesel/Fred, Hanna.

KHAZANEH--Fatemeh "Rafat," The family of Fatemeh "Rafat" Khazaneh announces with great sadness the death of their beloved mother and grandmother, who passed away peacefully on July 16, 2014, at the age of 90. Mrs. Khazaneh was known for her personal elegance, her many acts of kindness, and her devotion to her family who was the light of her life. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Abbas Khazaneh, with whom she was married for 50 years. She is survived by her four children Amir, Manda, Ali, and Mamad; her son-in-law Mehrdad; daughter-in-law Heather; and her grandchildren Fatima, Alexander, and Christopher.

JARCHO--Irma S.,on July 17, 2014. Beloved wife of the lateDr. Saul Jarcho. Loving mother of Andrew and his wife Cathy and the late Thomas, survived by his wife Fredrica. Cherished grandmother of Jesse, Laurie, Julia, and Nicholas, great-grandmother of Christopher and great-great-grandmother of Lila Jane. She is also survived by numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. She was a well respected teacher in the metropolitan area for 40 years and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call on Sunday, July 20, 2-5pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC. Interment private.

HURLEY--Barbara. The family and friends of Barbara Hurley Melville sadly announce her passing on July 15 at the age of 79. She was predeceased by her mother Jeanne Piccirilli Hurley, her father Edward J. Hurley and her brother Edward H. Hurley. Barbara was the granddaughter of Horatio Piccirilli, one of the acclaimed Piccirilli Brothers, well known sculptors whose work is found throughout New York City, most notably the Maine Monument at Columbus Circle. They also sculpted the Lincoln Memorial in Washington D.C., Barbara was a graduate of Skidmore College and worked professionally for many years as a prominent designer in the textile industry. She enjoyed a full, interesting and accomplished life. Barbara played tennis and was at one point ranked 16th as an amateur. She rode horses, played the piano and prided herself in having a pilot's license. She traveled widely and enjoyed the friendship of many prominent figures in the arts and fashion world. She was an avid reader of the New York Times. Barbara had great affection for her pet dogs. Most recently her Shih Tzu, China, had been her dearest companion. Following a private service, interment will take place at the family plot in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx on Tuesday, July 22, 2014 at 11:30am.

HOWELL--Ralph D. Jr.,passed away June 26, 2014 in Lansdale, PA. He was 89. Mr. Howell was a principal at E.W. Howell Co., in Babylon, NY until 1984. The most notable of his construction achievements late in his career were the restoration of the US Trust Co., NY, the Shermerhorn Row Block at South Street Seaport and the Hotel Plaza Athenee, NY. He served on the boards of St. Johnsland at Kings Park, New York State Business Council in Albany, McCauley Waterstreet Mission, Stony Brook School, the Associated General Contractors of America in Washington and the Tanzanian Children's Fund. He also served as the President of the Building Contractors Association of both New York City and New York State. Sailing was his passion and he raced a Celebrity on Great South Bay. He later sailed his yawl on Long Island Sound and chartered on several oceans around the globe. He lived in Lansdale, PA, having formerly lived in Mill Neck, NY, New York City, Northport, ME and Boca Raton, FL. He was an elder of the Seacrest Presbyterian Church in Delray Beach, FL. He is survived by three of his daughters, Robin Best, Claudia Fish and India Howell. His wife Natalie Gray Howell passed away in 2005 and his daughter Candy Choate passed away in 2006. He will be interred in the family plot in Babylon Rural Cemetery following a memorial service at Chapey & Sons Funeral Home in West Islip, NY on August 4, 2014. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Tanzanian Children's Fund, 2 Atlantic Ave., 4th Floor, Boston, MA 02110.

HANNA--Alistair. The partners of McKinsey & Co. deeply mourn the passing of our cherished colleague and friend, Ali Hanna, who was an esteemed and valued member of our Firm for 23 years. Ali joined McKinsey in 1974 from Harvard Business School, having already earned a Ph.D. in nuclear physics from Queens University in Belfast. He was elected a Principal in 1979 and a Director in 1986, retiring from McKinsey in 1997. Following his productive tenure at McKinsey, Ali devoted much of his time to serving Alpha North America, a non profit that provides training programs to improve the health of churches. Ali was a brilliant and inspiring counselor to a wide array of client leaders. He provided insightful and seminal thinking in our microeconomic practice, leading our Firm's Microeconomic Center from 1984 to 1990, and our Stamford Office from 1993 to 1996. As an innovative and prescient leader, Ali had a profound impact on our Firm and the professional development of its partners and associates. He was a beloved mentor and loyal friend to a generation of McKinsey colleagues. Ali's countless contributions to our Firm, his entrepreneurship and contagious energy, his warm and humorous collegiality, and his caring friendship created an enduring legacy that will always be appreciated. We offer our deepest condolences to Ali's wife Nancy, his daughter Anne, and to his entire family, and we join them in mourning the loss of a truly remarkable man.

HANNA--Alistair Matthew. Alistair Matthew Hanna, 69, of Manhattan and Lawrence, NY, died on July 12, 2014, of cancer. Born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, in 1945, Ali earned a B.Sc in Physics in 1968 and a Ph.D in Nuclear Physics in 1972, both from Queen's University, Belfast. In 1974, he received an MBA from Harvard Business School and joined McKinsey & Company where he became a Director and served as Managing Partner of the Stamford Office. Ali led the Firm's microelectronics and software practices and was a leader in the telecommunications and aerospace groups. Since retiring from McKinsey in 1997, Ali founded the non-profit organization, Alpha North America which offers the Alpha Course to churches in the U.S. to help them bring people to faith in Christ. In 2004, he brought Alpha to Latin America. With his wife, Nancy, he owned and operated Ardtara Country House Hotel in Upperlands, Northern Ireland. With partners, he was developing Bushmills Dunes Golf Resort outside Bushmills, Northern Ireland. Bushmill Dunes was the culmination of a life dream, combining Ali's passions for golf and for the people of Northern Ireland. Ali also served on the Boards of Fountain House, New York City; Trinity Church Wall Street; and Queen's University Foundation. He was president of U.S. Friends of Queen's. Beyond Ali's many professional contributions, Ali inspired and warmed almost every one he met. His kindness and love of life, his Irish way and humor, his respect for people and his deep faith and humility -- these characteristics, coupled with Ali's brilliance and perseverance, made him one of a kind. Ali was for so many a dear and loyal friend and to his family, a beloved and devoted husband, father, brother and uncle. Ali is survived by his wife, the Reverend Nancy W. Hanna, and her daughter, Anne Warner Lee (Hocheong Lee); his brother, David Hanna (Linda), and their children, Paul (Whitney) and Patricia (Neil). The funeral will be on Tuesday, July 22, 2014, at 1pm at St. Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Avenue (51st Street). In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Alistair Matthew Hanna can be made online to Alpha Latin America at www.alphausa.org/alihanna or to the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation (Meso Foundation) at www.curemeso.org/ donations (select Tribute Wall option).

ELKUS--Christopher J. Ligonier, PA, died July 16, 2014. The Board of Directors of Lenox Hill Neighborhood House notes with sadness the death of Christopher J. Elkus, the devoted President of our Board of Directors from 1975 to 1979. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Gretchen and the entire family. The Board of Directors Lenox Hill Neighborhood House

ELKUS--Christopher James, passed away peacefully at his home in Ligonier, PA on Wednesday, July 16th following a long and progressive illness. He was born in New York City on February 7, 1941 and was raised in Pittsburgh, PA, the son of James H. Elkus and Lenore R. Elkus. His mother was a founder of WQED-TV in Pittsburgh and a Distinguished Daughter of Pennsylvania. His father was an industrial engineer. His paternal grandfather, the Hon. Abram I. Elkus, served as US Ambassador to Turkey under President Wilson and as a judge on the New York State Court of Appeals. His maternal grandmother, Hulda Lashanska, was a celebrated American concert soprano. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Gretchen M. Elkus of Ligonier, PA, his son James M. EIkus and grand-daughter Sonya R. Elkus of New York City and his sister Peggy H. Elkus of Pittsburgh. His brother Jonathan H. Elkus of Geneva, Switzerland died in 2003. He is also survived by his stepchildren William M. Duryea of Tampa, FL and his children William, Peter and Andrew Duryea and Melissa Duryea Lewis of San Anselmo, CA and her children Olivia and Augusta Lewis. Mr. Elkus was a graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, Yale University and New York University School of Business. He resided in New York City throughout most of his adult life where he worked as an investment manager for large corporations and organizations such as the United Nations. He was dedicated member of his community and served as President of the Lenox Hi Neighborhood House, a multi-service organization that has served people in need on the East Side of Manhattan and on Roosevelt Island for over 120 years. He later founded Waterford Capital Management upon his retirement to Ligonier, PA. He was an avid sportsman, traveler and lover of the outdoors. While at St. Paul's he excelled at football, rowing and wrestling. Following his competitive sports years he enjoyed skiing, fishing, hunting, golf, squash and tennis. He was a member of the Racquet & Tennis Club and the Brook Club in New York, the Piping Rock Club on Long Island and the Rolling Rock Club in Ligonier, Pennsylvania. His family extends their warmest thanks to his doctors and his dedicated caregivers Nan, Trudy, Tracy, Tammy M., Sue, Karen and Tammy T. A memorial service will be held at the Rolling Rock Club in Ligonier, PA on Saturday, September 6th at 11am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Paul's School with 'Elkus Family' in the memo section (Attn: Gifts Manager, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH, 03301, 603-229-4713) or to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House with 'Christopher Elkus' in the memo section (Attn: Development Department, 331 East 70th Street, New York, NY 10021). The J. Paul McCraken Funeral Chapel, Inc., Ligonier, PA is assisting the family, 144 E. Main St., Ligonier, PA 15658.

DAVIDSON--Carol Kreeger, an artist who concentrated on the abstract figure and on the introduction of large interactive sculptures, died June 16, in Bloomfield, CT. She was born in Chicago, IL, on May 17, 1929. She earned a BFA from the University of Hartford Art School and an MFA from the Rhode Island School of Design. Kreeger Davidson was particularly interested in the ancient art forms of Egypt, Greece, Cambodia, and Islam and their relationship to modern culture. In 1974, she was given a one-woman show at the New Britain Museum of American Art, and that successful exhibition was a springboard to a place in the Betty Parsons Gallery and to many other New York exhibitions. From the 1970s on, she split her working time between her studios in SoHo and West Hartford, CT. Many of her largest pieces are at museums and universities, including Designated Angels, placed at the University of Chicago, Araby at the University of Saint Joseph in West Hartford, Sacella at the New Britain Museum of American Art, and Eric the Red at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. In 2013, several of her works, including Days of Danger and Telemone, were installed on the grounds of the Connecticut Governor's Residence in Hartford. A comprehensive study of her work, The Abstract Figure: Carol Kreeger Davidson, A Retrospective, was published in 2002. She is survived by her husband of 63 years, Donald Davidson; her daughter Cynthia Davidson and son-in-law Jeff Bjork of St. Paul, Minnesota; her son Jeffrey Davidson of Cortona, Italy; her sister Margy Fridstein of Denver, Colorado; and several nieces and nephews.

CRESPI--Countess Viviana Stokes. died peacefully in her sleep in Vevey, Switzerland early on Wednesday morning, June 11, 2014. Friends of many years were with her. Countess Crespi was born in Washington, DC in 1923. Her parents were Margaret Drummond-Wolff and Sylvanus Stokes, Jr. and her grandparents were Carolyn Snowden Andrews and Gibson Fahnestock of Washington, DC and Newport, RI. Educated at Miss Hewitt's Classes in New York City and abroad, Countess Crespi lived an international life in Washington, Newport, New York, Morocco, Italy, Switzerland and Grenada. Countess Crespi's husband, Count Marco Fabio Crespi, pre-deceased her. Countess Crespi's only child, her beloved son Marcantonio Crespi, died in 2005. Countess Crespi will be remembered with great love by those who were captivated not only by her intelligence, sharp wit and humor, but also by the sentimental softness resting always within her eyes. Her legacy of grand romance and grander loyalties lives on. Contributions may be made in Countess Viviana Crespi's name to the existing "Professor Marcantonio Crespi Scholarship Fund" at Lafayette College, 307 Markle Hall, Easton, PA 18042 (attention Mrs. Susan Bradlau).

COVINGTON--Treadwell Downing, of Southampton, LI died at home on July 9, 2014 on his 88th birthday. A partner in Total Television Productions, Inc., a member of ASCAP and the University Club in New York. Survived by two daughters, Caroline Armistead Gordon Covington and Coline Elizabeth Covington; as well as grandsons Justin and Charles Kesser. Interment at Magnolia Cemetery in Charleston, SC. A Memorial Service will be held in September at the Dune Church in Southampton. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978.

COOPER--Sidney, passed away July 16, 2014, age 89 survived by a sister Vivian Hyman, Nephews Alan, Steven, Barry; sister-in-law Joan Cooper, Nieces Sherry, Iris, Nephew Billy, first cousins Barbara Steenstrup and Stuart Cooper. Sid was a combat medic in WWII he Received the Bronze Star and Purple Heart Medal. He graduated CCNY. Worked as CFO for Macy's, as well as an Executive at Bond Stores, Peerless Co. & Allied Stores corp. Sid fought a long and tedious battle to restore Due Process of Law to Veterans mistreated by the Veterans Administration. Donations may be sent to The National Veterans Legal Program in Washington DC. Graveside services are at King Solomon Cemetery, 550 Dwasline Road, Clifton, NJ at 1pm Sunday, July 20, 2014.

COHN--Marion, 90, died June 27 at home in West Hartford, CT. Beloved wife of Martin for 65 years, she was raised in Brooklyn and had lived in Rockville Centre, NY, and Sarasota, FL. A graduate of Hunter College, she was a vice president at Parker Jewish Institute in New York. She is at peace and sorely missed by loving sons Kenneth, Roger, and Lewis and three sisters, five grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. Donations to Parker Jewish Institute Foundation.

BYRNE--The Hon. John Noel, on July 17, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Ann. Devoted father of Tara and Linda. Cherished grandfather of Jack and Delia. Beloved brother of Linda, Louis and the late Kenneth. Native of Kilkelly, Co. Mayo Ireland. Supreme Court Justice of the State of New York Bronx County. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, July 21, 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 404 E. 87th St., NYC.

BLATT--Stanley David, lived most of his life in Roslyn, NY and passed away at a retirement community in Louisville, CO on July 9th. A Graveside Service was held at New York's Monte Fiore Cemetery. He is survived by his wife Myriam; sons Steven and Joel, two grandchildren and many other family and friends. He is preceded in death by his parents Irving and Jessie Blatt. Stanley was a pediatrician for 41 years in Forest Hills, NY. He had a great fondness for helping many children and families. He enjoyed his retirement years in Broomfield, CO with volunteering and spending time with his family. Stanley will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him.

BECTON--Elizabeth Hall. Betsy passed away peacefully at home in Atlantic Beach, Florida on Sunday morning, July 13 after a long and valiant struggle with lung cancer. Her husband of 53 years, Philip, was with her and her beloved Australian Cattle Dog, Roo was lying on the floor by her bed. Betsy was a gifted artist, a designer, an avid gardener, and a masterful chef. An extraordinary mother as well, she made everything she touched more beautiful and made friends of all ages and in every walk of life everywhere she went. She will be greatly missed by an eclectic community of admirers. A vivid portion of her 53 years of marriage was spent during the late 1960s in Tampico, Mexico, where her husband operated a cotton farm, "Rancho Los Cinco" and their daughter Lacy learned Spanish as her first language. Betsy was born on August 21, 1940 in Hackensack, N.J., the first daughter of William Wainwright and Anne Flagg Hall who predeceased her. Survivors include her husband Philip Neal Becton II, of Atlantic Beach, FL, their three children, and four grandchildren. She has two surviving sisters and a brother. Another sister, Jane, predeceased her. Children and grandchildren are: Philip Neal Becton, III of Washington, D.C and his daughter Edlyn. Susan Lacy Adam and husband Scott of Richmond, VA and their children, Georgia and Nicholas. William MacEwan Becton and wife Amber of Los Angeles, CA and their daughter Louisa. Sisters and brother are: Nancy Atkins Peck of Glen Rock, NJ, William Hall of Montclair, NJ, Sara Wilson of Princeton, NJ and Naples, FL. Betsy asked to be cremated and requested that there be no funeral. Instead we will have celebrations of her life in Atlantic Beach, FL where she lived the past 13 years, Atlanta, GA where she lived almost 30 years previously, and the New Jersey Shore where she spent her childhood. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to Betsy's Garden at the Beaches Area Historical Society, 381 Beach Boulevard, Jacksonville Beach, FL 32250.

APPEL--Carl, on July 12, 2014, age 92, died peacefully, after a long illness, surrounded by his family. He was predeceased by his wife of 70 years, Rose, and is survived by his children Joseph (Patty), David (Sally) and Sharon, and his grandchildren Naomi, Jonathan, Jacob, Elizabeth and Julia. Carl lived the American dream; he arrived from Poland at age 13, graduated from Lincoln High School, served in the Air Force during WWII and then returned to New York to build a successful family and business over the next 60 years. His kindness, wisdom and generosity touched the lives of family and friends the world over. He will be terribly missed by all those who were so fortunate to have crossed his path. In lieu of flowers, donations to UJA would be appreciated.

Three years after sharp cuts to the state’s family planning budget, Texas is examining ways to fill the gaps in access to health care for poor women.

GLENN--Thomas E. Gone a year and yet alive in all our hearts. The ornaments you designed and the canvasses you painted still bring people happiness. .

STRAUSS--Nancy Bloch, 86, of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of New York City, died unexpectedly on July 16. Predeceased by her loving husband, William L. Strauss II. Survived by her children: Bob (Laurie), Judy (Edward) and Barbara (Peter). Grandmother of Jarrett (Jason), Jessica, Lauren (Ryan), Christine, and Lisa. Sister of Alan (Suzanne). Avid reader and stamp collector. A memorial service to be held at a future date.

Sokol--Dorothy Lehrer, of Brooklyn and Commack, NY died on July 19, 2014 in her 85th year of Alzheimer disease. Dorothy was born in Brooklyn on December 28th 1928. Dorothy retired after a long and distinguished career as a Social Worker and Therapist. A life-long progressive and feminist, Dorothy was active in League of Women Voters and National Organization for Women. Beloved wife of Louis Sokol, devoted mother of Marc (Deirdre), Marjorie (David Seman), and William (Laura Ferro). Grandmother of Zachary, Theo, Pascal Seman and Hannah Sokol. Adored sister to Joyce Romanoff (Maya), Elyse Price (Warren), and Robert Coven (Jeanette). Beloved sister-in-law to Dr. Charlotte Sokol (Dr. Martin Blechman), Naomi Sokol O'Sullivan, the late Rose Hollis, and the late Robert Sokol. She is also survived by many nieces and nephews. We are all proud and grateful to have loved and been loved by Dorothy. Marc S. Sokol Marjorie Sokol William Morris Sokol

ROSENTHAL--Lois, 75, on July 20, 2014, died peacefully. She is survived by her husband Richard, their children Jennie (Allan) Berliant and David, her grandchildren Elizabeth and Andrew Berliant and Eva and Mae Rosenthal, and her brother Harvey (Mary) Reis. An activist, environmentalist, supporter and participant in organizations that defended the oppressed, the hungry, and the disadvantaged, she initiated many programs and activities. From the Ohio Innocence Project which has exonerated 17 wrongfully convicted people, to the Fresh Produce initiative at the Freestore Foodbank, and the Rosey Reader Program which has provided books to over 30,000 Cincinnati Public School children, grades K-3, to foster a love of reading, to her creation of Uptown Arts which provides free classes in art, music, acting and dance to five-ten year old city kids. During Lois' 28-year tenure on the board of the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, she and her husband established the Rosenthal New Play Prize which produced 15 world premier productions, several nominated both for the Pulitzer Prize and produced in New York. As a member of the Board of the Cincinnati Art Museum, Lois and Dick endowed the museum to allow free admission in perpetuity. Lois was also a member of the Board of The National Underground Railroad Freedom Center. There, once again drawing on her compassion for those with little or no voice, she envisioned, championed and funded Invisible: Slavery Today, the world's first museum-quality, permanent exhibition on the subjects of modern-day slavery and human trafficking. Along the way, Lois wrote a weekly consumer column for the Cincinnati Enquirer for 10 years, had a call-in radio show, and wrote features for several national magazines. Among her seven books, Living Better was a Book of the Month Club selection. Lois relaunched Story magazine in 1989 with her husband. In five of the 10 years she edited Story, it was nominated for the National Magazine Award for short fiction. In two of those years Story won the prestigious award. Like the founders of Story-- Whit Burnet and Martha Foley-- who first published the works of today's marquis writers, Lois first published stories by Juno Diaz, Elizabeth Graver and Nathan Englander among others. Mother, wife, friend to many, Lois Rosenthal transformed organizations, intellectually and with creative determination. We're all better for her high standards, her dynamic personality, the impact she made on so many lives, and her contagious enthusiasm for doing good.

ROITMAN--Jaime, 71, of Clifton, NJ (formerly of Bogota, Colombia), passed away on July 19th, 2014, after a long fight with Alzheimer's. Before retiring, Jaime worked in the American Stock Exchange. His passion was Bridge, where he achieved the title of International Silver Great Master. He leaves behind his wife of 45 years Diana Roitman. His son and daughter-in-law Daniel and Sharon Roitman of Westfield. His daughter and son-in-law Ilana and Robert Finkelstein of Belmont, MA. His grandchildren will greatly miss their Zeide. Donations can be made to Cure Alzheimer's Fund: (curealz.org).

PIENE--Otto. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the loss of Otto Piene. Piene played an important role in the revival of the contemporary art scene in Germany after World War II, forming the artist group Zero with Heinz Mack, and establishing an international network of colleagues who redefined art in the aftermath of the war. Piene pioneered the use of light as a medium for room-scaled installations that he called "Light Ballets" and the use of fire and smoke to make paintings. He subsequently realized his vision for transforming the sky into an arena for art, coining the term Sky Art. The Guggenheim will celebrate Piene in an exhibition this October, which was developed in close consultation with the artist. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to the artist's family on the occasion of this untimely loss. William L. Mack, Chairman; and Jennifer Blei Stockman, President, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation; Richard Armstrong, Director, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation

O'BRIEN--Pat. The New York Continuo Collective is bereft at the death of Pat O'Brien, the most remarkable musician, teacher, mentor, and friend. Pat was world renowned for his understanding and practical application of performance practice, from early instruments to modern guitar. He was a compendium of musical knowledge; an impeccable scholar. Pat's performances were exquisitely elegant, be it on lute or blues guitar. There was hardly a subject of any kind in which Pat was not conversant. He cared deeply about people and the fate of the world. We share the sorrow of his loss with his beloved wife, Mary Lou, cherished daughter, Elanor, as well as the entire Early Music community.

NIR--Yehuda. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member, Yehuda Nir. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to his family. Scott N. Bolton, Rabbi Marc D. Ashley, President

NIR--Yehuda, on July 19. Beloved husband of Bonnie Maslin. Loving father of Daniel, Aaron, David, and Sarah. Cherished grandfather of Phoebe, Sophie, Jonah and Leo. Lovingly cared for by Beverly Moore. Services, Monday 1:15pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

NELSON--George F.,93, on July 18, 2014 at home in New York City. He is survived by his wife of 72 years, Ann; his son Robert; daughter-in-law Bonnie; and granddaughter Miranda. Was Vice President of Advertising and Publicity in New York for Warner Bros., the motion picture company. Memorial will be held at 2:00pm on Wednesday, July 23, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York City, at 91st St.

KHAZANEH--Fatemeh "Rafat," The family of Fatemeh "Rafat" Khazaneh announces with great sadness the death of their beloved mother and grandmother, who passed away peacefully on July 16, 2014, at the age of 90. Mrs. Khazaneh was known for her personal elegance, her many acts of kindness, and her devotion to her family who was the light of her life. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Abbas Khazaneh, with whom she was married for 50 years. She is survived by her four children Amir, Manda, Ali, and Mamad; her son-in-law Mehrdad; daughter-in-law Heather; and her grandchildren Fatima, Alexander, and Christopher.

KEIL--Barbara Miller, 93, Westminster West, VT. Formerly of Nyack, NY died July 1, peacefully at home from natural causes. Co-founder of Rockland Parent - Child Center. Guardian Ad Litem. Survived by husband Jack, children Nick and Jill, Betsy and Roger and five grandchildren. Predeceased by son Peter. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to Rockland Parent Child Center, 137 1st Ave., Nyack, NY 10960.
KAPLAN--Florence. Died July 20, 2014. Beloved wife of Jack for 61 years, devoted mother, loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Kind, wonderful friend.

BETTS--Charles Rosseter. Charles Betts died on Monday, July 14, 2014 in St. Paul, Minnesota where he lived. He was born on December 18, 1934 in New York City. He is survived by his two children, Paul Betts and Sharon Stella Betts, his sister Phyllys Betts Fleming and his two granddaughters, Lucie and Anna Betts. He will be buried in Woodlawn Cemetery in New York.

BECTON--Elizabeth Hall. Betsy passed away peacefully at home in Atlantic Beach, Florida on Sunday morning, July 13 after a long and valiant struggle with lung cancer. Her husband of 53 years, Philip, was with her and her beloved Australian Cattle Dog, Roo was lying on the floor by her bed. Betsy was a gifted artist, a designer, an avid gardener, and a masterful chef. An extraordinary mother as well, she made everything she touched more beautiful and made friends of all ages and in every walk of life everywhere she went. She will be greatly missed by an eclectic community of admirers. A vivid portion of her 53 years of marriage was spent during the late 1960s in Tampico, Mexico, where her husband operated a cotton farm, "Rancho Los Cinco" and their daughter Lacy learned Spanish as her first language. Betsy was born on August 21, 1940 in Hackensack, N.J., the first daughter of William Wainwright and Anne Flagg Hall who predeceased her. Survivors include her husband Philip Neal Becton II, of Atlantic Beach, FL, their three children, and four grandchildren. She has two surviving sisters and a brother. Another sister, Jane, predeceased her. Children and grandchildren are: Philip Neal Becton, III of Washington, D.C and his daughter Edlyn. Susan Lacy Adam and husband Scott of Richmond, VA and their children, Georgia and Nicholas. William MacEwan Becton and wife Amber of Los Angeles, CA and their daughter Louisa. Sisters and brother are: Nancy Atkins Peck of Glen Rock, NJ, William Hall of Montclair, NJ, Sara Wilson of Princeton, NJ and Naples, FL. Betsy asked to be cremated and requested that there be no funeral. Instead we will have celebrations of her life in Atlantic Beach, FL where she lived the past 13 years, Atlanta, GA where she lived almost 30 years previously, and the New Jersey Shore where she spent her childhood. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to Betsy's Garden at the Beaches Area Historical Society, 381 Beach Boulevard, Jacksonville Beach, FL 32250.

ZORNOW--Marion. of Coconut Creek, FL and Southbury, CT died on July 19 at age 90. She attended the Juilliard School and began a career as a soprano before marrying her husband of 50 years, Dr. Jack Zornow. Her love and encyclopedic knowledge of music continued throughout her life. She is survived by her sons David (Martha) and Todd and her grandchildren Sam, Hannah, and Ethan.

ZALMAN--Jane. Jane Zalman, nee Beach, passed away peacefully, and surrounded by family, on Tuesday, July 15, 2014. She is survived by her sister, Lynn O'Riley, daughters Hollie Watman and partner Robert Futterman, Salome Edgeworth, Sara Pascal and husband Clement Pascal, and grandchildren Carley Watman, and Lily and Keegan Ripley. A class act with fire-red hair, Jane grew up in Lake Forest, IL, before calling Manhattan home, where she enjoyed 35 years of joyful marriage to her soul mate, Gil Zalman. Jane was a globetrotter and world-class conversationalist. She ran a family-owned salt mine, worked as a travel agent, and operated a family business consultancy, as well as earned a masters degree from Columbia University. She loved her country home in New Hamburg along the Hudson River where she enjoyed gardening, pottery, and welcoming countless family and friends with fine food and spirits-and her brilliant laugh.

TANNENBAUM--Elaine Frankel, on July 20, 2014. Loving wife of the late Barney. Devoted mother of Sue (Ron Margolies), Ed (Miyuki Fukumoto), Peter (Ruth Oscar), and Bobbi (Steven Goodman). Adored grandmother of Nancy and Dan Ginsberg and Neil and Jessica Margolies. Cherished GG of Lily, Owen and Elle. Donations may be made to Ovarian Cancer Research.

Sokol--Dorothy Lehrer, of Brooklyn and Commack, NY died on July 19, 2014 in her 85th year of Alzheimer disease. Dorothy was born in Brooklyn on December 28th 1928. Dorothy retired after a long and distinguished career as a Social Worker and Therapist. A life-long progressive and feminist, Dorothy was active in League of Women Voters and National Organization for Women. Beloved wife of Louis Sokol, devoted mother of Marc (Deirdre), Marjorie (David Seman), and William (Laura Ferro). Grandmother of Zachary, Theo, Pascal Seman and Hannah Sokol. Adored sister to Joyce Romanoff (Maya), Elyse Price (Warren), and Robert Coven (Jeanette). Beloved sister-in-law to Dr. Charlotte Sokol (Dr. Martin Blechman), Naomi Sokol O'Sullivan, the late Rose Hollis, and the late Robert Sokol. She is also survived by many nieces and nephews. We are all proud and grateful to have loved and been loved by Dorothy. Marc S. Sokol Marjorie Sokol William Morris Sokol
SENBAHAR--Fani. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. Louis M. Solomon, Parnass

SENBAHAR--Fani. On July 20, 2014. Darling wife to Sabetay, lioness mother to Vivian and Izak, loving mother-in-law to Stephen and Sarah, devoted big sister to Eti and Jojo, and slave grandmother to Albi, Semi, Alexi and Oliver. She was Fabulous. She was Strong. She was Selfless. Above all she was a Legendary Cook. She will be in our hearts forever and ever. Service Tuesday at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity.

ROSENBERG--Rita, passed away peacefully at her home in New York City on July 21, 2014. She was 101 years old. Rita was the daughter of Jacob Rosenberg and Bertha Bixler Rosenberg. Her brother, Emanuel Rosenberg, and sister-in-law, Laura Rosenberg died in the early 1980s. She is survived by cousins in New York and Cleveland where she lived for several years before moving back to New York City with her family. A service in Rita's honor will be held at "The Riverside," 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue on Wednesday, July 23rd at 10am. Burial to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in Rita's memory to Jewish Guild Healthcare, (an affiliate of Lighthouse Guild), 15 West 65th St., New York, NY 10023.
PARNESS--Stanley. Old and dear friend, we will all miss your wisdom and your special sense of humor. Our table remains reserved at Lusardi's. Steve Heard

NELSON--George. The Board and staff of the Film Society of Lincoln Center notes with deep sadness the death of one of its most beloved Board members. George's sage advice and connections provided the Film Society with indispensable programming opportunities. We send our love and sympathy to Ann, Bob, Bonnie and Miranda. Ann Tenenbaum, Chairman, Daniel H. Stern, President, Lesli Klainberg, Executive Director

LeSAGE--Curtis William. Curtis William LeSage, 1949-2014 of Madison CT, died unexpectedly July 4th while in Germany doing what he loved most, traveling the great cities of Europe. He was 65. The cause of death was pneumonia. Curtis followed his father, Bernard R. LeSage, graduating from Choate School. He later graduated from Tufts University and Thunderbird School of Global Management. He began his long career in advertising at Leo Burnett in Chicago, moving to New York to join Ogilvy and Mather in 1976. Curtis was based in many European cities for O & M including Paris, Frankfurt, Vienna and London and retired from WPP Group London in 2007. A frequent international traveler for both business and pleasure, he was fluent in many languages making him comfortable in any foreign city. Curtis was a wonderful raconteur and held membership in numerous clubs throughout the east coast. He will be missed by family and friends. He is survived by his mother, Barbara LeSage, two sisters, Nancy LeSage Hellmuth, Judith LeSage Grassi and his niece and nephew, Grayson Hellmuth Rueckert and William W. Hellmuth. Private funeral services will be held in Madison.

KHAZANEH--Fatemeh "Rafat," The family of Fatemeh "Rafat" Khazaneh announces with great sadness the death of their beloved mother and grandmother, who passed away peacefully on July 16, 2014, at the age of 90. Mrs. Khazaneh was known for her timeless elegance, her many acts of kindness, and her devotion to her family who was the light of her life. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Abbas Khazaneh, with whom she was married for 50 years. She is survived by her four children Amir, Manda, Ali, and Mamad; her son-in-law Mehrdad; daughter-in-law Heather; and her grandchildren Fatima, Alexander, and Christopher.

KELLEY--Mary Anne, 80, of Blue Point, Long Island, died on July 21, 2014, after a long illness. Beloved wife of Gilbert. Loving mother of Stephen, Lara (Peter Rubin) and Matthew. Proud grandmother of Courtney, Alyssa, Acadia and Robert. Funeral service 12 noon, Wednesday at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Middle Road, Sayville. Interment to follow in the parish cemetery.

KEIL--Barbara Miller, 93, Westminster West, VT. Formerly of Nyack, NY died July 1, peacefully at home from natural causes. Co-founder of Rockland Parent - Child Center. Guardian Ad Litem. Survived by husband Jack, children Nick and Jill, Betsy and Roger and five grandchildren. Predeceased by son Peter. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to Rockland Parent Child Center, 137 1st Ave., Nyack, NY 10960.

GRANVILLE--Janet Knotts, died peacefully at home, Wednesday, July 16, 2014. Janet was born in Washburn, Wisconsin on June 19, 1921 daughter of Gilbert Lloyd Knotts and Alice Elizabeth McCoy Knotts, both from long time Delaware families. Her father, a safety engineer, worked for the DuPont Company in Wilmington and his work later took the family from Interlaaken in Washington State and finally to Falmouth, Maine where Janet spent many of her formative years. Janet's mother later married Frank C. "Spike" Evans after the death of her first husband. Spike was the son of the Rev. Lewis Darenydd Evans, the longest serving minister of the First Congregational Church in Camden, thus cementing another family tie to Maine. As a young girl Janet designed clothes simply for her own amusement an interest she carried forward to her studies at Skidmore where she majored in textile and clothing design. Leaving Skidmore she headed for New York City where she studied at Toby-Coburn School for Fashion Careers. She worked for a period of time as Service Manager in McCreery and Company, a department store. This led to a job at a leading fashion magazine as a women's page editor, providing fashion firsts and hints. During the war years Janet left the fashion world and went to work in Brooklyn, New York in war related industry. At the same time she also served as an air raid warden in Manhattan. While in New York she met Maurice "Butch" Granville whom she married in January 1945 in Falmouth, Maine. At the time Butch was working for the Petroleum Administration for War based in Washington DC and traveling extensively within the US helping to develop additional aviation gas supplies for the war. They spent their honeymoon skiing in Canada, a sport she mastered while living in Maine. She and Butch raised two children as his job took them from New York City to Camden, New Jersey, a stint in Washington DC during the Korean War and then to Port Arthur, Texas, to Darien and ultimately Greenwich, Connecticut. After her husband's retirement as Chairman and CEO of Texaco Inc. they settled in Rockport, Maine and Key Largo, Florida. Janet was an avid fisherman, particularly adept at fly fishing for salmon in Canada. She was an ardent golfer and loved boating and fishing in Florida and working in the garden wherever she was living. She was active in the local Cub Scout troop while living in Darien and also served on the town's beautification committee. In Port Arthur she was a Camp Fire Girl leader. She is survived by her husband of almost 70 years Butch Granville, two children, a daughter Carol Blyberg of Brunswick, Maine and a son Frederick Granville of Shawnee, Kansas as well as two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. She is also survived by a sister Alice Knotts Cooney and her husband Daniel Cooney of Darien, Connecticut. Services will be private. Services are in the care of Burpee, Carpenter & Hutchins Funeral Home, 110 Limerock Street, Rockland, Maine.

BEIER--Norman S.,passed away at his home on July 11, 2014. Mr. Beier was born July 21, 1926. He received his BA from Brooklyn College, his MA from Columbia, and his LLD from Columbia Law School, where he was an editor of the Law Review. He served in the United States Navy from 1945-1946. Mr. Beier was Judge Irving Kaufman's first clerk and then was an Assistant U.S. Attorney in 1952. He joined the firm of Kayser Roth where he was Vice President and General Counsel, and then was Of Counsel to the firm Abelman, Frayne and Schwab. Mr. Beier was one of the earliest members of the Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains and served as President in 1981. Mr. Beier is survived by his wife of 66 years Susan; his brother Joel, his children Ellen and David, and his grandchildren Corinne, Tamara, and Samuel. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to an organization of your choice.

BARNES--Chaplin Bradford, of Westerly, Rhode Island, aged 73, died July 20th at his home in Westerly, RI. Educated at the Choate School, Yale, Yale Law School and University College, Oxford University, where he studied international law, he was a lawyer, a conservationist, and a local historian. A founding Director of the Watch Hill Conservancy and Watch Hill Lighthouse Keepers Association, President of the Watch Hill Chapel Society, he was the author of a history of Watch Hill, Watch Hill Through Time, and collaborating author of a history of Watch Hill architecture, Watch Hill Style. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Trowbridge, two daughters, Sarah Chaplin Barnes and Diana Brewster Barnes Bender, three grandchildren, two stepchildren, Andrew R. Sheriff of and Nathalie Sheriff Comstock and their children. Memorial Service, July 26th, at 10am, Watch Hill Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Home and Hospice Care of RI.

SPIEGEL--Betty B. 1930-2013 A memorial to remember that one year ago today our cherished friend and family member Betty Benson Spiegel who passed away in Virginia Beach at home. ZORNOW--Marion. of Coconut Creek, FL and Southbury, CT died on July 19 at age 90. She attended the Juilliard School and began a career as a soprano before marrying her husband of 50 years, Dr. Jack Zornow. Her love and encyclopedic knowledge of music continued throughout her life. WEISSMAN--H Ronald. Junior Achievement of New York mourns the passing of H Ronald Weissman. For nearly three decades, Ron served as a dedicated member and Treasurer of the Junior Achievement of New York Board of Directors. Ron worked tirelessly to advance Junior Achievement's mission to inspire and prepare young people to succeed in the global economy. We will remember him as a leader of integrity, passion and commitment. Our thoughts are with the Weissman family and Ron's many admirers and colleagues in the business community. Richard J. Poccia, Chairman and Joseph A. Peri, President, Junior Achievement of New York

WEISSMAN--H Ronald, CPA and Independent Board Member, died at 70 on Saturday evening in Houston, TX. Mr. Weissman was born in the Bronx, NY on June 26, 1944. He graduated from Union College with a degree in economics and earned a full scholarship to attend Columbia Graduate School of Business. While obtaining his MBA, he was part of the Beta Gamma Sigma MBA honor society and the recipient of the Robert H. Montgomery Prize in Accounting. In 1970, he joined Arthur Andersen LLP, where he spent 32 years of his career. Mr. Weissman was named Partner in 1980 and served as Managing Partner of Transaction Advisory Services for the firm. In 2002, Mr. Weissman joined Ernst & Young LLP as a Senior Partner. He was a member of the Financial Services Office, the global managing partner on two of the firm's most significant Office of the Chairman accounts, and leader of the OCA for the Americas IFRS Network. Following his retirement from E&Y in 2009, Mr. Weissman served as the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the FHLBanks Office of Finance and Chairman of its Audit Committee. He was a Member of the Board of Directors of Sears Canada, Inc. and a former Member of the Board of Directors of Encore Capital Group, Inc. Mr. Weissman was passionate about education and mentorship. He began his career as a high school math teacher, and for 28 years served as Treasurer on Junior Achievement of New York's Board of Directors. In 1967, Ron married the love of his life, Alys Weissman, his wife of 47 years. Almost lifelong New Yorkers, they lived in Chappaqua, NY until 2012 when they relocated to Houston, TX to be near their grandchildren. Mr. Weissman's survivors, in addition to his wife Alys, include daughter, Stephanie Layne, and son, Randy Weissman; his sister, Judi Sternberg; grandchildren Jennie and Thora Layne. A memorial service will be held at 4pm on Thursday, July 24th at the St. Regis Hotel, 2 East 55th Street at 5th Ave. New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to White Plains Hospital and to Junior Achievement of New York.

OLSON--Vera E.,87, of Pompton Plains, NJ, passed away on July 21, 2014. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Vera was the daughter of the late Carl and Alma Anderson. Vera was a Sunday school teacher and member of Good Shepherd Lutheran Church in Brooklyn and Trinity Lutheran Church in Dover. Vera is survived by her husband of 62 years, Walter; and her daughter, Laura. A memorial service will be held 4pm Friday, July 25 at Trinity Lutheran Church, Dover, NJ.

NOVACK--Muriel Jacobson, 82, peacefully on July 22, 2014, Stamford, CT. McGOLDRICK--Marjorie E.,(nee Kunkel) of Darien, CT died on July 18 at the age of 90. She grew up in Muskegon, Michigan and moved to New York to attend Manhattanville and Juilliard. KHAZANEH--Fatemeh "Rafat," The family of Fatemeh "Rafat" Khazaneh announces with great sadness the death of their beloved mother and grandmother, who passed away peacefully on July 16, 2014, at the age of 90. Mrs. Khazaneh was known for her timeless elegance, her many acts of kindness, and her devotion to her family who was the light of her life. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Abbas Khazaneh, with whom she was married for 50 years. She is survived by her four children Amir, Manda, Ali, and Mamad; her son-in-law Mehrdad; daughter-in-law Heather; and her grandchildren Fatima, Alexander, and Christopher.

GRUMAN--Jessie. The board of trustees of the Center for Advancing Health (CFAH) mourns the loss of our beloved and brilliant colleague, Jessie Gruman, president and founder of CFAH. Those of us fortunate enough to work with Jessie have also lost a dear friend. For over two decades, Jessie focused her efforts and the efforts of CFAH on advancing patient engagement and helping people find and benefit from good health care. We will deeply miss her powerful and inspiring voice. No words can adequately express our sadness at Jessie's death or our gratitude for the opportunity to know her. We offer our deepest condolences to Jessie's husband, Richard Sloan, and to all members of the Gruman and Sloan families.

GRUMAN--Jessie. The William B. Ziff Fellows of the Center for Advancing Health remember Jessie Gruman, our great colleague, friend and inspirational leader. Jessie had a unique combination of behavioral science expertise, public policy savvy, personal experience (way too much for one person) and an indomitable and refreshing feistiness and common sense. Oh, how we will miss her voice, her sensibility and her spirit. Hers was a life well lived and an inspiration to all to make a difference. We send our sympathies to her husband of 30 years, Richard Sloan, and to all members of the Gruman and Sloan families.

GRUMAN--Jessie. The staff of the Center for Advancing Health mourns the passing of our cherished president, Jessie Gruman. An inimitable force of intellect, with a wry wit and deep sense of fun, Jessie was an inspiration to each of us. She challenged us personally and professionally while giving 100% herself. Jessie was a tireless advocate for increasing people's engagement in their health and health care. Our last morning together was full of plans for the week ahead. We are bereft by our loss and send our deepest sympathies to Jessie's beloved husband, Richard Sloan, and to all members of the Gruman and Sloan families.

GRUMAN--Jessie Christine. 60, of New York and Washington, DC, died at home in New York on July 14, 2014. Jessie was born in Berea, KY, December 7, 1953, and grew up in upstate New York, Montana, Wisconsin and Oregon. She graduated from Vassar College in 1975 and received a PhD in social psychology from Columbia University in 1984. In 1992, she founded the Center for Advancing Health, an independent, nonprofit research and policy institute based in Washington, DC, for which she served as president until her death. She was the author of "AfterShock: What to Do When the Doctor Gives You or Someone You Love a Devastating Diagnosis." Jessie received honorary doctorates from Brown, Carnegie Mellon, Clark, Georgetown, New York, Northeastern, Salve Regina, Syracuse and Tulane Universities, and the Presidential Medal of the George Washington University. She was also honored by Research! America, the National Coalition for Cancer Survivorship and the Society for Behavioral Medicine, which in 2014 created the Jessie Gruman Award for Health Engagement. She was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the Council on Foreign Relations. She was a fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine and the Society for Behavioral Medicine. She served on numerous boards and advisory panels including, most recently, the Center for Medical Technology Policy, the Claremont School of Community and Global Health, the Journal of Participatory Medicine, the Milbank Memorial Fund, the Sallan Foundation and VillageCare. She is survived by Richard Sloan, her devoted and loving husband, and many loving family members. Memorial services will be held this fall in New York and Washington, DC. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jessie Gruman Memorial Fund at the Center for Advancing Health, Washington, DC; VillageCare, New York; the Southern Center for Human Rights, Atlanta; City Harvest, New York.

GRANVILLE--Janet Knotts, died peacefully at home, Wednesday, July 16, 2014. Janet was born in Washburn, Wisconsin on June 19, 1921 daughter of Gilbert Lloyd Knotts and Alice Elizabeth McCoy Knotts, both from long time Delaware families. Her father, a safety engineer, worked for the DuPont Company in Wilmington and his work later took the family from Interlaaken in Washington State and finally to Falmouth, Maine where Janet spent many of her formative years. Janet's mother later married Frank C. "Spike" Evans after the death of her first husband. Spike was the son of the Rev. Lewis Darenydd Evans, the longest serving minister of the First Congregational Church in Camden, thus cementing another family tie to Maine. As a young girl Janet designed clothes simply for her own amusement an interest she carried forward to her studies at Skidmore where she majored in textile and clothing design. Leaving Skidmore she headed for New York City where she studied at Toby-Coburn School for Fashion Careers. She worked for a period of time as Service Manager in McCreery and Company, a department store. This led to a job at a leading fashion magazine as a women's page editor, providing fashion firsts and hints. During the war years Janet left the fashion world and went to work in Brooklyn, New York in war related industry. At the same time she also served as an air raid warden in Manhattan. While in New York she met Maurice "Butch" Granville whom she married in January 1945 in Falmouth, Maine. At the time Butch was working for the Petroleum Administration for War based in Washington DC and traveling extensively within the US helping to develop additional aviation gas supplies for the war. They spent their honeymoon skiing in Canada, a sport she mastered while living in Maine. She and Butch raised two children as his job took them from New York City to Camden, New Jersey, a stint in Washington DC during the Korean War and then to Port Arthur, Texas, to Darien and ultimately Greenwich, Connecticut. After her husband's retirement as Chairman and CEO of Texaco Inc. they settled in Rockport, Maine and Key Largo, Florida. Janet was an avid fisherman, particularly adept at fly fishing for salmon in Canada. She was an ardent golfer and loved boating and fishing in Florida and working in the garden wherever she was living. She was active in the local Cub Scout troop while living in Darien and also served on the town's beautification committee. In Port Arthur she was a Camp Fire Girl leader. She is survived by her husband of almost 70 years Butch Granville, two children, a daughter Carol Blyberg of Brunswick, Maine and a son Frederick Granville of Shawnee, Kansas as well as two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. She is also survived by a sister Alice Knotts Cooney and her husband Daniel Cooney of Darien, Connecticut. Services will be private. Services are in the care of Burpee, Carpenter & Hutchins Funeral Home, 110 Limerock Street, Rockland, Maine.

BUSHELL--Gordon. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member, Gordon and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his loved ones. Board of Governors Michael Mann, President

BERK--Frances, the adored matriarch of a large family, died on Saturday at the age of 94. Her love of life was contagious and she had an extraordinary number of friends the world-over. Frances Epstein was born in North Arlington, NJ, the child of Eastern European immigrants. After graduating as valedictorian of her class, she earned a scholarship to NYU where she studied law. She moonlighted as a singer and pursued this career after being offered a contract from Universal Studios. She was singing at renowned clubs on the East coast when she met a handsome naval officer while performing at Scaroon Manor on Scroon Lake, NY. Leon Berk swept "Eppie" off her off her feet and they married in 1942. He died in 2003. Fran's dazzling personality and wonderful spirit lives on in the memory of her three children, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

BEIER--Norman S.,passed away at his home on July 11, 2014. Mr. Beier was born July 21, 1926. He received his BA from Brooklyn College, his MA from Columbia, and his LLD from Columbia Law School, where he was an editor of the Law Review. He served in the United States Navy from 1945-1946. Mr. Beier was Judge Irving Kaufman's first clerk and then was an Assistant U.S. Attorney in 1952. He joined the firm of Kayser Roth where he was Vice President and General Counsel, and then was Of Counsel to the firm Abelman, Frayne and Schwab. Mr. Beier was one of the earliest members of the Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains and served as President in 1981. Mr. Beier is survived by his wife of 66 years Susan; his brother Joel, his children Ellen and David, and his grandchildren Corinne, Tamara, and Samuel. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to an organization of your choice.

BARNES--Chaplin Bradford, of Westerly, Rhode Island, aged 73, died July 20th at his home in Westerly, RI. Educated at the Choate School, Yale, Yale Law School and University College, Oxford University, where he studied international law, he was a lawyer, a conservationist, and a local historian. A founding Director of the Watch Hill Conservancy and Watch Hill Lighthouse Keepers Association, President of the Watch Hill Chapel Society, he was the author of a history of Watch Hill, Watch Hill Through Time, and collaborating author of a history of Watch Hill architecture, Watch Hill Style. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Trowbridge, two daughters, Sarah Chaplin Barnes and Diana Brewster Barnes Bender, three grandchildren, two stepchildren, Andrew R. Sheriff of and Nathalie Sheriff Comstock and their children. Memorial Service, July 26th, at 10am, Watch Hill Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Home and Hospice Care of RI.

BARASH--Mary A.,on July 18, 2014, of Longboat Key, FL. Loving and devoted wife of Dr. Ira M. Barash for 57 years. Mary is survived by her adoring husband, four children and their spouses: Faith (Richard McManus), Louisa (Scott David), Andrea (Dite Van Clief) and David (Rachel), and loving grandchildren: Lucas, Callan, Sarah, and Zachary. Her family and friends will greatly miss her. Donations can be made to the Longboat Library, 555 Bay Isle Rd, Longboat Key, FL 34228 or to the American Heart & Lung Association.

AMGOTT--Madeline, a pioneer woman in television, died Saturday at age 92 in Manhattan. Funeral at 10am Friday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. Shiva calls Friday from 4-8pm and Saturday/Sunday from 12-4pm.
