TAFT--William J.,82. Bill died on July 22, 2014 after a valiant struggle against Leukemia. He was a devoted husband to Adrienne for 58 ++ years, never spending time apart and will be missed in the most profound way by her as well as their three children, Stephen, Rodney and Margot. He is also survived by six grandsons who called him Papa and loving daughters and sons-in-law. He was a generous altruistic person, loyal friend, golfer and was full of life. We all love you up to the moon and back. Services Friday 10am at Temple Israel, New York, 112 E. 75th Street. If possible, please donate blood in his memory as the gift of blood gave him the gift of life. Donations to New York Weill Cornell Medical Center.

OLSON--Vera E.,87, of Pompton Plains, NJ, passed away on July 21, 2014. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Vera was the daughter of the late Carl and Alma Anderson. Vera was a businesswoman on Wall Street working at Shearson Lehman for many years. She married Walter Olson on June 21, 1952 and the couple settled in Montville before moving to Cedar Crest Village. Vera was a Sunday school teacher and member of Good Shepherd Lutheran Church in Brooklyn and Trinity Lutheran Church in Dover. Vera is survived by her husband of 62 years, Walter; and her daughter, Laura. A memorial service will be held 4pm Friday, July 25 at Trinity Lutheran Church, Dover, NJ.

MERCK--Albert. Albert Wall Merck died peacefully at his home in Lexington, MA. on July 22. Following an early career at Merck & Co., he devoted decades of his life to public service in the fields of politics, education and philanthropy. He was born on August 31, 1920, the second son of George W. Merck, and Josephine Wall Merck. He was raised in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, NJ, and New York City, where he attended St. Bernard's School. He graduated from St. George's School in Newport, RI in 1939. His college years at Harvard were interrupted by the war, during which time he served as a first lieutenant in the field artillery in the Pacific. He returned to Harvard after the war, but chose to be included in the class of 1943. Mr. Merck married Katharine Evarts in 1946. They were devoted to each other for the following 68 years. Mr. Merck began his career at Merck & Co., the pharmaceutical company established in New York by his grandfather in 1890. The company originated with E. Merck of Darmstadt, Germany. In the mid-1960s Mr. Merck turned his attention to education and public service. He earned Masters degrees in Education at Columbia University and Rutgers University. Among many board memberships he served on the Boards of St. George's School and Westminster Choir College. He also served on Board of the Regional Plan Association from 1961 to 1987. He was Chairman of the RPA in the 1960s during a period of rapid expansion of the New York metropolitan area. In 1971, Mr. Merck was elected to the New Jersey Assembly, representing the portion of Morris County that includes Mendham, where he and his family were located for 47 years. Upon the advent of casino gambling in New Jersey, Mr. Merck was appointed to the Casino Control Commission by Gov. Brendan Byrne. He enjoyed the challenge of applying ethical principles to the work of the Commission and often found himself at odds with the casino interests. During the 1980's Mr. Merck served as Chairman of the New Jersey Board of Higher Education. He also held a seat on the Board of Merck & Co. for many years, retiring in 1993. In 1998 Mr. and Mrs. Merck moved to Brookhaven in Lexington, MA where he embarked on another phase of public service. He worked tirelessly to accelerate the adoption of information technology in the field of teaching and learning. These projects involved a wide variety of institutions including the Friends Academy of North Dartmouth, St. George's School, Lesley University and Harvard Graduate School of Education. Mr. Merck's family life included travel and summers in Mattapoisett, MA. He enjoyed sailing, fishing, reading, singing, and playing the piano. A raconteur and family patriarch, he delighted friends and family with anecdotes, wit and a superb grasp of history. Mr. Merck was pre-deceased by his daughter Katharine, and is survived by his wife Katharine, his son Albert in California, Friedrike Merck of Bearsville, NY, Patience Chamberlin of Exeter, NH, and Wilhelm Merck of Hamilton, MA. He had eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

LUKOMNIK--David, 70, of the East Village, Manhattan, died July 21 following complications from diabetes. Brother of Jon, brother-in-law to Lynn Davidson and Len Rodberg; uncle to Julia, Aidan, Simon and Josie; guardian to Michael Smalls. Funeral at noon, Sunday at Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

KLEBAN--Donald M. On July 23, 2014 after a valiant battle with lung cancer. Survived by children Daniel and Matthew, daughters-in-law Janet and Rosa; grandchildren David, Abigail, Lillian, Esme and Aaron, and cherished love Deborah Wecker. A graduate of Alfred University and NYU School of Law, Don's career spanned 40 years as a corporate attorney and investment banker in New York City. In retirement, his passions turned to his Florida home, golf and poker. He will be missed every day by his loving family and devoted friends, and he will always be remembered for his larger than life spirit, generosity, and wit. Memorial service Friday, July 25, 2014, 1:15pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the Closer to Free Fund, specifically earmarked for Thoracic Medical Oncology-Dr. Herbst (which supports Yale Cancer Center) and mailed to P.O. Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-0611.

KINGSLEY--John McCall Jr. December 1, 1931 July 19, 2014. John McCall Kingsley, Jr. died at home in Greenwich on July 19, 2014, surrounded by his family. The cause of death was lymphoma. He was born on December 1, 1931 in Berlin, Germany to John McCall and Elizabeth Curry Kingsley. He attended Greenwich Country Day School, and graduated from Groton School, and Yale University in the class of 1953. He received his MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1955. Subsequently he served for two years in the United States Army Finance Corps. His professional career began at Price, Waterhouse & Company, during which time he received his CPA from New York University. He then worked at Dillon, Read & Co., Inc. as an Associate of Corporate Finance, and then as Vice President of Finance at General Host Company. In 1971 he joined Sturm, Ruger & Co., Inc. as Executive Vice President and Director. He retired in 1996, but continued serving the company as a Director, and then Presiding Director, until 2010. He was active in numerous philanthropic organizations, as well as serving on hospital and healthcare related boards. A great deal of his time was focused on finding improved treatments for Hydrocephalus. John is survived by his wife of 47 years, Ines, his son, John McCall, III, his daughter Kate Kingsley Lund (Ted), and two grandchildren, William and Brady Lund. A Memorial Service will be held at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT on Wednesday, July 30, 2014 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Hydrocephalus Association, 4340 East West Highway, Suite 905, Bethesda, MD 20814 (http://www.hydroassoc.org).

HERZ--Dr. Marvin I.,of Bal Harbour, FL, 86, died Monday, July 21, 2014, at Mt. Sinai Medical Center in Miami due to complications from renal failure. A former President of The American College of Psychiatrists as well as a former President of The American College of Psychoanalysts, Dr. Herz was an educator and a scientist whose research in schizophrenia had a major impact on the treatments provided to patients with major mental illness in the U.S. and Europe. During his career, Dr. Herz served at the Chairman of the Department of Psychiatry at SUNY Buffalo. He also held various positions at the medical schools of Columbia University, Emory University and The University of Rochester, and until his death, was an attending psychiatrist at Jackson Memorial Hospital, University of Miami. Dr. Herz received a number of awards during his career and was the author and editor of numerous books, articles, and research papers on the causes and treatment of schizophrenia. Predeceased by his daughter Joan Herz Tafti. Survivors include his beloved wife of 61 years, Leslie Mittelman Herz of Bal Harbour; two children, Suzanne Herz of New York City and Joseph Herz of New York City; and four grandchildren, Ariana Tafti, Julia Daniel, Jane Herz and Nicholas Daniel. Funeral services will be private and a memorial service will be scheduled at a later date.

GOLDBERG--Richard, 79, on July 23. Loving husband to Rosalie, his wife of 51 years; devoted father to David, Billy and Dana; and proud grandfather of seven. Born in Brooklyn to Ben and Mary, Richard graduated Colgate and served his country as a U.S. Navy corpsman. He was a businessman, photographer and gardener who enjoyed family, travel and golf. Memorial services: The Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam, Friday, July 25, 11:15am. Contributions: Magen David Adom www.afmda.org

FORLAGER--Margaret Schwartz, 90, died July 22. She was predeceased by husbands Hyman C. Schwartz, 46 years, and Harold Forlager, 18 years. Survived by sons Michael Schwartz, Redwood City, CA; Marvin Schwartz, Little Rock, AR; daughter, Debra Bradley, Manahawkin, NJ; six grandchildren and three great-granddaughters.

ELYACHAR--Daniel. The Yeshiva University Family and the Sephardic Council of Overseers is saddened by the passing of Daniel Elyachar, z'l, a well-known real estate developer, twin brother of the late Ralph Elyachar and brother of Ruth Turner, beloved father of Jonathan Elyachar and his siblings who recently established the Elyachar Family Yeshiva College Scholarship Fund for Sephardic Students, and was an admired grandfather and great-grandfather. He was the son of the late revered Colonel Jehiel R. (and the late Jean) Elyachar, a Yeshiva University Benefactor who played a major role in the development of YU's Sephardic Studies Program. May the entire Elyachar family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, President Emeritus David Eshaghian, Sephardic Council of Overseers, Chairman

ELYACHAR--Daniel. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Daniel Elyachar. He leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Daniel's children, David, Ann, Jonathan and Jodie, Matthew and Gloria, Adam and Stephanie, and Joshua; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

ELYACHAR--Daniel 1927-2014. Loving father, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother, uncle and friend passed away peacefully on July 21 in his home in New York City. Daniel's career spanned many decades in real estate development and management of commercial and residential properties in the New York metro area and Sarasota, Florida. He was a graduate of the University of Michigan who served in WWII. He is survived by his children David, Ann, Jonathan and Jodie, Matthew and Gloria, Adam and Stephanie, and Joshua, as well as 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral will be held on Wednesday, July 23rd at 9:45am at the Plaza Jewish Funeral Chapel with Shiva observed Wednesday and Thursday from 4-8pm at Park Avenue Synagogue.

COOPER--Alice Joyce. March 11, 1924 July 23, 2014. Survived by her sons Iles and Scott, daughters-in-law Beverly Ginsburg and Andria Grundman; grandchildren Sarah and husband Scott, Jesse, Sharon, Suzanne, Nina and Benjamin; great-grandchildren Mackenzie, Milo, Sadie and Max. Reunited with the love of her life, Samuel "Butchie." Daughter of Samuel and Ida Pessin; sister of David. She lived her life giving great love, respect and kindness to all around her; selfless through her own illnesses and hardships, always concerned about family and friends; always living life every day to the fullest. Funeral Services will be held today, 1pm at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. Forest Hills, NY 11375.

BERGMAN--Madelyn (Green). On July 23, 2014 of Llyod Harbor, NY. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of loving and devoted wife to Steve, adored mother to Lainie (Glenn), Liza (Angelo), and predeceased by her daughter, Adrienne. Cherished by her grandchildren Rachel, Evan, Cailen, Meredith and Jordan. Loved immensely by many friends. Funeral services will be held Friday July 25th 10:00am at Gutterman's Funeral Home 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY. Contributions in her honor may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, NY 11714, or online at lustgarten.org

TAFT--William J.,82. Bill died on July 22, 2014 after a valiant struggle against Leukemia. He was a devoted husband to Adrienne for 58 ++ years, never spending time apart and will be missed in the most profound way by her as well as their three children, Stephen, Rodney and Margot. He is also survived by six grandsons who called him Papa and loving daughters and sons-in-law. He was a generous altruistic person, loyal friend, golfer and was full of life. We all love you up to the moon and back. Services Friday 10am at Temple Israel, New York, 112 E. 75th Street. If possible, please donate blood in his memory as the gift of blood gave him the gift of life. Donations to New York Weill Cornell Medical Center.

O'DALY--Fergus Jr.,71, of Northport, NY passed away on July 22, 2014. Fergus was born to the late Fergus Sr. and Mary (King) O'Daly, March 5, 1943 in Brooklyn, NY, where he grew up with the vibrancy that accompanies being the fifth of 10 children. It was also in Brooklyn that Fergus met Anita (Holst), with whom he would share 50 years of marriage. As a young family they moved to Long Island and have called the harbor village of Northport their home for the past 45 years. Fergus is survived by his four children: Christine (Michael) DiLandro, Bridget (John) Tarleton, Peggy (Eric) Colby and Fergus III. Fergus was blessed with six grandchildren who are a true reflection of his heart: Matthew, Brendan, Jack, Justin, Perry and Ansley. As a young man, Fergus had a passion for art and design. At age 16 he got a summer job as an assistant in the art department of a small ad shop, and the die was cast -- Fergus knew advertising would be his passion. He took nighttime art classes at Pratt while working in the mailroom at BBD&O. Hard work always paid off for Fergus, and a year later he was promoted to the art department where he earned that drawing board. He later joined Poppe Tyson, a small B2B agency. At 'Poppe', Fergus realized his potential and grew to take on the roles of Creative Director, President and finally CEO. Under Fergus' leadership, Poppe Tyson produced great work for such notable clients as Bethlehem Steel, Pfizer, Carter Wallace, Otis Elevator and, of course, several of New York City's finest steak houses, including Ben Benson's and Smith and Wolinsky's (where Fergus was always greeted warmly). However, equally important to the work was the relationships and culture that Fergus fostered among employees, clients and vendor partners this was his hallmark. As the advertising business evolved, Fergus was there he had a vision to build the first interactive ad agency. With Poppe's parent company, Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhart his conviction gave birth to DoubleClick, the first online media company, and Poppe.com, regarded for many firsts in the digital marketing era. Fergus would later go on to found FODA (Fergus O'Daly & Associates), which excelled at digital solutions for brands including: IBM, Coty Inc., HP, Toshiba and many others. But Fergus was much more than an ad guy. He drew his strength from family and friends. Growing up in a large family, he developed a strong sense of humor among many other survival skills. He was a partner to Anita and an always-proud Dad. He could be counted on for a joke or Irish song. He enjoyed the pulse of Manhattan, the tides of Northport, sailing on the Chesapeake, the inns of Ireland, an early tee time, walks with Molly and the Jersey Shore with family. Reposing Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport, Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm and Saturday 10-12 Noon, with the Service at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations to V.N.S. Hospice "Hospice House", 505 Main Street, Northport, NY 11768, in Fergus' memory.

MICKENS--Dr. Alvin D.,BCFE, 80. Business Economic Consultant and Professor of Economics, State University of New York, Old Westbury. Passed away peacefully on July 23, 2014. Always in our hearts, he will remain in our thoughts forever. With much love, Jian and Tammy.

LEE--Knute Diedrich, 85, of Fair Hill, MD, died peacefully at day's end in Colora, MD, on July 13, 2014. Son of the late Arthur and Frederika Lee, he is survived by his dear companion Ellen Torrey, his children Arthur Jeduthan Lee, Lucile Adele Lee, Julia Lee Carlson, Robin Andrew Lee, and five grandchildren. Knute is preceded in death by his wife, Nancy Wellington Lee, and sister, Ingeborg Lee Muller. A veteran, Knute served as a lieutenant in the United States Army during the Korean War. Passionate about art, life, and especially sailing, Knute was a past US Sailing Judge and Umpire. A life member of the New York Yacht Club and the International Star Class YRA, Knute was a member of The Catboat Association, past member of North East River YC, Bellport Bay YC, and The Corinthians. Possessed of a joyful zest for living, Knute brought vibrancy to everything he did: he is deeply missed. A memorial service will be held in Bellport, NY, August 9, 2014, at 1:00pm. Donations in his memory may be made to US Sailing Youth Programs, at www.ussailing.org, or PO Box 1260, Portsmouth, RI, 02871. R. T. Foard Funeral Home, 410-658-6030.

KINGSLEY--John McCall Jr. December 1, 1931 July 19, 2014. John McCall Kingsley, Jr. died at home in Greenwich on July 19, 2014, surrounded by his family. The cause of death was lymphoma. He was born on December 1, 1931 in Berlin, Germany to John McCall and Elizabeth Curry Kingsley. He attended Greenwich Country Day School, and graduated from Groton School, and Yale University in the class of 1953. He received his MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1955. Subsequently he served for two years in the United States Army Finance Corps. His professional career began at Price, Waterhouse & Company, during which time he received his CPA from New York University. He then worked at Dillon, Read & Co., Inc. as an Associate of Corporate Finance, and then as Vice President of Finance at General Host Company. In 1971 he joined Sturm, Ruger & Co., Inc. as Executive Vice President and Director. He retired in 1996, but continued serving the company as a Director, and then Presiding Director, until 2010. He was active in numerous philanthropic organizations, as well as serving on hospital and healthcare related boards. A great deal of his time was focused on finding improved treatments for Hydrocephalus. John is survived by his wife of 47 years, Ines, his son, John McCall, III, his daughter Kate Kingsley Lund (Ted), and two grandchildren, William and Brady Lund. A Memorial Service will be held at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT on Wednesday, July 30, 2014 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Hydrocephalus Association, 4340 East West Highway, Suite 905, Bethesda, MD 20814 (http://www.hydroassoc.org).

BARNETT--Bill M.,83, having recently relocated to Ann Arbor from Fort Worth, died on July 23 from complications of Alzheimer's. Everyone in the family was surprised to learn from all of his caregivers that he was a tall man. With a brilliant mind and a sharp wit Bill was a leader in college textbook publishing at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and was widely respected and deeply admired as a friend, colleague, manager, and advisor. He leaves behind his loving and adored wife Amy, his devoted daughter Donna Satin, son-in-law Les Satin, and two wonderful grandsons, Jake and Max Satin. Bill will be greatly missed by his many friends and associates. Donations may be made to St. Joseph Mercy Hospice at stjoesannarbor.org.

McGIVERN--Diane, PhD, RN, FAAN. of Staten Island, NY, died Monday, June 30, 2014, in Staten Island University Hospital, Ocean Breeze, after a lengthy battle with spinal cancer. She was 75. Dr. McGivern will be remembered for her compassion and tireless work in nursing, nursing education and health policy, as well as her efforts on behalf of general education in New York State, as a 15 year member of the Board of Regents of New York State. Born Diane O'Neill in Cleveland, Ohio, Dr. McGivern earned her Bachelor of Science degree in nursing from St. John's College in Ohio and began her career as a staff nurse at the renowned Cleveland Clinic. After her marriage to Dr. Bernard McGivern, the couple moved to New York where Diane worked at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. She received her master's and Ph.D. degrees in nursing from New York University. As a nursing educator, Dr. McGivern taught first at Hunter College from 1966 to 1968, and the Division of Nursing at NYU from 1968 to 1972. From 1972 until 1977, she chaired the Adult Health and Illness section of the Department of Nursing at Lehman College of City University in the Bronx. In 1977, Dr. McGivern became Associate Dean and Professor of Nursing at the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. In 1987, McGivern became Head of the Division of Nursing at New York University's School of Education (now the College of Nursing), holding the Erline Perkins McGriff Professorship in Nursing. McGivern served as Division Head until 2002. "Much of where we are today standing strong as a top-ranked and highly respected College of Nursing is thanks to Diane's vision and tireless advocacy on our behalf," said Eileen Sullivan-Marx, current Dean of the NYU College of Nursing. "The lasting, positive influence that Diane has had on the College and on each and every one of us who had the privilege to work with her cannot be overstated. Among the many remarkable leaders we count among our distinguished NYUCN family, Diane truly stood out, and she will be greatly missed." McGivern was a nursing scholar, editor, and author focusing on advancing the practice of nursing. She co-authored the comprehensive textbook, Nurse Practitioners: Evolution of Advanced Practice, used by students in advanced practice nursing programs nation-wide. Her accomplishments and awards included a gubernatorial appointment to the New Jersey Commission on Health Science, Education and Training and membership on the New York City Chancellor's Task Force on Child Health. Named a Robert Wood Johnson Health Policy Fellow in 1981, she held leadership positions in the American Nurses Association, American Association of Colleges of Nursing, American Academy of Nursing, National League for Nursing and the Nursing Cabinet of Mount Sinai/ NYU Health. She was appointed to commissions to acknowledge and elevate the contributions of the nursing profession to health care policy at the state and national level. In 1991, McGivern was the first nurse to be elected to the New York Board of Regents, which is responsible for the general supervision of all educational activities within the state, a post she held for 15 years. She was chosen vice chancellor of the board in 1998 and served in that capacity until 2001. In addition, she chaired the Blue Ribbon Task Force on the Future of Nursing in New York State, 2001. In addition to her professional accomplishments, Dr. McGivern was an elegant, articulate and lovely woman who shared her sharp intellect, culinary skills and warm sense of humor with her many friends and associates. The NYU family extends its sad condolences to her family, her husband, Dr. Bernard (Bud) McGivern, and her daughter, Ryan McGivern. New York University College of Nursing Eileen M. Sullivan-Marx, PhD, RN, FAAN, Dean & Erline Perkins McGriff Professor

KAUFMAN--Bel. The National Yiddish Theatre - Folksbiene mourns the passing of our beloved friend and colleague Bel Kaufman, noted author, teacher and speaker. Her devotion and affection for the Yiddish theater community was a source of strength and inspiration to us. She carried on the legacy of her grandfather, the Yiddish literary giant Sholem Aleichem, both in her own career as a writer and through her outspoken support of Yiddish culture. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Sidney Gluck, her brother Dr. Sherwin Kaufman, her daughter Thea Goldstine, son Jonathan Goldstine, and her entire family. Jeffrey Wiesenfeld , Zalmen Mlotek, Bryna Wasserman and the entire Board and Staff of The Folksbiene

GREENBERGAlan C. "Ace" AJC mourns the passing of our beloved friend and colleague. Ace served for many years as Chairman of our Wall Street Division and Herbert H. Lehman Tribute. He himself was twice the recipient of our Lehman Award. Though a Wall Street legend, he was known for his common touch, good humor, and love of bridge and magic. Indeed, for decades he enchanted us with his warmth, generosity, and ceaseless devotion to the well-being of the Jewish people and the rights and dignity of all. In his Memos from the Chairman, Ace advised: "We must not count on luck." And he never did. He relied on hard work, driven by his dedication to the highest ideals. We are deeply grateful for his friendship, and send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Kathy, and his family. Stanley Bergman, AJC President David Harris, AJC Executive Director

GREENBERG--Alan C.,In sorrow, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records the passing of our distinguished member, Alan "Ace" Greenberg, devoted Jewish communal leader and humanitarian. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him and benefited from his commitment and compassion. The Temple Emanu-El Family

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery (HSS) community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of Alan C. Greenberg, a long-time supporter and friend. His exceptional philanthropy improved the lives of countless patients through his establishment and support of The Kathryn O. and Alan C. Greenberg Center for Skeletal Dysplasia. The first of its kind in New York City, the center brings together a multidisciplinary team of health care professionals committed to helping people of all ages with skeletal dysplasia through clinical care, research and education. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Kathryn, a Life Trustee of HSS, and to his entire family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery

FITTS--Peter C.,April 30, 1940 - July 16, 2014. Impeccably honest, always respected international banker and protector of credit standards; member of the Citibank and Fleet executive diaspora. Mischievous son of the late Howard P. and Katharine G. Fitts, of Wellesley, MA. Williams College, Class of 1962; MBA Babson. Brilliantly funny, irascible but irreplaceable husband and beloved Rock of Gibraltar for Colleen Kaftan, his wife of 22 years. Father and challenging role model for Jeff (Leslie), Catharine (Derik Keel), and Alan. Grandpa of Sara, Jessie, and Michael. Also survived by ex-wives Candida Fitts and Anne Strauss. Lifelong lover of dogs and cats, beautiful spaces, intellectual challenges, unfamiliar cultures, and his haven in Williamstown, MA. Our deepest appreciation to the wonderful people at Genesis Keene Center, NH, for taking such good care of him and making his final months so very special. Rest in peace, PCF.
