WIENER--Roslyn Joy. It is with great sorrow that we announce the passing of Roslyn Joy Wiener on July 25th, 2014. Daughter of the late Harry and Milly Radutzky, stepdaughter of Pat Radutzky, wife of the late Mark Wiener for 37 years, loved sister of Ellen (Giorgio), adored mother of Sandy (Michele) and Amy (Dean) and grandmother of Madeleine, Jacob, Vivienne and Sienna. Rozzie enriched the lives of everyone she touched. Her dedication to social action was a lifelong passion with 30 years of volunteering at North Shore Hospital and 20 years as Co-Chair of The Black-Jewish Dialogue between Mt. Olive Baptist Church and Temple Beth-El. Funeral services will be held on Monday, July 28, 2014 at 1pm at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck with interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Donations can be made to The Hospital for Special Surgery, Department of Rheumatology or Temple Beth-El of Great Neck.

STANDARD--Michael, of Burlington, VT, a retired partner in the New York law firm Rabinowitz, Boudin, Standard, Krinsky and Lieberman, died at the age 79 on July 2 at Martha's Vineyard. The cause of death was pneumonia. He graduated from Columbia College in 1955 and Brooklyn Law School in 1959. He leaves his wife of 48 years, Elinore Hart Standard, his son, Dr. Sam Standard, daughter-in-law, Laura Standard and two grandchildren, Elias and Maya Standard. Michael Standard will be buried in Chilmark, MA, on August 8. A remembrance will be held in September in Burlington.

SORELL--Micheline, died peacefully in Rye Brook, NY, on July 23, 2014. Born in 1926 in Brussels, Belgium and for 62 years beloved wife of Gerald (Jerry) and mother of Tom, (Janet), Sandi and grandmother of Luke, Katie, Lisa and Robert. Private services to be held in Falmouth, MA.

Sokol--Dorothy Lehrer, of Brooklyn and Commack, NY died on July 19, 2014 in her 85th year of Alzheimer disease. Dorothy was born in Brooklyn on December 28th 1928. Dorothy retired after a long and distinguished career as a Social Worker and Therapist. A life-long progressive and feminist, Dorothy was active in League of Women Voters and National Organization for Women. Beloved wife of Louis Sokol, devoted mother of Marc (Deirdre), Marjorie (David Seman), and William (Laura Ferro). Grandmother of Zachary, Theo, Pascal Seman and Hannah Sokol. Adored sister to Joyce Romanoff (Maya), Elyse Price (Warren), and Robert Coven (Jeanette). Beloved sister-in-law to Dr. Charlotte Sokol (Dr. Martin Blechman), Naomi Sokol O'Sullivan, the late Rose Hollis, and the late Robert Sokol. She is also survived by many nieces and nephews. We are all proud and grateful to have loved and been loved by Dorothy. Marc S. Sokol Marjorie Sokol William Morris Sokol

SMITH--Joyce Arrington, passed away peacefully at home in Houston on Wednesday, the 16th of July 2014. Joyce was born in Tulsa, OK, and graduated from the University of Texas at Austin with a degree in education. In her early years, she taught elementary school in Houston and on military bases in Germany with the U.S. Department of Defense. After returning home, she received her Master's degree from the University of Houston. She married James Henry Smith, her loving husband for 20 years, and after their daughter was born, she continued working as a wife and mother. Later in life, she started a new career as a bridal consultant, which she enjoyed for over a decade. Joyce loved decorating for holidays, traveling with her daughter, and playing bridge with her friends. For two and a half years, Joyce valiantly battled invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC), a type of breast cancer that comprises 10-15% of all breast cancer diagnoses. It is the second most common type of breast cancer, affecting 30,000 women per year in the U.S. alone. ILC is not typically detected in yearly mammograms, so the cancer is more advanced when diagnosed and more difficult to treat. Likewise, its progression to other parts of the body can be difficult to see in x-rays and other types of scans. Joyce's dream was to help establish the world's first ILC clinic that would treat patients, educate the medical community about the disease, and help develop new therapies specifically targeting ILC. She also hoped to find a way to change insurance companies' restrictive rules for allowing breast MRIs (one of the few scans to reliably detect ILC) in the hope of increasing early ILC detection. Joyce was very passionate about her cause, and even during difficult treatments, she continued to work tirelessly to increase ILC awareness. Her family will continue this work in her memory. She is survived by her daughter, Jamie Smith Luff, son-in-law Martin Luff, and grandson James; sister, Joan Arrington Miers; and many other members of her extended family.

SIDRAN--Dr. Miriam, 94, physicist and educator, died in New York City at home July 23, 2014. BA Brooklyn College 1942, MA Columbia University 1949, PhD NYU 1956. Professor Baruch College CUNY 197289, Chair Science Department 198389, Professor Emerita 1990. Member American Association Physics Teachers, New York Academy Science. Contributor to many professional publications. Beloved mentor to students and friends. Survived by sisters June Mandelkern and Sonya Greenfield, niece Marjorie Greenfield, nephews William Greenfield and Nicolas, Michael, and Peter Mandelkern, and seven great-nieces/nephews. Memorial service will be planned.

SCHNABEL--Donald. Passed away on July 20, 2014, in the company of his family. In 1962, following service as a Lieutenant in the US Naval Reserve, he joined the commercial real estate firm Julien J. Studley, Inc., where he worked as a broker for 43 years. His proudest business achievement was his assembly of the land upon which New York City's CitiCorp Center was built. In 1988, he was named as one of the top ten real estate brokers by Crain's New York Business, and he lectured widely at Harvard, Yale and NYU. He served as a Trustee of both St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital and Continuum Health Partners, and was a board member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. He leaves behind wife Xiao Wei Sun, stepdaughter Chen, son Eric and granddaughters Astrid and Annika. He was married for 34 years to Eileen Schnabel, who passed away in 2005. A memorial will be held August 24, 2:30pm, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

RUDERMAN--Elaine Rose, 84, of San Diego, CA passed away peacefully in her home on July 20th. Born in Brooklyn along with younger sister Bonnie to parents Nettie and Max Rose, Elaine earned her Bachelor of Science at Cornell and her Master of Arts at NYU. Elaine wed the late Sidney Ruderman in 1953. She was a loving mother to the late Joan Ruderman and the late Paul Ruderman. Elaine spent her career as a home economist for the New York State Extension service and as an accomplished reporter for CBS Radio in Manhattan before retiring with Sidney to Mendota Heights, MN. After Sidney's passing, Elaine found love again with John Holzheimer in San Diego, CA. There, she remained active in both the Mendota Heights and San Diego communities, serving as president of her Hadassah chapter and as an influential member of Beth Jacob Congregation (Mendota Heights) and Ner Tamid (San Diego) Synagogues. She is survived by partner John Holzheimer; sister Bonnie Cohn; nephew Kneel Cohn; niece Leslie Cohn; daughter-in-law Dianne Ruderman; and grandchildren Michael and Elizabeth Ruderman. Often described as a "force of nature," her courage, humor, intellect, wisdom, and love will be missed dearly.

RIEGEL--William Murchie. William Murchie Riegel, of Duxbury, MA and Scottsdale, AZ, passed away July 20, 2014. Born January 25, 1928 in New York City to John Lawrence Riegel and Margaret Murchie Riegel, Bill was a graduate of Deerfield Academy ('46) and Williams College ('50), and he served as a Naval officer in the 6th fleet from 1952 until 1955. Mr. Riegel began his career in the paper, packaging and forest products industry at the Riegel Paper Company in Riegelsville, PA, which was founded by his great-grandfather John Leidy Riegel, eventually rising to become Executive Vice President. He was President of Riegel Products Corporation and went on to become Chairman of the Board, as well as Executive Vice President of Southwest Forest Industries, Inc. in Phoenix, AZ, and President of Amax Forest Products, Inc. in Greenwich, CT. He later founded Riegel Associates, a management and consulting firm based in Duxbury, MA and served as Chairman of the Board of the Bryce Corporation in Memphis, TN. Mr. Riegel served on various boards associated with the paper industry and in his retirement, was a Director of both the Historic Winslow House in Marshfield, MA and the Manomet Center for the Conservation Sciences in Manomet, MA. He was a member of the Duxbury Yacht Club and Paradise Valley Country Club. Mr. Riegel was married to Susan Richards before separating in 1967. Mr. Riegel is survived by his wife of 44 years, Nancy Bailey (Nickerson) Riegel, children William Murchie Riegel, Jr., Guy Richards Riegel, Katherine McMartin Riegel Schobert, Margaret Winslow Riegel Steinbock, and step-children Elizabeth Nickerson Seltzer and Joshua Bailey Nickerson, as well as 15 grandchildren. The burial will be private. A memorial service is planned for Saturday, August 16th at 3:00pm at St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church in Duxbury. Contributions in lieu of flowers, can be made to The Historic Winslow House (634 Careswell St., Marshfield MA 02050) or the Manomet Center for Conservation Sciences (125 Manomet Point Road, Plymouth, MA 02360).

READ--Clare Taylor, 85, died July 18 in Exeter, NH, after battling a terminal illness. She leaves Bert, her adoring husband of 53 years; sons John and Bill, daughter Wendy; sister Sarah; brother Larry and four grandchildren. She was an avid watercolorist, opera lover, tennis player, sailor, and gardener. But she will perhaps be best remembered as the "hostess-with-the-mostess," graciously entertaining friends and family from far and wide. Always positive, exceedingly generous, ever active, a loving mother and devoted wife, she will be missed by many and forgotten by few. In lieu of flowers, donate to Kirkwood Gardens, 603-968-7194 ext. 12. Memorial service: August 17, 2pm, Church Island, Squam Lake, NH.

PEVNEY--Donald R.,January 21, 1934 July 20, 2014, of Riverhead, NY, passed away at his home on Sunday after a long illness. He was 80 years old. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, he was a graduate of Columbia College and New York University School of Medicine. He served in the United States Navy from 1960 to 1963 before settling in Riverhead, where he was the town pediatrician for many years before retiring from clinical practice in the late 1990s. He was a lifetime fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics, a member of the Suffolk County Medical Society, the Medical Society of the State of New York, and the Suffolk Pediatric Society, of which he was a past president. In later years he served as a consultant for the Medical Liability Mutual Insurance Company of New York and was a frequent lecturer on standards of care in pediatrics. He found great joy and pride in his family, his work and his many intellectual pursuits, and will be remembered as a uniquely capable physician and a generous and caring person who was always willing to provide help and advice to friends and family. Dr. Pevney is survived by his wife, Jacqueline Wargo Pevney of Riverhead; his brother, Dr. Bruce Pevney of Carlsbad, California; his son David B. Pevney and wife Esther of Charlotte, North Carolina; his daughter Andrea J. Pevney of Riverhead; and his daughter Donna Masterson, her husband John and grandchildren Molly, John Jr. and Julia Masterson of Medfield, Massachusetts. We will miss him dearly.

MICKENS--Dr. Alvin D.,BCFE, 80. Business Economic Consultant and Professor of Economics, State University of New York, Old Westbury. Passed away peacefully on July 23, 2014. Always in our hearts, he will remain in our thoughts forever. With much love, Jian and Tammy.

MERCK--Albert. The Bennington College community mourns the death of Albert Merck, beloved friend and trusted advisor. He was a leading light for education and passionate advocate for Bennington. His grace, humor, and wise counsel will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to his devoted wife--our dear Kate--and to his entire family. Alan Kornberg, Chairman, and Mariko Silver, President

MERCK--Albert. The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation mourns the loss of Albert Merck. Al was an advocate for low-cost universal access to digital education long before it became fashionable. He matched his words with pioneering initiatives at schools and institutions across the country, including Woodrow Wilson. He was 93 when he died, but his vision made people who were decades younger feel older than he was. When someone his age dies, there is a tendency to express loss by recounting that person's achievements. In Al's case, the loss is what he might have accomplished in the future. Trustees and Staff of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation Princeton, NJ

McGIVERN--Diane, PhD, RN, FAAN. of Staten Island, NY, died Monday, June 30, 2014, in Staten Island University Hospital, Ocean Breeze, after a lengthy battle with spinal cancer. She was 75. Dr. McGivern will be remembered for her compassion and tireless work in nursing, nursing education and health policy, as well as her efforts on behalf of general education in New York State, as a 15 year member of the Board of Regents of New York State. Born Diane O'Neill in Cleveland, Ohio, Dr. McGivern earned her Bachelor of Science degree in nursing from St. John's College in Ohio and began her career as a staff nurse at the renowned Cleveland Clinic. After her marriage to Dr. Bernard McGivern, the couple moved to New York where Diane worked at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. She received her master's and Ph.D. degrees in nursing from New York University. As a nursing educator, Dr. McGivern taught first at Hunter College from 1966 to 1968, and the Division of Nursing at NYU from 1968 to 1972. From 1972 until 1977, she chaired the Adult Health and Illness section of the Department of Nursing at Lehman College of City University in the Bronx. In 1977, Dr. McGivern became Associate Dean and Professor of Nursing at the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. In 1987, McGivern became Head of the Division of Nursing at New York University's School of Education (now the College of Nursing), holding the Erline Perkins McGriff Professorship in Nursing. McGivern served as Division Head until 2002. "Much of where we are today standing strong as a top-ranked and highly respected College of Nursing is thanks to Diane's vision and tireless advocacy on our behalf," said Eileen Sullivan-Marx, current Dean of the NYU College of Nursing. "The lasting, positive influence that Diane has had on the College and on each and every one of us who had the privilege to work with her cannot be overstated. Among the many remarkable leaders we count among our distinguished NYUCN family, Diane truly stood out, and she will be greatly missed." McGivern was a nursing scholar, editor, and author focusing on advancing the practice of nursing. She co-authored the comprehensive textbook, Nurse Practitioners: Evolution of Advanced Practice, used by students in advanced practice nursing programs nation-wide. Her accomplishments and awards included a gubernatorial appointment to the New Jersey Commission on Health Science, Education and Training and membership on the New York City Chancellor's Task Force on Child Health. Named a Robert Wood Johnson Health Policy Fellow in 1981, she held leadership positions in the American Nurses Association, American Association of Colleges of Nursing, American Academy of Nursing, National League for Nursing and the Nursing Cabinet of Mount Sinai/ NYU Health. She was appointed to commissions to acknowledge and elevate the contributions of the nursing profession to health care policy at the state and national level. In 1991, McGivern was the first nurse to be elected to the New York Board of Regents, which is responsible for the general supervision of all educational activities within the state, a post she held for 15 years. She was chosen vice chancellor of the board in 1998 and served in that capacity until 2001. In addition, she chaired the Blue Ribbon Task Force on the Future of Nursing in New York State, 2001. In addition to her professional accomplishments, Dr. McGivern was an elegant, articulate and lovely woman who shared her sharp intellect, culinary skills and warm sense of humor with her many friends and associates. The NYU family extends its sad condolences to her family, her husband, Dr. Bernard (Bud) McGivern, and her daughter, Ryan McGivern. New York University College of Nursing Eileen M. Sullivan-Marx, PhD, RN, FAAN, Dean & Erline Perkins McGriff Professor

McDERMOTT--W. Stanley, 90, on July 24 of natural causes at his home in New York City surrounded by his family. He was born on November 17, 1923 in Piermont, New York to Lillian H. (Billington) and John J. McDermott. He attended Columbia and Rutgers Universities. He enlisted in the U S Army Air Corp during World War II and served in the China, Burma, and India theatre. He was a survivor of the HMT Rohna troop ship sinking in November of 1943, the single greatest loss of American lives at sea during the war. This tragedy was attributed to the first use of a German guided bomb during WWII. His professional career in the forest products industry began at the Camp Manufacturing Company in Franklin, VA. Subsequently he served in a number of executive positions in the forest products industry in and around New York City. In the early 1950's he began his long career at Bulkley Dunton and Company rising to the positions of CEO and Chairman until his retirement in 2002. Stanley was a long time member and member of the Board of Governors of the Union League Club of New York. He was also an avid golfer and member of the Knickerbocker Country Club in Tenafly, New Jersey. Stanley is survived by his dear companion Charlotte Hewson of New York, NY his sons William S. (Dina) of Bedford, NY and Bruce H. (Joana) of New York, NY as well as by two granddaughters Alyson and Louisa. A funeral mass will be held on Wednesday, July 30 at 10am at the Church of our Savior, 59 Park Avenue at 38th Street, New York, NY.

MAZZOLA--John W.,who led Lincoln Center for The Performing Arts for twenty years, passed away on Thursday, July 24, 2014 in New York City. He was 86. A lawyer with the firm of Millbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy, he joined Lincoln Center in 1962 and became its chief executive officer in 1968. Mr. Mazzola skillfully steered the expansion of Lincoln Center and its programs, providing access to high quality performing arts to a city depressed by financial hardship. He passionately increased accessibility to the arts through public and televised concerts. Above all, his family was his overriding theme and connection. As noted in an article written by George Sturm for the Music Associates of America, "(i)t is as if the communion with his wife Sylvia and daughters Alison and Amy(was) constantly recharging his battery, making it possible for him to make vital, productive and imaginative connections among the countless details of his daily labors." He was decorated Cavaliere Ufficiale Ordine al Merito della Repubblica Italiana and Officer Ordre des Arts et des Lettres France. He was a member of The Misquamicut Club (Rhode Island). He was born and raised in Bayonne, New Jersey and was a graduate of Tufts University (1949) and the Fordham Law School (1952). He served in the Air Force USN 45-46 and in Japan with the CIC-US Army 53-55. Mr. Mazzola is survived by his wife Sylvia (Drulie), a former theatrical producer, daughter Alison Mazzola, sister Jane Sharkey, son-in-law Terence "Tad" Flynn, and beloved grandchildren James Davis Flynn and Christina Pleasant Flynn. He was predeceased by his daughter Amy Mazzola Flynn. He will be remembered for his wry wit, storytelling, his love of cooking and entertaining. He loved sailing and the East Beach. Visitation will be held Monday, July 28 from 2:00pm to 6:00pm at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Avenue. A Funeral Service will be held on Tuesday, July 29 at 10:30am at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, where he served as an usher for many years. The family asks that donations be made to The Brearley School-Amy Mazzola Flynn Fund, 610 E. 83rd St. New York, NY 10028.

MATTEI--Dr. Frank, age 95, died June 20, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Bea, devoted and loving father of Frank. Frank proudly served in the Army during WWII, at the rank of Captain. He was a graduate of Jefferson Medical College where he also enjoyed being a professor and mentor. He practiced as an orthopedic surgeon in Philadelphia until his retirement in. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date.

LIPTON--Phyllis Kahn, beloved mother of Michael and Joshua, died Sunday July 20 in New York City at the age of 95 after a long illness. She is survived by her sons, their wives Catherine Bayliss and Ruth Elena Seidler, and her beloved grandsons Benjamin and Oliver.

LIPSCHITZ--Lou. New Alternatives for Children mourns the passing or our beloved Treasurer. Lou was an early and devoted supporter of our agency. His skilled financial leadership helped us grow as we navigated the complex child welfare system. His passion, optimism and wisdom will be sorely missed by the entire NAC family. Our heartfelt condolences to Tobey and his wonderful family, with whom we share the grief of his loss. Robert Friedman, President Arlene Goldsmith, Executive Director

LeSAGE--Curtis William. Curtis William LeSage, 1949-2014 of Madison CT, died unexpectedly July 4th while in Germany doing what he loved most, traveling the great cities of Europe. He was 65. The cause of death was pneumonia. Curtis followed his father, Bernard R. LeSage, graduating from Choate School. He later graduated from Tufts University and Thunderbird School of Global Management. He began his long career in advertising at Leo Burnett in Chicago, moving to New York to join Ogilvy and Mather in 1976. Curtis was based in many European cities for O & M including Paris, Frankfurt, Vienna and London and retired from WPP Group London in 2007. A frequent international traveler for both business and pleasure, he was fluent in many languages making him comfortable in any foreign city. Curtis was a wonderful raconteur and held membership in numerous clubs throughout the east coast. He will be missed by family and friends. He is survived by his mother, Barbara LeSage, two sisters, Nancy LeSage Hellmuth, Judith LeSage Grassi and his niece and nephew, Grayson Hellmuth Rueckert and William W. Hellmuth. Private funeral services will be held in Madison.

LEIBOWITZ--Robert. Robert "Bob" "Lebo" Leibowitz, died July 14th after a 4++ year battle with pancreatic cancer. An executive in the textile industry, Bob worked for Bennettsville Printing of New London, CT after a 27 year stint as Vice-President of Cone Mills. His cheerful disposition and eagerness to help others endeared him to one and all. Bob is survived by his wife Georgiana Zamel of Yonkers, NY, his daughter and son-in-law Sarah and Mark McCullough, their daughters Courtney and Morgan of Boca Raton, FL; his daughter-in-law Brett Leibowitz, her sons Nathaniel, Greyson and daughter Hilary of Nantucket, MA; his brother and sister-in-law Arthur and Pamela Leibowitz of Green Valley, AZ; and many cousins, nieces and nephews. Bob was predeceased by his son Robert "Robbie" Leibowitz. A private service is planned for Westerly, RI. Plans for Memorial Services in Rhode Island and in New York will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Cure Pancreatic Cancer Fund at: www.lustgarten.org For online condolences, please visit: www.gaffney dolanfuneralhome.com

KREINIK--David. Consummate ad man and devoted husband and father, David Kreinik, 84, who is best remembered for his quick wit and eternal sense of humor as well as his deep and abiding love for his family, his friends, and all things New York, died Thursday, July 3rd in New Orleans, LA. His wife, Sandra and his daughter, Sasha, survive him. Sasha will host an informal gathering in New York on Monday, August 4th at 6pm. Please visit the family guestbook at www.lakelawnmetairie.com for details.

KOVAR--Lillian Cohen, 95, on July 17, 2014. Sociologist and professor emerita, Bronx Community College. Wife of late Leo Kovar, mother of Naomi, Joshua and Rachel, sister of Sylvia Cohen, grandmother of Eli. Memorial scheduled late summer.

KOERNER--Marcia, (Schure) formerly of Great Neck, NY. Passed away peacefully on July 24th, at the age of 81. She was the "wonderful" wife of her late husband, Ira. She is survived by her loving and devoted children Nancy and Richard Goldberg, Steven and Rosa, Robert and Corrie, David and Debbie, and her sister-in-law of 60 years, Ruth Eppsteiner. She is the proud grandmother of Caroline and Michael Paris, Jeremy Goldberg, Caitlyn, John, Justin and Jacob Koerner, and caring cousin to Adrienne Schure, Deborah and Julie Lokin. Rest in peace Grandma Marcia.

KLEBAN--Donald M. On July 23, 2014 after a valiant battle with lung cancer. Survived by children Daniel and Matthew, daughters-in-law Janet and Rosa; grandchildren David, Abigail, Lillian, Esme and Aaron, and cherished love Deborah Wecker. A graduate of Alfred University and NYU School of Law, Don's career spanned 40 years as a corporate attorney and investment banker in New York City. In retirement, his passions turned to his Florida home, golf and poker. He will be missed every day by his loving family and devoted friends, and he will always be remembered for his larger than life spirit, generosity, and wit. Memorial service was held on Friday, July 25, 2014. Contributions may be made to the Closer to Free Fund, specifically earmarked for Thoracic Medical Oncology-Dr. Herbst (which supports Yale Cancer Center) and mailed to P.O. Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-0611.

KEESING--Aleida (nee van Tijn), passed away at home on July 25, 2014, surrounded by her loving children. Born in Amsterdam, the Netherlands in 1918, she and her cherished late husband Gustaaf Keesing, DDS, fled from Antwerp, Belgium and arrived in New York in March, 1940. They shared a life-long love for one another and were blessed with 67 years of marriage. She was an exemplar of devotion for her family, spiritual strength, and wisdom, and persevered where others would have abandoned hope. She is survived by her beloved children Bette Sparago and Andrew (Linda), and grandsons Daniel and Jeffrey Keesing. She was predeceased by her parents Benjamin and Betje van Tijn, and brother Mozes, all were murdered in Sobibor, Poland in 1943. Her beloved sister, Sara van Gelder, who lived in Haifa, Israel, passed away in 2009. She was an extraordinarily devoted wife, mother, sister, and daughter-in-law, and source of love, dedication and inspiration to her many friends around the world. We will always be inspired by her love of life, her strength during great adversity, and be blessed by her love and devotion for us. Private funeral, shiva at her home on July 28, 5:00-8:00pm, and Andrew's home on July 29, 7:00-9:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the New Rochelle Chapter of Hadassah, or a charity of your choice.

KAUFMAN--Charlene, of Hewlett, NY. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister-in-law passed away on Wednesday, July 16, 2014 at 6am surrounded by her daughters. She was predeceased by her loving husband Edward Kaufman after 43 years of marriage. She is survived by her children Cindy and Larry Kohn and Jill and Ralph Betesh, and her loving grandchildren Remi, Garrett, Adam and Lexi. She was so loved and will be greatly missed and cherished in our hearts forever. There are no words for how special you were and how much about life you taught us.

KAUFMAN--Bel. It is with profound sadness that the Hunter College community mourns the passing of our esteemed alumna Bel Kaufman '34, who touched millions with her best-selling novel Up the Down Staircase. Bel was an ardent supporter of the College and a frequent visitor, who most recently attended and spoke at Hunter's first all-class Homecoming. In 2001, Hunter awarded Bel an honorary degree for her literary achievements and her service to the College and in 2011, at the age of 100, she taught a class at Hunter on Jewish humor. Bel will always be remembered for her wit, her kindness and her generosity. Contributions in her honor can be sent to the Bel Kaufman Fund at the Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10065. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College

KAUFMAN--Bel. The National Yiddish Theatre - Folksbiene mourns the passing of our beloved friend and colleague Bel Kaufman, noted author, teacher and speaker. Her devotion and affection for the Yiddish theater community was a source of strength and inspiration to us. She carried on the legacy of her grandfather, the Yiddish literary giant Sholem Aleichem, both in her own career as a writer and through her outspoken support of Yiddish culture. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Sidney Gluck, her brother Dr. Sherwin Kaufman, her daughter Thea Goldstine, son Jonathan Goldstine, and her entire family. Jeffrey Wiesenfeld , Zalmen Mlotek, Bryna Wasserman and the entire Board and Staff of The Folksbiene

KAUFMAN--Bel. As the only sibling of Bel Kaufman, I mourn the death of my remarkable sister, who died of natural causes in her New York apartment on July 25 at the age of 103. She is survived by two children, Thea and Jonathan Goldstine, by a granddaughter, Susan Goldstine, and by her husband of more than forty years, Sidney Gluck. She is also survived by my own children, Kenneth and Keith Kaufman, and by my grandchildren Kara, David, and Rachel. Bel and I emigrated to America from Russia with our family in 1922, when Bel was eleven years old. She used to say that she learned to speak English by osmosis, or at least enough to receive her B.A., Magna Cum Laude, from Hunter College and her M.A. with first honors from Columbia University. Our grandfather was the famed and much-beloved author-humorist Sholom Aleichem, whose Tevye stories inspired the Broadway musical "Fiddler on the Roof." I've known my wonderful sister for all of my 94 years. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for any donations in Bel's memory to: Yivo Institute for Jewish Research, 15 West 16th St., NY, NY 10011, www.yivo.org; National Yiddish Theatre-Folksbiene, 90 John St. #

KAUFMAN--Bel. In loving memory of our aunt and great-aunt Bel Kaufman, who captivated us with her presence, her exuberant sense of style, and her insistence that she was too busy to get old. A magnet for other people, she held court when she had company glamorous, graceful, witty, funny and kind. She scoffed at life when it didn't go her way and danced with verve through all the rest. She is missed. Kenneth, Linda, Kara and David Kaufman

HOWELL--Ralph D. Jr.,formerly of Long Island and NYC, passed away on June 26th in Lansdale, PA. He is survived by daughters Robin Best, Claudia Fish and India Howell, and niece Karen Gunn. His legacy includes three grandchildren, Ashley Best, Reed Choate, and Whitney Shepard, and six great-grandchildren. His wife Natalie and daughter Cassandra Choate predeceased him. A principal of E.W. Howell, Co., he was active in numerous professional and civic organizations. (For full details, see The New York Times on July 20th). A memorial service will be held on August 4th at 11:00am at Chapey and Sons in West Islip.

HOSODA--Fumiko. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Fumiko Hosoda, a devoted opera lover and enthusiastic member of our Golden Horseshoe, who served on the Met board from 2003 to 2010. On behalf of everyone at the Met, we extend our sincere condolences to her family and friends. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Kevin W. Kennedy, President & CEO Mrs. Walter J. Laughery, Jr., Major Gifts Chairman Peter Gelb, General Manager

HOLLAND--Ethel, mother of John, grandmother of Joshua, aunt of Jill, Beth and Toni, died peacefully in her sleep at 96. A nurse and a MOMA volunteer for decades, she was predeceased by husband Jesse and daughter Jessica. A proud Democrat, she voted in 20 presidential elections.

HOFFMAN--Kenneth, our dearly beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend has passed. His financial expertise, quick sense of humor and sport enthusiasm will be greatly missed by all. His constant love and devotion will keep our wonderful family together forever.

HAPPEL-ROSEMARK--Erika, 94, peacefully, at home in Los Angeles, on July 21, 2014. She is survived by her son, Peter, and his family. We mourn the passing of "Ruth," an analysand of Melanie Klein's and a landmark case history in the annals of childhood psychoanalysis.

GRUMAN--Jessie. The board of trustees of the Center for Advancing Health (CFAH) mourns the loss of our beloved and brilliant colleague, Jessie Gruman, president and founder of CFAH. Those of us fortunate enough to work with Jessie have also lost a dear friend. For over two decades, Jessie focused her efforts and the efforts of CFAH on advancing patient engagement and helping people find and benefit from good health care. We will deeply miss her powerful and inspiring voice. No words can adequately express our sadness at Jessie's death or our gratitude for the opportunity to know her. We offer our deepest condolences to Jessie's husband, Richard Sloan, and to all members of the Gruman and Sloan families.

GRUMAN--Jessie. The William B. Ziff Fellows of the Center for Advancing Health remember Jessie Gruman, our great colleague, friend and inspirational leader. Jessie had a unique combination of behavioral science expertise, public policy savvy, personal experience (way too much for one person) and an indomitable and refreshing feistiness and common sense. Oh, how we will miss her voice, her sensibility and her spirit. Hers was a life well lived and an inspiration to all to make a difference. We send our sympathies to her husband of 30 years, Richard Sloan, and to all members of the Gruman and Sloan families.

GRUMAN--Jessie. The staff of the Center for Advancing Health mourns the passing of our cherished president, Jessie Gruman. An inimitable force of intellect, with a wry wit and deep sense of fun, Jessie was an inspiration to each of us. She challenged us personally and professionally while giving 100% herself. Jessie was a tireless advocate for increasing people's engagement in their health and health care. Our last morning together was full of plans for the week ahead. We are bereft by our loss and send our deepest sympathies to Jessie's beloved husband, Richard Sloan, and to all members of the Gruman and Sloan families.

GRUMAN--Jessie Christine. 60, of New York and Washington, DC, died at home in New York on July 14, 2014. Jessie was born in Berea, KY, December 7, 1953, and grew up in upstate New York, Montana, Wisconsin and Oregon. She graduated from Vassar College in 1975 and received a PhD in social psychology from Columbia University in 1984. In 1992, she founded the Center for Advancing Health, an independent, nonprofit research and policy institute based in Washington, DC, for which she served as president until her death. She was the author of "AfterShock: What to Do When the Doctor Gives You or Someone You Love a Devastating Diagnosis." Jessie received honorary doctorates from Brown, Carnegie Mellon, Clark, Georgetown, New York, Northeastern, Salve Regina, Syracuse and Tulane Universities, and the Presidential Medal of the George Washington University. She was also honored by Research! America, the National Coalition for Cancer Survivorship and the Society for Behavioral Medicine, which in 2014 created the Jessie Gruman Award for Health Engagement. She was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the Council on Foreign Relations. She was a fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine and the Society for Behavioral Medicine. She served on numerous boards and advisory panels including, most recently, the Center for Medical Technology Policy, the Claremont School of Community and Global Health, the Journal of Participatory Medicine, the Milbank Memorial Fund, the Sallan Foundation and VillageCare. She is survived by Richard Sloan, her devoted and loving husband, and many loving family members. Memorial services will be held this fall in New York and Washington, DC. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jessie Gruman Memorial Fund at the Center for Advancing Health, Washington, DC; VillageCare, New York; the Southern Center for Human Rights, Atlanta; City Harvest, New York.
GREENBERG--Alan C. The Board of Directors of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America mourns the loss of fellow Director Ace Greenberg. You are a "Good Scout". With deepest sympathy.

GREENBERG--Alan "Ace". Unique in every way and our cherished friend. We shall miss this magical person, but he remains in our hearts forever. Our love and sympathy to his beloved wife Kathy and his entire family. Paula and Leon

GREENBERG--Alan C. The New York Legal Assistance Group (NYLAG) mourns the loss of Alan C. Greenberg, beloved husband of our founder and visionary philanthropist, Kathryn O. Greenberg. We extend our sincerest condolences to Kathy, as well as to Lynn and Caleb Koeppel, Ted and Kathleen Greenberg, and the entire Greenberg family. Abby S. Milstein, Chair Yisroel Schulman, Attorney-in-Charge

GREENBERG--Alan "Ace". Alan's many superb qualities are known. The Ace I knew thrived and was thrilled when honest hardworking people succeeded. He responded to help the little guy. He noticed those suffering. He cheered for those who had no one cheering. Alan, I love you and will miss you. When we catch up promise me you won't talk politics. Mike Saperstein
GREENBERG--Alan "Ace". My mentor, my guide and my life long best friend. Murray Koppelman

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Trustees and community of the American Museum of Natural History are saddened by the death of Alan C. Greenberg, a longtime friend of the Museum. He was elected a Trustee in 1996, serving on the Executive Committee, Exhibition Policy Committee and Science Policy Committee, and was named an Honorary Trustee in 2005. His love of nature and science were as palpable as his mastery of magic. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife Kathy and the entire Greenberg family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

GREENBERG--Alan. Seventy years ago there formed a friendship that has been one of the wonderful events of my life. I tried to give as good as I got. You were the best and I will forever think of you and treasure our time together. Alvin "Russian" Einbender

GREENBERG--Alan C. The community of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, Yeshiva University, is deeply saddened by the loss of Alan C. Greenberg, our beloved and respected friend and husband of Kathryn O. Greenberg, Cardozo's Board Chair Emerita. Alan lent his heart unreservedly to the law school and to its students. With his brilliance, ingenuity, and practicality, he, with Kathy, advanced the very foundation of the law school. He made magic for Cardozo in a myriad of ways. Together with Kathy, a 1982 graduate of Cardozo and Chair of its Board of Overseers from 2003-2010, Alan supported initiatives that have had a profound impact on our students and faculty, including establishing a scholarship in his name that allows students who dream of pursuing a legal education to receive one at Cardozo, and supporting the creation of a new student center at the law school, The Kathryn O. and Alan C. Greenberg Center for Student Life given in honor of Dean David Rudenstine. Alan opened his home to our community, organized events, spoke with students and brought in speakers. Alan's lifetime philanthropic spirit matched Kathy's deeply held interest in providing access to justice for the underserved. Their combined passion gave rise to the Kathryn O. Greenberg Immigration Justice Clinic at Cardozo, the Guardianship Clinic, and the exponential expansion of the law school's public service auction, an enterprise that raises funds to support student work in public service. There are hundreds of Cardozo students and alumni whose public interest law experiences and careers were launched by the generosity of Alan and Kathy. Countless underrepresented individuals and communities have been served by these students and attorneys. There are few people who have the talent, the heart, the vision and skill to make better the lives of others and to advance the ethos of an institution. Alan Greenberg was such a man and everyone at Cardozo is deeply grateful and is better for having met and been touched by him. He understood the problems people face and had a gift for finding simple and effective ways to solve them. We send our love and deepest sympathies to Kathy and to Alan's children, Ted Greenberg and Lynne Koeppel, son-in-law Caleb Koeppel, sister, DiAnne Hirsch, brother, Maynard and grandchildren, Alison, Melissa, Sam, Max, and Kyle, a 2012 graduate of Cardozo. Matthew Diller, Dean Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, Yeshiva University David P. Samson, Chair Cardozo Board of Overseers

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Yeshiva University family and the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law are deeply saddened by the loss of Alan C. Greenberg, a cherished Jewish communal, civic, and business leader whose cherished dear wife, Kathryn, was Chair of the Board of Overseers of the Cardozo School of Law. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Board of Governors, Membership and Staff of Deepdale Golf Club, note with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Mr. Alan C. Greenberg. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President

GREENBERG--Alan C. UJA-Federation of New York deeply mourns the passing of Alan C. (Ace) Greenberg, a giant in our community and a stalwart champion of the Jewish people, both at home and in Israel. Ace was a consummate role model who had the incredible ability to inspire others to give as generously as possible. For years, Ace hosted our Annual Campaign Launch that became known with some reverence and affection as the "Greenberg Event." He was a legend of Wall Street and a philanthropic icon, and his memory, spirit, and impact will remain an enduring legacy at UJA-Federation and throughout the community at large. Ace leaves behind a loving family that carries on his legacy of exceptional philanthropic commitment and leadership. We extend our deepest condolences to Ace's wife, Kathy; his children Ted and Lynne Koeppel (Caleb); his brother, Maynard; his sister, Diane Hirsch; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Raoul Wallenberg Committee of the United States mourns the death of its Chairman Emeritus and the fervent champion of Raoul Wallenberg. His chairmanship was like no other, and we continue to benefit from his leadership. Our condolences to Kathy; Lynn and her family; and to Ted. Alan was so courageous; we shall miss him. Rachel Oestreicher Bernheim, Chairman and The Board of Directors of The Raoul Wallenberg Committee of the United States

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of Alan C. Greenberg, a dedicated member of the Library family. He joined the Library's Board of Trustees in 1985 and was an especially active member for many years, serving as Vice Chairman and as a member of several important Board Committees. He was named a Life Trustee in 2003. He was a generous Library supporter and strongly committed advocate. We offer our deep sympathies to all of his family and friends. Neil L. Rudenstine, Chairman; Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti; Anthony W. Marx, President
GREENBERG--Alan "Ace". You taught me about more than just the Market. Everything I have I owe to you. You were one of a kind. Thanks from one of your "PSD" grads. Ed Gutman
GREENBERG--Alan C. September 3, 1927 - July 25, 2014, Service Tuesday 11am at Temple Emanuel-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.
GOLDBERG--Richard. Enduring memories created by a wonderful friend. He will be missed. Rhoda and Richard Klein

GITLOW--Abraham L. NYU and its Leonard N. Stern School of Business deeply mourn the loss of its visionary Dean Emeritus, Abe Gitlow. A remarkable teacher, charismatic leader, and prolific author, during his 40 years of service Abe Gitlow was a principal architect of the stature and renown the Stern School enjoys today. He first joined the NYU School of Commerce, as it was then known, as a faculty member in 1947 after service in the Air Force. In two outstanding decades as dean, beginning in 1965, the School grew into a highly diversified institution with an international reputation for excellence in academic research and teaching through his emphasis on recruiting top faculty. And he ensured the School had a proud and fitting academic home -- Tisch Hall. Active even in retirement, Gitlow was a tireless supporter of NYU Stern, meeting with alumni, attending alumni conferences and gatherings, and setting an example of generosity and engagement for generations of students and alumni. A man of boundless optimism and energy, a cherished University citizen, and a wonderful colleague, Abe personified "the School of Opportunity," and transformed the School and the lives of generations of students. He will be greatly missed. His family and loved ones are in our thoughts and our hearts; we want them to know his spirit will live on in NYU's memory and in the great school he served with such distinction and devotion and did so much to build. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees William Berkley, Chair-elect, NYU Board of Trustees, and Chair of the Stern Board of Overseers John Sexton, NYU President Peter Blair Henry, Dean, Leonard N. Stern School of Business

FUCHS--Frank.(December 16, 1947 July 19, 2014). Our oldest and dearest friend passed away on July 19th. Raised in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn by his mother, he was the kindest and friendliest of souls. We spent our summers together at Raquette Lake and Indian Hill Music and Arts Camp. Frank attended Elizabeth Irwin High School, the class of '65. He moved to Los Angeles in '91, working as a songwriter and producer. Frank produced both "Woody's 20 Grow Big Songs" and "Daddy O Daddy" highlighting his loving relationship with the Guthrie family. When you have spent a lifetime together as we have, it is impossible to say "goodbye". Instead, we will continue to pass down all the stories to our kids, to sing all those Everly Brothers songs, and to love you. -Arlo, Joady, and Nora Guthrie

FITTS--Peter C.,April 30, 1940 - July 16, 2014. Impeccably honest, always respected international banker and protector of credit standards; member of the Citibank and Fleet executive diaspora. Mischievous son of the late Howard P. and Katharine G. Fitts, of Wellesley, MA. Williams College, Class of 1962; MBA Babson. Brilliantly funny, irascible but irreplaceable husband and beloved Rock of Gibraltar for Colleen Kaftan, his wife of 22 years. Father and challenging role model for Jeff (Leslie), Catharine (Derik Keel), and Alan. Grandpa of Sara, Jessie, and Michael. Also survived by ex-wives Candida Fitts and Anne Strauss. Lifelong lover of dogs and cats, beautiful spaces, intellectual challenges, unfamiliar cultures, and his haven in Williamstown, MA. Our deepest appreciation to the wonderful people at Genesis Keene Center, NH, for taking such good care of him and making his final months so very fulfilling. Rest in peace, PCF.

FEIN--Sidney, 74, on July 24. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Dr Sidney Fein, loving husband to Evelyne and brother to Sheldon. Born in Brooklyn to Samuel and Golda. He took immense pride in his career of psychiatry; caring for patients at his private practices in Park Slope and Bayside and at Methodist Hospital. He will always be remembered for his great kindness and concern to all those around him. The Knicks have lost their greatest fan. Funeral services: Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. Sunday, July 27, 1pm.
EGGINTON--Geoffery. The Colgate Boys of Summer have sadly lost one of their charter members. Geoff, keep hitting 'em straight. Love Sacha, Dickie & Jimmy
DREXLER--Sherman, 88, whose career as a painter covered more than 50 years. He was a brilliant conversationalist and loyal friend. He leaves behind his wife Rosalyn and son Dan.

D'AMATO--Brenda, on July 24, 2014 of Plandome Manor. Visitation will be held at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Tuesday from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday 11:15am, St. Mary's Church, Manhasset with Interment to follow at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY.
D'ALTON--Martina. December 22, 1946 to July 23, 2014. Editor, writer, artist. Author of The New York Obelisk (Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1993).

COHN--Harvey. Fellow of the American Mathematical Society and member of the Society since 1942, died on May 16 at the age of 90. He was a brilliant Mathematician, an adoring husband, father and grandfather, and faithful friend and mentor to his colleagues and students. Born in New York City in 1923, Cohn received his B.S. degree (Mathematics and Physics) from CCNY in 1942. He received his M.S. degree from NYU (1943), and his Ph.D. from Harvard (1948) after service in the Navy (Electronic Technicians Mate, 1944-46). He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa (Sigma Chi), won the William Lowell Putnam Prize in 1942, and was awarded the Townsend Harris Medal in 1972. A pioneer in the intensive use of computers in an innovative way in a large number of classical mathematical problems, Harvey Cohn held faculty positions at Wayne State University, Stanford, Washington University Saint Louis (first Director of the Computing Center 1956-58), University of Arizona (Chairman 1958-1967), University of Copenhagen, and CCNY (Distinguished Professor of Mathematics). After his retirement from teaching, he worked in a variety of capacities for the National Security Agency and its research arm, IDA Center for Computing Sciences. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Bernice, of Laguna Woods, California and Ft. Lauderdale, FL, his son Anthony, daughter Susan Cohn Boros, three grandchildren and one great-granddaughter.

CHASE--Major Hollis H.,of Harrison, NY, aged 98, died July 22 while vacationing in Switzerland. Beloved father of Kenneth H. Chase of New York City, brother of Wilbur P. Chase of Maryland, and uncle of four. Born 1916 in NYC, Hollis flew a B-24 in the Pacific in WWII, receiving two distinguished flying crosses. With a BS from Ohio State University and an MBA from NYU, he became a CPA. Onetime General Auditor of General Foods Corporation, he completed his career at NYU. For nearly 30 years, he has resided at the Westchester Country Club with his beloved wife, Beverly Seaman, who died in 2011. Service arrangements to be announced.

CERTO--Louis. The BBH Old Boys and Girls mourn the passing of Lou Certo, Senior Partners' Hallman, Retired. Born in Staten Island, New York on October 10, 1938, died in Waynesboro, Virginia on July 4, 2014. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Edna, his sons John, Mark, Steven and their families.
CANOLESIO--Paul E.,died July 22, 2014 at home in Auburn, NY after a five year battle with kidney cancer. Kathleen Fedor, companion of 32 years, was at his side.
BONOMO--Rosakate. Died on July 22, 2014. Born November 21, 1928. Sister, mother, educator in NYC Schools. Mother to Andrew (deceased 2001) and George Dellon. Grandmother to four boys.

BENSON--Elena V. "Helen," on July 22 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Robert E. Cherished mother of Elena Ganzenmuller (Peter), William M.(Sara), David P. (Lorimer Burns). Predeceased by children Christine Pell and Robert E. Jr. Loving grandmother of ten and great-grandmother of ten. Graduate of Adelphi University. She was an avid bridge player and enjoyed reading the Bridge columns from many newspapers. Funeral services private. Memorial gifts may be made to the Glen Cove Boys and Girls Club, 113, Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Cove, NY 11542.

BARNETT--Bill M.,83, having recently relocated to Ann Arbor from Fort Worth, died on July 23 from complications of Alzheimer's. Everyone in the family was surprised to learn from all of his caregivers that he was a tall man. With a brilliant mind and a sharp wit Bill was a leader in college textbook publishing at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and was widely respected and deeply admired as a friend, colleague, manager, and advisor. He leaves behind his loving and adored wife Amy, his devoted daughter Donna Satin, son-in-law Les Satin, and two wonderful grandsons, Jake and Max Satin. Bill will be greatly missed by his many friends and associates. Donations may be made to St. Joseph Mercy Hospice at stjoesannarbor.org.

BARASH--Mary A.,on July 18, 2014, of Longboat Key, FL. Loving and devoted wife of Dr. Ira M. Barash for 57 years. Mary is survived by her adoring husband, four children and their spouses: Faith (Richard McManus), Louisa (Scott David), Andrea (Dite Van Clief) and David (Rachel), and loving grandchildren: Lucas, Callan, Sarah, and Zachary. Her family and friends will greatly miss her. Donations can be made to the Longboat Library, 555 Bay Isle Rd, Longboat Key, FL 34228 or to the American Heart & Lung Association.

ALPER--Norman, 84 years, passed away after a courageous battle with Alzheimer's on Friday, July 25, 2014. Survived by his beloved wife, Francine. Loving father of Daniel, Robert, Tish Richard and Jodi Freed. Adored grandfather of Lily, Ethan, Genny, David, Joshua and Olivia. Beloved brother of Mel Alper. Memorial donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. Services will be held Sunday, July 27, 2014 at the Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills at 11:30am.

WIENER--Roslyn Joy. It is with great sorrow that we announce the passing of Roslyn Joy Wiener on July 25th, 2014. Daughter of the late Harry and Milly Radutzky, stepdaughter of Pat Radutzky, wife of the late Mark Wiener for 37 years, loved sister of Ellen (Giorgio), adored mother of Sandy (Michele) and Amy (Dean) and grandmother of Madeleine, Jacob, Vivienne and Sienna. Rozzie enriched the lives of everyone she touched. Her dedication to social action was a lifelong passion with 30 years of volunteering at North Shore Hospital and 20 years as Co-Chair of The Black-Jewish Dialogue between Mt. Olive Baptist Church and Temple Beth-El. Funeral services will be held on Monday, July 28, 2014 at 1pm at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck with interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Donations can be made to The Hospital for Special Surgery, Department of Rheumatology or Temple Beth-El of Great Neck.

RIEGEL--William Murchie. William Murchie Riegel, of Duxbury, MA and Scottsdale, AZ, passed away July 20, 2014. Born January 25, 1928 in New York City to John Lawrence Riegel and Margaret Murchie Riegel, Bill was a graduate of Deerfield Academy ('46) and Williams College ('50), and he served as a Naval officer in the 6th fleet from 1952 until 1955. Mr. Riegel began his career in the paper, packaging and forest products industry at the Riegel Paper Company in Riegelsville, PA, which was founded by his great-grandfather John Leidy Riegel, eventually rising to become Executive Vice President. He was President of Riegel Products Corporation and went on to become Chairman of the Board, as well as Executive Vice President of Southwest Forest Industries, Inc. in Phoenix, AZ, and President of Amax Forest Products, Inc. in Greenwich, CT. He later founded Riegel Associates, a management and consulting firm based in Duxbury, MA and served as Chairman of the Board of the Bryce Corporation in Memphis, TN. Mr. Riegel served on various boards associated with the paper industry and in his retirement, was a Director of both the Historic Winslow House in Marshfield, MA and the Manomet Center for the Conservation Sciences in Manomet, MA. He was a member of the Duxbury Yacht Club and Paradise Valley Country Club. Mr. Riegel was married to Susan Richards before separating in 1967. Mr. Riegel is survived by his wife of 44 years, Nancy Bailey (Nickerson) Riegel, children William Murchie Riegel, Jr., Guy Richards Riegel, Katherine McMartin Riegel Schobert, Margaret Winslow Riegel Steinbock, and step-children Elizabeth Nickerson Seltzer and Joshua Bailey Nickerson, as well as 15 grandchildren. The burial will be private. A memorial service is planned for Saturday, August 16th at 3:00pm at St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church in Duxbury. Contributions in lieu of flowers, can be made to The Historic Winslow House (634 Careswell St., Marshfield MA 02050) or the Manomet Center for Conservation Sciences (125 Manomet Point Road, Plymouth, MA 02360).
RADOW--Ruth, January 31, 1926 to July 23, 2014. Loving wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Thank you for the life you gave us. The Willensky Family

MAZZOLA--John. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts mourn the passing of John Mazzola, who served as President of Lincoln Center from 1977 through 1982, as well as in a number of executive positions at the performing arts center beginning in 1964. A passionate supporter of increasing accessibility to the arts, Mazzola was deeply involved with the Mostly Mozart Festival, Live From Lincoln Center on PBS, and other key initiatives during their formative years. We extend our deepest sympathies to his widow, Sylvia, and to his family and friends. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

MAZZOLA--John W.,who led Lincoln Center for The Performing Arts for twenty years, passed away on Thursday, July 24, 2014 in New York City. He was 86. A lawyer with the firm of Millbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy, he joined Lincoln Center in 1962 and became its chief executive officer in 1968. Mr. Mazzola skillfully steered the expansion of Lincoln Center and its programs, providing access to high quality performing arts to a city depressed by financial hardship. He passionately increased accessibility to the arts through public and televised concerts. Above all, his family was his overriding theme and connection. As noted in an article written by George Sturm for the Music Associates of America, "(i)t is as if the communion with his wife Sylvia and daughters Alison and Amy(was) constantly recharging his battery, making it possible for him to make vital, productive and imaginative connections among the countless details of his daily labors." He was decorated Cavaliere Ufficiale Ordine al Merito della Repubblica Italiana and Officer Ordre des Arts et des Lettres France. He was a member of The Misquamicut Club (Rhode Island). He was born and raised in Bayonne, New Jersey and was a graduate of Tufts University (1949) and the Fordham Law School (1952). He served in the Air Force USN 45-46 and in Japan with the CIC-US Army 53-55. Mr. Mazzola is survived by his wife Sylvia (Drulie), a former theatrical producer, daughter Alison Mazzola, sister Jane Sharkey, son-in-law Terence "Tad" Flynn, and beloved grandchildren James Davis Flynn and Christina Pleasant Flynn. He was predeceased by his daughter Amy Mazzola Flynn. He will be remembered for his wry wit, storytelling, his love of cooking and entertaining. He loved sailing and the East Beach. Visitation will be held Monday, July 28 from 2:00pm to 6:00pm at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Avenue. A Funeral Service will be held on Tuesday, July 29 at 10:30am at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, where he served as an usher for many years. The family asks that donations be made to The Brearley School-Amy Mazzola Flynn Fund, 610 E. 83rd St. New York, NY 10028.

LIPSCHITZ--Lou. New Alternatives for Children mourns the passing or our beloved Treasurer. Lou was an early and devoted supporter of our agency. His skilled financial leadership helped us grow as we navigated the complex child welfare system. His passion, optimism and wisdom will be sorely missed by the entire NAC family. KOVAR--Lillian Cohen, 95, on July 17, 2014. Sociologist and professor emerita, Bronx Community College. Wife of late Leo Kovar, mother of Naomi, Joshua and Rachel, sister of Sylvia Cohen, grandmother of Eli. Memorial scheduled late summer.

KAUFMAN--Bel. The Town Hall mourns the passing of a great author, unique artists and friend who died this past weekend at 103 years young. Bel Kaufman has been a long standing member of Town Hall's Arts In Education Advisory Board and a supporter of the hall. Our deepest sympathy goes out to her family, friends and all who loved this great women. The Trustees and Staff of the Town Hall Foundation.

KAUFMAN--Bel. In loving memory of our aunt and great-aunt Bel Kaufman, who captivated us with her presence, her exuberant sense of style, and her insistence that she was too busy to get old. A magnet for other people, she held court when she had company glamorous, graceful, witty, funny and kind. She scoffed at life when it didn't go her way and danced with verve through all the rest. She is missed. Kenneth, Linda, Kara and David Kaufman

KAUFMAN--Bel. As the only sibling of Bel Kaufman, I mourn the death of my remarkable sister, who died of natural causes in her New York apartment on July 25 at the age of 103. She is survived by two children, Thea and Jonathan Goldstine, by a granddaughter, Susan Goldstine, and by her husband of more than forty years, Sidney Gluck. She is also survived by my own children, Kenneth and Keith Kaufman, and by my grandchildren Kara, David, and Rachel. Bel and I emigrated to America from Russia with our family in 1922, when Bel was eleven years old. She used to say that she learned to speak English by osmosis, or at least enough to receive her B.A., Magna Cum Laude, from Hunter College and her M.A. with first honors from Columbia University. Our grandfather was the famed and much-beloved author-humorist Sholom Aleichem, whose Tevye stories inspired the Broadway musical "Fiddler on the Roof." I've known my wonderful sister for all of my 94 years. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for any donations in Bel's memory to: Yivo Institute for Jewish Research, 15 West 16th St., NY, NY 10011, www.yivo.org; National Yiddish Theatre-Folksbiene, 90 John St. #
