ZARROW--Herbert S. December 25, 1919 - July 29, 2012 It's been two years, we miss you more each day. Gabrielle and Larry

WICKENS--Elaine Margolis. Peacefully at 84 in Santa Fe, New Mexico on July 19, 2014. Faculty member of Bankstreet College and Children's School for 30 years. Photographer, children's book writer, activist, she is survived by a life-long friend, Marc Siegel, of New York City, a host of devoted friends in Northern New Mexico and New York, and loving new generations of the Margolis family in the US and Brazil.

SUBIN--Alvin, our beloved father and G-Pa, died peacefully surrounded by his loving family on Saturday. For 93 years, he lived a storybook life. Ruth was his treasured wife for 66 years. With her in his heart, he served in the Pacific during WWII. With her by his side, they explored the world. He was a consummate businessman, meticulous and successful as the founder of Cotillion Formals and later the Maywood Tennis Club. The devoted father of Mary, Barbara, and Nancy and adored by his family, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren, he will be dearly remembered and always loved.

SUPINO--Jane Brill, passed away peacefully on July 26th surrounded by her family. Beloved mother of Eric Cohler and Jennifer Cohler Mason, sister of David H. Brill, Jr., devoted grandmother to Andrew and Colin, mother-in-law to Alan and loving friend to many. Jane was born in Chicago in 1934 to Marguerite and David Harris Brill, an attorney who served in President Dwight D. Eisenhower's administration. Jane's life journey took her from majoring in art at the University of Michigan, to practicing interior design in New York City, to graduating with a master's degree in social work from Hunter College. Jane later obtained analytical training, practicing as a psychotherapist for more than 30 years. A passionate patron of the arts and indefatigable traveler, Jane ventured the world from Azerbaijan to Timbuktu. A memorial service in celebration of a life well lived will be held at Manhattan's Unitarian Church of All Souls on Lexington Avenue, Thursday July 31st at 2pm. In lieu of flowers please send donations in her name to the Central Park Conservancy.

SCHNABEL--Donald. The Board of Directors and Staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center note with great sadness the passing of Donald Schnabel, an esteemed and valued member of our Board since 1987. Don played a key role in the Rose Building Campaign which provided state-of-the-art rehearsal and office facilities for the Society. He loved chamber music and his insight, guidance, and generosity will be long remembered and appreciated. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Xiaowei and family. Jim O'Shaughnessy, Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han, Artistic Directors Suzanne Davidson, Executive Director

SCHIFF--Morton Irwin, loving husband to Toby; sister to Susan Feiler; father to Nancy and Deborah; and grandfather to Matthew, Scott, and Eric, died on July 26 at age 79 of heart failure. He was predeceased by his father Milton and his mother Gertrude. Morton was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 1, 1935. He received his B.S. in Civil Engineering from CUNY, his M.A. in Mechanical Engineering from Brooklyn Polytechnic, and his M.B.A from Fairleigh Dickinson. He was Vice President of Special Products at IAC until 1998. Funeral Services will be held on Tuesday July 29, 2014, 11am at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State St, Spring Valley, NY. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Memorial contributions in Morton's memory should be made to Leukemia Lymphoma Society or American Heart Association.

OSSERMAN--Nancy Moses, of Mamaroneck, passed on July 26, 2014, age 87. Daughter of the late Henry and Lucy (Goldschmidt) Moses. Survived by her children: Georgette, Dede, Kermit, Julliet, Susie, Henry and predeceased by son, Barney. Grandmother of nine; great-grandmother of four. Funeral Service is Wednesday, 12 noon, Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road. Mamaroneck, NY, 914-381-1809. Interment: Salem Fields Cemetery.

McENIRY--Catherine M.,94. Died July 22, 2014, in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Wife for 60 years of the late Murray W. McEniry. Mother of Philip L., David W., and Roger S. McEniry and Catherine E.M. Sullivan. Mother-in-law of Carolyn Acosta and David E. Sullivan and former mother-in-law of Courtney Johnson McEniry; she leaves also Roger's partner Karen P. Riley. Grandmother of Tessa, Grace, Andrew and Eloise McEniry and of John, Thomas, and Peter Sullivan. Survived also by her nephew Mark Altherr and his wife Gloria and her niece Anne Templeton and her husband Peter. Great-aunt of Isabella, Andre, and Sofia Altherr and John and William Templeton. Daughter of the late John J. McPolan and Florence Maurer McPolan, sister of the late Virginia McPolan Altherr and John J. McPolan, Jr., sister-in-law of the late Andre Altherr, and aunt of the late Roland Altherr. Graduate of Barnard College, Class of 1939, and Columbia Law School, Class of 1942. Resident of Scarsdale, New York for more than 50 years; resident of Cambridge for the last 7++ years. Memorial private. Contributions in her memory may be made to: Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic Inc., 4 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, N.Y. 10532-2143 or National Stroke Association, 9707 E Easter Lane Suite B, Centennial, CO 80112.

MAZZOLA--John. The Board and Staff of the Princess Grace Foundation-USA mourn the passing of John Mazzola, who served as the Arts Advisory Board Chair from 1984 through 1989. He was integral in creating the Princess Grace Awards program that supports emerging artists nationwide, and we are thankful for his vision. Everyone at the Foundation extends deepest sympathies to his family.

LEE--Stanley L.,July 27 (a month shy of 95), at home in Manhattan. Beloved husband of the late Ann R. Lee. Dear father of Nancy (Gordon Johnson), Ted (Deborah), and Ken (Muriel). Grandfather of Seth and Toby Johnson; Matthew, Anna, Jamie, and Nina Lee; and Sam and Noah Lee. Great-grandfather of Malachi. A hematologist deeply engaged in teaching, research and patient care, he left private practice in 1959 to become first director of Maimonides Hospital's hematology division in 1959. After a detour into administration (director of medicine at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, dean and acting president of SUNY Downstate Medical School), he returned to teaching house staff and hematology fellows as director of hematology/ oncology at Brookdale Hospital, and, after retirement, continued teaching at Methodist Hospital, Maimonides, and LICH, in Brooklyn. During and after World War II, Dr. Lee served in US army as a medical officer in the Pacific and Japan. Memorial at a later date.

LANG--Gertrude, died at home on July 27th at age 97. A graduate of Cooper Union, consummate artist, she worked and traveled widely -Macy's sales clerk, WWII draftswoman, red diaper mother, teacher and director at North Shore Community Arts Center, founder of Students Abroad, AARP cover girl. Her beloved husband, Sheldon Lang, died in 1953. Loved and missed by her children, Jo of Manhattan, Peter (Katherine Lapierre) of Cambridge, MA; grandchildren Daniel and Emma Lang, David (Sara) and Debra Wolkenfeld; step-grandson Daniel Wolkenfeld; great-grandchildren Noam, Akiva, Hillel and Sophie Wolkenfeld; cousins, nieces, nephews and all who know her. Funeral 11:15am Tuesday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam.

KANE--Gloria B.,of Plainview, NY on July 27, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Loving wife and best friend of the late Gerald. Gloria was the loving mother of Linda Kane, Barbara Kane and Larry Wittenberg, and cherished and devoted grandmother of David and Ariel Wittenberg, Alexandra Kane Rudansky and Julia Rudansky. Donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center for breast cancer research.

IMBLEAU--Valerie, a retired RN of Canaan, CT, left this world for the next on July 23, 2014. She leaves behind her beloved sister, Yvonne Imbleau, M.D., of Salisbury, CT; her adoring Jack Russell companion, Moxie, and her extended family of friends. A Mass of Christian Burial was held at Saint Mary's Church, 76 Sharon Road, Lakeville, CT 06039, on Saturday, July 26. Memorial contributions may be made to The Kildonan School, 425 Morse Hill Rd, Amenia, NY 12501 or to AIDS Walk New York, 446 West 33rd St, 6th floor, New York NY 1000. For a full obituary, please visit: www.kennyfuneralhomes.com The Kenny Funeral Homes of Sharon, CT has care of services.

GRUMAN--Jessie. The Board of Directors of the Nathaniel Wharton Fund mourns the loss of Dr. Jessie Gruman, our respected colleague and friend, and the devoted and beloved wife of our long-time Board member, Dr. Richard Sloan. As founder and president of the Center for Advancing Health, a nonprofit health policy organization, Dr. Gruman brought intelligence, fine judgment, and unstinting vigor to the cause of patient advocacy. As a result of her own battles with cancer, she was resolute in examining the complicated factors that affect how people act with regard to their health and health care, and in focusing on helping patients to be empowered and engaged in their own care. Our thoughts are with her cherished Richard and all of Jessie's loving family members and friends. Ralph N. Wharton, M.D. Executive Director

GREENBERG--Alan "Ace." Aside from your market savvy you taught me good from bad, right from wrong, and to return phone calls promptly! I learned how to be a "customer's man" from you one of my best mentors! You instilled in me that the more you give the more you get! How true. At Bear Stearns you were the person who gave guys like me the opportunity to thrive as a "PSD." Thank you for all - especially our friendship. Shelley Bergman

GREENBERG--Alan C.,The New York Police and Fire Widow's and Children's Benefit Fund mourns the passing of Alan "Ace" Greenberg. Ace was a true friend and a generous supporter of our organization for over three decades. He was our 1993 Honoree and then he continued to serve as a valued member of our Honorary Board. Chairman Stephen J. Dannhauser added, "Ace never hesitated to answer the call for the families of our fallen first responders. He will be greatly missed by everyone at our organization and by all who knew him." We send our sincerest condolences to his family and friends.
GREENBERG--Alan "Ace". You taught me about more than just the Market. Everything I have I owe to you. You were one of a kind. Thanks from one of your "PSD" grads. Ed Gutman

GREENBERG--Alan C.,The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Alan Greenberg, a dedicated supporter of WCS and the Bronx Zoo across several decades. Mr. Greenberg will be remembered for his generous contributions with his wife Kathy to some of the Bronx Zoo's most beloved exhibits, including the Congo Gorilla Forest, Madagascar! and Tiger Mountain. The renovation of the former Bronx Zoo Lion House with the Greenbergs' support led to the first landmarked building in New York City to receive a gold LEED rating. WCS extends its deepest sympathies to Mrs. Greenberg, Alan's children Ted and Lynne, and the rest of Mr. Greenberg's friends and family.

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Raoul Wallenberg Committee of the United States mourns the death of its Chairman Emeritus and the fervent champion of Raoul Wallenberg. His chairmanship was like no other, and we continue to benefit from his leadership. Our condolences to Kathy; Lynn and her family; and to Ted. Alan was so courageous; we shall miss him. Rachel Oestreicher Bernheim, Chairman and The Board of Directors of The Raoul Wallenberg Committee of the United States

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Harmonie Club mourns the death of Alan C. Greenberg, an honored member of our Club for over 60 years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family in this difficult time. Services are 11:00am Tuesday July 29 at Temple Emanuel. Philip R. Cowen, President, The Harmonie Club

GREENBERG--Alan "Ace". A true pioneer, visionary, role model, mentor and trusted friend. Your compassion and fierce loyalty to your friends was genuine, and we all felt it. We will miss your smile, your sense of humor and most of all your friendship. Pal- you left your mark permanently in our hearts. Our deepest condolences to Kathy and the entire Greenberg family. Michele and Steven Sweetwood

GREENBERG--Alan. Our hero. No one had greater enthusiasm, courage, loyalty, and generosity. You were tremendous in every way, and it was our privilege to be your friend. Our love and deepest condolences to Kathy and the family. Jeanne and Herb Siegel

GREENBERG--Alan C. Ace Greenberg was a dear friend. I mourn the loss of this wonderful man who contributed so much, not only to The New York Public Library where he was a Trustee, but to myriad local and national institutions. Ace was a generous man and a great philanthropist. My deepest condolences to dear Kathy and the entire Greenberg family. Vartan Gregorian, President, Carnegie Corporation of New York; Former President, The New York Public Library

GREENBERG--Alan C. The Jerusalem Foundation deeply mourns the passing of Alan "Ace" Greenberg, a devoted friend and benefactor of Jerusalem and former board member. His generous spirit will forever live on in the projects he and his family brought to life. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Kathy, and the entire Greenberg and Koeppel families. Ruth Cheshin, Emeritus Pres. Mark Sofer, President Sallai Meridor, Int'l Chairman Alan G. Hassenfeld, Chairman

GREENBERG--Alan. Seventy years ago there formed a friendship that has been one of the wonderful events of my life. I tried to give as good as I got. You were the best and I will forever think of you and treasure our time together. Alvin "Russian" Einbender

GREENBERG--Alan. Thanks To Scandinavia mourns the passing of Alan "Ace" Greenberg, our longstanding supporter and friend. Ace established an annual scholarship at the University of Oklahoma commemorating the heroic rescue of Jews during World War II. For over 30 years, The Ted H. Greenberg Memorial Scholarship has been a living and breathing tribute. We extend our deepest condolences to Kathy and his entire family. Laurie Netter Sprayregen, President
GREENBERG--Alan C. September 3, 1927 - July 25, 2014, Service Tuesday 11am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

FREEMAN--William G.,Jr., 84, died peacefully on July 26, 2014 at his home in Mountain Lake, Lake Wales, Florida. He was born in Greenwich, Connecticut to William Goodell Freeman and Mary Fahnestock Freeman, and attended Brunswick School through ninth grade. He graduated from Phillips Academy Andover in 1948 and received his BA from Yale in 1952. While at Andover and Yale, Bill made many lifelong friends whom he cherished. Following two years in the U.S. Air Force, where he was honorably discharged as a First Lieutenant, he was employed by Texaco, working in several positions including General Manager of Marketing, Europe. A highlight of his long career with Texaco was when Bill, his wife Ruth, and their three daughters lived in Puerto Rico and Jamaica. After leaving the Caribbean in 1970, the family settled in New Canaan, Connecticut. Following his retirement from Texaco in 1988, Bill taught and coached ice hockey at Brunswick School for three years. He was an avid gardener and fisherman, coached ice hockey at the New Canaan Winter Club, and served on the Board there. A member of the Country Club of New Canaan, Bill was an enthusiastic golfer, playing as much as possible at his Florida residence, where he also served on the Board. He was a dedicated member of the Musketeers and the United States Seniors' Golf Association. Bill loved his family dearly, and will be greatly missed. Surviving are his wife Ruth of 60 years, three daughters, Ruth, Ann, and Carol, two grandsons, Stephen Schoder and William Schoder, a sister Mary Blackwell, and a brother James Freeman. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 4, 2014 at St. Mark's Church, New Canaan, CT. Memorial gifts may be sent to: Mountain Lake Community Service, PO Box 832, Lake Wales, FL, 33859.

DUELL--Irene on July 27, 2014. Beloved wife of Jonathan De Sola Mendes; loving mother of Thea and Benjamin Duell. Funeral service: Wednesday, July 30, 2014, 10am at Park Avenue Synagogue, Madison Avenue and East 87th Street.

BERGONZI--Carlo. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Carlo Bergonzi, who sang more than 320 starring roles with the company in a Met career that spanned 32 years. He made his company debut in 1956 as Radames in Verdi's Aida and sang his last Met performance, of Edgardo in Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor, in 1988. He made his final appearance with the company in 1996, when he sang an aria from Verdi's Luisa Miller at a gala celebrating James Levine's 25th anniversary. He sang a total of 22 roles at the Met, 10 of them in the Verdi operas for which he was best known, and was particularly praised for the beauty and warmth of his singing and for his elegant attention to style and phrasing. We offer our sincerest condolences to his family, friends, and many admirers around the world. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director
BERGONZI--Carlo. A kiss, another kiss and yet another kiss. Rabbi Saul Wohlberg, Haverstraw, NY

BASHEIN--Harriet, nee Glasberg died July 27 in the Hebrew Rehabilitation Center, Roslindale MA at age 99 of Alzheimer's disease. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel, she is survived by her son Jonathan and his wife Gail of Foxboro, MA and daughter Ellen Wolf of Forest Hills, her grandchildren Joshua Wolf and his wife Sheva, Ben Bashein and his husband Christian Langbein, Rebecca Wolf, David Bashein and his wife Liz, Jacob, Sarah and Rachel Bashein, and great grandchildren, Zane and Evrett Wolf. Harriet, a long time resident of Forest Hills, was a lifetime member of the National Council of Jewish Women. She served multiple terms as the Pres. of the Forest Hills Chapter. She adored symphony and opera. Services Tuesday, July 29 at 2:00 P.M. Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the National Council of Jewish Women.

ARNOLD--William Irvin, 89, born in St. Marys, PA, died peacefully on July 21, 2014 at his home in Ossining, NY. He served in the Infantry in Europe in 1944 and 1945 where he received four battle stars and a Purple Heart. He entered Harvard in 1946, graduating in three years, and joined Turner Construction Co. in 1953, managing projects, including Corporate Headquarters for American Can, General Electric, and AT&T Long Lines. When he retired in 1990 he was their Chief Engineer. In 1956 he married Marijean Clark. In 1963 they moved to an old Ossining, NY farmhouse. Marijean died in 2012 having been married 55 years. Together their primary volunteer work was with Teatown Lake Reservation from its inception, and the Saw Mill River Audubon. He is survived by three children; William C., David W., and Susan E., daughter-in-law Lynne, five grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Memorial services will be private.

WITENKO--Barbara. Girlfriend Happy Birthday. Miss you like crazy. Love, Diana

VENNEMA--Carey, died peacefully in his home in the West Village on July 24, 2014, surrounded by his family. He was born March 18, 1921 to Mildred Carey and Augustus Whiton Vennema in Passaic, NJ. He attended the Passaic Collegiate School, graduated from The Choate School and Amherst College in the Class of 1943. He received his JD from New York University in 1958. He was a veteran of World War II, having trained in the French-speaking Cryptologic Unit of the US Army. During Law School, he met Mary Holly Webb, then a student at Union Theological Seminary, and the two married in 1956 and raised four children in Greenwich Village. His most meaningful life's work was spent fighting to preserve the architecture and character of his beloved Greenwich Village through his involvement with Save the Village, the Committee for Artist Housing and Community Board 2 as well as his work for the Town of Swans Island, Maine by drafting the first Shoreline Ordinance and Clam Ordinance. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Holly, children Amy Vennema and Betsy Humes of Park Slope, Brooklyn, Willa Vennema of Portland, Maine, and Kenneth Vennema of Sugar Land, Texas, ten grandchildren and an extended family of loving in-laws. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made to the Elder Care Outreach of Swans Island c/o Donna Wiegel.

Devoted father of Ira (Allyn) and Mark (Candy); precious poppa of Erin and Leigh Minsky, Randi and Scott Alper, Jared and Riki Udell, Scott and Jessica Udell and Zachary Udell; adored great-grandpoppa of Alexander, Avery and Austin Minsky, Sienna Alper and Blake Udell. The family would appreciate donations in his memory to Congregation Tifereth Israel or University of Arkansas Myeloma Center, www.myeloma.uams.edu or 501-526-2873 or Siegel Multiple Myeloma Fund, edonald@hackensackUMC.org or 551-996-3720

SUPINO--Jane Brill, passed away peacefully on July 26th surrounded by her family. Beloved mother of Eric Cohler and Jennifer Cohler Mason, sister of David H. Brill, Jr., devoted grandmother to Andrew and Colin, mother-in-law to Alan and loving friend to many. Jane was born in Chicago in 1934 to Marguerite and David Harris Brill, an attorney who served in President Dwight D. Eisenhower's administration. Jane's life journey took her from majoring in art at the University of Michigan, to practicing interior design in New York City, to graduating with a master's degree in social work from Hunter College. Jane later obtained analytical training, practicing as a psychotherapist for more than 30 years. A passionate patron of the arts and indefatigable traveler, Jane ventured the world from Azerbaijan to Timbuktu. A memorial service in celebration of a life well lived will be held at Manhattan's Unitarian Church of All Souls on Lexington Avenue, Thursday July 31st at 2pm. In lieu of flowers please send donations in her name to the Central Park Conservancy.

PERLMUTTER--Sylvia, 91, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, aunt, mentor, friend, passed away peacefully on July 25. She is survived by her daughters Alarra (Bette), Chelscee (Lisa); sons-in-law Peter and Fuad (Phillip); grandchildren Ariel, Channing, Samuel, Alexandra, Anna and great-grandchild Teddy. She was an interior designer, travel agent, art dealer and world traveler who loved life passionately. Her generosity and love for family and friends was boundless. Funeral services: July 30, at 12 noon at Temple Sinai of Roslyn, Long Island.

AMSTERDAM--Erica Lemle. The attorneys and staff of Amsterdam & Lewinter, LLP, express their deepest sympathies to our founding partner Mark Lemle Amsterdam, his children Lauren and Matt, his brother John and sister Cathy and the entire Amsterdam family.

AMSTERDAM--Erica Lemle, of Hewlett Harbor, and Sanibel, died peacefully following a wonderful life of 93 years. Loving mother, grandmother, and sister. Born in Berlin in 1921. Educated in Berlin, London, and Cooper Union after coming here in 1937. Well known interior designer as Erica Lemle, she decorated homes in the metropolitan area and abroad. Served on the board of NYSID, and recognized in Who's Who. An elegant lady, outstanding athlete. Member of the Seawane Club for 57 years. Her family came first and last and at all places in between. Predeceased by her adoring husband Leonard. Subsequently, in a wonderful relationship with Kurt Bernheim. Survived by her children Mark, John and Cathy (Joel Vogel), grandchildren Kimberly Sais, Lauren (Walter) and Matthew Amsterdam, Jenny and Andrew Vogel; sister Marion Ames (Walter), her "adopted family" Monica, Dan and Eli Gelb and Barry Wachsberger and her beloved friend, companion and care giver Elvin Herrera.

ABRONS--Mimi (Muriel) Mulwitz, died July 25th at the age of 83. Born and raised in Port Chester, NY, Mimi attended Fieldston through high school, and then Bard College for two years. She had a deep love of classical music, and was an extremely accomplished pianist, performing in numerous workshops. Fellow students often played for her before a recital, valuing her sensitive interpretation of the music. Mimi had a passion for language. She tutored the wives of Japanese businessmen in English, helping them with the difficult adjustment to a country and language about which they had little knowledge. This resulted in lifelong friendships that lasted well after the women had returned to Japan. Her marriage to Richard Abrons ended in divorce in 1983. Services will be held Thursday at 11:30am at Congregation Tifereth Israel, 40 Hill Street, Glen Cove, NY 11542. The family would appreciate donations in his memory to Congregation Tifereth Israel or University of Arkansas Myeloma Center, www.myeloma.uams.edu or 501-526-2873 or Siegel Multiple Myeloma Fund, edonald@hackensackUMC.org or 551-996-3720

SHAFMAN--Arthur, producer and talent manager who brought Mummenshanz to Broadway, and Red Skelton, Burl Ives and Hildegarde to Carnegie Hall, died July 28 of pancreatic cancer. He was 75. Shafman who made deals on a handshake, shepherded the careers of the silent (mimes Shields and Yarnell) and the singers (cabaret performers Michael Feinstein, Andrea Marcovicci, K.T. Sullivan, Mark Nadler, Karen Akers, Wesla Whitfield, Tammy Grimes, Heather MacRae and Sandra Reaves-Phillips among others). The only thing he worshipped more than talent was his wife, Jill Gordon Joseloff, who survives him as do his sister and brother-in-law Susan and Jack Balsam. A memorial will be held in September. Donations may be made to Broadway Cares, 165 W. 46th Street; NY, NY 10036.

SALTZMAN--Anita, 93, of Pompton Plains, NJ, died peacefully on July 29, 2014. Born in Brooklyn to Irene (Kaplan) and Irving Altman, she graduated from Brooklyn College and lived and worked in Washington, DC, where she met her husband Larry. They were married for over 60 years before his passing in 2011. Anita and Larry raised their family in Bethpage, NY. She and Larry later moved to New York City and then to Longboat Key, FL, where they lived for over 25 years before moving to New Jersey to be closer to family. Anita was an avid reader, writer and movie buff, and lover of classical and jazz music. She had an incredible gift for understanding people. She was a passionate advocate for children, and was especially proud of her volunteer work as an elementary school literacy tutor in Sarasota. Anita was an incredible and devoted grandmother, understanding and encouraging her grandchildren's unique talents and interests. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Edward and Mary Saltzman of New Vernon, NJ, daughter and son-in-law Emily and Stuart Rosen of Avon, CT, and grandchildren Jeffrey Rosen, Leah Rosen and Madeleine Saltzman. Donations may be made to The Eye Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc., www.eyedonation.org, or a charity of your choosing.

NADLER--Dr. Gerald, 90, passed away at his home on July 28, 2014. Professor Nadler was IBM Chair Emeritus in Engineering Management at the University of Southern California. Before his departmental chairmanship at USC, he was Chairman and Professor at the University of Wisconsin at Madison and at Washington University in St. Louis. He served as President of the Center for Breakthrough Thinking, Inc., an international management consulting firm of affiliates. Dr. Nadler has written over 200 published articles and 15 books, several of which have been translated into nine languages. Dr. Nadler is survived by his wife of 67 years, Elaine; his brother Melvin; and by his three children, Burton, Janice and Robert, as well as by his eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

MINNERS--Robert W.,89, died at the Southwestern Vermont Medical Center in Bennington, Vermont, on Monday, July 21, 2014 after a prolonged battle with Parkinson and leukemia. His devoted wife, Maria, was at his bedside. Born June 17, 1925 in New York, NY, he was the son of Florence Heuser and Walter Minners. Bob enlisted in the U.S. Army and served in the Japanese theatre. He was a graduate of Columbia University. In 1953 he founded Minners Design Inc. in New York City, which soon became known as the premier firm in the china, glass and silver area of the Hotel and Restaurant Industry. Throughout his life Bob was an avid skier and competitive tennis player. He was a charter member of the Stratton Mountain Country Club. He and his wife split their time between John's Island and Stratton Mountain with his last years spent in the serenity of their mountaintop Stratton home sustained by his caring and nurturing wife and bolstered by his wry wit and surprising courage. A private burial was held at the family plot in the Kenisco Cemetery, Valhalla, NY, on Wednesday July 23, 2014. A remembrance gathering for friends and family at Stratton will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to VNH of Vermont & New Hampshire, 66 Benning Street, #

KASS--Ann Ruth, 91 - July 29, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Edwin A. Kass. Adored sister of Elinor D. Alpern. In addition to her sister, she is survived by her many caring cousins and friends. She is and will always be greatly missed.

JAMESON--Virginia. Born Virginia V. Yannello in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, 1941. Died July 29th, 2014, Newtown, PA. Attended St. John Villa Academy, Staten Island. Beloved wife, mother and friend. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Dementia Society of America, PO Box 600, Doylestown, PA 18901 or www.dementiasociety.org.

JACOBS--Paul. Much beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Marci and Peter, father-in-law of LeeAnn and adored "Papa" of Alison, Melissa, Noah and Hailey, died peacefully on July 29th. We will miss his sense of humor and his genuine warmth. Interment today 1pm at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

HUNTER--Sam. The Jewish Museum mourns the passing of Sam Hunter, former director of the Museum (1965-1967) during highly influential exhibitions of such artists as Max Ernst, Philip Guston, Kenneth Noland, Ad Reinhardt, Larry Rivers, and the seminal survey, "Primary Structures: Younger American and British Sculptors." We send our heartfelt condolences to the Hunter family. Robert A. Pruzan, Chair Claudia Gould, Helen Goldsmith Menschel Director
FRIEDMAN--Bob. 7/25/39-7/31/13. Always in our hearts. Always in our thoughts. Sandy, Jane, Dennis, and Hannah

FARLEY--Mary K. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of Mary Kay Farley, a long-time supporter and friend, who served on our Board of Trustee from 1980 to 2008. In 2008, she became a Life Trustee and served on the Development Committee for many years. Her benevolence to the hospital spun out of her firsthand observation of its excellence in clinical care and research. Mrs. Farley's keen interest in orthopedics precipitated the dedication of The James D. Farley Family Laboratory for Connective Tissue Genetics, a primary site for scientific investigations on connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome. She was also a significant supporter of the David B. Levine MD Chair dedicated to scoliosis research. Through her generosity and steadfast service, Mrs. Farley played an important role in advancing our mission of providing the highest quality clinical care, research, education and community service. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, Surgeon-in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery

FAIR--Charles M.Charles M. Fair, 97, of Wakefield, Rhode Island, died July 28, 2014 at South County Hospital in Wakefield, of lymphoma. He was a multitalented man with a varied career: editor, poet, banana importer, computer-company executive, script writer/ narrator, historian, and neurology researcher at Massachusetts General Hospital. In 1963 he went as a Guggenheim Fellow to UCLA's Brain Research Institute, and the following year became a resident scientist in MIT's Neurosciences Research Program, one of the few to have held an appointment there with no academic degree. Mr. Fair published light verse in Punch and The New Yorker, book reviews in the Washington Post and The Providence Journal, and a regular column in the American Poetry Review. He authored three books on neuroscience, The Physical Foundations of the Psyche (Wesleyan University Press, 1963), Memory & Central Nervous Organization (Paragon House, 1988), and Cortical Memory Functions (Birkhauser, 1992); a number of papers on brain function; and three nontechnical books: The Dying Self (Wesleyan University Press, 1969), From The Jaws of Victory (Simon & Schuster, 1971), and The New Nonsense (Simon & Schuster, 1974). His books have been published in Britain and translated into Italian, German, and Danish. His creativity also included a lifelong love of jazz, and he played both piano and vibraphone. He loved sailing, the Red Sox, good conversation, and he even tried his hand at farming. He also wrote and narrated the soundtrack for the original Salem Witch Museum, in Salem, Massachusetts. The only child of Charles Maitland Fair and Gertrude (Bryan) Fair, he was born in New York City and was raised in Manhattan and in Oyster Bay, New York. He attended the Buckley School, the Fay School, St. Paul's School, and Yale University. Charles is survived by his wife of 34 years, Louise (Sadler) Kiessling M.D., FAAP, and two daughters, Ellen Bryan Fair of New York City and Shushan, New York, and Katherine Healy Fair, Ph.D., and her husband, Raphael Colb, of Fort Ann, NY and Exeter, NH. He was predeceased by his son, Charles M. (Chip) Fair, and his former wife Kay (Ruddy) Fair. A gathering in his honor will be held at the South Kingstown Land Trust Barn at 17 Matunuck Beach Road, Wakefield, RI 02879 on Sunday August 17 at 2:00pm. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island, South Team, 1085 N. Main Street, Providence, RI 02904; South County Hospital, 100 Kenyon Avenue, Wakefield, RI 02879; or the Rhode Island Food Bank, 200 Niantic Avenue, Providence, RI 02907. For guest book and condolences, averystortifuneralhome.com.

CAVANAUGH--Charles Ahern. Charles Ahern Cavanaugh, 39, of San Antonio, Texas, passed away on July 15, 2014. He died at home surrounded by loved ones after a long battle with cancer. Charles was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota on June 12, 1975 to Mike and Zoe Cavanaugh. He graduated from Jesuit High School in Portland, Oregon and received degrees in Political Science and Theology from the University of Notre Dame in 1997. Charles married Emilia Gamez on August 12, 2006. Prior to moving to San Antonio in 2012, he spent 11 years residing in New York City, working with Davis Selected Advisors as a trader, research analyst, and portfolio manager. Charles was co-manager of the Davis Financial Fund from 2007-2012. Charles is survived by his wife Emilia, son Aidan; parents Mike and Zoe Cavanaugh; brother John Cavanaugh (Lisa); sister Elizabeth Lowe (Mark); nieces, nephews, aunts and uncles. Thank you Charles for being a man of faith, wildly generous, outrageous, unique, fun and thoughtful. Most of all, thank you for being you. Memorial donations may be made to Maggie's Place at email@maggiesplace.org or 602-262-5555.

READ--Clare Taylor, 85, died July 18 in Exeter, NH, after battling a terminal illness. She leaves Bert, her adoring husband of 53 years; sons John and Bill, daughter Wendy; sister Sarah; brother Larry and four grandchildren. She was an avid watercolorist, opera lover, tennis player, sailor, and gardener. But she will perhaps be best remembered as the "hostess-with-the-mostess," graciously entertaining friends and family from far and wide. Always positive, exceedingly generous, ever active, a loving mother and devoted wife, she will be missed by many and forgotten by few. In lieu of flowers, donate to Kirkwood Gardens, 603-968-7194 ext. 12. Memorial service: August 17, 2pm, Church Island, Squam Lake, NH.

PRAGER--Arthur. Adored dad of Emily Prager, G-Dad of Lulu Prager, stepdad of Nora Elcar-Verdon, son of the late Elsie and Joe Prager. 8th Airforce war hero, NYC Mayor's Official, President of Royal Oak Foundation and Irish Georgian Society, author, lover, exemplary friend. NICCHI--Roseann (nee Monteleone), peacefully and surrounded by her family on July 30, 2014. Loving wife of Thomas Nicchi, beloved daughter of Mary and the late Aurelio Monteleone., cherished sister of Charles, Thomas and Barbara, Helen Jean and the late Lewis Monteleone, adored mother of Mari, Jennifer, Jacqueline and Thomas, beloved grammy to Alex, Jake, Hannah, Mathieu, Hailey, Erica and JT, loving aunt to many nieces and nephews. She loved to travel, garden and spend time with her family. Her infectious smile will be greatly missed.

MAZZOLA--John W. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing of former Lincoln Center President John W. Mazzola, a steadfast advocate of the arts in New York whose forward-thinking inauguration of "Live From Lincoln Center" brought the New York Philharmonic to music lovers around the world. We extend sincere condolences to his family.

LARSEN--Carol Stroll, aged 78, passed away quietly at home on July 30th after a short illness. Loving wife of Leslie H. Larsen, Jr. Beloved mother of Kari Larsen Pedone. Adoring grandmother of Maddie and Ellie. Daughter of the late Dr. George and Helen Stroll of Shelter Island, NY. Niece of Gloria Hegeman of Vero Beach, FL. Graduate of St. Mary's in Garden City, 1954 and Rollins College, 1958, Winter Park, FL. Publicity Director of Peck and Peck Stores, President of Les Paniers (The Baskets), member Nassau Country Club and Who's Who of American Women 1968-69. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY on Saturday 3-5pm and 7-9pm and Sunday from 4-7pm at the Shelter Island Funeral Home, 23 W. Neck Road, Shelter Island, NY. Religious Services will be held at the Shelter Island Presbyterian Church on Monday. Interment to follow in the Emily French Memorial Cemetery in Shelter Island. Donations in her memory may be made to the Rollins College Fund, Winter Park, FL.

Kelsey--Harvey Jr. The Jay Heritage Center is saddened by the passing of a cherished friend, Harvey Kelsey Jr. He demonstrated a lifelong love and respect for the natural world and valued the sylvan beauty of gardens, trails and open spaces. He gave freely of his time and counsel to many organizations within his community, offering honest insights where his opinion could make a positive difference and benefit more people outside himself. Harvey spurred us on in our work with his loyalty, his indominatable energy, his humor and his ability to sail beyond obstacles to any horizon. We will miss him greatly and extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, grandchildren, family and friends who continue his legacy.

FARLEY--Mary Kathryn. 1935-2014. Wife, mother, sportswoman and philanthropist. Life champion.

FAIR--Charles M.Charles M. Fair, 97, of Wakefield, Rhode Island, died July 28, 2014 at South County Hospital in Wakefield, of lymphoma. He was a multitalented man with a varied career: editor, poet, banana importer, computer-company executive, script writer/ narrator, historian, and neurology researcher at Massachusetts General Hospital. In 1963 he went as a Guggenheim Fellow to UCLA's Brain Research Institute, and the following year became a resident scientist in MIT's Neurosciences Research Program, one of the few to have held an appointment there with no academic degree. Mr. Fair published light verse in Punch and The New Yorker, book reviews in the Washington Post and The Providence Journal, and a regular column in the American Poetry Review. He authored three books on neuroscience, The Physical Foundations of the Psyche (Wesleyan University Press, 1963), Memory & Central Nervous Organization (Paragon House, 1988), and Cortical Memory Functions (Birkhauser, 1992); a number of papers on brain function; and three nontechnical books: The Dying Self (Wesleyan University Press, 1969), From The Jaws of Victory (Simon & Schuster, 1971), and The New Nonsense (Simon & Schuster, 1974). His books have been published in Britain and translated into Italian, German, and Danish. His creativity also included a lifelong love of jazz, and he played both piano and vibraphone. He loved sailing, the Red Sox, good conversation, and he even tried his hand at farming. He also wrote and narrated the soundtrack for the original Salem Witch Museum, in Salem, Massachusetts. The only child of Charles Maitland Fair and Gertrude (Bryan) Fair, he was born in New York City and was raised in Manhattan and in Oyster Bay, New York. He attended the Buckley School, the Fay School, St. Paul's School, and Yale University. Charles is survived by his wife of 34 years, Louise (Sadler) Kiessling M.D., FAAP, and two daughters, Ellen Bryan Fair of New York City and Shushan, New York, and Katherine Healy Fair, Ph.D., and her husband, Raphael Colb, of Fort Ann, NY and Exeter, NH. He was predeceased by his son, Charles M. (Chip) Fair, and his former wife Kay (Ruddy) Fair. A gathering in his honor will be held at the South Kingstown Land Trust Barn at 17 Matunuck Beach Road, Wakefield, RI 02879 on Sunday August 17 at 2:00pm. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island, South Team, 1085 N. Main Street, Providence, RI 02904; South County Hospital, 100 Kenyon Avenue, Wakefield, RI 02879; or the Rhode Island Food Bank, 200 Niantic Avenue, Providence, RI 02907. For guest book and condolences, averystortifuneralhome.com.

BERNSTEIN--Helen Lipman. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Helen Lipman Bernstein, beloved wife of the late Harold Bernstein. Her exceptional philanthropic traditions live on through the generosity of her cherished family. We extend our condolences to Helen's entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

AVERY--Alice O'Neill. The trustees and staff of the American Museum in Britain express our deepest sorrow at the death of our good friend and museum patron, Alice Avery. Alice, a dedicated traveler of Museum tours since 1978 and who easily won the count of being the most traveled supporter and patron, starting her trips with Director Ian McCallum, and following with Bill McNaught, Sandra Barghini and most recently, Richard Wendorf. She was not only the most traveled of our life members, but also someone who was always generous in entertaining Museum members on the trips to Los Angeles. She lived a long life and even towards the end displayed enthusiasm for new experiences and had a memory, all of us would be pleased to call our own. Her generosity, dedication and friendship will be deeply missed. Alfred M. Vinton, Chairman Mark E. Haranzo, Deputy Chairman American Museum in Britain Linda Hackett, President Halcyon Foundation

ALBERT--Ethel B. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Ethel B. Albert, 96, of New York, NY. Died July 30th 2014. Ethel was the daughter of Adolph and Kate Brumbeger, loving wife to Irving who had passed some years earlier. Sister to Belle, Sid, Sylvia, and Caroline. She is survived by her nephew Arthur, four great-nephews Andrew, Ian, Alex and Robert and three great-nieces, Audrey, Deborah, and Kate. Ethel earned a Master's Degree in English from Columbia University, taught English and worked on Wall Street. After she retired, she volunteered for 17 years at The Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan. She was passionate about Bridge, Golf, travel, the arts and supported various charities within her community. Her grace and elegance will be greatly missed by her family and friends. Services will be held at the Union Field Cemetery, this Sunday, August 3rd, 8211 Cypress Avenue, Ridgewood, NY 11385 at 10:45am.

WEINTRAUB--Max. We mourn the loss of a revered and generous man, a respected visionary, a New Yorker through and through, and a dear friend. Max was not only a founder, but an integral part of the PACE family for 65 years. He never left usand he never will. Sincere condolences from all of Max's friends at Pace Advertising.

WEINTRAUB--Max. Max exemplified the kind of person we all wish to be. He was a partner in the formation of Pace Advertising, North American Development and other building ventures. His work with children in the lower east side school system provided extras that included supporting the annual year book and trips to Belmont and the Big Apple Circus. Max was a man of many parts: Impresario, Cowboy, Bon Vivant and long-time Friend. He will be missed by us all. Eli Schonberger and Gail Guillet

WEINTRAUB--Max. Loving and beloved father of Aviva Weintraub, and father-in-law of Gordon Tapper, Max Weintraub has died at the age of 92. Max was a WWII veteran (CBI Air Transport), retired adman, avid participant on horseback trail rides in Arizona, longtime public school volunteer, off-off-Broadway music impresario, and so much more. A lifelong New Yorker who loved spending summers in Vermont, he never forgot his roots on the Lower East Side. Sweet, generous and kind, friend to many, and devoted to his extended family, he was a gentleman and a gentle man. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan on Sunday, August 3, at 11:45am. Aviva Weintraub Gordon Tapper

TULIS--Maurice "Murray," (91) a proud native New Yorker, died on July 28, 2014. Murray is survived by his wife Joyce of 65 years; his children Mark (Elaine), Michele (Jeff), and Dana (predeceased Eddie); and his grandchildren, Jonah, Ben (Claire), Rebecca, Elena, Jessie; his step-grandson Faron, and many adoring cousins. Murray grew up in Brooklyn, was a World War II Navy Veteran, and raised his family in Seaford and Manhasset Hills. Murray was a well-known, talented and respected interior designer at Tulis Fashion House Furniture at 2 Park Ave, New York City.

SANLIER-LAMARK--Xavier, 87, of New York, NY passed away, July 29, 2014 in New York. Born in Paris, France on December 1, 1926 the son of the late Enrique and Maria (Hervas Moncho) Sanlier-Lamark. He is survived by, a lifelong companion Norman Odlum. A niece Regina Romero Sanlier-Lamark and a great niece, Regina Suarez Romero, both of Spain. www.Dunnfh.com.

Kelsey--Harvey Jr. The Jay Heritage Center is saddened by the passing of a cherished friend, Harvey Kelsey Jr. He demonstrated a lifelong love and respect for the natural world and valued the sylvan beauty of gardens, trails and open spaces. He gave freely of his time and counsel to many organizations within his community, offering honest insights where his opinion could make a positive difference and benefit more people outside himself. Harvey spurred us on in our work with his loyalty, his indominatable energy, his humor and his ability to sail beyond obstacles to any horizon. We will miss him greatly and extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, grandchildren, family and friends who continue his legacy.

JAMESON--Virginia. Born Virginia V. Yannello in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, 1941. Died July 29th, 2014, Newtown, PA. Attended St. John Villa Academy, Staten Island. Beloved wife, mother and friend. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Dementia Society of America, PO Box 600, Doylestown, PA 18901 or www.dementiasociety.org.

HEATH--Clifford J.,Jr. Clifford John Heath, Jr., 88, of Basking Ridge, NJ, passed away peacefully on July 29th, 2014. Cliff was a loving husband, father and grandfather and a dedicated businessman known for his integrity and diplomacy. Cliff was born in Englewood, NJ on October 4th, 1925 to Clifford J. Heath, Sr. and Beatrice Heath. He graduated from Teaneck High School in 1943 and enlisted in the US Army, serving in WWII in Europe. After the war he returned and attended Lawrenceville Prep, Princeton, and Columbia Universities, majoring in Government and Political Science. His business career included home building in Bergen/Mercer counties in the early 1950's, and President of Precipitation Associates of America from 1958-1992, an air pollution control company serving the Asphalt paving industry. From 1981 to 1992 Cliff served as President of the New Jersey Asphalt Paving Association, Executive Vice President of SWK Paving Engineering, Inc. from 1993-1996, then Executive Vice President of the New Jersey Alliance for Action from 1996-2012. Cliff was also a member of American Society of Highway Engineers, American Society of Testing and Materials, American Association of Paving Technology, the Transportation Research Board, and New Jersey Society of Municipal Engineers. He also served on the board of the New Jersey Society of Asphalt Technologists. Cliff was a patriot and like many members of the greatest generation, he took his obligations as a citizen seriously. He was keenly interested in public policy and enjoyed wide ranging debates on the issues of the day. Clifford is survived by his beloved wife of 39 years, Susan Heath, six children, Stuart Heath of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Gary Glaser of Fairfield, CT, Steven Heath of Williston, ND, Deborah (Glaser) Henry of Fairfield, CT, Daniel Glaser of New York City, and Matthew Glaser of Wynnewood, PA, and 13 grandchildren, all of whom adored and loved him very much. He is predeceased by his first wife, Barbara (Mannhardt) Heath. Burial will be private.

HANKS--Jane Richardson, born August 2, 1908, died July 27, in Bennington, VT at age 105. Her anthropological field work among Native Americans and the Thai influenced future scholars. Memorial service October 19, North Bennington, Vermont.

FRIEDMAN--Jack B. Long-time science educator, co-founder and past president of the National Center for Science Education, has died of heart failure at age 88. He first taught biology at the Bronx High School of Science, and was the founding chairman of the Science Department at Syosset, NY High School. After retirement, he continued teaching biology at Nassau Community College and Hofstra University. He was a passionate advocate for teaching scientific principles in schools, with evolution an important example. Jack was happily married for 60 years to Betty, and was a loving and devoted father and grandfather. He is survived by his beloved children Warren and Fran, his adored grandchildren Jesse and Sarah Strigler, and his dear in-laws Laura and Burt Klayman. Memorial donations may be made at the NCSE.com website.

FEINBERG--Wilfred, passed away on July 31, 2014 at the age of 94. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Susan, Jack and Jessica. Adoring grandfather of Samuel, Dasha, Rebecca, Andrew, Eliza and Kayla. He was a Federal Judge for 50 years, and served as Chief Judge of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals from 1980 to 1988. He was also the ping-pong champion of Mount Vernon, NY at the age of 13. Services are private; a memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Honorable Wilfred Feinberg Scholarship in Law at Columbia University.
FARLEY--Mary Kathryn. 1935-2014. Wife, mother, sportswoman and philanthropist. Life champion.

BLOOMFIELD--Randall. Dr. Randall Dudley Bloomfield was born in Harlem on August 3, 1923. He had a distinguished medical career in obstetrics and gynecology and gynecologic oncology for more than fifty years. After serving his country honorably in World War II, he graduated from City College and received his medical degree from the State University of New York, Downstate Medical Center, followed by a residency at Kings County Hospital Center and a fellowship at Memorial Sloan Kettering. Some of the many achievements and appointments in his illustrious career are Director of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Kings County Hospital, President of the Alumni Association of Downstate Medical Center, President of the Medical Society of the County of Kings, and delegate to the American Medical Association. Randall Bloomfield was very happily married for 61 years to Edris Bloomfield. He is survived by his children, Diane and Robert, his son-in-law, Sam and his granddaughter, Alicia. Services will be held Saturday, August 2, 2014 at 11am at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 1081 Nostrand Ave., Brooklyn, NY.

AVERY--Alice O'Neill. The trustees and staff of the American Museum in Britain express our deepest sorrow at the death of our good friend and museum patron, Alice Avery. Alice, a dedicated traveler of Museum tours since 1978 and who easily won the count of being the most traveled supporter and patron, starting her trips with Director Ian McCallum, and following with Bill McNaught, Sandra Barghini and most recently, Richard Wendorf. She was not only the most traveled of our life members, but also someone who was always generous in entertaining Museum members on the trips to Los Angeles. She lived a long life and even towards the end displayed enthusiasm for new experiences and had a memory, all of us would be pleased to call our own. Her generosity, dedication and friendship will be deeply missed. Alfred M. Vinton, Chairman Mark E. Haranzo, Deputy Chairman American Museum in Britain Linda Hackett, President Halcyon Foundation
