SELIGMAN--Benjamin D. 7/10/04 - 8/03/07. In remembrance of your wisdom, strength and devotion. Your loving family.
HELFMAN--Donald. It's been two years since you left us. We miss you terribly. You are always in our hearts. Your Loving Family
FRANKEL--Bertha. Dearest Mom, 22 years have gone by. Miss you and think of you always. -Loving daughter
DOSS--Jay. On August 3, 2009 you left us for your rest. We know you are still watching over all your family and friends. We love and miss you always. The family of Jay Doss
CARROLL--Vern. With deep sadness and regret, we remember the loss of Vern Carroll, who died a year ago today. He lives on in us, his voice remains as vivid as ever. We love and remember you always.
ACKERMAN--Martin S. 8/2/93 Twenty one long years, missed and loved. You fill our hearts - now, then, always. Diane and Kelly

WOLOSKER--Lisa, passed away peacefully three days before her 101st birthday. Darling wife of the late Peter Wolosker and dearly beloved mother of Grace Gliedman and Steven Wolosker and loving mother in law to Monroe Gliedman. Adored grandmother of Wendy Beizer, Michael Gliedman, John Gliedman and Lake Wolosker. Soulmate of her dear sister Ruth Provet. Lisa was a gentle and loving heart.

WELCH--Thomas. Born December 4, 1915. Great-grandson of Thomas Bramwell Welch, inventor of Dr. Welch's "Unfermented Grape Drink" and pioneer of the fruit juice industry. Grandson of Charles Edgar Welch, who formed the Welch Grape Juice Co. Son of Edgar Thomas Welch, President of the Welch Grape Juice Co. Thomas Welch attended Swarthmore College, transferred to Cornell University from which he graduated in 1939. He was one of the first people hired for the Linde Division of Union Carbide Corporation in Buffalo, NY, which was testing a variety of inorganic chemicals, including silicone. In the early 1940's, the US started researching the properties of silicones to help with the war effort. Thomas worked for Union Carbide developing the silicone business from 1940 until his retirement in 1976. With a B.S. in Chemistry, Thomas ultimately rose to the highest level of Union Carbide's corporate structure with appointment to the company's Central Management Committee in 1965. In 1967 he was appointed Director of Research and Development, Chemicals and Plastics Division. He managed the design and construction of the $37 million (today's dollars) research facility at Tarrytown, NY. Between 1969 and his retirement in 1976, Thomas directed a team of 250 researchers and staff at Tarrytown as well as those at two other locations, in Pennsylvania and West Virginia. At the time of his retirement, the company's silicone business, one that Thomas was key in developing, had reached sales equivalent of $450 million in today's dollars. After retiring at age 60, Thomas, together with his wife Jane Todd Welch, devoted most of their energies to charitable activities, especially helping to advance the work of their daughter, Martha G. Welch MD, who had pioneered a method for treating childhood emotional, behavioral and developmental disorders. Thomas's counsel and support led her to transition from private practice to her current basic and clinical research position as Associate Professor of Psychiatry and Co-Director of the Nuturescience Program in Pediatrics at Columbia University Medical Center. Thomas continued to play a key role in Dr. Welch's research career as mentor and advisor up until the time of his death. During his career at Union Carbide and throughout his long life, Thomas Welch was highly loved and respected. He will long be remembered and deeply missed for his compassion, his ethics and his moral compass.
WEISBARD--Jeanne, on August 1, 2014 at 96. A valiant woman. Dear wife of the late Marco. Loving mother of Gail Marks and Peter Weisbard. Adoring grandmother of Michael, Daniel and David.

WEINTRAUB--Max. Three generations of our family grieve the passing of our dear friend Max. We met 57 years ago and have loved and respected him every day. Max was, in every way, the finest and most beloved man we have ever known. Joan and Milton Bagley and family

WEINTRAUB--Max. We mourn the loss of a revered and generous man, a respected visionary, a New Yorker through and through, and a dear friend. Max was not only a founder, but an integral part of the PACE family for 65 years. He never left usand he never will. Sincere condolences from all of Max's friends at Pace Advertising.

WEINTRAUB--Max. Loving and beloved father of Aviva Weintraub, and father-in-law of Gordon Tapper, Max Weintraub has died at the age of 92. Max was a WWII veteran (CBI Air Transport), retired adman, avid participant on horseback trail rides in Arizona, longtime public school volunteer, off-off-Broadway music impresario, and so much more. A lifelong New Yorker who loved spending summers in Vermont, he never forgot his roots on the Lower East Side. Sweet, generous and kind, friend to many, and devoted to his extended family, he was a gentleman and a gentle man. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan on Sunday, August 3, at 11:45am. Aviva Weintraub Gordon Tapper

TULIS--Maurice "Murray," (91) a proud native New Yorker, died on July 28, 2014. Murray is survived by his wife Joyce of 65 years; his children Mark (Elaine), Michele (Jeff), and Dana (predeceased Eddie); and his grandchildren, Jonah, Ben (Claire), Rebecca, Elena, Jessie; his step-grandson Faron, and many adoring cousins. Murray grew up in Brooklyn, was a World War II Navy Veteran, and raised his family in Seaford and Manhasset Hills. Murray was a well-known, talented and respected interior designer at Tulis Fashion House Furniture at 2 Park Ave, New York City.

STEIN--Susan, nee Volpert, died of bladder cancer on July 28, 2014 in Greenwich, CT where she lived for 47 years, raising her own children and mentoring their friends who thrived in the warmth of Susan's home. She enjoyed cooking and baking, traveling, playing tennis, gardening, attending opera and theater and commuting to Baruch College where she taught statistics in the graduate program for 25 years. She was the much adored wife of Steven J. Stein; mother of Matthew and Danny Stein and of Victoria Stein Feltman; mother-in-law of Kristen Vinyon Stein, Lauren Stein and Joshua Feltman and treasured Grandma of Jacob, Mimi, Claire, Eliza, Amelia, Lucy, Benjamin, George and Oliver. She is also survived by brother Howard Volpert for whom she had great affection. Susan was a graduate of Cornell University, BS 1962, Hunter College, MA 1966, and the City University of New York, Ph.D 1984. She was born to Marion and Myron Volpert on May 3, 1940 in Syracuse, NY. After Cornell, she began married life in Manhattan before moving to Greenwich. She spent considerable time in Geneva, Switzerland and Port La Galere, Theoule, France where she made friendships that lasted a lifetime; as did her friendships in Greenwich, Manhattan and London. Her interests and memberships included the Metropolitan Opera Club, the Milbrook Club (Greenwich) and the Queens Club (London). Her kindness and generosity and consideration for others was boundless and her memory will live in the hearts of all who knew her. A Memorial Service will take place on August 5th at 10:30am at Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. Donations may be made in memory of Susan Volpert Stein to Cornell University Alumni Affairs and Development Office, 130 East Seneca St., Suite 400, Ithaca NY 14850.

SHACHAT--Leon M. January 12, 1924-July 31, 2014. Formerly of South Orange, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Patricia H; loving father to Jill (David), Abby, Steven (Amy) and loving PopPop to Adam, Michael, Phoebe, Jake and Aaron. Mr. Shachat was a Veteran of WWII who served in Europe as a Corporal. He graduated from Rutgers University, and was a member of the Colonel Henry Rutgers Society. He was a principal founder of Shachat & Simson, an accounting firm in New Jersey and a longstanding member of Temple Oheb Shalom. He appreciated beauty of all kinds, a really fine meal and most of all, loved his family. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the National Parkinsons Foundation.

REIZES--Alyce Callahan, 71, Highland Beach, FL, formally Lake Success, NY died July 28, 2014. Survived by son Thomas H. (wife Gwyn and son Henry) Reizes of Albany, NY, and partner Jerry Kozierow. A memorial to be held in Highland Beach, Fl. Interment in Arlington Cemetery, Drexel Hill, PA. Contributions may be made in her name to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, www.ccfa.org.

SELIGMANN--Jean, 69, on July 11, 2014, after a long and valiant battle with MS and ovarian cancer. Dear sister of Mary Ascheim, loving aunt and great-aunt of Tom Ascheim, Jane Winston, Nicholas Ascheim and their eight children, devoted friend of June Winters. For 30 years a courageous and talented writer and editor at Newsweek and a lifelong lover of languages, classical and modern. Her sharp wit and gentle wisdom will be long remembered.

REISMAN--Hilda, (nee Rabinowitz) passed away on July 15, 2014 at the age of 86, after a sudden illness. Predeceased in 2011 by her beloved husband of 62 years, Arnold Reisman, she is survived by her children and their spouses, Richard (Susan), Robert (Lisette), David (Emma), and Daniel (Gabriella), and her 11 loving grandchildren, Elizabeth, Lillian, Jacob, Eli, Rachel, Simone, Joseph, Isaac, Jackson, Raquel, and Ethan. Hilda received her B.S. in Mathematics from CCNY and a Masters in Education. She enjoyed various hobbies and avocations throughout her life. She was a teacher in the Yorktown, NY public school system, an avid tennis player, a skilled bridge player, and a consummate chef. However, her highest calling came as a spouse, mother, grandmother, and friend, sharing her companionship, love, and wisdom with all who were touched by her. We are better people because of her, but her departure leaves a deep void in us all. The family is asking that donations be made in Hilda's memory to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) at www.aspca.org or by sending a check to: ASPCA Tribute, 520 8th Avenue, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10018.

RABINOWITZ--Rene S.,age 92, was the wife for 45 years of Rubin Rabinowitz of Clifton, NJ. She died peacefully in her sleep Saturday, August 2, 2014. Rene is survived by her sister Dulie (Eugene) Kahn of Falls Church, VA, her sons Andrew of Chicago, IL, and Peter of CA, stepsons Jonathan (Denise) of New York City, Joshua (Richmond) of Montclair, NJ, grandson Alex of Hoboken, NJ, granddaughter Kate of Annapolis, MD, and great-grandson Maxwell, as well as many nieces and nephews. Rene was a successful public relations person until her retirement. She was a member of the board of The Reece School of New York City and of The Citizens Committee for the Children of New York. Through her charities and benefactions, she assisted many organizations. A memorial occasion will be planned for the future in lieu of a service and Shiva.

POSNACK--Adam Todd, died suddenly Tuesday evening in New City, NY. He was 47 years old. The son of Gail and Stanley Posnack of New City, NY, he was born on New Year's Eve 1966 in New York. He grew up in Airmont, NY with his two sisters, Beth Hecht and Jennifer DeMarchi. He attended Suffern High School, where he captained the football, wrestling and baseball teams. Adam earned a B.A. from Princeton University in 1989 and was a member of the Varsity Football team. He had a highly distinguished, 25-year career in finance at UBS, Deutche Bank, Jefferies, and most recently, FBR & Co., where he was a Managing Director and Head of Convertible Bond Sales. Known for his larger-than-life personality, intense drive, and wonderful sense of humor, he was a loving son, husband, father, and loyal friend. He performed tireless charity work as a Board Member on behalf of the Familial Dysautonomia Foundation. His greatest joys in life came from his wife, Robin Fiddle Posnack, and their four children, Cody, Jack, Hunter and Charlotte. He often remarked being a father was the greatest gift he'd ever received. In addition to his wife and children, he is survived by his parents, sisters, sisters-in-law and brothers-in-law, nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, August 3, at 10:30am at Temple Beth El, 415 Viola Road, Spring Valley, NY. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Dysautonomia Foundation: http://famdys.org/adam.

O'BRIEN--John F.,83, died at home in Pinehurst, North Carolina on July 30th, 2014. He was born in Kansas City, Missouri in 1931. He is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Arline; his daughters Jennifer Livingstone and Stephanie Kodweis; his treasured son-in-law John Kodweis, and grandchildren Teagan, Hugh, Christian and Fritz. His intellect and humor will be missed. A funeral service will be held Monday, August 4th, St. Anthony of Padua, Southern Pines, North Carolina at 10am. Boles Funeral Home and Crematory, Inc. in Pinehurst will be assisting the family.

NADLER--Dr. Gerald, 90, passed away at his home on July 28, 2014. Professor Nadler was IBM Chair Emeritus in Engineering Management at the University of Southern California. Before his departmental chairmanship at USC, he was Chairman and Professor at the University of Wisconsin at Madison and at Washington University in St. Louis. He served as President of the Center for Breakthrough Thinking, Inc., an international management consulting firm of affiliates. Dr. Nadler has written over 200 published articles and 15 books, several of which have been translated into nine languages. Dr. Nadler is survived by his wife of 67 years, Elaine; his brother Melvin; and by his three children, Burton, Janice and Robert, as well as by his eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

NICCHI--Roseann (nee Monteleone), peacefully and surrounded by her family on July 30, 2014. Loving wife of Thomas Nicchi, beloved daughter of Mary and the late Aurelio Monteleone., cherished sister of Charles, Thomas and Barbara, Helen Jean and the late Lewis Monteleone, adored mother of Mari, Jennifer, Jacqueline and Thomas, beloved grammy to Alex, Jake, Hannah, Mathieu, Hailey, Erica and JT, loving aunt to many nieces and nephews. She loved to travel, garden and spend time with her family. Her infectious smile will be greatly missed.

MORGENSTERN-Frank N. Age 98. Beloved husband of Deborah for 69 years; revered father of Richard, Carol Kaufman, and Alan; treasured grandfather of Michael, David and Sari Morgenstern, and Michael and Amalia Kaufman; and cherished father-in-law of Tamara Morgenstern and Jeffrey Kaufman. Attorney, mortgage banker, real estate and hotel developer, investor, philanthropist and champion tennis player. He conducted his life brilliantly, meritoriously, without pretense or vanity, with an unparalleled strong will, and his success was never flaunted. He was utterly devoted to his family, and his strong mind was possessed of clear thought to the end. We are devastated to say goodbye to our patriarch. Funeral at Old Mount Carmel Cemetery, 8345 Cypress Hills St., Ridgewood, Queens, NY, on Monday August 4th at 11am.

McGRATH--James P. "Jim," Age, 90, of Hopkins, MN, passed away on July 30. Born and raised in New York City, he grew up during the Depression, was a United States Army Air Corps Veteran, laid tracks for the New York Central Railroad, drove a bus up and down Broadway and had a long career in the New York Courts, first as a Court Officer and rising to Chief Clerk of the Family Courts in Queens and Brooklyn. A stint in the Civilian Conservation Corps planted a love for the great outdoors, and he became an avid camper, hiker and backpacker. He also was at the forefront of the running revolution in the 1970s, competing in many marathons - including the first five-borough NYC marathon (in 3 hours, 13 minutes) and the legendary "run for the hoses" 1976 Boston Marathon - as well as ultra-marathons. Though he initially dropped out of high school, he nevertheless became a life-long learner, and was taking physics, trigonometry, European history and many other classes at the University of Minnesota in his 60's and 70's. He was a devoted and active friend of Bill W. for 48 years. Preceded in death by his brother John "Red" and sister Angela Young. Survived by his loving wife of 61 years (and amazing care-giver) Ann; sons Kevin of Brooklyn, NY; Dennis (and Stephanie) of Minnetonka, MN; James (and Joan) of Lake Ron-konkoma, NY; and Patrick of Forest Hills, NY; and six grandchildren - Kerry, Cailin, Aidan, Maura, Owen and Miles. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations to the Adirondack Mountain Club, Development Dept., 814 Goggins Rd., Lake George, NY 12845. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, August 16 at Washburn-McReavy Funeral Home in Eden Prairie, MN.

LeVINE--Barbara Grande, 73, died of lung cancer July 24, 2014 in New York City. Born and raised in Jersey City, NJ, she received a BA from Douglass College at Rutgers University, New Bruns-wick, NJ, and an MSW from Hunter College School of Social Work, New York City. Following success as a couture fashion model, in 1991 she began a second career as a psychotherapist and wellness educator. An AIDS activist, she was a board member and volunteer counselor for Gay Men's Health Crisis (1983-1995). For women re-entering the workforce, she created the award-winning "New Colors at Midlife" program at Marymount Manhattan College's Center for Living and Learning. Predeceased in June 2013 by her husband David Eliot LeVine, she is survived by her goddaughter Donna Daniels, her beloved cat Smokey, and loving friends. Donations gratefully appreciated: Humane Society of New York.

KELSEY--Harvey M. Jr.,died July 30, 2014 at age 91. His blessed life included Phillips Academy 1941, Princeton 1945, Harvard MBA 1949, US Army 1942-1946, President Talcott Inc., 25 years, CFO Johnson and Higgins eight years, boards of Burke Rehabilitation Hospital, Miriam Osborn Home, and Association for the Protect of the Adirondacks. Marrying Anne Talcott in 1947 was the greatest event of his life. Sharing their love of the outdoors with his five kids created his most cherished memories. Predeceased by Anne his wife of 55 years and Tanner his fifth grandson, he is survived by Peg, Karen, Peter, Jimmy, Harvey, their spouses Grant, David, Brenna, Ellen, and Sue, 14 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

KOVARSKY--Abraham, 76, of River Vale, NJ passed away on May 15, 2014 in the presence of his devoted wife. Called Bobby by his family and friends, he was born in Bronx, NY. He graduated from Bronx High School of Science at age 17, and subsequently from NYU, Phi Beta Kappa and SUNY Down State Medical School, Alpha Omega Alpha. After completing his internship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, New York City, he was drafted into the Army where he was given the Army Achievement Medal for outstanding service and dedication to his patients. This theme would follow him his whole career. Following a General Surgery Residency at the Bronx Veterans Hospital and an Orthopedic Surgery Residency at Mt. Sinai Hospital, NYC, Bobby joined a practice in Springfield, MA where he volunteered two days a week at the Shriner's Hospital for Disabled Children. Upon moving to New Jersey, he established a private practice and continued his work with disabled children at Helen Hayes Hospital, Haverstraw, NY. After five years at Helen Hayes Hospital, Bobby was asked to become Chief of the Children's Orthopedic Service; it was then that he founded the Westwood Orthopedic Group. Bobby was highly respected among the Columbia-Presbyterian residents who rotated through Helen Hayes Hospital Program, many of whom remained in contact with him throughout his life. His kindness, generosity and dedication to the well being of others characterized him. Roslyn Sandra, his wife of 50 years, survives Bobby. Also surviving are his loving daughters, Deborah Khan (her husband Bassam) and Sharon Hood; and his precious grandchildren Julia and Jared Khan, Julian and Cameron Hood. He will be truly missed. Donations in memory of Abraham (Bobby) Kovarsky may be made to: Shriner's Hospital for Children 516 Carew Street, Springfield, MA 01104. shrinershospitalforchildren.org

KAZANTZIS--George. Beloved father and grandfather, preceded in death by his loving wife Mary, died August 1, 2014 surrounded by his devoted family. Services to be held at Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Humane Society of New York.

KAUSHIK--Surendra, Ph.D. Died on July 30, 2014. He was born in Rajasthan, India on June 21, 1944. Dr. Kaushik moved to USA in 1970 and he lived in Briarcliff Manor, NY for 33 years with his wife Helena until her passing. Dr. Kaushik was a distinguished professor at Pace University Lubin School of Business. In Helena's honor he founded the Mrs. Helena Kaushik Women's College in India. Dr. Kaushik saw the College to its 15th year. The College has graduated thousands of young women who have gone on to be elements of change in their communities. In recognition of Dr. Kaushik's contributions, he was awarded the Pravasi Bharatiya Divas award, India's highest honor given to a non-resident Indian. Dr. Kaushik was also honored by a Resolution of the NJ General Assembly, a Resolution of the NY State Assembly, and he was entered in the Congressional Record by Congresswoman Nita Lowey. In lieu of flowers, donations are welcome to the Helena Kaushik Education Foundation, P.O. Box 234, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. www.helenakaushik.org.
JENCKS--Richard W.,retired CBS Broadcast Group President, dies at 93. See news story at MarinIJ.com.

HINES--Mary M.,Mary M. Hines of New York City and formerly Boston, MA passed away on July 27, 2014 at the age of 64. Mary fought a valiant battle against glioblastoma a fight that she never surrendered to in spirit or determination. A graduate of Simmons College with a certificate from Harvard in Special Studies in Administration and Management, Mary spent 25 years working in the communications field in New England before relocating to Manhattan 15 years ago. Born in Cleveland, OH, Mary was raised in Englewood, NJ. She always lived her life to its fullest working, traveling and enjoying everything that the world had to offer. An ardent Democrat and a fierce bridge player, Mary was a dedicated daughter, sister, aunt, and loyal friend. She is predeceased by her parents, George A. and Mary M. Hines formerly of Englewood, NJ; she is survived by her adoring sisters, Frances A. Falk of West Milford, NJ, Ellen E. Hines of Fort Lee, NJ and brother, Paul K. Hines (Anna) of Stuart, FL. Her nieces and nephews, Kathleen and Kevin Falk, Emily Hyde (Jake), Julia, Grace, and Michael Hines should consider themselves blessed having had an Aunt as devoted as she was. Mary's loyal circle of friends span across the country and ocean you know who you are and how much you meant to Mary. We will each have to deal with the ache in our hearts as a result of her death but we will celebrate her life and remember with fondness how she touched each and every one of us and made us better people simply by the examples she set and by living her life with passion, honor and kindness. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Interment will take place at the Community Mausoleum at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Sleepy Hollow, NY. Mary's concern was always for those who were less fortunate. Donations can be made to The Loaves and Fishes Soup Kitchen and Pantry on behalf of Mary M. Hines at The Church of St. Paul the Apostle. Please make checks payable to The Church of St. Paul the Apostle (with a note included to benefit the Loaves and Fishes Program) and mailed to 405 W. 59th St. New York, NY 10019. We all wish you Godspeed, Mary. Services by Barrett Funeral Home Tenafly.

HSU--Dan. Also named Xu I-Cheng: renowned Chinese-American artist, died on Thursday, July 31, 2014 in Gillette, NJ. He was 83. Born on April 11, 1931 in the city of Hangzhou, in the Zhejiang Province of China, he started to paint at the age of seven. He studied traditional Chinese painting under a number of famous artists, and obtained advanced degrees in art and architecture from several Chinese universities. Starting in 1955, he served for 30 years as a professor of art and architecture at China Southeast University. Having resided in the United States since 1985, he was a member of the California Art Association and the Rutgers University Art Museum (as a special invitational member). He has authored several books and his work has been exhibited widely both in China and in America including in New York, California, Houston, New Jersey, Shanghai, Hangzhou, Beijing, and Nanjing. He participated in the design of the Astor Chinese Garden Court, completed in 1981, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. In 2011 and 2012, he donated over 300 pieces of art to be preserved for generations to come, held by two museums in his hometown the Hangzhou Arts and Crafts Museum, which contains a dedicated exhibition hall of his work, and Hangzhou's West Lake Museum, which holds in trust a collection of his paintings. He will be remembered for his tireless commitment to teaching, and his lifelong dedication to his artistic ideal, bringing to life traditional Chinese painting in a contemporary context. He has been lauded in the media as a "dual prodigy of painter and architect," and "China's Monet." He will be buried at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, New York. The wake will be held at 4pm, with a funeral service at 6pm, on Friday, August 8, 2014 at the Higgins Home for Funerals, Watchung, NJ.

HEATH--Clifford J.,Jr. Clifford John Heath, Jr., 88, of Basking Ridge, NJ, passed away peacefully on July 29th, 2014. Cliff was a loving husband, father and grandfather and a dedicated businessman known for his integrity and diplomacy. Cliff was born in Englewood, NJ on October 4th, 1925 to Clifford J. Heath, Sr. and Beatrice Heath. He graduated from Teaneck High School in 1943 and enlisted in the US Army, serving in WWII in Europe. After the war he returned and attended Lawrenceville Prep, Princeton, and Columbia Universities, majoring in Government and Political Science. His business career included home building in Bergen/Mercer counties in the early 1950's, and President of Precipitation Associates of America from 1958-1992, an air pollution control company serving the Asphalt paving industry. From 1981 to 1992 Cliff served as President of the New Jersey Asphalt Paving Association, Executive Vice President of SWK Paving Engineering, Inc. from 1993-1996, then Executive Vice President of the New Jersey Alliance for Action from 1996-2012. Cliff was also a member of American Society of Highway Engineers, American Society of Testing and Materials, American Association of Paving Technology, the Transportation Research Board, and New Jersey Society of Municipal Engineers. He also served on the board of the New Jersey Society of Asphalt Technologists. Cliff was a patriot and like many members of the greatest generation, he took his obligations as a citizen seriously. He was keenly interested in public policy and enjoyed wide ranging debates on the issues of the day. Clifford is survived by his beloved wife of 39 years, Susan Heath, six children, Stuart Heath of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Gary Glaser of Fairfield, CT, Steven Heath of Williston, ND, Deborah (Glaser) Henry of Fairfield, CT, Daniel Glaser of New York City, and Matthew Glaser of Wynnewood, PA, and 13 grandchildren, all of whom adored and loved him very much. He is predeceased by his first wife, Barbara (Mannhardt) Heath. Burial will be private.

GROUP--Ida Jean.Ida Jean Group, 85 passed away July 26th. She epitomized what a mother, wife and friend should be. She was beautiful, loving nurturing, intelligent, compassionate and loved. She will be missed and emulated by her three children. A finer human being never walked this earth.

FRIEDMAN--Jack B. Long-time science educator, co-founder and past president of the National Center for Science Education, has died of heart failure at age 88. He first taught biology at the Bronx High School of Science, and was the founding chairman of the Science Department at Syosset, NY High School. After retirement, he continued teaching biology at Nassau Community College and Hofstra University. He was a passionate advocate for teaching scientific principles in schools, with evolution an important example. Jack was happily married for 60 years to Betty, and was a loving and devoted father and grandfather. He is survived by his beloved children Warren and Fran, his adored grandchildren Jesse and Sarah Strigler, and his dear in-laws Laura and Burt Klayman. Memorial donations may be made at the NCSE.com website.

DUELL--Irene. It is with overwhelming sadness that we announce the passing of Irene Duell on July 27th in New York City. She was 92. Irene was a Holocaust survivor who managed to escape the Warsaw Ghetto at 25 and begin what would be a full and beautiful life in New York City. Irene was the beloved wife of John Mendes, as well as of the late Manny Duell, Jack Perlstein, and Peter Ganz; mother of Andrew, Thea and Benjamin; grandmother of Damon, Alexander, Colin, Nicholas and Marcus and great-grandmother of baby Oona. She was a source of bright and boundless optimism, strength and grace to all who knew and loved her. She will be missed but not forgotten.

FEINBERG--Wilfred, passed away on July 31, 2014 at the age of 94. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Susan, Jack and Jessica. Adoring grandfather of Samuel, Dasha, Rebecca, Andrew, Eliza and Kayla. He was a Federal Judge for 50 years, and served as Chief Judge of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals from 1980 to 1988. He was also the ping-pong champion of Mount Vernon, NY at the age of 13. Services are private; a memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Honorable Wilfred Feinberg Scholarship in Law at Columbia University.

COURSON--Pearl "Penny," passed away peacefully Friday July 11, 2014 at her home in Santa Barbara, CA after a long battle with cancer at the age of 90. Born September 14, 1923 in Chicago, IL, Penny was the daughter of the late Paul Schmidt of Vienna, Austria and the late Margaret Jarvis Schmidt of Illinois. She is survived by her daughter Judith Courson Burton, granddaughter Emily Burton and husband Chris McGillin, grandson James Burton and wife Deja Rabb Burton, and her great-grandchildren Everett, Simone, and Colette. She was preceded in death by her daughter Pamela Courson Morrison and husband Columbus "Corky" Courson. A child of the depression Penny overcame tough circumstances. After she married Corky they traveled the world. She was a connoisseur of the arts and worked as an interior designer. She was a homemaker and great cook who loved to entertain for family and friends. Penny was a staunch liberal with a feisty personality. She loved politics and was a lifelong reader of The New York Times. She loved her Bichon Frise Lola and her dearest friend Jaime Camargo, who cared for her and her husband when they took ill. Penny's ashes will be interred next to the love of her life, her husband of 64 years. Memorial services will take place at the Santa Barbara Cemetery chapel on August 16th at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider donating to the Jim Morrison Film Award at UCLA or The Santa Barbara Hospice, which was very helpful in her last days.

COHEN--Robert, 90, died on July 31 from complications of congestive heart failure. A loving husband, devoted father, generous friend, masterful story-teller, and fierce patriot, Bob lived life fully, with dignity, honor, style, and purpose. He defended our country in war, and fought passionately for human rights and civil rights in peace. A war hero who hated war, Bob was awarded the Bronze Star, French Legion of Honor, and Russian Hero of the Great Patriotic War. He landed on D-Day, fought in the Battle of the Bulge, and served in four other campaigns in World War II. He lived every day with memories of his remarkable Band of Brothers--those courageous and vulnerable young men, of every race, class, religion, and region, who served with him and did not have the good fortune to return home. He leaves behind his loving wife, Alene, his daughter (Elizabeth) and three sons (Michael, Joshua, and Ken), and eight grandchildren (Daniel, Stephen, Jessica, Lucas, Isabel, Douglas, Ondine, and Caleb). We all love him and miss him.

CHIAZZO--Romano. His sudden death on July 30, 2014 leaves behind in deep mourning his wife Hella, daughter Manuela, grandson Charles, niece Viviana, brother-in-law Antonio, sister-in-law Renate and all relatives. He will be deeply missed by all.

BURTON--Peggy, 87, a renowned New York advertising executive, documentary film producer and art collector, whose pioneering career spanned over seven decades, died peacefully on July 24 in her home at the Metropolitan Tower surrounded by her daughter, Linda Burton and her granddaughter Tara Isabella Burton. From an entry-level position with Young & Rubicam in the 1960s where, as a woman, she was denied admittance into its executive training program, she persevered and went on to build a successful career as a senior account executive at Daniel & Charles Advertising, as the Director of Advertising & Communications for American Express and as Senior Vice President of Advertising for The Dreyfus Corporation as well as President of its in-house advertising agency. Prior to entering advertising she was a successful model and freelance television producer in New York from the 1940s through the early 1960s. After her retirement from Dreyfus in 1994 she returned to film producing and was the assistant producer of the Emmy Award winning documentary "The Mystery of the Sphinx" while establishing a world-wide consulting practice on web-based marketing. Until her death she continued to be an active member of numerous boards and organizations in New York, including Business Executives for National Security, the Fine Arts Club, the Dutch Treat Club and the New York Athletic Club and served weekly as a volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Peggy's indefatigable energy, intellectual curiosity, love of dancing, and joie de vivre continued even in her final decade: from studying history at Oxford University to mastering the tango in Buenos Aires. A life-long traveler on Cunard's transatlantic ocean liners, Peggy was proud to have "never sat out a single dance" on those weeklong voyages, even during her final November crossing.

BRADY--Edward J.,76, of Paramus, NJ formerly of Darien, CT died peacefully at home surrounded by his family on July 31, 2014. Beloved husband of Ethel (Olhausen); loving father of Tracy Brady and Michael Brady and his wife Kimberly; dear grandfather of Christopher, Sean, William and Nora and beloved and devoted brother of Alice Gordon. A funeral service will be held Tuesday, August 5th at 11:30am at the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Fisher House Foundation, 111 Rockville Pike, Suite 420, Rockville, MD 20850-5168. www.vanemburgh.com.

BLOOMFIELD--Randall. Dr. Randall Dudley Bloomfield was born in Harlem on August 3, 1923. He had a distinguished medical career in obstetrics and gynecology and gynecologic oncology for more than fifty years. After serving his country honorably in World War II, he graduated from City College and received his medical degree from the State University of New York, Downstate Medical Center, followed by a residency at Kings County Hospital Center and a fellowship at Memorial Sloan Kettering. Some of the many achievements and appointments in his illustrious career are Director of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Kings County Hospital, President of the Alumni Association of Downstate Medical Center, President of the Medical Society of the County of Kings, and delegate to the American Medical Association. Randall Bloomfield was very happily married for 61 years to Edris Bloomfield. He is survived by his children, Diane and Robert, his son-in-law, Sam and his granddaughter, Alicia. Services will be held Saturday, August 2, 2014 at 11am at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 1081 Nostrand Ave., Brooklyn, NY.
BERNSTEIN--Helen Lipman. We were special friends for 66 years. We shared all our good times and some sad ones. I will never forget you. Charlotte

BERNSTEIN--Helen Lipman, (nee Altstadter), 89, passed away peacefully at her home in Palm Beach, FL, on July 28, 2014. Born June 30, 1925, in Stamford, CT. Predeceased by her late husbands Justin W. Lipman and Harold P. Bernstein. She was a loving mother to Josh (Jo-Ann) Lipman, Dorian Baldwin, and Ann-Louise (Antonio) Beltramini. Adored grandmother to Brooke (Eric) Wenzel and Rory Lipman. She was a cherished mother, grandmother and great-grandmother to Harold Bernstein's family.
BERGEN--Arthur R. Born April 7, 1923, New York, NY Died July 19, 2014, Oakland, CA.

BERNSTEIN--Eric M.,79, died July 24, 2014 in Langhorne, PA. Beloved son of Theodore M. Bernstein, former New York Times Editor, and Beatrice (Alexander) Bernstein. Lovingly cared for since 1946 at The Woods School, Langhorne.
BEATY--William, II, 91, died July 24, 2014 at his home in Union, SC. (www.holcombefuneralhomes.com)

AVERY--Alice O'Neill. The trustees and staff of the American Museum in Britain express our deepest sorrow at the death of our good friend and museum patron, Alice Avery. Alice, a dedicated traveler of Museum tours since 1978 and who easily won the count of being the most traveled supporter and patron, starting her trips with Director Ian McCallum, and following with Bill McNaught, Sandra Barghini and most recently, Richard Wendorf. She was not only the most traveled of our life members, but also someone who was always generous in entertaining Museum members on the trips to Los Angeles. She lived a long life and even towards the end displayed enthusiasm for new experiences and had a memory, all of us would be pleased to call our own. Her generosity, dedication and friendship will be deeply missed. Alfred M. Vinton, Chairman Mark E. Haranzo, Deputy Chairman American Museum in Britain Linda Hackett, President Halcyon Foundation

ABRONS--Mimi (Muriel) Mulwitz, died July 25th at the age of 83. Born and raised in Port Chester, NY, Mimi attended Fieldston through high school, and then Bard College for two years. She had a deep love of classical music, and was an extremely accomplished pianist, performing in numerous workshops. Fellow students often played for her before a recital, valuing her sensitive interpretation of the music. Mimi had a passion for language. She tutored the wives of Japanese businessmen in English, helping them with the difficult adjustment to a country and language about which they had little knowledge. This resulted in lifelong friendships that lasted well after the women had returned to Japan. Her marriage to Richard Abrons ended in divorce in 1983. She loved and was loved by her children, Peter, Leslie, and John, as well as by their spouses Annabella, Rameen, and Debbie, her grandchildren Dylan, Emily, Kira, Pauline, Matthew, Eric, and Andrew, her nieces, nephews and their children. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions in Mimi's memory can be made to Doctors Without Borders.
Eric McClure, a driver in Nascar’s Nationwide Series, sustained a head injury in a 2012 crash but has continued racing.
The death toll in Gaza grew on Sunday, with Palestinian officials reporting a strike near the entrance of a United Nations school sheltering displaced residents.

Glenn Greenwald talks about his evolving role in the new media landscape in an interview with David Carr.

Mr. Homm is accused of buying and selling lightly traded shares among entities he controlled in a practice known as portfolio pumping. Authorities say his goal was to artificially inflate the value of the hedge fund he managed, Absolute Capital Management Holdings Ltd.

The plaques of five of the six recent inductees to the Baseball Hall of Fame will be leaving Cooperstown, N.Y., this month for some long trips.

Powered by serves that reached 143 miles per hour, second-seeded Milos Raonic of Canada reached his first final of the season by beating Donald Young of the United States, 6-4, 7-5, at the Citi Open in Washington.
The bride and groom met during a Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City event.
Both lawyers, the bride and groom are clerks for federal judges in Illinois.
The couple are both at Harvard, where the bride is a postdoctoral fellow and the groom is a microfabrication engineer.
The couple met in law school.
Cheryl Hines, an actress, director and producer, married Robert Kennedy Jr. , an environmental lawyer, on Saturday.
The bride is a senior analyst at an accounting firm. The groom is the director of finance for a natural gas production company.
The bride oversees editorial and social media content for hotel company; the groom is a senior copywriter for an advertising agency.
The couple met at Johns Hopkins.
The bride works as a consultant to schools and nonprofit organizations. The groom is an English teacher.
Mr. Bekier is a lawyer and Mr. Swaden is a talent agent.
The couple met at George Washington University.
The bride is the president of Converse College, and the groom sells construction and farming equipment, and is in the real estate and investment business.
The bride and groom work for congressmen.
The bride plans to receive an M.B.A from Columbia. The groom is a reporter for CNBC.com.
The bride is a contracts and intellectual property lawyer. The groom is the senior producer for “CBS This Morning.”
The bride works for the Sierra Club and the groom works for Accenture.
The bride is in law school; the groom works for a bank.
The bride and groom met while earning master’s degrees from Northwestern.
A documentary cinematographer marries a psychiatrist.
Mr. Wilson is a casting director in Manhattan. Mr. Cuevas is an executive assistant at Bank of America.
The bride is an assistant elementary-school teacher in New York; the groom works for NBC Sports, in New York.
The bride will be a pediatrician. The groom works for an investment company.
The bride works at a girls school; the groom at Nascar.
The couple are among the founders and directors of Lili’s Lift, which benefits children with disabilities.
The bride is a founder of a company devoted to selling healthy food. The groom is studying for two master’s degrees.
The bride is a doctor. The groom is a vice president of an investment bank.
Mr. Hatter works in fund-raising and public relations at the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation; Mr. Montello is a fashion designer at Jump Design Group.
The bride and groom met during an internship program in Washington. She is a Democrat and he is a Republican.

On a soggy track following torrential rain, Usain Bolt gave the Commonwealth Games a display of showmanship and speed to anchor Jamaica’s 4x100-meter relay team to a gold medal at the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow.
Bradley Wright-Phillips scored his Major League Soccer-leading 18th goal of the season and the 10-man Red Bulls beat the New England Revolution, 2-1, in Harrison, N.J.
Kenny Perry eagled the last hole after waiting out a thunderstorm to take a one-shot lead after the second round of the Champions Tour’s 3M Championship in Blaine, Minn.
Trixton won the Hambletonian, beating Nuncio by a half-length in the $1.2 million race for 3-year-old trotting colts and geldings at the New Meadowlands Racetrack in East Rutherford, N.J.
Serena Williams reached her fourth final of the season by taking the last eight games to beat Andrea Petkovic, 7-5, 6-0, on Saturday.
In the first season since Mariano Rivera's retirement, the Yankees have been able to rely on Dellin Betances and David Robertson.
Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Anthony Rendon’s home run and four runs batted in backed up Jordan Zimmermann’s performance on the mound as Washington trounced Philadelphia.
The Canadiens have agreed to terms with defenseman P.K. Subban on an eight-year deal.
The Montreal Canadiens have agreed to terms with defenseman P. K. Subban on an eight-year deal. Subban had 10 goals and 43 assists last season.
Jacob deGrom and the Giants’ Jake Peavy carried no-hit bids through six innings before the Mets scored four runs in the bottom of the seventh to earn the win.

BARROW--Bernie. Gone 21 long years, always in our hearts. Love, Joan and the children

SELIGMANN--Jean, 69, on July 11, 2014, after a long and valiant battle with MS and ovarian cancer. Dear sister of Mary Ascheim, loving aunt and great-aunt of Tom Ascheim, Jane Winston, Nicholas Ascheim and their eight children, devoted friend of June Winters. For 30 years a courageous and talented writer and editor at Newsweek and a lifelong lover of languages, classical and modern. Her sharp wit and gentle wisdom will be long remembered.

SELIGMAN--Lillian, 85, July 30, 2014. Beloved wife of Harvey. Devoted mother of George and Susan Applebaum (Robert) and grandmother of Jonathan, Alana, and Gabrielle. Graveside service held on August 1 at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Queens.

SCAFIDI--Angela F.,passed away on August 2, 2014 in Secaucus, NJ. She retired after 40 plus years from Brown Brothers Harriman (New York City, Financial District) and was the Executive Assistant to Anthony Enders, the Senior Partner. Riotto Funeral Home, Jersey City, NJ. For more information: www.riottofh.com

RABINOWITZ--Rene S.,age 92, was the wife for 45 years of Rubin Rabinowitz of Clifton, NJ. She died peacefully in her sleep Saturday, August 2, 2014. Rene is survived by her sister Dulie (Eugene) Kahn of Falls Church, VA, her sons Andrew of Chicago, IL, and Peter of CA, stepsons Jonathan (Denise) of New York City, Joshua (Richmond) of Montclair, NJ, grandson Alex of Hoboken, NJ, granddaughter Kate of Annapolis, MD, and great-grandson Maxwell, as well as many nieces and nephews. Rene was a successful public relations person until her retirement. She was a member of the board of The Reece School of New York City and of The Citizens Committee for the Children of New York. Through her charities and benefactions, she assisted many organizations. A memorial occasion will be planned for the future in lieu of a service and Shiva.
MORGENSTERN--Frank. Many fond memories of Frank. Love Elaine Schwartz and Family

LANG--David Benjamin, beloved son of the late Justice Irving Lang and Judith Lang. Remembered by his sister, Tammy Lang Hartel, his aunt, Yolanda Mendola and his uncle, Ross Talarico. Poet, musician, beautiful soul. Services today, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. We love you, David, so much.

KELSEY--Harvey M. Jr.,died July 30, 2014 at age 91. His blessed life included Phillips Academy 1941, Princeton 1945, Harvard MBA 1949, US Army 1942-1946, President Talcott Inc., 25 years, CFO Johnson and Higgins eight years, boards of Burke Rehabilitation Hospital, Miriam Osborn Home, and Association for the Protect of the Adirondacks. Marrying Anne Talcott in 1947 was the greatest event of his life. Sharing their love of the outdoors with his five kids created his most cherished memories. Predeceased by Anne his wife of 55 years and Tanner his fifth grandson, he is survived by Peg, Karen, Peter, Jimmy, Harvey, their spouses Grant, David, Brenna, Ellen, and Sue, 14 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

KAYDEN--Herbert J.,We lost a wonderful father and grandfather who was loved by all who knew him. Joelle, Philip and Eleanor; David and Debbie. In Shakespeare's words, "His life was gentle, and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, This was a man."

KATZ--Noah, born March 13, 1952 in White Plains, NY. Left us too soon, July 31, 2014, Jamaica Plain, MA. Pre-deceased by his loving mother Frances (Wollin) Katz; devoted son of Stanley Katz (and stepmother, Florence). Adored brother of Cima Katz (Gary Tebor). Cherished by his cousins, extended family and friends. Noah spent his adult life devoted to working with the elderly. A world traveler and marathon runner, his genuine enthusiasm for life was infectious to all around him. Graveside service at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 130-04 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY on Tuesday, August 5 at 2:00pm.

CHEIT--Earl F. "Budd", died on August 2, 2014 at the age of 87 at home in Kensington, California. He was Edgar F. Kaiser Professor of Business and Public Policy Emeritus and Dean Emeritus of Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. Survived by his wife June, four children and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Haas School of Business or Cal Performances at the University of California.

HORWICH--Ruth, died peacefully in her home in Chicago on July 21st. Born a leap-year baby in 1920, she was really only 23 1/2 years old! Ruth and her late husband Leonard began collecting art in the late 50's, and were drawn to artists such as Alexander Calder, Jean Dubuffet, Wifredo Lam, Eduardo Matta, the Chicago Imagists and European Surrealists. Together they created a diverse collection motivated by what they liked, often buying works by unknown artists. After Leonard's death in 1983, Ruth enthusiastically continued to support artists young and old and to buy folk art, outsider art and local contemporary art along with work by more well-known artists. Ruth donated their large collection of Calder mobiles and stabiles to the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, of which she and Leonard were founding members, and also donated works of art to the Art Institute and to the Smart Museum at the University of Chicago. She was a chair of the Hyde Park Art Center for 40 years and a board member of Poetry Magazine and the Art Institute of Chicago, a supporter of the outsider art museum In'tuit and many theaters in Chicago such as Victory Gardens and Steppenwolf. The Horwiches were also instrumental in donating to the city of Chicago the large outdoor sculpture by Jean Dubuffet which stands in the plaza of the State of Illinois building. They knew many of the artists whose work they collected which gave the collection a special feeling, and this included artists such as Calder, Lam and Dubuffet along with many Chicago artists. She generously opened her home to artists and museum groups and enjoyed sharing her love of art with everyone. As her oldest great grandson, Jasper, said, when asked what he loved about his great-grandmother, "Her house was like a museum but you could touch everything!" She is survived by her four children, Barbara Horwich Lloyd, Jonathan, Ann Snider, Bill, by three grandchildren, Pamela Lloyd (Renny Gleeson), Emily Shaw (Simon Shaw) and Roanne Horwich, and by four great-grandchildren, Jasper, Rufus, Sophie and Willow. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 20th at 3pm at KAM Isaiah Israel Congregation in Chicago. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Hyde Park Art Center, 5020 S. Cornell Ave. Chicago, IL 60615 or to the Museum of Contemporary Art, 220 E. Chicago Ave., Chicago, IL 60611.

BROWN--Nona Baldwin. Mrs. Brown died July 25 in Washington, D.C., aged 96. She was preceded in death by her sister, Elizabeth Baldwin Montbach; her brother, Thomas Baldwin; and her husband, Clinton B.D. Brown. She is survived by 11 nieces and nephews; many great-nieces and nephews, and a multitude of great-grand-nieces and nephews. Memorial celebration Sunday, August 10, 2pm, Grand Oaks, 5901 MacArthur Blvd., Washington, D.C. Memorial donations to Vassar College, or to a local Humane Society.

BALL--Helen Sheila (nee Rothenberg), 94, passed away on August 2, 2014. Born on January 3, 1920 in Brooklyn, NY, predeceased by her late husbands, Daniel David Goldberg and Sidney Ball. Mother (and Mother-In Law) to Marc Stuart Goldberg, Paul Cary Goldberg and his wife, Lee, Elyse Robin Spielberg and her husband, Melvin and Lynne Dale Goldberg Wool and her husband, Robert. Grandmother to David and Andrew Spielberg, Rebecca Goldberg and Simon and Ezra Wool. A Second Mother to David Ball and Barbara Buff and a Second Grandmother and Great-Grandmother to Rachel and Sarah and their children. A funeral service will be held 10:00am Tuesday, August 5, at Rosenthal Memorial Chapel, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah.

BARROW--Bernie. Gone 21 long years, always in our hearts. Love, Joan and the children

WEINTRAUB--Max. We mourn the loss of an instinctively kind man whose life was enveloped in doing good. A devoted alumnus of our school, Max Weintraub exemplified the noblest ideals of charity. With modesty, he assisted numerous deserving causes. He gave greatly of his means and he gave greatly of his spirit, mentoring well into his eighties public school children from disadvantaged homes. May his memory remain a blessing. Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, Marvin Schick, President

TUCKER--Sheila Bullock, of Vero Beach, FL. Born November 12, 1937, Glen Cove, NY. Died July 31, 2014. Mother of Marian W. Payson, Parker L. Payson, Bryan R. Tucker. Wife of the late Harry K. Tucker, Jr. Sister of the late Cynthia Lake Woodger and the late H. Ridgely Bullock, Jr. Cousin of Edith S. Bouriez. Daughter of the late Marian Batterman Bullock and H. Ridgely Bullock. Survived by daughters-in-law Helen P. Wiley and Mary A. Williams and six grandchildren. Memorial service September 20, 2014, 11am, Trinity Episocpal Church, Vero Beach, FL. Interment at Locust Valley Cemetery. Contributions may be made to VNA Hospice Foundation, 1110 35th Lane, Vero Beach, FL 32960.

SUSSKIND--Maud, 87, of Boca Raton, FL passed away peacefully on Sunday, August 3, 2014. Born in Amsterdam, formerly of Manhattan and Westhampton Beach, NY. Survived by four children and five grandchildren. More info: glickfamilyfuneralhome.com.

SOBEL--Gerson, 104, died peacefully in his home in Rockville Centre. Gerson graduated Syracuse University where he was captain of the water polo team. After college, he sailed the Caribbean until returning to Manhattan to go into the stationery business. A great storyteller, his stories about New York and New Yorkers were a source of fascination and laughter to everyone who heard them. When he retired, he resumed competitive swimming and was inducted into the Metropolitan Hall of Fame in 2012. Preceded in death by his wife, Pearl, and son James, he is survived by his daughter Judith, son Tom (Marge), grandchildren Paul, Erik, Lisa, David and Daniel and by his great-grandchildren, Hawkins and Macy. A celebration of Gerson's life will be announced and held later. The family requests no flowers.
SERRANO--Miguel, We will never forget your courage dear friend. Love, Arlene Harrison and The Gramercy Park Block Association

SCHECHTER--Paulette. The Trustees of The Fire Island Synagogue are greatly saddened to learn of the passing of Paulette Schechter, mother of Co-President and Treasurer, Ed Schechter. Our deepest condolences to Ed, Wendi, Deborah, Diane and their families. The Fire Island Synagogue Shaul Magid, Rabbi Basya Schechter, Cantor

SCHECHTER--Paulette, 92, on August 4, 2014. Beloved wife of her late husband Nathan. Devoted mother of Ed (Wendi), Deborah, and Diane and grandmother of David and Rachel. A funeral service will be held 12 noon, Wednesday, August 6, at Star of David Chapel, 1236 Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY.

REIZES--Alyce Callahan, 71, Highland Beach, FL, formally Lake Success, NY died July 28, 2014. Survived by son Thomas H. (wife Gwyn and son Henry) Reizes of Albany, NY, and partner Jerry Kozierow. A memorial to be held in Highland Beach, Fl. Interment in Arlington Cemetery, Drexel Hill, PA. Contributions may be made in her name to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, www.ccfa.org.

POST--Steve. The Board of Trustees and Staff of New York Public Radio mourn the loss of Steve Post. Answering to no one, Steve graced WNYC's air for more than 25 years, sharing his unique take on the day's news, his irreverence and beautiful music with a devoted audience. He hosted WNYC's Morning Music and The No Show. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Laura, his family, his friends and his countless fans. Cynthia King Vance, Chair; Laura Walker, President and CEO

POLL--Christine. Born February 20, 1918 - died peacefully at home in New York, August 2, 2014. She was 96. Her culinary talents pioneered the creation and growth of the gourmet food profession and along with her husband of 60 years, William Poll, ran a successful, family owned gourmet business on the Upper East Side. There she was responsible for the introduction of new foods and ideas which included her infamous Baked Potato Thins of which her mantra was "baked, not fried". A warm and vivacious woman, she had time and interest for everyone and was always generous to those in need. She will be remembered for her tireless charity work for her church, her school, the Ronald McDonald House and various other charities. Beloved mother of William, Jr., (and Edith), Stanley, Joy (and Chris Steele), Anita (and Ted Nussbaum), Tana, (and Cliff Hunnicutt), James, Maria and (Paul Hadjiyane). Adored grandmother of Christine Ladikos, William III, Timothy O'Sullivan, Dean, Christopher, Damian and Justin Steele and adoring great-grandmother of Constantine and Vassili Ladikos, Kori, Nicholas and Alex Steele and William Poll IV. Also her devoted niece Sultana Tselides. Adored daughter-in-law Katina Poll and loving caregiver Flora Boholst. Viewing at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. on Wednesday and Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. Funeral services on Friday 9:30am at The Transfiguration of Christ Greek Orthodox Church, 38-05 98th St., Corona. Internment Mt Olivet Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Transfiguration Church, St Basil's Academy, The Garden School, St Michael's Home for The Aged, Ronald McDonald House or the Make-A-Wish Foundation.

PARKER--Gilbert Selwyn, passed on August 3 at the age of 86 after a lengthy illness. Dr. Parker received his Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering in 1947 and Master of Science in Mechanical Engineering in 1949, both from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and his Ph.D in Engineering from Columbia University in 1964. After serving in the Army Corps of Engineers, Dr. Parker spent most of his career at IBM. He is survived by his loving sons Jeffrey Parker and Christopher Parker.

KLEINHAUS--Felicia. It is with overwhelming sadness that we announce the passing of Felicia Kleinhaus on July 27, 2014. Felicia was the beloved wife of Natan, as well as of the late Daniel Kleinman; mother of Robert, Madlein and Abigail; adored grandmother of Alex, Drew, Emily, Dillon and Joshua. She was a source of strength and grace to all who knew and loved her and will be missed but never forgotten.

KAYDEN--Herbert J.,M.D. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our esteemed and beloved friend Herbert Kayden. A man of enormous warmth, wisdom, and kindness, he was a distinguished, caring, and compassionate physician. Herb heartily championed the University's mission of science for the benefit of humanity. Together with his cherished wife, Gabrielle Reem, he was a frequent visitor to campus, bringing a profound curiosity and passion to our biological research initiatives. He enjoyed many friendships with our faculty, who treasured their time with him. A true Renaissance man, his interests extended well beyond the sciences, especially to art where his taste was visionary, and his friendships with artists were deep. His kindness was matched by his generosity, greatly benefitting this institution and others. At Rockefeller, he supported young scientists and he established a chair in memory of Gabrielle. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children and grandchildren: Joelle, Philip, and Eleanor; David and Debbie; and the entire Kayden family. Russell L. Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Barry S. Coller, Physician-in-Chief Paul Greengard, Vincent Astor Professor Cori Bargmann, Torsten N. Wiesel Professor Vanessa Ruta, Gabrielle H. Reem and Herbert J. Kayden Assistant Professor

KAYDEN--Dr. Herbert J. Storm King Art Center mourns the loss of Dr. Herbert J. Kayden, a friend and supporter. He and his late wife, Dr. Gabrielle Reem, were visionary collectors who befriended many great artists. We will remember his passion for art and his extraordinary generosity and wisdom.
HALSEY--Stephen Simmons. June 13, 1927 to April 22, 2014. President Emeritus of the American Express Foundation. Survived by his wife Louise, daughter Alexandra, son Nicholas, and six grandchildren.

GLASSMAN--Robert Martin, of Livingston died at home on August 4, 2014. The beloved husband, father, and grandfather was 87 years old. Services will be held 11:30am Wedenesday at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman in Livingston with interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Bob was a proud graduate of New Utrecht High. He worked many jobs during his youth, including stints at the original Nathan's in Coney Island, as a Good Humor man, and many summers during college at White Roe Lake hotel in the Catskills experiences which became the source of many interesting and instructive anecdotes for children and grandchildren. Bob majored in economics at Brooklyn College, graduating in 1948. Starting his own business while still in college, he soon established a children's apparel business, Kenilworth Sportswear, which he grew from a one-man operation to an organization with national distribution and over 350 employees. He was the president of the company until he retired in 2006. He married the love of his life, Sandra (Sandy) Gottesman, also a Brooklyn College grad, who worked beside him in the business and life for over 60 years. They enjoyed vacations at various ocean resorts, from South Carolina to Florida to Mexico to Colombia, and they made friends everywhere they went. Bob had a keen intellect and avid curiosity. He was very well-read, enjoyed basketball, and loved to talk with people from all walks of life about their hometowns, careers, and interests. Besides Sandra, he is survived by his three children Andrew, Peter, and Caryl, and Andrew's wife, Jean Folsom, and Caryl's husband, Thomas Donatucci. He is also survived by his four grandchildren Jonathan, Carlie, Gabrielle and Madeleine and by his sister, Beulah Laub. His family is greatful for the loving care given to him by his aides, Tuns, Gloria and Olinto. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Brooklyn College, the Southern Poverty Law Center, or Doctors without Borders.

FINKELSTEIN--Dr. James, died peacefully on Friday, August 1, 2014, at the Williams House Hospice at the Washington, DC Home. A beloved husband and partner in love and learning with Barbara Finkelstein, his wife of 54 years; a wise and passionate champion of daughters Donna Finkelstein and Ed Magarian; and Laura Helene Finkelstein. A beacon of strength, love and laughter as grandfather "Turtle Papa" to Brian and Hannah Magarian and Matthew, Talia and Courtney Loeb; dear brother of Miriam (Melvyn) Davis. Graveside funeral services will be held on Wednesday, August 6, 2014, 11am at Judean Memorial Gardens, Olney, MD. Barbara and family will be at home for friends and family in Washington, DC on Tuesday from 7-9pm, on Wednesday after the service and Thursday and Friday from 7-9pm. Services entrusted to Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, Washington, DC. 800-500-5401.

EPPS--Dru. The entire Hebrew Home at Riverdale family mourns the loss of Dru Epps. Dru was a kind, considerate member of the RiverWalk community, beloved by her daughter Kim, son-in-law Jeff Greenberg, her grandchildren and all who had the privilege of knowing her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Epps and Greenberg families. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

CHEIT--Earl F. "Budd", died on August 2, 2014 at the age of 87 at home in Kensington, California. He was Edgar F. Kaiser Professor of Business and Public Policy Emeritus and Dean Emeritus of Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. Survived by his wife June, four children and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Haas School of Business or Cal Performances at the University of California.

CASTELNUOVO-TEDESCO--Lisbeth Stone, of New York, NY, died on Friday, August 1st, 2014 after a long illness. She was 78. Lisbeth was born in Belmont, MA and received her BA from Smith College. She lived over the years in Florence, Los Angeles, Nash- ville and New York. She was married to the late Pietro Castelnuovo-Tedesco, the James G. Blakemore Professor of Psychiatry at Vanderbilt University. She was a scholar of medieval art history, having earned her PhD at the University of California Los Angeles, and was the co-author of "Italian Medieval Sculpture in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Cloisters" in 2010. She is survived by her daughters Diana and Costanza Castelnuovo-Tede- sco. A private memorial service will be held in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Lisbeth's memory to the Metro- politan Museum of Art. Please specify that the gift is in memory of Lisbeth Castelnuovo-Tedesco and include the additional instructions of "For the Department of Medieval Art."

BROWN--Nona Baldwin. Mrs. Brown died July 25 in Washington, D.C., aged 96. She was preceded in death by her sister, Elizabeth Baldwin Montbach; her brother, Thomas Baldwin; and her husband, Clinton B.D. Brown. She is survived by 11 nieces and nephews; many great-nieces and nephews, and a multitude of great-grand-nieces and nephews. Memorial celebration Sunday, August 10, 2pm, Grand Oaks, 5901 MacArthur Blvd., Washington, D.C. Memorial donations to Vassar College, or to a local Humane Society.

BRIGELL--Sylvia, 98 on August 3, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Max, devoted mother of Barbara and Cynthia, proud grandmother of Daniel, Eila, Stephanie and Lauren, great-grandmother of Andrew and Max.

BRAGAZZI--Olive Lawson, on August 2, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Anthony Joseph. Loving mother of John Anthony. Curator for many years of prominent private art collections and later the Director of the Pierre Matisse Foundation. Reposing at the Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York City, Wednesday and Thursday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Wellfleet Public Library, 55 West Main Street, Wellfleet, MA 02667.

BLOOMFIELD--Randall D.,M.D., SUNY Downstate Medical Center mourns the passing of Randall D. Bloomfield, MD, a 1953 graduate of the College of Medicine who remained involved with Downstate over his long and distinguished career. A strong advocate for Downstate, he was a current member of the campus College Council. Dr. Bloomfield was a pillar of the community and a beloved icon for his contributions to health care and to addressing health disparities throughout Brooklyn. Among the projects he nurtured was PRISM, a program that brought students from the Medgar Evers College Preparatory School to Downstate for career counseling and mentoring. A member of many professional societies and the recipient of numerous honors, he was an attending at Kings County Hospital Center and held faculty appointments at Downstate from 1958 until his retirement in 1999. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family, colleagues, and friends. John F. Williams, Jr., MD, EdD, MPH, FCCM President Ian L. Taylor, MD, PhD Dean of the College of Medicine

BEAN--Kenneth, of South Orange, NJ and Longboat Key, FL died peacefully on August 4, 2014 at the age of 92. He is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Anne Alexander Bean, their two sons, Thomas and Douglas, and their wives Elaine Becker and Sue Bean, his three grandchildren, Sam, Bradley and Emily, his brother Donald and his sister Gloria. He was a 1943 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and received an MBA from the Wharton School in 1947. He was co-founder, and for many years President, of Tollner & Bean, Inc., dealers in Municipal Bonds. During WWII he served in the US Navy as a Lieutenant aboard the Destroyer Escort USS Holt in the Atlantic and Pacific Theaters. Known to some and unknown to many of his family and friends, he was a published poet. In one of his poems he wrote of the paradox his children confronted in knowing their father as a man of business but also as someone who was exhilarated when he wrote poems. He always considered the literary part of his life to be an important part of who he was. Services will be held on August 6, 2014 at 1:00pm at Bernheim Apter Funeral Home, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ.
