SWARTZ--Barbara E.,died peacefully in New York on July 31, 2014 at age 69 after a long period of declining health. Formerly the director of the New York University Law School's clinic at Bedford Hills Prison, she later became a Distinguished Professor of Law at Touro College Law Center, Long Island, where she also created the school's human rights program in Berlin. A long-time human rights advocate, she served as a consultant to the World Health Organization and other international groups. Her passion later in life was mediation, helping people amicably resolve both domestic and workplace disputes. For several years, she served as a commentator on Court TV. She earned a J.D. from NYU and master's degrees in political science and public health from the Universities of Michigan and Columbia, respectively. Barbara was diagnosed with kidney disease at age 28 and spent 12 years on hemodialysis before receiving a kidney transplant, which sustained her life during the past 18 years. She demonstrated an indomitable will to live a full life and to act on her commitment to human rights in spite of the limitations imposed by illnesses, inspiring many by her example. Barbara loved to travel and developed lasting friendships worldwide. She met her husband, Knud-Erik Rosenkrantz, in Copenhagen 35 years ago. In lieu of a funeral, a celebration of Barbara's life will be held at a later time. Donations may be sent to: Compassion & Choices of New York, 244 Fifth Avenue, #

SCHECHTER--Paulette, 92, on August 4, 2014. Beloved wife of her late husband Nathan. Devoted mother of Ed (Wendi), Deborah, and Diane and grandmother of David and Rachel. A funeral service will be held 12 noon, Wednesday, August 6, at Star of David Chapel, 1236 Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY.

ROSENGARTEN--Frank. The Officers and Directors of Wellwood Cemetery Association, Inc. and Beth Moses Cemetery Corporation mourn the passing of our colleague and fellow officer and Director of many years Frank Rosengarten. His wise counsel and genial countenance will be sorely missed.

ROSENGARTEN--Frank, was a truly extraordinary person. He fell in love with Italy as a young man and devoted the rest of his life to studies related to its culture and politics, receiving a PhD from Columbia University in the 1950's in Italian. He wrote many books and numerous articles on important people in the anti-fascist press there. This passion tied in with his longtime interest in socialism, and he was a co-founder and an editor of the journal Socialism and Democracy. Gramsci became a special focus of his work and he translated Gramsci's letters from prison. A professor of Italian studies at several universities, he was Professor Emeritus at Queens College. But his interests covered many subjects unrelated to Italian, and included a love of theater, movies, and music and books, which he devoured on many subjects. But more important than his many accomplishments, including receiving his second Doctorate, in his retirement, in French from The CUNY graduate Center. His dissertation on the young Proust received an award. More importantly was his gift for friendship. His love for and loyalty to friends and family were total. If you had the rare privilege of being part of his circle, you had a friend and mentor for life. He adored his children Dan and Lydia, and his late son, Philip as well as his grandchildren, Melina and Emi, and his sister Jo. He was also a devoted husband of over 30 years to his late wife, Lucille. He was irreplaceable and his absence will leave a big hole in all their hearts. A memorial service will be held at the Casa Italiana in the fall, and there will be a shiva on Thursday night at his apartment, 160 East 84th. He will leave a hole in peoples hearts and lives.

RODNICK--Warren, on August 5, 2014. Longtime resident of Great Neck. Beloved husband of Carole, Loving Father of Myles (Elizabeth) and Stuart (Stephanie), Cherished Grandfather of Olivia, Charles, Justin, Jared and Daisy, brother to Ilene. Warren was a successful businessman, a lover of the arts, avid reader, accomplished horticulturist and sports enthusiast. A true intellectual and a spirited Maverick. He will be missed.

POLL--Christine. Born February 20, 1918 - died peacefully at home in New York, August 2, 2014. She was 96. Her culinary talents pioneered the creation and growth of the gourmet food profession and along with her husband of 60 years, William Poll, ran a successful, family owned gourmet business on the Upper East Side. There she was responsible for the introduction of new foods and ideas which included her infamous Baked Potato Thins of which her mantra was "baked, not fried". A warm and vivacious woman, she had time and interest for everyone and was always generous to those in need. She will be remembered for her tireless charity work for her church, her school, the Ronald McDonald House and various other charities. Beloved mother of William, Jr., (and Edith), Stanley, Joy (and Chris Steele), Anita (and Ted Nussbaum), Tana (and Cliff Hunnicutt), James, Maria and (Paul Hadjiyane). Adored grandmother of Christine Ladikos, William III, Timothy O'Sullivan, Dean, Christopher, Damian and Justin Steele and adoring great-grandmother of Constantine and Vassili Ladikos, Kori, Nicholas and Alex Steele and William Poll IV. Also her devoted niece Sultana Tselides. Adored daughter-in-law Katina Poll and loving caregiver Flora Boholst. Viewing at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. on Wednesday and Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. Funeral services on Friday 9:30am at The Transfiguration of Christ Greek Orthodox Church, 38-05 98th St., Corona. Internment Mt Olivet Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Transfiguration Church, St Basil's Academy, The Garden School, St Michael's Home for The Aged, Ronald McDonald House or the Make-A-Wish Foundation.

PHELAN--Frances (Frank) Wallace, businessman and philanthropist, 88, passed away Monday, August 4th, 2014. He died in the comfort of his home in Melville, New York, surrounded by his family. Born in Brooklyn, New York, on June 15, 1926, he was the loving son of Frances Phelan and Florence Wallace and was married to Mary (Ahern) Phelan for 68 years. He is survived by his wife; three children, Mark (and Maryellen) Phelan of Chappaqua, Deborah Phelan of Sausalito, California, and Frank Phelan of Point Lookout; six grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by one grandchild. In a career which spanned over sixty years, Mr. Phelan's business endeavors included serving as the Vice-President and Owner of The DIC Concrete Corporation, which completed construction on many New York City landmarks including 101 Park Avenue, the original 1 World Trade Center, the Pan Am building, Lefrak City, Albany Office Tower, and Trump Towers. Since 1970, through a DIC Concrete subsidiary, DIC Underhill JV, he completed construction of Co-op and Starrett Cities, and many other major buildings. He was a leading developer of both low income and luxury housing, including Liberty Court, Liberty House, and Liberty Terrace in Battery Park City. He was one of the principle owners of BSR Management Corp., Capital Airlines Inc., and Certified Industries Inc. In 1975, prior to the Iranian Revolution, Mr. Phelan oversaw and completed the construction of Farahzad and Ekbatan, the largest mass housing complex in western Tehran. His legacy as a great businessman can be seen not only through his tangible accomplishments, but also through the many people for whom he was a mentor and a source of inspiration. One colleague of over forty years recently described him as a "gentle, gentle, gentleman." His charitable work is channeled through the Phelan Foundation, which supports causes such as Building Homes for Hero's, an organization providing veterans housing; and the humanitarian work of agencies such as Doctors without Borders, The Sisters of the Poor, and St. Jude's Hospital. He also generously donated to the Catholic Church. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, August 6th, 2014, at the Vernon C. Wagner Funeral Home in Plainview, New York between 5-9pm. The Funeral mass follows on Thursday, August 7th, 2014, at Plainview's St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church at 11am. Mr. Phelan will be buried at St. Charles Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Phelan Foundation.
MORGENSTERN--Frank. Our condolence to the Morgenstern family - Richard, Carol and Alan. Gary and Sharyn Kevin Stuart and Thea Kayne

KAYDEN--Dr. Herbert J. The entire Bard College community mourns the passing of Dr. Herbert J. Kayden who, along with his late wife, Dr. Gabrielle H. Reem, shared a belief in education and love of the arts generously with the College. They supported Bard's science program, providing funds for the science and computation building that bears their names as well as scholarships for students to study at Bard and at Bard's partnership program with The Rockefeller University. We were honored to present them with the John and Samuel Bard Award in Medicine and Science. We will deeply miss Dr. Kayden's kindness, sharp intellect, and warmth, and will remember him always with affection and respect. We extend our condolences to his children, Joelle and David, and his grandchildren. Charles P. Stevenson Jr., Chair David E. Schwab II, '52, Chair Emeritus Leon Botstein, President

MARCALUS--Robert Louis, passed away at home surrounded by family on Monday, August 4, 2014. He was born in Plainfield, NJ in 1921. Robert grew up in Elizabeth, NJ and attended the Pingry School and the University of Vermont. Mr. Marcalus enlisted in the United States Navy in World War II, served on an attack transport ship and was honorably discharged in 1946. After naval service, Robert resumed his employment with the family business Marcalus Manufacturing Co, which was started by his father, Nicholas, in 1932. Robert was a self-taught papermaker with exceptional interpersonal skills. The family business eventually evolved into Marcal Paper Mills, Inc. Robert had a tireless work ethic. His astute business leadership enabled him to oversee business operations in Elmwood Park, Bloomfield, Philadelphia, Massachusetts, California, Florida, Maine and New Hampshire. In 1970 Robert became President of Marcal. Upon the death of his father in 1979, he became Chairman of the Board and CEO. Marcal continued to operate as a family business until 2008. Even with all of his business responsibilities, he knew by name and he knew the personal stories of the many hundreds of people that worked for the company. For over 45 years and up to his passing, Robert was President of Green Acre Woodlands, Inc., a timberlands and real estate investment company. Working closely with the NH Forest Legacy Program, Robert's leadership of Green Acre resulted in the preservation of thousands of acres of New Hampshire forests for open spaces, agriculture and public recreational use. Mr. Marcalus was a longtime member and devoted parishioner of the Church Of Saint Elizabeth, Wyckoff, NJ. He married his childhood sweetheart, the former Norma Altenburg. Robert and Norma recently celebrated their 72nd wedding anniversary. They have lived in Wyckoff, NJ since 1946. Robert and Norma are parents of son Nicholas and wife Emily of Sugarloaf, PA, daughter Jeannette and husband Charles Bonin of Morristown, NJ, predeceased son Robert, survived by daughter-in-law Dariel of Pompton Plains, NJ, daughter Anne Sedler of Hawthorne NJ, daughter Lisa Perkowski of Basking Ridge, NJ and son Peter and wife Karen of Oakland, NJ. They are blessed with 17 grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren. He was a devoted husband, loving father, generous patron to many individuals and charities. He deeply believed in service to the community. Robert will be remembered as a true gentleman in every sense and an individual who cared about people. There will be a celebration of Robert's life with a memorial service at The Church of St. Elizabeth, 700 Wyckoff Ave, Wyckoff, NJ on Friday, August 8th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in his memory to Saint Joseph's Regional Medical Center Foundation, Paterson, NJ. Donation link at http://bit.ly/1olR54p. Services handled by the Vander Plaat Funeral Home of Wyckoff (www.vpfh.com).

HERTZLICH--Leonard, died peacefully at home, August 4, 2014 at the age of 92, of North Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Briarcliff Manor, NY. Born in the Bronx, NY to Emma and Herman Hertzlich. After serving in the 119th Signal Service Corps, graduated Fordham University with a degree in B.S. in Pharmacy. Owned and operated several retail pharmacies in Westchester County, NY. Pre-deceased by his beloved wife of 53 years, Ruth Hertzlich. Survived by daughters Helaine Hertzlich and Caryl Hahn, son-in-law Jeffrey Hahn; grand-children Zoe, Michael, Evan and Ali; and partner Lenore Mintzer. Loving uncle and great uncle. Graveside service Thursday, August 7th at 2:00pm at Mt. Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.
HATTENBACH--Flora, of Long Beach and East Meadow, NY on Wednesday, July 30, 2014. Wife of the late Leonard. Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Funeral services are private.

HASTINGS--Gerald A.,of Oradell, NJ (formerly of New City, NY) passed away on August 4, 2014. Father of Mary Elizabeth "Baby," Devon "Bones," Molly "Peanut" and Owen "Boo." Son of Joan and the late Gerald. Brother of Linda Kane (Andy), Robert (Jeanine), Kevin (Cathy) and the late Stephen. Friends may call today 3-5pm and 7-9pm at the Higgins Funeral Home 321 South Main Street, New City, NY. A Mass of Christian burial will be offered on Thursday, 11am at St. Francis of Assisi Church, West Nyack, New York.

GRAMMAS--Michael, of Bedford Corners, passed away peacefully on August 2, 2014. He was born on January 3, 1939 in Apidia, Greece to Theodore and Konstandina Grammas. He immigrated to the US with his family as a teenager. Michael was the owner of Michael's Florist in the Bronx for many years before owning the Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle. Michael was a loving, giving, honest and hardworking man whose greatest joy was spending time with his family. He also enjoyed fishing, was a huge fan of soccer and most especially loved gardening. He is survived by his beloved wife, Christina. He was a loving father of five children who survive him: Andreas (Ageliki), Dennis (Carrie), Frangiskos, Michelle (Aurelio), and Tina. He was the proud and cherished grandfather of five grandchildren: Alexandria, Christina, Eleni, Elisavet and Maria Louiza. He will be deeply missed. The family will receive condolences during visitation on Thursday morning, August 7, 2014 from 9:45-11:00am at The Church of Our Saviour in Rye, NY. A funeral service will follow at 11am followed by the burial to be held at the Greenwood Union Cemetery in Rye, New York. Luncheon to follow at Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Michael's memory to Save the Children, 501 Kings Hwy E, Fairfield, CT 06825. Donations can also be submitted electronically as well at www.savethechildren.org.

FRIEDMAN--Loretta. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Loretta Friedman. She passed peacefully in her sleep in the presence of her family on August 4th, 2014 at her home at 25 Central Park West. She is survived by her loving husband, Bernard and her two daughters Jessica and Jacqueline. A memorial service for friends and family is scheduled for Thursday, August 7th, 2014 at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY .

FLOMENHAFT--Kalman, passed away on August 5, 2014, after 80 years. His heart and beautiful soul emphasized family strength and togetherness with loved ones and in his profession as Social Worker and Family Therapist. Survivors are his wife Flora; children David and his spouse Marion; Brenda and our friend Joan; Susan and her spouse Mark; and four grandchildren Anne, Alana, Adam and Julia.

CHEIT--Earl F. "Budd", died on August 2, 2014 at the age of 87 at home in Kensington, California. He was Edgar F. Kaiser Professor of Business and Public Policy Emeritus and Dean Emeritus of Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. Survived by his wife June, four children and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Haas School of Business or Cal Performances at the University of California.

BROWN--Nona Baldwin. Mrs. Brown died July 25 in Washington, D.C., aged 96. She was preceded in death by her sister, Elizabeth Baldwin Montbach; her brother, Thomas Baldwin; and her husband, Clinton B.D. Brown. She is survived by 11 nieces and nephews; many great-nieces and nephews, and a multitude of great-grand-nieces and nephews. Memorial celebration Sunday, August 10, 2pm, Grand Oaks, 5901 MacArthur Blvd., Washington, D.C. Memorial donations to Vassar College, or to a local Humane Society.

BRAGAZZI--Olive. The Board and staff of the Pierre and Tana Matisse Foundation mourn the passing of Olive Bragazzi, director of the former Pierre Matisse Foundation. Throughout her long career, Ms. Bragazzi was an enlightened leader with a steadfast commitment to the arts. She will be remembered for the generosity of spirit that made her an invaluable friend and colleague. Robert H. Horowitz, President Alessandra Carnielli, Exec. Dir. Eugene V. Thaw, VP Emeritus

BEAN--Kenneth, of South Orange, NJ and Longboat Key, FL died peacefully on August 4, 2014 at the age of 92. He is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Anne Alexander Bean, their two sons, Thomas and Douglas, and their wives Elaine Becker and Sue Bean, his three grandchildren, Sam, Bradley and Emily, his brother Donald and his sister Gloria. He was a 1943 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and received an MBA from the Wharton School in 1947. He was co-founder, and for many years President, of Tollner & Bean, Inc., dealers in Municipal Bonds. During WWII he served in the US Navy as a Lieutenant aboard the Destroyer Escort USS Holt in the Atlantic and Pacific Theaters. Known to some and unknown to many of his family and friends, he was a published poet. In one of his poems he wrote of the paradox his children confronted in knowing their father as a man of business but also as someone who was exhilarated when he wrote poems. He always considered the literary part of his life to be an important part of who he was. Services will be held on August 6, 2014 at 1:00pm at Bernheim Apter Funeral Home, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ.

WILLIAMS--Richard. Director of The Fresh Air Fund's Camp Tommy. The Fresh Air Fund, its Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of Richard Williams. Richard worked for The Fund for over 40 years, beginning as a junior counselor in 1966. He was a Senior Camp Director and Director of Camp Tommy, formerly known as Camp Pioneer. Richard was dedicated to improving the lives of the thousands of New York City children who benefited from his guidance, direction and commitment. He was a mentor and role model to the campers and friend to us all. We offer our deepest sympathy and heartfelt condolences to his family, and we are saddened by this profound loss. A memorial service will be held on Sunday August 10, 2014 at 3:00pm at the Judkins Colonial Home, 428 West 4th Street, Plainfield, New Jersey 07060. William P. Lauder Chairman of the Board John N. Irwin III President Jenny Morgenthau Executive Director The Fresh Air Fund

WENGROVER--Anita. It is with overwhelming sadness that we announce the passing of Anita Wengrover, wife of the late Bernard Wengrover, on August 5, 2014. Anita died peacefully in her home in Boca Raton, Florida. A devoted mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister and aunt, she loved and was loved by her children, 11 grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Anita was known for her beauty, strength, and zest for life. May her memory remain a blessing.

VOLINO--Kathryn. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of Ronald McDonald House New York mourn the passing of Kathryn Volino, wife of the former Chief Financial Officer, Francis Volino and longtime friend and supporter of our organization. STOLLERMAN--Gene H. M.D.,passed away on August 1, 2014 at the age of 93. He was born in Brooklyn, New York on December 6, 1920. He was a graduate of Dartmouth ('41) and Columbia University P&S ('44). He served in the US Army as a Captain in the Medical Corp. He was a renowned national and international pioneer of the research and treatment of rheumatic fever. He was also lauded as a great teacher and mentor who inspired two generations of students who carry on his approach to clinical care, research and teaching. He is survived by his children, John Stollerman and Anne DiZio; daughter-in-law Rhonda Stollerman, granddaughters Jennifer Meyburg Landrebe, Sarah DiZio, and Corynne Stollerman, and numerous relatives. He was predeceased by first wife, Corynne M. Stollerman, second wife Vita M. Stollerman, and his daughter Lee Stollerman Meyburg. He published a memoir, Medicine: A Love Story. Dr. Stollerman strove to develop a humanistic approach to medicine, considering each patient, colleague and student with empathy and compassion. Contributions can be made to Lake Sunapee Region VNA and Hospice or Doctors Without Borders.
SCHACHTER--Irving. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the sudden loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to his family. Louis M. Solomon, Parnas

ROSENGARTEN--Frank. The Officers and Directors of Wellwood Cemetery Association, Inc. and Beth Moses Cemetery Corporation mourn the passing of our colleague and fellow officer and Director of many years Frank Rosengarten. His wise counsel and genial countenance will be sorely missed.

ROSENGARTEN--Frank. Frank was a truly extraordinary person. He fell in love with Italy as a young man and devoted the rest of his life to studies related to its culture and politics, receiving a PhD from Columbia University in Italian. He wrote many books and numerous articles on important people in the anti-fascist press there. This passion tied in with his longtime interest in socialism, and he was a co-founder and an editor of the journal Socialism and Democracy. Gramsci became a special focus of his work and he edited Gramsci's Letters from Prison. A professor of Italian studies at several universities, he was Professor Emeritus at Queens College. But his interests covered many subjects unrelated to Italian, and included a love of theater, movies, music and books, which he devoured on many subjects. During his retirement, he received a second doctorate in French from the CUNY Graduate Center, and his dissertation on the young Proust received an award. But more important than all his accomplishments was his gift for friendship. His love for and loyalty to friends and family were total. If you had the rare privilege of being part of his circle, you had a friend and mentor for life. He adored his children Dan and Lydia, his grandchildren, Melina and Emi, and his sister Jo. He was irreplaceable and his absence will leave a big hole in all their hearts and lives. A memorial service will be held at the Casa Italiana in the fall, and there will be a shiva on Thursday night at his apartment, 160 East 84th St.

RODNICK--Warren, on August 5, 2014. Longtime resident of Great Neck. Beloved husband of Carole, Loving Father of Myles (Elizabeth) and Stuart (Stephanie), Cherished Grandfather of Olivia, Charles, Justin, Jared and Daisy, brother to Ilene. Warren was a successful businessman, a lover of the arts, avid reader, accomplished horticulturist and sports enthusiast. A true intellectual and a spirited Maverick. He will be missed.

RALSTON--Martin A.,resident of New Rochelle and formerly of Brooklyn, passed away August 6, 2014 at the age of 92. Devoted husband of Ruth, father of Amy Ralston Seife, father-in-law of Howard Seife, and grandfather of Emily, Alexander and William. Funeral to be held Friday, August 8 at 10am at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont. Shiva at the Seife home in Larchmont. For more information go to: JJFFH.com.
MOOMJY--Albert. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and long time friend, Albert Moomjy, and send condolences to his family.

KAYDEN--Dr. Herbert J. The trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Herbert J. Kayden, MD, professor emeritus of Medicine and a distinguished cardiologist and scientist in the NYU Department of Medicine. A 1943 graduate of NYU School of Medicine, Dr. Kayden's investigations surrounding arrhythmias were instrumental in developing treatment protocols in the 1950s, and as a physician, he was at the forefront of preventive cardiology. Each year, the Division of Cardiology bestows the Herbert Kayden Award to an outstanding physician-scientist who works in the areas that Dr. Kayden pioneered. Dr. Kayden was married to Gabrielle Reem, MD, professor emeritus of Pharmacology, who passed away in 2011, and their son, David S. Kayden, MD, is a 1980 alumnus of NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Kayden will be remembered for his devotion to medicine, science, his patients, and NYU Langone Medical Center. Our community extends our deep condolences to his family and friends. Robert I. Grossman, MD, The Saul J. Farber Dean and CEO, NYU Langone Medical Center

FLOMENHAFT--Kalman, passed away on August 5, 2014, after 80 years. His heart and beautiful soul emphasized family strength and togetherness with loved ones and in his profession as Social Worker and Family Therapist. Survivors are his wife Flora; children David and his spouse Marion; Brenda and our friend Joan; Susan and her spouse Mark; and four grandchildren Anne, Alana, Adam and Julia.

FAUER--Stanley, age 91, passed away on August 4, 2014 in Palm Beach, FL. Formerly of Woodmere, NY and Flint, MI. Beloved husband of Pat; loving father of Robert (Kristina), Stephen (Shari) and David. Cherished grandfather of Allie, Erin and Chase. Stanley served in World War II in Patton's Third Army and received The French Legion of Honor. He was Vice President of Hertz Truck Division, President of GMC Quality Truck Sales, Inc. and he was a Hadassah Associate. Funeral service to be held on Friday, August 8, 2014 at 11am at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY under the direction of I.J. Morris. Contributions in Mr. Fauer's memory may be made to Hadassah, 3545 S. Ocean Blvd, #

COOK--Arthur Francis, Jr.,a resident of Osterville, MA, and Manasota Key, FL, formerly of Dedham, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, August 5, 2014 of pancreatic cancer. Art was the son of Arthur and Catherine (Martin) Cook. He grew up in Arlington, MA. After graduating from Fordham University, he joined the United States Marine Corps. In 1959, Art completed his military service as a First Lieutenant and moved to New York City where he joined the advertising agency of Doherty, Clifford, Steers, and Shenfield. A few years later, he moved to Boston to join the firm of BBD&O. Later, he pursued a career in commercial industrial real estate at Ryan Elliott and C.W. Whittier, where he was a managing partner until his retirement. Art believed strongly in contributing his time and efforts to the communities in which he lived. For many years, he served as a dedicated trustee of the Faulkner Hospital, the Brimmer & May School, the North Bennett Street Industrial School, the Centerville Library, the Barnstable Land Trust, and the Lemon Bay Conservancy. He was a long time member and past board member of the Dedham Country and Polo Club and the Hyannisport Club, as well as a member of the Jacaranda West Country Club of Venice, FL and the Beach Club in Centerville, MA. In his retirement, Art loved to ride his bike on Cape Cod, hike the trails of the National Sea Shore and spend time at the library. His love of daily swims in the ocean, no matter the temperature, was well known to all who knew him. Art was an avid golfer, tennis player and skeet shooter throughout his life. Art is survived by his wife Cici, son Laurence, daughters Nina and Jennifer, son-in-law Will Ruhl, granddaughter Meredith and her husband Patrick, granddaughter Caroline and great-grandson Raul. He is also survived by his sister Wilma Maus and her husband Bob and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his younger brother Robert Cook, formerly of Tempe, Arizona and his parents Arthur and Catherine Cook. The Cook family is grateful to the VNA Hospice of Cape Cod, especially to Paula and Sue, for the wonderful care Art received. In lieu of flowers, donations in Art's memory may be made to the Barnstable Land Trust, P.O. Box 224, Cotuit, MA 02635 or the VNA Hospice of Cape Cod, 434 Rte.134, Suite D3, South Dennis, MA 02660. A service in celebration of Art's life will be held on Monday, August 11th at 2:00pm at St. Andrew's By the Sea, Hyannis Port, MA. For online guestbook and directions, please visit www.johnlawrencefuner alhome.com.

CHEIT--Earl F. "Budd", died on August 2, 2014 at the age of 87 at home in Kensington, California. He was Edgar F. Kaiser Professor of Business and Public Policy Emeritus and Dean Emeritus of Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. Survived by his wife June, four children and three grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Haas School of Business or Cal Performances at the University of California.

BLOCK--Harriet Joan, 78, died Sunday, August 3 in NYC. Loving wife to Irwin for 58 years. Services Friday, August 8 at 3:00pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to the National MS Society of NYC -SNY Chapter in memory of Harriet Block, 733 Third Avenue, NY, NY 10017.
